1201 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Packer Collegiate Institute v. University of State of New York


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


273 A.D. 203; 76 N.Y.S.2d 499; 1948 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4563



January 7, 1948 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff school brought a declaratory judgment action against defendants, a state university, the New York Commissioner of Education, and the Board of Regents, as to the validity of N.Y. Educ. Law § 3210. Pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act §§ 546-548, the parties submitted the controversy to the court upon their respective briefs.


OVERVIEW: The school was a private educational institution for girls, incorporated by a special act of the legislature. The school maintained a nursery school, a kindergarten, and an elementary school. The school did not receive any public funds and was not supported by any established religious group. The school refused to register with the New York Commissioner of Education as required by N.Y. Educ. Law § 3210. The school alleged that the statute was not a proper and legitimate exercise of New York's police power and contravened U.S. Const. amend. IV, §1 and New York Const. art. I, § 11. The court disagreed. The court held that the statute and the regulations established by the Board of Regents were a valid exercise of the state's police power. Because all schools were affected with a public interest, the state had the authority to regulate schools under its police power.


OUTCOME: The court ordered judgment in favor of defendants, held that the regulations were valid and constitutional, and ordered that the school was enjoined and restrained from maintaining a nursery school, kindergarten, or elementary school until it registered in the manner required by New York statutes and regulations.


HEADNOTES

School - regulation - (1) contention of private school that Education Law (§ 3210, subd. 2, par. e) and regulations of Board of Regents which require it, as condition to maintenance of its nursery school, kindergarten and elementary school, to register with State Education Department are unconstitutional, overruled - (2) all schools affected with public interest and subject to reasonable regulation - (3) that private nursery schools not regulated prior to 1939 no reason for denial of State's power to do so now - (4) reasonable regulation not denial of rights - (5) State may legislate for welfare of immature children - (6) regulations as to schools' buildings, equipment, hours, etc., fall within legislative power - (7) assertion of State's interest in minimum standards no denial of rights; statute requiring registration of private nursery school and regulations enacted thereunder not beyond State's police power - (8) that no hearings had by Legislature before enactment of statute not fatal - (9) valid distinction between private and religious schools exists; no discrimination in statute against [***2] private schools - (10) statute does not illegally delegate legislative power.

1. Upon submission of controversy a private educational institution contends that section 3210 (subd. 2, par. e) of the Education Law and regulations of the Board of Regents adopted pursuant thereto, requiring such an institution, as a condition to maintenance of its nursery school, kindergarten and elementary school, to register with the State Education Department, are unconstitutional. Such contention is overruled and plaintiff is enjoined from maintaining such schools until registered in the manner required by the statute and the regulations.

2. All schools, public or private, are affected with a public interest and hence subject to reasonable regulation under the police power of the State.

3. That the State had not entered the field of regulating private nursery schools and kindergartens prior to 1939, is not a sound reason for denying its power to do so now.

4. Reasonable regulation is not a denial of the right of freedom of choice as to the education of children, or the right to teach subjects not immoral or clearly inimical to the existence of society.

5. That the State, as parens  [***3] patrice of immature children may legislate for their safety, health, morals and general welfare, is not open to dispute.

6. Regulations as to buildings, equipment, financial resources, safety appliances, sanitary conveniences, hours of study or training, and the like, all come within this general legislative power, and do not conflict with any basic rights guaranteed by either the Federal or State Constitution. Moreover, the State may impose minimum scholastic and training standards, including qualifications for teachers, for both public and private nurseries, kindergartens and elementary schools.

7. The State has a pre-eminent interest in minimum standards. The assertion of this interest does not deny a choice of schools, or a reasonable choice as to training and curriculum. The statute requiring registration by private schools in the categories specified is not beyond the police power of the State, and the regulations promulgated thereunder are not arbitrary or unreasonable.

8. That the Legislature may have enacted the statute without legislative hearings or recorded debates is of no consequence. The statute on its face bears the mark of a legitimate purpose, viz.:  [***4] to legislate for the health, safety and general welfare of children.

9. The Legislature was not required for regulatory purposes to cast both sectarian and nonsectarian schools in the same mold where, in fact, there is a distinction between such schools. An act does not discriminate unconstitutionally against one class simply because it does not embrace all classes, where room for some distinction exists. The Legislature may choose for regulation the class where harmful effects are more apt to exist.

10. The statute does not illegally delegate legislative power. The power to lay out school districts, to approve plans for the erection of school buildings, to apportion public moneys and to withhold the same, to prescribe qualifications for teachers, curriculums and standards of training, are among some of the powers delegated. It would be impractical for the Legislature to cover by statutory enactment the detail and minutiae required for the adequate regulation of private schools or to attempt to set up standards that would necessarily involve the same details. A reasonable amount of discretion may be delegated to administrative officials.

 

1202 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hernandez


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


85 Misc. 2d 26; 378 N.Y.S.2d 879; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3272



December 10, 1975 


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- tampering with sports contest -- defendant jockey was lawfully convicted of attempted tampering with sporting event (Penal Law, §§ 110.00, 180.50), for appearing in paddock area before post time in possession of electrical shocking device; section 180.50 does not unconstitutionally delegate legislative powers to State Racing and Wagering Board.

Defendant, a jockey who appeared in the paddock area where he was to mount his horse for the race with an electrical shocking device shortly before post time, was lawfully convicted of attempting to tamper with a sporting event (Penal Law, §§ 110.00, 180.50). Defendant's actions went beyond mere preparation and come sufficiently close to the commission of the crime so as to constitute an "attempt". Section 180.50 of the Penal Law which prohibits tampering with a sports contest "in a manner contrary to the rules and usages" governing such a contest does not unconstitutionally [***2] delegate legislative powers to the State Racing and Wagering Board (see 9 NYCRR 4000.1 et seq.) in derogation of section 1 of article III of the State Constitution. The Legislature has the power to delegate to administrative authorities and agencies the power to establish and administer reasonable rules.

 

1203 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. James H. Northrop, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


85 Misc. 2d 298; 378 N.Y.S.2d 872; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3295



December 4, 1975 


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- littering -- defendant landlord was lawfully convicted of permitting litter to be deposited around rented premises (Islip Town Code, art III, § 32-19); antilittering statute is constitutional; defendant may not be convicted on second identical littering charge.

Defendant, a corporation engaged in the business of renting one-family houses to families in the Town of Islip, was lawfully convicted of permitting litter to be deposited in and around its rented premises (Islip Town Code, art III, § 32-19). Said antilittering statute is constitutional and consistent with the relevant State statutes (see 10 NYCRR 21.4 [c], 21.10-21.13). However, it was improper to convict defendant on a second identical littering charge.

 

1204 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Abrahams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


83 Misc. 2d 681; 373 N.Y.S.2d 725; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2961



June 18, 1975 


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sabbath breaking -- informations charging defendants with selling merchandise in violation of Sabbath Laws (General Business Law, §§ 3-12), were improperly dismissed upon ground that such laws are unconstitutional.

Informations charging defendants with selling merchandise in violation of the Sabbath Laws (General Business Law, §§ 3-12), were improperly dismissed on the grounds that the penalties for Sabbath breaking and the forfeiture provisions contained in sections 4 and 12 of the General Business Law were unconstitutionally vague and therefore incapable of enforcement. It was error to dismiss the informations.

 

1205 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bush


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


82 Misc. 2d 50; 365 N.Y.S.2d 125; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2555



February 11, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgments of conviction affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- trespass -- picketers who refused to leave supermarkets' area were properly convicted of trespass, third degree -- trespassing statute not so vague as to be unconstitutional on its face.

1. Picketers of supermarkets who defied a lawful order from an authorized person not to remain in the enclosed area and who unreasonably interfered with ingress and egress were guilty of trespass. Judgments convicting them of trespass in the third degree and sentencing them to unconditional discharges are affirmed by the Appellate Term.

2. The trespassing statute (Penal Law, § 140.05; § 140.00, subd 5) is not so lacking in ascertainable standards as to be unconstitutional on its face.

 

1206 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Wippette Sportswear, Inc. v. Hauer Knitting Mills, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


77 Misc. 2d 576; 356 N.Y.S.2d 165; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1193



March 20, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with $ 10 costs.


HEADNOTES

Replevin -- ex parte order of replevin -- artisan lienor is not entitled to prior notice before order of replevin is issued; bond sufficiently protects lienor.

A wholesale garment corporation which deposited a quantity of yarn with a knitting mill corporation, to be knitted into garments, commenced a replevin action and validly obtained an ex parte order of seizure upon a bond for double the value of the yarn. The artisan's lien on the yarn, asserted by the mill, is not such an interest as entitles such lienor to be given prior notice of the owner's application for the order of seizure as a matter of due process. The order and seizure were constitutional and lawful, and hence the mill's counterclaim for damages arising from the seizure [***2] is dismissed.

 

1207 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


81 Misc. 2d 926; 365 N.Y.S.2d 317; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2029



January 16, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of conviction reversed, etc.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- former jeopardy -- defendant, who was acquitted of charge of criminal impersonation by reason of Trial Judge's dismissal of charge at first trial, may not constitutionally be retried on same charge ( CPL 40.20).

Following a mistrial when the jury could not agree on a verdict, defendant was retried on six misdemeanor charges ( CPL 310.60, subd 2) and was convicted only of the charge of criminal impersonation (Penal Law, § 190.25). However, since the Trial Judge at the first trial dismissed the charge of criminal impersonation on the ground that the People as a matter of law failed to establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, thereby acquitting defendant of that charge, constitutionally, having been put in jeopardy at the first trial, defendant could not thereafter be retried on that same charge ( CPL 40.20). The conviction should be reversed and the information dismissed.

 

1208 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Carvelas


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


75 Misc. 2d 616; 348 N.Y.S.2d 77; 1973 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1289



September 26, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- harassment -- following altercation between waiter and headwaiter, water was charged with assault and harassment; court acquitted water of assault and properly convicted him of harassment -- harassment statute, when limited to words and/or gestures which directly tend to cause violence, is constitutional -- altercation did not occur in protected union-management activity -- nonjury trial did not prejudice defendant's rights.

1. Following an altercation in the banquet department of a hotel between a waiter who was a union shop steward and the headwaiter who was one of the nonunion or management personnel, the waiter was charged with assault in the third degree (a Class A misdemeanor) and with harassment (a violation). The Criminal Court of the City of New York acquitted the defendant [***2] of assault and properly convicted him of harassment.

2. By judicial construction, subdivisions 2 and 5 of section 240.25 of the Penal Law (harassment) are limited to words and/or gestures which substantially annoy a person to such a degree that there would be a direct tendency for the person so addressed to react by violence or by a breach of the public peace. So construed, the subdivisions are constitutional.

3. The altercation did not occur in a NLRB-protected setting.

4. Defendant was not prejudiced by failure to give him a trial by jury.

 

1209 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Poveromo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


79 Misc. 2d 42; 359 N.Y.S.2d 848; 1973 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1260



August 15, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


HEADNOTES

Waters and watercourses -- wetlands -- tidewaters within Suffolk and Nassau Counties -- though foreshore of Nissequogue River in Suffolk County is owned by State of New York in trust for People, local law of town (in Suffolk County) validly requires permit from town before anyone may dump fill in river.

A local law of the Town of Smithtown (in Suffolk County) prohibits any person from either removing or depositing or dumping any fill or other material in the bed of any watercourse or wetland without first obtaining a permit from the town. This local law validly and constitutionally applies to the foreshore beyond the mean high watermark of the Nissequogue River in Suffolk County, even though the foreshore is owned by the State of New York in trust for the use of the People (Navigation Law, § 2, subd. 4; ECL 15-0505, subd. 1; ECL 15-0103, subd. 1; ECL 15-0105, subd. 1; Town Law, § 64, subd. 10-a, and § 130, subd. 15).

 

1210 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kass


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


74 Misc. 2d 682; 346 N.Y.S.2d 641; 1973 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2145



March 12, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of conviction affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- physicians -- narcotics -- verdict convicting physican of unclassified misdemeanors, for issuing prescriptions unlawfully and not in good faith, was not irrational or repugnant -- trial court adequately defined "good faith" to jury -- statutes not so vague as to be unconstitutional.

1. A verdict convicting a physican of issuing 23 prescriptions unlawfully and not in good faith (Public Health Law, §§ 3305, 3373; cf. §§ 3330, 3385), to different individuals, on different dates, and for different narcotic, stimulant, and depressing drugs, and acquitting him of 6 other such counts, was not irrational or repugnant.

2. These violations of the Public Health Law were unclassified misdemeanors (Public Health Law, §§ 12-b, 3354, 3393; Penal Law, § 55.10, subd. 2, par. [e]).

3. These statutes are not so vague as to be unconstitutional.

4. The trial court adequately defined [***2] "good faith" to the jury.

 

1211 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ludlow


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


75 Misc. 2d 556; 348 N.Y.S.2d 20; 1972 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1554



September 20, 1972 



DISPOSITION: Orders reversed, etc.


HEADNOTES

Health -- watercraft -- watercraft operating on Hudson River must have approved device for treating or holding toilet sewage -- boarding and inspection constitutional (Navigation Law, § 33-c, subd. 4, par. [a]), and subd. 9).

1. The Navigation Law ( § 33-c, subd. 4, par. [a]), validly and constitutionally requires any watercraft operating on the Hudson River to be equipped with an approved device for treating or holding toilet sewage.

2. The Navigation Law ( § 33-c, subd. 9) validly and constitutionally authorizes a Ranger of the New York State Office of Parks and Recreation to board and inspect watercraft on the waters of this State.

 

1212 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Axel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


69 Misc. 2d 216; 329 N.Y.S.2d 992; 1971 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1024



December 20, 1971 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of conviction affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- commercial bribing -- statute defining commercial bribing is constitutional -- failure of statute to condemn specifically "improper" influence does not render it void.

1. Section 180.00 of the Penal Law, the commercial bribing statute, is not unconstitutional as being vague.

2. The failure of the statute to condemn specifically "improper" influence does not render it invalid.

 

1213 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Beltrand


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


67 Misc. 2d 324; 324 N.Y.S.2d 477; 1971 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1462



July 8, 1971 



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- loitering -- there was no proof of loitering for sufficient length of time to establish crime; order dismissing charge is affirmed.

In the absence of proof, on the preliminary hearing, of loitering for any appreciable length of time, the testimony was insufficient factually to establish the conjunctive elements of subdivision 6 of section 240.35 of the Penal Law. An order dismissing the charge of loitering is affirmed.

 

1214 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Arez


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


64 Misc. 2d 723; 314 N.Y.S.2d 504; 1970 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1333



September 14, 1970 


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Appellate Term -- appeal was properly taken to Appellate Term from New York City Criminal Court judgment convicting defendant of drug possession and, after Supreme Court's jury trial and verdict, certification and sentence as narcotic addict (Mental Health Law, § 208), committing him to custody of Narcotic Addiction Control Commission; provision (§ 208, subd. 3) that Supreme Court's certification and sentence "shall be deemed to be a judgment of the court in which the plea or verdict of guilty was entered" did not result in impermissible review by Appellate Term of rulings of court of co-ordinate jurisdiction; provision (N. Y. Const., art VI, § 8, subd. d) limiting appeals to Appellate Term to "other than appeals from the supreme court" reasonably presumed as intended to mean "from actions originating in the supreme court"; limited transfer procedure neither novel  [***2] nor prejudicial to defendant.

An appeal was properly taken to the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court from a judgment of the Criminal Court of the City of New York which convicted defendant of possessing a dangerous drug and, following his certification and sentence by the Supreme Court as a narcotic addict after a jury trial in the Supreme Court (Mental Health Law, § 208), committed him to the care and custody of the Narcotic Addiction Control Commission. The provision (Mental Health Law, § 208, subd. 3) that such certification or sentence "shall be deemed to be a judgment of the court in which the plea or verdict of guilty was entered" did not contravene the constitutional limitation (N. Y. Const., art. VI, § 8, subd. d) authorizing the Appellate Term "to hear and determine appeals now or hereafter authorized by law to be taken to the supreme court or to the appellate division other than appeals from the supreme court" by permitting an impermissible review by the Appellate Term of the rulings of a Supreme Court Justice having co-ordinate jurisdiction. Every rational and reasonable presumption of constitutionality must be indulged in favor of the statute and one such presumption [***3] is that the language "other than appeals from the supreme court" was intended to mean "other than appeals from actions originating in the supreme court". This action originated and remains in the Criminal Court despite the limited transfer, for the sake of convenience and orderly procedure, to a court better equipped to conduct a jury trial. Such procedure is neither novel in practice nor prejudicial to defendant.

 

1215 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Soto


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


64 Misc. 2d 515; 315 N.Y.S.2d 30; 1969 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1585



April 28, 1969 



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, etc.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- youthful offenders -- finding no significant distinction between young adult and youthful offender insofar as imposition of reformatory sentence is involved, and in light of holding of Court of Appeals that New York City Criminal Court lacks jurisdiction to impose reformatory sentence upon young adult, court remands for resentence case of defendant accorded youthful offender treatment following plea of guilty to criminal trespass in second degree and sentenced to reformatory for indefinite period.

1. Finding no significant distinction between young adult (Penal Law, art. 75) and youthful offender (Code Crim. Pro., § 913-e et seq.) treatment of miscreants insofar as imposition of a reformatory sentence is involved, and in the light of the holding of the Court of Appeals that the New York City Criminal Court lacks jurisdiction to impose the reformatory sentence provided for in article 75 of the Penal Law upon a young adult charged with a misdemeanor (Matter  [***2] of Hogan v. Rosenberg, 24 N Y 2d 207), the court remands for resentence the case of a defendant who was accorded youthful offender treatment following his plea of guilty to criminal trespass in the second degree and was sentenced to a reformatory for an indefinite period, as provided for in section 913-m of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

2. To limit the sentence of an adult convicted of a misdemeanor to no more than one year and to deprive the court of jurisdiction to impose a reformatory sentence upon a young adult in the absence of legislation authorizing a jury trial and providing procedural machinery therefor, while continuing to utilize the statutory provision for the imposition of a reformatory sentence upon a youthful offender would deprive the latter of equal protection of the laws.

 

1216 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


64 Misc. 2d 510; 315 N.Y.S.2d 66; 1969 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1839



January 15, 1969 



DISPOSITION: Judgments reversed, etc.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- fraudulent accosting -- defendants were convicted of fraudulent accosting, defined in section 165.30 of Penal Law as accosting person in public place and, either then or subsequently, making statements to such person of sort commonly made or used in perpetration of known type of confidence game -- convictions are reversed -- statute does not require fraudulent intent and standard to be applied is not set forth therein, nor does it depend upon understanding of person of ordinary experience or intelligence, but, rather, it is implicit that expert witness define confidence game involved -- although actions of defendants were not criminal per se, criminality was established by expertise and observations of officer, based on facts not made part of crime by statute itself.

1. Defendants were observed walking together and then separating, whereupon one of them approached a third party, showed him a piece of paper, flashed a roll of money and asked him for directions to [***2] a hotel, telling him that, if he would show him where it was and accompany him there, he would make it "worth his while". When the person so accosted said that he did not know the hotel, the other defendant approached, was asked the same question and said he knew where the hotel was, whereupon both defendants walked away. They were detained by a police officer who, after interviewing the person whom they had accosted, arrested them and found upon the person of each a "Michigan roll", consisting of imitation money with a genuine dollar bill on the outside. They were charged with fraudulent accosting under section 165.30 of the Penal Law, providing that a "person is guilty of fraudulent accosting when he accosts a person in a public place and, either at that time and place or subsequently in any place, he makes statements to such person of a sort commonly made or used in the perpetration of a known type of confidence game". At their trial, the arresting officer, who qualified as an expert, testified that they had been engaged in the "handkerchief switch game". Both were convicted. The judgments of conviction are reversed and the complaint against them dismissed.

2. Section 165.30 [***3] of the Revised Penal Law does not, on its face, require that there be a fraudulent purpose or intent and since it is not contained in the article defining larceny, cannot be read together with the provision of that article which requires intent for larceny. The standard to be applied is not set forth nor does it depend upon the understanding of a person of ordinary experience or intelligence, but, rather, it is implicit in the statute that an expert witness define the confidence game involved. Thus, in the present case, although the actions of defendants in inquiring as to the hotel's location and possessing a "Michigan roll", were not criminal per se, criminality was established by the expertise and observations of the officer, based on facts not made part of the crime by the statute itself.

3. It would be inconsistent with the plain language of the statute, which is clearly aimed at one who utters words, to hold that the playing of the confidence game had not proceeded sufficiently far to warrant the conviction of defendants.

 

1217 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Archibald


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


58 Misc. 2d 862; 296 N.Y.S.2d 834; 1968 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1120



October 18, 1968 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of conviction affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- male disguised as female -- male who appeared in public disguised as female was properly convicted of violating Code of Criminal Procedure (§ 887, subd. 7).

A male person who appeared in a New York City subway disguised as a female was properly convicted by the New York City Criminal Court of violating subdivision 7 of section 887 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Under said subdivision, it was not necessary to prove vagrancy or an intent to use the disguise to commit an illegal act; nor was said subdivision too vague and uncertain to have any valid constitutional application. The judgment of conviction was affirmed by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court.

 

1218 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fuller


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


57 Misc. 2d 350; 292 N.Y.S.2d 503; 1968 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1435



May 31, 1968 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Mental health -- drug addiction -- evidence adduced at hearing to determine whether defendant who pleaded guilty to possession of narcotics was addict was sufficient to sustain finding of addiction -- finding may be made upon preponderance of evidence and proof beyond reasonable doubt is not required -- proof of physical dependence upon drugs, without more, may warrant such finding -- statutory authorization for reception in commitment proceeding of statements obtained from alleged addict by doctor is not violative of privilege against self incrimination or right to counsel -- no deprivation of equal protection of laws results from not permitting jury trial in case of criminal commitment or from disparity in length of time of incarceration of addict and of nonaddict convicted of identical crimes -- program does not constitute cruel and unusual punishment -- definition of addict is not  [***2]  unconstitutionally vague.

1. Evidence adduced at a hearing to determine whether a defendant who had pleaded guilty to possession of narcotics was an addict was sufficient to sustain a finding of addiction.

2. A proceeding pursuant to sections 207 and 208 of the Mental Hygiene Law to commit an alleged addict is criminal in nature and the certification is the sentence imposed for the crime of which his guilt has been established and is deemed the judgment of conviction. However, the sole purpose of the commitment proceeding is to determine the sentence to be imposed. Since the hearing is concerned only with this and not with guilt or innocence, a finding of addiction may properly be made upon a preponderance of the evidence. Proof beyond a reasonable doubt is not required.

3. Proof of physical dependence upon drugs, without more, may warrant a finding of addiction.

4. Section 207 (subd. 5) of the Mental Hygiene Law, authorizing the reception in the commitment proceeding of statements obtained from the alleged addict by a doctor, but specifically prohibiting the use of such statements at his trial, is not violative of his privilege against self incrimination or his right to [***3] counsel.

5. There is a reasonable basis for permitting a jury trial in the case of a civil commitment (Mental Hygiene Law, § 206), where the person has not been charged with any crime, while not permitting it in the case of a criminal commitment (§ 208), where he has already been found guilty of a crime. Accordingly, no deprivation of equal protection of the laws is involved in this distinction.

6. No deprivation of equal protection of the laws results from disparity in the length of time of incarceration of an addict and of a nonaddict convicted of identical crimes.

7. A program for compulsory treatment of narcotic addicts does not constitute cruel and unusual punishment.

8. The definition of "addict" in section 201 (subd. 2) of the Mental Hygiene Law is not vague but is sufficiently clear to meet constitutional standards.

 

1219 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nieke


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


56 Misc. 2d 363; 289 N.Y.S.2d 448; 1968 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1750



February 8, 1968 



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- weapons -- Penal Law (§ 1897, subd. 4; § 1898, subd. 5) constitutional.

Dismissal of an information alleging a violation of section 1898 (subd. 5) of the Penal Law (cf. § 1897, subd. 4) is reversed and the information is reinstated. Those subdivisions are not unconstitutionally vague.

 

1220 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Tyler v. Eastern Discount Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


55 Misc. 2d 1002; 286 N.Y.S.2d 948; 1968 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1775; 5 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. (Callaghan) 273



January 31, 1968 



DISPOSITION: Order modified, etc.


HEADNOTES

Sales -- secured transactions -- release of security interest -- plaintiff, who did not receive statement, although demanded after payment in full of retail installment contract, that defendant no longer had security interest, is entitled to recover $ 1,200 credit service charge as penalty (Personal Property Law, § 414, subd. 2) rather than $ 100 (Uniform Commercial Code, § 9-404) -- section 414 does not deny equal protection of laws -- no public policy against imposition of penalty.

1. Upon the completion of payments under a retail installment contract covering home improvements, the seller is required to send a statement that he no longer claims a security interest under the financing statement and, if he fails to do so, the buyer is given the right to recover, under subdivision 2 of section 414 of the Personal Property Law (the Retail Instalment Sales Act) an amount equal to the credit service charge imposed,  [***2] or under section 9-404 of the Uniform Commercial Code, $ 100 in addition to any loss to the debtor caused by such failure. The history of the statutes indicates that section 414 of the Personal Property Law covers the transaction here involved and plaintiff, who demanded but did not receive the statement, is not restricted to the rights provided by the Uniform Commercial Code but is entitled to recover the $ 1,200 credit service charge paid by her.

2. The section does not deny equal protection of the laws for all holders of such secured obligations are equally subject to the law.

3. There is no public policy against the imposition of a penalty.

 

1221 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Sprowal


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


49 Misc. 2d 806; 268 N.Y.S.2d 444; 1966 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2303



January 13, 1966 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed as to defendant Sprowal and reversed as to defendant Gordon.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- loitering in or about school building -- defendant's free-speech right to distribute CORE leaflets, if constitutionally protected, was not abridged by applying to him Penal Law ( § 722-b) prohibiting loitering in or about school buildings or school grounds -- since this defendant urges further on appeal that 60-day sentence was unjustified, his criminal record of narcotics and other convictions is considered; judgment affirmed -- but, as to another defendant, who may have stood 300 feet away from school grounds, judgment is reversed and new trial ordered.

1. The Penal Law ( § 722-b), providing that a person "who loiters in or about any school building or grounds without written permission * * * or in violation of posted rules or regulations * * * shall be guilty of disorderly conduct," was properly applied to a person who stationed himself on the sidewalk in front of a public [***2] high school, near a sign which read "No loitering. Persons found loitering in front of the building are subject to the charge of Disorderly Conduct", and who insisted on distributing to the crowd of students who were emerging from the building at that time handbills urging them to join CORE and to support a proposed bill which would establish a civilian board to review charges of improper police activities. The constitutional right of free speech is not abridged by this application of the statute. One of the principal purposes of the statute -- to help school authorities and police protect impressionable young people against distributors of narcotics, obscenity and other evils -- would be frustrated if they were unable to stop persons who appeared to bear handbills only, but who might also be carrying narcotics or other devices.

2. This defendant also urges on this appeal that there was no justification for his sentence of 60 days in the city workhouse. In this connection, his prior criminal record may be considered. He has been convicted of narcotics violations three times, and once of disorderly conduct, and once of obstructing a police officer. His record does not commend [***3] him to appellate clemency.

3. However, as to another defendant, the judgment of conviction is reversed and fine remitted and new trial ordered. It is impossible to say, from the trial court's oral opinion, whether this defendant was convicted on testimony that he stood in front of the school building or on conflicting testimony that he stood on the street some 300 feet away from the school building. In the latter situation, he could not be said to be loitering in or about the school grounds.

 

1222 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Turner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


48 Misc. 2d 611; 265 N.Y.S.2d 841; 1965 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1362



November 11, 1965 



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- disorderly conduct -- meeting was held in area of heavy vehicular and pedestrian traffic to protest American involvement in Viet Nam; persons who used excessive force to resist proper police order to disperse were properly found guilty of disorderly conduct -- evidence of violation of any subdivision of section 722 of Penal Law will support conviction regardless of whether information charges one subdivision or another -- subdivision 3 of section 722 of Penal Law constitutionally applies to facts of this case.

1. An organization which was formed at Yale University to protest American involvement in the war in Viet Nam held a public meeting on a Saturday Summer afternoon in New York City in Duffy Square, which is a small island of concrete at the intersections of Broadway, Seventh Avenue, 46th Street and 47th Street. There was some evidence that this is a park and that the New York City Park Department Regulations [***2] require a permit for public meetings; however, such evidence, if any, was not relied on at the trial, and was not considered on this appeal. Nor was there sufficient evidence that the police had banned public meetings on this island. However, there was evidence that the meeting was attended by a group variously estimated as numbering 60 to 300 persons, that they were addressed by one defendant through a battery-powered megaphone, that the meeting interfered with pedestrian and vehicular traffic, that the police ordered the meeting dispersed shortly after it had opened, that the speaker refused to cease, that thereupon about a dozen policemen on foot and two mounted policemen forcibly dispersed the meeting, that a crowd of some 2,000 people was attracted by the commotion, and that the 17 defendants in this case actively resisted and interfered with the efforts of the police to disperse the meeting. Judgments convicting the 17 defendants of disorderly conduct (Penal Law, § 722, subds. 2, 3, 4) were affirmed by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court.

2. The duty of the police to regulate traffic and to prevent disorders and breaches of the peace in a congested vicinity justified [***3] their command that the meeting disperse.

3. Even if the order that the meeting disperse was improper or unlawful, defendants' physical resistance to it was more forceful than necessary and hence was illegal.

4. Evidence of a violation of any subdivision of section 722 of the Penal Law will support a conviction of disorderly conduct, regardless of whether the information charges one subdivision or another. These convictions are valid under both subdivisions 2 and 3 of section 722.

5. Subdivision 3 of section 722 of the Penal Law, prohibiting congregating on a public street and refusing to move on when ordered by the police, validly and constitutionally applies to the facts of this case.

 

1223 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kohler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


45 Misc. 2d 692; 258 N.Y.S.2d 279; 1965 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2138



March 24, 1965 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of conviction reversed, etc.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- speeding -- on trial for speeding, it was duty of trial court to inform defendant that he had right to be represented by counsel; conviction reversed and new trial ordered.

On the trial of a charge of speeding, a traffic infraction, it was the duty of the trial court to inform defendant that he had a right to be represented by counsel. Defendant's conviction is reversed and a new trial is ordered.

 

1224 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Schwebel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


44 Misc. 2d 1035; 255 N.Y.S.2d 760; 1965 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2349



January 20, 1965 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed on the law and complaint dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sabbath laws -- sale on Sunday -- individual who owned all stock of corporation lawfully sold on Sunday (Penal Law, § 2147-a; Administrative Code of City of New York, § E51-1.0) where he kept corporation's business closed on Saturday for observance of holy time, despite fact that he conducted business with aid of employees who were not members of family.

An individual owning all of the stock of a corporation lawfully "[conducted] a trade or public selling * * * on Sunday" in the City of New York within section 2147-a of the Penal Law and section E51-1.0 of the Administrative Code where he kept the corporation's business closed on Saturday, on which day he observed his holy time. It does not matter that, in conducting his business, he had the assistance of four employees not members of his family or that he conducted business in the name of a corporation of which he was the sole stockholder. The [***2] statute does not proscribe the employment of others in the conduct of the business.

 

1225 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Penn


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


48 Misc. 2d 634; 265 N.Y.S.2d 155; 1964 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1380



October 15, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- disorderly conduct -- protesters against discrimination by building trades unions, who sat down in path of trucks at site of public housing project and refused to move on, were properly convicted of disorderly conduct.

The 11 defendants in this case picketed the site of a public housing project under construction, in order to protest against discrimination against Negroes by the building trades unions. The Criminal Court of the City of New York found that several cement-mixing trucks were obstructed and halted, on the street and on an access road leading to a gate to the housing site, by some of the defendants who sat down in the path of the oncoming trucks and by others of the defendants who sat in front of the gate; that the defendants congregated on a public street, acted in a manner likely to produce violence, threatened the peace of the community, caused public consternation and alarm, and refused to move on [***2] when repeatedly requested by the police; and accordingly the court found the defendants guilty of disorderly conduct (Penal Law, § 722, subds. 3, 4). On appeal to the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court, the defendants contended that they were merely publicly asking that the laws against discrimination be enforced, and that their manner of so asking was a proper form of free speech and public assembly and petition for redress of grievances (U. S. Const., 1st and 14th Amdts.). The judgments of conviction were affirmed by the Appellate Term.

 

1226 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Galamison


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


43 Misc. 2d 72; 250 N.Y.S.2d 325; 1964 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1744



May 20, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- disorderly conduct -- pickets, against racial discrimination allegedly practiced by construction contractors for State, crossed police barricade and lay down in path of truck and created clear and present danger of breach of peace; convictions of disorderly conduct (Penal Law, § 722, subds. 2, 3) affirmed -- statute is not unconstitutionally vague -- State does not aid or abet racial discrimination -- enforcement of statute against these defendants does not contravene their freedom of expression or deny due process or equal protection of law.

1. On the public thoroughfare in front of premises on which contractors were erecting a college for the State of New York, some 20 persons picketed, apparently peacefully, carrying placards protesting against racial discrimination allegedly practiced against Negroes in the constrution industry. Eventually they crossed over a barricade which the police had erected at a gate to the premises, and they lay [***2] down in, on and around the gateway and sidewalk and thus interfered with traffic and prevented a truck loaded with materials from entering the premises. They were asked by the police, in vain, to leave the premises and to resume peaceful picketing on the sidewalk. Finally they were arrested and were properly charged with and found guilty of disorderly conduct under both subdivisions 2 and 3 of section 722 of the Penal Law. Said statute provides in part that "Any person who with intent to provoke a breach of the peace, or whereby a breach of the peace may be occasioned, commits any of the following acts shall be deemed to have committed the offense of disorderly conduct: * * * 2. Acts in such a manner as to annoy, disturb, interfere with, obstruct, or be offensive to others; 3. Congregates with others on a public street and refuses to move on when ordered by the police".

2. Beyond a reasonable doubt, defendants' acts presented a clear and present danger and likelihood of disorder and interference with traffic and breach of the peace.

3. The wording of section 722 (subds. 2, 3) of the Penal Law is not so vague as to make it impossible for a person of ordinary intelligence to know [***3] what conduct has been made criminal and so as to make his prosecution under such a statute an unconstitutional denial of due process of law (U. S. Const., 14th Amdt.; N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6). Furthermore, these defendants were charged with and were tried and convicted for violating both subdivisions 2 and 3, and not, as they seem to contend, for violating 2 "or" 3.

4. After hearing testimony on this issue, the trial court properly found that the State of New York does not have any policy or practice of aiding or abetting racial discrimination if any practiced by its independent contractors, and that the State is not using section 722 of the Penal Law so as to deny to these defendants the equal protection of the laws. (U. S. Const., 14th Amdt.)

5. After hearing testimony on this issue, the trial court properly found that the enforcement against these defendants of section 722 of the Penal Law does not contravene defendants' rights of freedom of expression (U. S. Const., 1st and 14th Amdts.; N. Y. Const., art. I, §§ 8, 9).

 

1227 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Sanabria


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


42 Misc. 2d 464; 249 N.Y.S.2d 66; 1964 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1865



April 16, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of conviction affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- conviction by two of three Judges in nonjury trial -- on trial of misdemeanor of sodomy, testimony of defendant's wife as to natural marital relationship properly excluded -- defendant's guilt was established beyond reasonable doubt -- reasonable doubt is not created by conviction by two of three Judges presiding at trial without jury; majority decision is not unconstitutional.

1. On the trial of a charge against defendant of sodomy as a misdemeanor, testimony of defendant's wife with respect to a natural marital relationship would neither prove nor disprove his ability or inclination to perform unnatural acts and was properly excluded.

2. Defendant's guilt was proven beyond a reasonable doubt. The conflicting testimony presented a question of credibility which was resolved by the trial court.

3. A reasonable doubt precluding conviction is not established by the fact that one of three Judges presiding [***2] at defendant's trial without a jury dissented from his conviction. A majority decision is not unconstitutional. Such 2 to 1 decision is not inconsistent with sections 428 and 430 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The unanimity required under section 428 is by a jury, not by a constitutionally authorized court sitting in judgment without a jury. A trial without jury as constitutionally authorized does not vitiate the presumption of innocence or the requirement that guilt be proven beyond a reasonable doubt. The judgment of the court, albeit by two of the three members, will be arrived at in conformity with, and with respect for, the presumption of innocence and all rights which belong to the accused.

 

1228 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York City Hous. Auth. v. Watson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


27 Misc. 2d 618; 207 N.Y.S.2d 920; 1960 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2190



November 17, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Final order reversed, etc.


HEADNOTES

Public housing -- termination of tenancy for undesirability -- public housing authority has right to establish procedures for terminating lease for undesirability (Public Housing Law, § 54) -- tenant may contest fact that authority has gone through established procedures but may not contest finding of undesirability -- accordingly, order dismissing summary proceedings to evict tenant whom landlord had determined was undesirable, and who refused to vacate upon receiving notice in accordance with terms of lease for month-to-month tenancy, on ground undesirability is issue for court, should be reversed.

In summary proceedings instituted by a municipal public housing authority, the landlord proved that it had determined that the tenant was undesirable and had given due notice to vacate, in accordance with the terms of [***2] the lease, which provided for a month-to-month tenancy, terminable upon notice by either party, and that the tenant did not vacate. The proceedings were dismissed on the ground that undesirability was an issue for the court under subdivision 6 of section 1410 of the Civil Practice Act. However, that statute applies to an existing tenancy either by lease or prolonged through rent control, not to one which has been terminated in a manner authorized by law. The subject housing is not rent controlled and the landlord has the right to establish rules and procedures to terminate a lease for undesirability (Public Housing Law, § 54). The tenant may contest the fact that the authority has gone through the established procedures, but not the finding of undesirability. Accordingly, the order below should be reversed and final order directed in favor of the landlord.

 

1229 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Sohmer Factors Corp. v. 278 Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, Second Department


13 Misc. 2d 142; 172 N.Y.S.2d 886; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3583



April 1, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Order unanimously modified so as to provide that plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is denied and as so modified affirmed, without costs on this appeal.


HEADNOTES

Corporations -- usury -- in action for money loaned and upon collateral bond for money loaned to corporate defendant, sufficient facts alleged by defendants to require trial of issue of fraud -- if defendants were induced by fraud to transfer their one-family house to corporation, it might be sufficient to defeat action -- transaction not in violation of General Corporation Law (§ 18) and Banking Law ( § 131) -- General Business Law ( § 374), as amended by chapter 968 of Laws of 1957, providing that corporation whose principal asset was one- or two-family dwelling could plead usury as defense, is unconstitutional -- agreement was not usurious when made, and Legislature could not give retrospective effect to statute permitting  [***2] defense of usury.

1. Defendant corporation executed and delivered to plaintiff a second mortgage on certain real property on October 16, 1954. The individual defendants executed a collateral bond in the sum of $ 2,900 with 6% interest payable in monthly installments. Twenty-two payments were made, leaving a balance of $ 1,119.32 which defendants refused to pay. Instead of $ 2,900, approximately $ 2,000 was advanced to defendants at the time of the closing of the transaction. An attorney and officer of plaintiff corporation stated that he told defendants that the loan would not be made at the rate of 6% and that they would be required to incorporate -- the purpose being to permit a greater interest rate than 6% -- and that he explained that title to their property would be conveyed to the corporation and the loan made to it secured by a second mortgage, and that they would be required to sign a collateral bond. The president of defendant corporation stated that he did not know that a corporation was to be formed to take title to his one-family house. Sufficient facts have been alleged by defendants to entitle them to a trial of the issue of fraud. If in fact defendants were [***3] induced by fraud to transfer their property to the corporation, it might be sufficient to defeat the action for money loaned in the sum of $ 1,119.32 and upon the collateral bond. Accordingly, a motion for summary judgment is denied.

2. The transaction was not in violation of section 18 of the General Corporation Law and section 131 of the Banking Law. These statutes are not applicable to the discount of loans secured by mortgages on real property.

3. Section 374 of the General Business Law, as amended by chapter 968 of the Laws of 1957, effective April 26, 1957, provides that no corporation may interpose the defense of usury in any action but that that provision "shall not apply to a corporation, the principal asset of which shall be the ownership of a one or two family dwelling, where it appears either that the said corporation was organized and created, or that the controlling interest therein was acquired, within a period of six months prior to the execution, by said corporation of a bond or note evidencing indebtedness, and a mortgage creating a lien for said indebtedness on the said one or two family dwelling; provided, that as to any such bond, note or mortgage executed [***4] by such a corporation and effective prior to April sixth, nineteen hundred fifty-six, the defense of usury may be interposed only in an action or proceeding instituted for the collection, enforcement or foreclosure of such note, bond or mortgage." That part of the quoted material beginning with the word "provided" was added by the Laws of 1957. Chapter 968 of the Laws of 1957 is invalid insofar as it is retrospective in effect in providing that a corporation may plead usury as a defense to a contract which had a valid inception. It impairs the obligation of that contract and is invalid to such extent. The agreement was not usurious when made and, since the agreement was valid in its inception, the Legislature could not constitutionally deprive plaintiff of all its rights therein.

 

1230 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Pontello v. O'Shea


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


200 Misc. 417; 106 N.Y.S.2d 934; 1951 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2263



May 17, 1951 



DISPOSITION: Final order reversed, etc.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- certificate of eviction -- certificate of eviction of State Rent Administrator that landlords required possession in good faith because of immediate and compelling necessity controlling on court in summary proceedings; such certificate not reviewable except in proceeding under Civil Practice Act (art. 78).

In summary proceedings, a certificate of eviction of the State Rent Administrator that landlords sought possession of an apartment in good faith because of immediate and compelling necessity for their own use and occupancy was controlling. The granting of the certificate could not be reviewed except by means of a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice [***2] Act (L. 1946, ch. 274, § 9, as amd. by L. 1951, ch. 443).

 

1231 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hunt v. Gilmore


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Term, First Department


198 Misc. 50; 98 N.Y.S.2d 322; 1950 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1767



April 20, 1950 



DISPOSITION: Final order reversed, etc.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- removal of squatters -- (1) person occupying apartment with permission of statutory tenant after tenant quits apartment and who pays tenant substantial consideration for furniture in apartment is squatter -- (2) as to squatter, Administrative Code of City of New York (§ U41-7.0) does not require certificate of eviction -- (3) under Federal law no certificate of eviction needed to remove squatter; if conflict exists as to eviction provisions of Federal law and local law, Federal law takes precedence.

1. A person who obtained possession of an apartment from a statutory tenant and who paid such statutory tenant a substantial consideration for furniture in the apartment is an intruder. In a statutory tenancy, the provisions of the lease cover the obligations of the parties unless in contravention of the statute. Since tenant was obligated to surrender possession to landlord under the lease and his occupancy was that only [***2] which was continued by the statute upon the condition therein prescribed -- to pay the landlord the rent to which landlord was entitled -- the statute gave tenant no right to confer any privilege of occupancy upon a stranger by assignment. The sale of tenant's furniture to such stranger with the intention of having the stranger continue in occupancy after tenant left is a subterfuge and evasion of the letter and purpose of the statute.

2. Section U41-7.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York contains no provision or definition bringing a squatter within the terms of the local law and does not require a certificate of eviction for anyone other than "A tenant, subtenant, lessee, sublessee, or other persons entitled to the possession or to the use or occupancy of any apartment" (subd. b, par. 5). No evil of the emergency would be cured if a tenant, kept in possession against the will of landlord and about to remove, were permitted to substitute a stranger in his place as tenant. The emergency statutes were designed to protect tenant's occupancy. When tenant's occupancy ends, landlord is entitled to repossession.

3. Under the Federal rent regulations a person in the [***3] position of respondent herein may be removed without a certificate of eviction. If there is a seeming conflict between the eviction provisions of the Federal law and those of the local law, the Federal law having pre-empted the field of rent control takes precedence over the State or local law. The action of the State Legislature in enacting chapter 1 of the Laws of 1950 validating all provisions of the Local Laws of the City of New York relating to evictions and maximum rents cannot give force to a provision of a local law which is in conflict with the Federal statute controlling rents.

 

1232 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


State v. Rutkowski


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Sullivan County


84 Misc. 2d 613; 379 N.Y.S.2d 279; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3188



December 31, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Summary judgment is granted to the plaintiffs with respect to the fourth cause of action of the complaint.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, the State of New York and the Commissioner of Health, sought summary judgment on their action against defendant property owners for a permanent injunction restraining them from selling parcels of real estate out of a realty subdivision until a subdivision plan was filed with and approved by the New York State Department of Health and the appropriate district office. They also sought statutory penalties and to abate a public nuisance.


OVERVIEW: The property owners challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1116 and N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 17-1505, under which the State had brought its action. The court denied the State's motion for summary judgment and granted summary judgment in favor of the property owners on the State's first three causes of action, holding that while the intent and thrust of both N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1116 and N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 17-1505 were salutary and necessary, they were so vague and indefinite as to be beyond judicial construction to enforce the legislative intent. While there could be no quarrel with the legislative right to enact statutes establishing and regulating water or sewage disposal systems in realty subdivisions, such enactments were to be structured so that land owners were informed and advised as to what was required in order to protect the public's safety. The statutory scheme was silent as to how the public health was protected by requiring documented plans for residential development while permitting unsupervised construction of recreational facilities.


OUTCOME: The State's motion for summary judgment with respect to the first three causes of action of their complaint was denied and summary judgment was granted to the property owners. Summary judgment was granted to the State with respect to the fourth cause of action to abate a public nuisance caused by two of the property owners.


HEADNOTES

Health -- realty subdivision water supply -- sections 1115 and 1116 of Public Health Law and ECL 17-1505, which define "subdivision" as tract divided into five or more parcels and require filing of map or plan for residential subdivision prior to sale of lands therein are unconstitutionally vague, since statutes permit unsupervised sales for recreational purposes and may be avoided by division of plot into four parcels with sale of lots effected therefrom; accordingly, plaintiffs are denied summary judgment restraining defendants' realty transactions absent approved plan and defendants are granted summary judgment declaring statutes unconstitutional -- plaintiffs are granted summary judgment to abate public nuisance caused by failure of defendants' sewage system.

1. Sections 1115 and 1116 of the Public Health Law and ECL 17-1505, which define "subdivision" as a tract divided into five or more parcels and which require filing of a map or plan of a residential subdivision prior to the sale of lands therein, are unconstitutionally vague and indefinite. The statutory [***2] scheme permits unsupervised realty sales for seasonal recreational purposes, while requiring documented plans for residential development. A landowner could avoid application of the statutory requirements by dividing his plot into four parcels and selling lots from such parcels. Accordingly, the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment restraining the defendants from further realty transactions absent an approved subdivision plan is denied and the defendants are granted summary judgment declaring the statutes unconstitutional.

2. The plaintiffs are entitled to summary judgment with respect to their action to abate a public nuisance based upon the failure of the defendants' sewage disposal system, which creates a danger to the public health.

 

1233 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Wambat Realty Corp. v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Essex County


85 Misc. 2d 489; 378 N.Y.S.2d 912; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3316; 6 ELR 20131



December 31, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowner brought an action for declaratory judgment that the Adirondack Park Agency Act (Act), N.Y. Exec. Law art. 27, enacted by 1971 N.Y. Laws 706, was constitutionally invalid to the extent that it impaired the powers of the town in relation to zoning regulations and other planning work as granted in N.Y. Stat. Law § 10(6), (7). Both the landowner and defendant state filed motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The landowner contended that a land development project that was allowed under local law was frustrated by the regulations and implementing action of the Adirondack Park Agency that was created under the Act. The landowner argued that seven sections of the Act in particular restricted and limited the landowner in the use of his land, were unconstitutional, and were in violation of N.Y. Stat. Law § 10(6), (7). The State contended that the enactment of the challenged provisions of the Act was authorized by N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 3(a) because it related to matters other than the property, affairs, or government of a local government. The court held that the Act, and the plan and map adopted pursuant to the Act, related to matters other than the property, affairs, or government of a local government and were not in violation of either N.Y. Const. art. IX, §§ 1,2, or N.Y. Stat. Law § 10(6), (7). The court held that the Act also was not in violation of any of the landowner's rights.


OUTCOME: The court granted the State's motion for summary judgment and declared the Adirondack Park Agency Act constitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Environmental conservation -- Adirondack Park Agency Act -- Adirondack Park Agency Act (Executive Law, art 27) and adoption pursuant to it of Adirondack Park Land Use and Development Plan and Plan Map are lawful and proper in that they relate to matters other than property, affairs or government of local government, and are not in violation of article IX (§§ 1, 2, subds [a], [b], par [1]) of State Constitution nor chapter 205 of Laws of 1964 (Statute of Local Governments); act is "general law", and did not require passage by Legislature with approval of Governor in two successive calendar years (NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd [b], par [1]).

Plaintiff, a landowner within the Town of Black Brook, felt that its land development project, which was permissible under local law, was frustrated by the regulations and implementing action of the Adirondack Park Agency under the provisions of the Adirondack Park Agency Act (Executive Law, art 27), and brought an action seeking to declare certain sections of the act null and void. Summary judgment is granted to defendants. The act and the adoption pursuant to it of the Adirondack Park Land Use and Development Plan and Plan Map [***2] are, as a matter of law, lawful and proper in that they relate to matters other than the property, affairs or government of a local government, and are not in violation of article IX (§§ 1, 2, subds [a], [b], par [1]) of the New York State Constitution or chapter 205 of the Laws of 1964 (Statute of Local Governments). The act is a "general law" and exceeds the scope and purport of the constitutional and statutory language "property, affairs or government of any local government" as employed in both the State Constitution and the Statute of Local Government in defining exclusions from the powers of local governments and reservations thereto to the Legislature. It follows then that the act did not require passage by the Legislature with approval of the Governor in two successive calendar years (NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd [b], par [1]). The preservation of the unique qualities of the Adirondacks has long been the State's concern, and while area alone is not determinative, as against the limited bounds of the town, an area of six million acres is regulated by the act.

 

1234 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Reisch v. Reisch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Rockland County


85 Misc. 2d 107; 379 N.Y.S.2d 275; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3280



December 30, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner wife filed an application pursuant to the Family Court Act § 438 for payment of attorney fees by respondent husband.


OVERVIEW: The husband challenged the fee application on several grounds. First, he alleged that the form of the wife's request for counsel fees was defective in that it did not contain a notice of motion setting forth a date for argument. The court held that the physical form of the papers submitted was not significant. Secondly, the court rejected the husband's argument that the motion was not timely under § 438, because the trial court had discretion to hear the issue immediately after the final disposition. Thirdly, § 438 was not discriminatory and unconstitutional, because it was reasonably related to the legitimate government interest. Without the power to award a needy wife counsel fees, her rights, in many cases, would not be adequately protected. Lastly, the court held that to deny counsel fees would be an abuse of discretion. After considering factors such as the time expended, the nature and difficulty of the problem, the results obtained, and the financial circumstances of the parties, the court awarded attorney fees to the wife.


OUTCOME: The court granted the wife's petition for attorney fees.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and wife -- support proceedings -- counsel fees -- allowance of counsel fees to wife in support proceeding does not unconstitutionally discriminate against husband to whom fees are not allowable, since classification has reasonable purpose of allowing needy wife to prosecute action properly -- wife's request for counsel fees is not defective for failure to contain notice of motion, since request was in open court with affirmation at court's direction and form of papers is not significant -- motion is not untimely because made after decision by court, since issue may be determined after final disposition in Judge's discretion.

1. The allowance of counsel fees to the petitioner wife in a support proceeding does not unconstitutionally discriminate against the husband to whom counsel fees are not allowable. The classification has the reasonable purpose of allowing a needy wife to prosecute her action properly.

2. Petitioner's request for counsel fees is not defective for failure to contain a notice of motion, since the request was made in open court with an affirmation submitted at the court's direction, and the form of the papers submitted is not significant.

3. Petitioner's [***2] motion for counsel fees is not untimely because it was made after a decision by the court, since a Family Court Judge has the discretionary power to determine such issue after final disposition.

 

1235 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Thompson v. "Lincoln Budget Corp."


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 894; 389 N.Y.S.2d 508; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3379



December 26, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petitioner's motion is granted as modified. Respondents' cross motion is denied. Motion to intervene granted.

Petitioner shall serve a copy of this order on all respondents by ordinary mail.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner administrative judge filed a motion against respondent successful party for discovery under N.Y. C.P.L.R. §§ 3107, 3120 in an action to determine if the successful party's default judgment was obtained by fraud against the trial court pursuant to § 217-a of the N.Y. Judiciary Law. The successful party filed a motion to dismiss the action. The attorney general filed a motion to intervene in the action.


OVERVIEW: The administrative judge filed an action to determine whether the successful party's default judgment was obtained by fraud against the trial court. The successful party claimed that the action was time-barred. The court ruled for the administrative judge because the one-year statute of limitations under N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 5015 did not apply to a court's power to examine its own judgments. Thus, § 217-a of the N.Y. Judiciary Law was retroactive. Also, the fraud action was filed within the six-year statute of limitations under N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 213(9) from the discovery of the fraud. Where the action was transferred from the administrative judge to another judge, § 217-a of the N.Y. Judiciary Law provided an impartial judge. The claim that § 217-a failed to provide for a jury trial was irrelevant where no party requested a jury trial. The court allowed the attorney general to intervene. The court granted the administrative judge's motion for an oral examination under N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 3107 but denied the motion for discovery and production of documents under N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 3120 without prejudice unless it was needed after the oral examination.


OUTCOME: The court denied the successful party's motion to dismiss but granted the attorney general's motion to intervene in the action to determine if the successful party's default judgment was obtained by fraud against the trial court. The court granted the administrative judge's motion for an oral examination but denied the motion for additional discovery and production of documents without prejudice.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- inherent power over judgments.

1. Section 217-a of the Judiciary Law creates no new grounds for vacating and setting aside default judgments beyond those grounds embraced by the concept of the inherent and unlimited power of the courts over their own proceedings. The section merely codifies an illustrative, but incomplete, list of recognized, valid grounds upon which a court may modify or set aside its judgments, establishing orderly procedures to represent the public interest. Accordingly, the retroactive application of section 217-a to actions commenced prior to its effective date involves no exercise of power greater than that already possessed, and retroactive application is necessary to effect the legislative intent to discover abuses of court processes.

2. No Statute of Limitations applies to the court in an action under section 217-a of the Judiciary Law, since courts are not subject to time limitations and none would be appropriate where a wrong involves an [***2] injustice in the use of the court's own processes. The unlimited grounds for exercise of the court's powers over its own proceedings may not be limited in time. If any existing limitation might be considered applicable, it would be the six-year limitation for an action based upon fraud, which runs from discovery of the fraud, and the subject proceeding would be timely thereunder.

3. The one-year period under CPLR 5015 within which a default judgment may be vacated is inapplicable to the court.

4. The disposition of a proceeding under section 217-a of the Judiciary Law is determined by an impartial Judge solely on the basis of the doing of substantial justice, and there is, accordingly, no deprivation of due process.

5. Oral examination under CPLR 3107 should precede discovery under CPLR 3120 in order to elicit information upon which the right to discovery may be intelligently adjudicated.

 

1236 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Flushing Nat'l Bank v. Municipal Assistance Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


84 Misc. 2d 976; 379 N.Y.S.2d 978; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3246



December 23, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all these reasons, summary judgment is granted to the defendants and the complaint is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant debtors filed a motion for summary judgment to dismiss the complaint alleging that a moratorium act (Act) violated the state and federal constitutions. Plaintiff creditor filed a cross-motion for summary judgment and attacked the validity and enforceability of the Act.


OVERVIEW: The debtors had issued and sold bonds and notes to aid the city financially. The Act imposed a three-year moratorium on the enforcement of outstanding city notes in order to avoid destructive actions during the time the city required to regain its financial health. The court entered summary judgment in favor of the debtors and dismissed the complaint. The court found that the Act did not violate U.S. Const. art. I, § 10 by impairing contracts between the city and its noteholders. The court determined that the Act did not abrogate the liability of the city and there was no violation of the state constitution. The court concluded that both noteholders and bondholders were treated equally, both had the right to be paid, and provision was made to pay them in full.


OUTCOME: Summary judgment was granted to the debtors and the creditor's complaint alleging that a moratorium act violated the state and federal constitutions was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- moratorium legislation -- Emergency Moratorium Act for City of New York -- act imposing three-year moratorium on enforcement of outstanding short term city notes at time of grave public emergency is constitutional -- Moratorium Act does not violate section 10 of article I of United States Constitution by impairing contracts between city and its noteholders since priority must be given to public interest over strict compliance with contract clause -- act does not violate article VIII of State Constitution by refusal to adhere to restrictions therein on borrowing and securing city notes or with respect to limited time for redemption of city notes -- act not in conflict with Federal Bankruptcy Act since it does not bind nonconsenting creditors to composition plan -- Equal Protection Clause of Fourteenth Amendment of United States Constitution not violated although act applies to city notes but not city bonds -- declaration of unconstitutionality would be inequitable.

1. In an effort to aid the City of New York during its financial crisis at a time [***2] of grave public emergency, the Legislature enacted the New York State Emergency Moratorium Act for the City of New York (L 1975, ch 874). This act imposes a three-year moratorium on the enforcement of outstanding city notes all of which are short term obligations so as to avoid destructive actions while the city regains its financial health. The Moratorium Act does not violate section 10 of article I of the United States Constitution by impairing contracts between the city and its noteholders. The States have a duty to prevent the literal enforcement of contractual terms in order to protect the health, safety or welfare of their citizens. Therefore, in the public interest the economic interests of the State should be given priority over strict compliance with the contract clause.

2. The Moratorium Act does not violate sections 2, 10 and 12 of article VIII of the New York State Constitution by a refusal to adhere to the restrictions therein on borrowing and securing the city notes. The act provides for the ultimate payment of interest and full principal without relieving the city from its pledge of "faith and credit". The city is obligated to collect and allocate revenues within [***3] constitutional priorities. Although the city is not restricted in relation to its taxing power, the realistic limitations of this power were recognized by the Legislature which passed the Moratorium Act as an emergency measure so that the city could fully meet its obligations.
