3. Section 2 of article VIII of the State Constitution is not violated with respect to the limited time of two years following the initial indebtedness for redemption of city notes. This clause is not applicable to city short term notes. Assuming that it does apply, the Moratorium Act would be sufficient to extend the maturity date of the indebtedness.

4. The Moratorium Act is not in conflict with subdivision (i) of section 83 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act (US Code, tit 11, § 403, subd [i]) which provides that no State law which prescribes a method of composition of indebtedness of municipalities should be binding on nonconsenting creditors. The Moratorium Act permits an extension of indebtedness so as to allow the city time to pay in full. It is not a composition plan empowering the city to discharge, cancel or force surrender of the notes.

5. The Moratorium Act does not violate the Equal Protection [***4] Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution because it applies to city notes and not to city bonds. There are distinctions between notes and bonds. Since the city has a problem in meeting its short term note obligations of over $ 3 billion while it is capable of meeting its long term indebtedness, a moratorium has been imposed on notes and not on bonds. This cannot be considered a constitutional violation of equal rights since both noteholders and bondholders have the right to be paid in full.

6. A declaration of unconstitutionality of the act would be inequitable. The public would face the unpredictable but costly results of default leading to financial disaster for the city while the noteholders would lose interest and a substantial portion of their principal. Strict adherence to legalistic concepts is far outweighted by the equities in favor of constitutionality.

 

1237 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Brauer v. Iroquois Gas Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Niagara County


85 Misc. 2d 936; 381 N.Y.S.2d 166; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3338



December 22, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The complaint is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a city treasurer, filed an action against defendant gas company, seeking a declaration that the gas company's franchise of 1884 was invalid and that the relationship with the city was governed by the city charter of 1907, which required a 25 year limit to franchises and payment by the gas company of 2 1/2 percent of its gross income. The gas company filed a counterclaim.


OVERVIEW: The city treasurer sought a declaration that a lack of definiteness existed as to the beginning and terminating date of the franchise of 1884. The court disagreed, finding that no termination date was added to the franchise at its creation. The court held that in the absence of any conditions as to length of the duration of the rights granted, the conclusion was inescapable that the rights granted should be exercised in perpetuity and by successors to the original franchise. The city treasurer also claimed that the expressed conditions upon which the purported franchise was given were no longer maintained by the gas company. The court found that the city treasurer failed to allege a single factual violation of any express or implied condition of the grant of 1884. On the contrary, his own amended complaint alleged that the gas company maintained pipes and apparatus for delivery of its product to customers in the city. Finally, as to the city charter and its requirement of a 25 year limit on franchises, the court held that the charter was prospective in nature and did not apply to the agreement between the city and the gas company.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the city treasurer's complaint and the gas company's counterclaim.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- gas franchises -- franchise granted in 1884 is valid and governs defendant's relationship with plaintiff -- franchise of 1884 is not void for lack of definiteness as to commencement and termination dates; rights granted should be exercised in perpetuity -- no time limit as to duration of franchise can be found by implication -- defendant has not violated any express or implied condition of franchise grant; fact that Public Service Commission controls rates for utilities does not invalidate underlying franchise -- franchise is not governed by 25-year limit imposed on franchises by title XXIX of North Tonawanda City Charter; charter provision applies prospectively -- geographic limits of original franchise are not restricted to small part of present city -- since charter provision not applied retrospectively, 2 1/2% gross income rate set forth in title XXIX is not applicable to defendant; accordingly, defendant is not liable for money judgment and plaintiff's complaint is dismissed -- since title XXIX is inapplicable, defense of Statute of Limitations and question of constitutionally are not relevant -- plaintiff is entitled  [***2] to have its rights in context of this fact situation determined by court of law; therefore doctrine of estoppel is not relevant.

1. In 1884 a franchise was granted to a predecessor of defendant by the Village of North Tonawanda for the furnishing of gas and gas services to its residents. This franchise grant was expanded in 1895 to include an area which is now the City of North Tonawanda. In 1888 a similar franchise was granted to another predecessor. The City of North Tonawanda succeeded in 1897 to the liabilities of the village, and defendant became a successor to the original franchises. Title XXIX of the City Charter of North Tonawanda was enacted in 1907 to govern franchise grants. No franchise has ever been granted to defendant or its predecessors under this provision. The franchise of 1884 is not void for lack of definiteness as to commencement and termination dates. In the absence of any conditions as to length of the duration of the rights granted, these rights should be exercised in perpetuity.

2. No time limit as to the duration of the franchise can be found by implication. Since the franchise gives no express time limit as to duration, its existence is perpetual.  [***3] Accordingly, it cannot be implied that the franchise is effective for a reasonable time, which time has now expired.

3. Defendant has not voided the franchise by violating any express or implied condition of the franchise grant. Since the inception of the franchise in 1884 there has been an unbroken chain of performance and proper legal succession to the original franchise. Defendant has not charged more than the rate set forth in the original franchise grant and the fact that the Public Service Commission controls rates for utilities in this State does not invalidate the underlying franchise.

4. The franchise is not governed by the 25-year limit imposed on franchises by title XXIX of the charter. This charter provision applies prospectively. The words "shall be" indicate a legislative intent for prospective application and no reference is made to any franchises previously granted.

5. Although the City of North Tonawanda's boundaries have expanded greatly since permission was granted in 1884 by the village, the geographic limits of the original franchise are not restricted to a small part of the present city. The franchise was amended in 1895 by the village to include what [***4] are now the limits of the city. Furthermore, in 1897 the city became liable for all the liabilities of the village.

6. The 2 1/2 gross income rate set forth in title XXIX for the sale of gas and services in the City of North Tonawanda is not applicable to defendant since this charter provision is not to be retrospectively applied to the relationship between the parties. Furthermore, a franchise creates a contractual right which is constitutionally protected from subsequent impairment by a municipal authority. Accordingly, since defendant's relationship with plaintiff is governed by the franchise of 1884, which is valid, defendant is not liable for a money judgment and plaintiff's complaint is dismissed.

7. Since title XXIX of the charter does not control the legal relationship between the parties, neither the defense of Statute of Limitations nor the question of constitutionality is relevant to the decision.

8. Plaintiff is entitled to have its rights in the context of this fact situation determined by a court of law, and therefore the doctrine of estoppel is not relevant. Accordingly, defendant's counterclaim, predicated on its rights being adversely affected, is dismissed.

 

1238 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rotodyne, Inc. v. Consolidated Edison Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


85 Misc. 2d 347; 378 N.Y.S.2d 899; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3307



December 18, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is in all respects denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant contractors filed a motion for partial summary judgment dismissing the first cause of action to foreclose plaintiff subcontractor's mechanic's lien on the ground that the subcontractor expressly waived its right to file a mechanic's lien in the construction contract allegedly breached by the contractors.


OVERVIEW: The subcontractor entered into a construction contract that included an express waiver of its mechanic's lien rights. An alleged breach of contract led the subcontract to file a notice of lien. Thereafter, the legislature enacted N.Y. Lien Law § 34 (1975), which declared waivers of mechanic's liens to be void as against public policy. The subcontractor sought to enforce the lien, and the contractors filed a partial summary judgment motion relying on the waiver. The court denied the motion, holding that § 34 applied retroactively to prevent enforcement of the waiver. Such application of § 34 did not constitute impairment of contractual rights in violation of U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, because the statute was designed for the general good of the public by protection of subcontractors and materialmen who were not economically strong enough to resist demands that they waive a valuable statutory right created specifically for their protection.


OUTCOME: The court denied the contractors' motion for partial summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Liens -- mechanic's lien -- waiver of right to file mechanic's lien is unenforceable even though it was executed prior to enactment of statute declaring such waivers void as against public policy and wholly unenforceable.

A waiver of the right to file a mechanic's lien is unenforceable even though it was executed prior to the enactment of section 34 of the Lien Law, which was effective July 1, 1975, and which provides that "Notwithstanding the provisions of any other general, specific or local law, any contract, agreement or understanding whereby the right to file or enforce any lien created under article two is waived, shall be void as against public policy and wholly unenforceable". The sweeping language of that section clearly indicates an intention that it apply to pre-existing contracts. Nor does such application unconstitutionally impair contractual rights.

 

1239 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. O'Neill


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


85 Misc. 2d 130; 379 N.Y.S.2d 244; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3282



December 13, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is in all respects denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged in two indictments with drug offenses that could result in a life sentence if he were found guilty. He moved the court for dismissal of the indictments in the furtherance of justice pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.40 and, in the alternative, for an order directing the prosecutor to recommend probation pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 65.00(1)(b).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was a popular college student. He did well academically and participated in athletics and other extra-curricular activities. He was charged with the sale of cocaine with a transaction price of $ 7,000. He agreed to cooperate with the police after his arrest in order to receive the prosecutor's recommendation of probation. The prosecutor deemed his efforts insufficient to warrant the recommendation. He presented numerous letters from university officials attesting to his bright future. The court held that his social, economic, or educational status furnished no reason for dismissal of the charges. Neither could the court force the prosecutor to exercise his discretion to recommend probation.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- criminal sale of controlled substance -- indictment for criminal sale of controlled substance should not be dismissed in furtherance of justice, since social, economic or educational status of defendant presents no compelling reason for dismissal -- court may not require recommendation of probation for class A-III felon, since recommendation is discretionary and condition precedent to court action.

1. An indictment of the defendant for criminal sale of a controlled substance should not be dismissed in furtherance of justice, since there is no compelling reason for dismissal. Notwithstanding that the defendant is a high scholastic achiever and active in sports and extra-curricular activities, the social, economic or educational status of the defendant should not exempt him from possible conviction for what he knew to be a crime.

2. The court may not require the prosecutor to recommend probation as an alternative to imprisonment for a class A-III felony. The District Attorney's recommendation is a matter of discretion which should not be interfered with except under the most unusual and compelling circumstances. Since the [***2] recommendation is a condition precedent to court action, the court is without power to force the prosecutor to act against his own judgment.

 

1240 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Moore


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Fulton County


85 Misc. 2d 4; 377 N.Y.S.2d 1005; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3269



December 12, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, charged in the second count of their respective indictments with violating N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 805-a(1) prohibiting the solicitation or acceptance of a gift with a value greater than $ 25 by a municipal officer or employee, contended that § 805-a(1) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendants, who were municipal officials, contended that § 805-a(1) was unconstitutional and violative of the Due Process Clause of the Constitutions of the United States and the State of New York in that it failed to adequately set a standard by which reasonable men could reach a determination as to what were circumstances in which a gift was intended to influence the in their capacity as municipal officials and that the statute was unduly vague and unspecific. The prosecution maintained that the statute was not unduly vague in that the exercise of common sense could guide an individual in identifying the nature of the prohibited conduct. The court held that the language of the second prohibition in § 805-a(1) left too much to the discretion of police or enforcement officials to determine criminality. The court was disturbed by the fact that the intent of the donor of the gift, not the intent of the municipal official accepting it, was controlling. The court found these deficiencies serious and violative of the equal protection of the law. The court, concluding that the two prohibitions in § 805-a(1) were severable, retained the first prohibition and severed the second.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motions to dismiss after finding one of the statute's prohibition unconstitutional but severable from the remainder.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- acceptance of gift by municipal employee -- first prohibition of subdivision 1 of section 805-a of General Municipal Law, under which municipal officer or employee is forbidden to "directly or indirectly, solicit any gift", is constitutional; language is clear, definite and unequivocal, so much so that no rational argument can be levied against its intent and meaning -- second prohibition prohibits municipal officer or employee from accepting or receiving any gift having value of $ 25 or more, in any form "under circumstances in which it could be reasonably inferred that the gift was intended to influence him, or could reasonably be expected to influence him", and is unconstitutional; such language is vague and without any standards or guidelines and accordingly, is violative of due process and equal protection clauses of State and Federal Constitutions.

1. Defendants were indicted for violating subdivision 1 of section 805-a of the General Municipal Law, which in general prohibits municipal officers or employees from soliciting any gift or accepting or receiving any gift having a value of $ 25 or more under circumstances in which it could be inferred that the gift [***2] was intended to influence him in the performance of his official duties. On defendants' motion to dismiss on the grounds that the statute is unconstitutionally vague, the first part of the statute is upheld. The statute is severable and prohibits two separate and distinct types of conduct: soliciting a gift of any value under all circumstances, and accepting or receiving any gift of $ 25 or more, even if unsolicited, in any form, under circumstances intended or expected to influence the official in his official duties. Under the first prohibition, a municipal officer or employee is forbidden to "directly or indirectly, solicit any gift". This particular prohibition and language is clear, definite and unequivocal, so much so that no rational argument can be levied against its intent and meaning, and is therefore declared to be constitutional.

2. Under the second prohibition, a municipal officer or employee is forbidden to accept or receive any gift having a value of $ 25 or more, in any form, "under circumstances in which it could reasonably be inferred that the gift was intended to influence him, or could reasonably be expected to influence him". Such language is vague and without [***3] any standard or guidelines whatsoever, and accordingly, is unconstitutional as violative of the due process and equal protection clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions. The wording does not set forth any commonly accepted or understood circumstance or set of circumstances under which it can be reasonably inferred that a gift is intended to influence or could reasonably be expected to influence an official in the performance of his duties or was intended as a reward for any official action on his part. Nor does it contain any standard or guidelines by which such a determination may be ascertained.

 

1241 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Weber v. Kowalski


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Dutchess County


85 Misc. 2d 349; 376 N.Y.S.2d 996; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3308



December 11, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff driver sought review of the denial of his application for a general preference and filed a motion for leave to reargue the denial alleging jurisdictional problems because defendant tortfeasor was a non-resident of the county to which the court transferred his action.


OVERVIEW: The driver filed suit against the tortfeasor for injuries he and his family sustained in a car accident with the tortfeasor. The court denied the driver's application for a general preference and directed the transfer of the action to county court. The driver filed a motion for leave to reargue and alleged jurisdictional problems because the tortfeasor was a non-resident of the country to which the action was transferred. The court granted the driver's motion leave to reargue and denied his motion for a general preference. The court found that the general preference rule, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 22, § 674.1, which allowed the court to transfer tort cases to county court where the possible recovery was under a certain dollar amount was constitutional. The court held that the courts had the inherent power to control their own calendars. The court also held that the rule did not violate due process because the driver never had a vested right that was taken away. The court also held that the rule did not violate the equal protection clause because there was a reasonable basis for the classification that was the efficient running of the court docket.


OUTCOME: The court granted the driver leave to reargue and upon reargument the court denied the river's application for a general preference provided that the tortfeasor consented to the transfer to county court and agreed not to assert in personam jurisdictional objections, by filing an affidavit to that effect with the calendar clerk; otherwise, the court would grant the driver's application for a general preference.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- denial of general preference -- since plaintiffs in automobile negligence case failed to convince Dutchess County Supreme Court that they could recover in excess of $ 10,000 on each separate cause of action, application for general preference is denied; absent nonmonetary jurisdictional questions, test for general preference is whether claims asserted could result in recovery in excess of lower court's monetary jurisdiction -- general preference rule of Second Department (22 NYCRR 674.1) does not deprive plaintiffs of due process or violate their right to have damages assessed by jury -- fact that Dutchess County (Ninth Judicial District) does not have rule in regard to varying of monetary limitations upon transfers down does not violate equal protection -- where jurisdictional problems cause actions to be heard in Supreme Court that would otherwise be heard in County Court, policy in Ninth Judicial District is to conditionally deny general preferences provided defendant agrees to waive jurisdictional objections.

1. After an automobile accident in which personal injuries were allegedly sustained, a husband and wife instituted an action against defendant in Dutchess [***2] County Supreme Court. Thereafter another action was brought on behalf of their two infant children and in the father's own behalf, and the actions were ordered consolidated. In addition to a demand for a jury trial, the complaints alleged five causes of action wherein the wife sought $ 50,000, the children sought $ 25,000 each, and the husband sought a total of $ 36,500 (two causes of action for loss of services, one for property damage). Demands for special damages of approximately $ 4,000 were incorporated in both complaints. While permanent injuries were claimed for the wife and children, medical records and doctors' letters did not support those claims. A note of issue and statement of readiness were filed and an application for a general preference was made. The application for a general preference was denied and the action was ordered transferred to the Dutchess County Court upon the expiration of 90 days unless plaintiffs renewed the application. Upon plaintiffs' motion to reargue, the application for a general preference is again denied. However, if defendant does not consent to the transfer to County Court and agree not to assert in personam jurisdictional objections,  [***3] the application will be granted. Plaintiffs failed to convince the court that they could recover in excess of $ 10,000 on each of the separate causes of action. While the Second Department rule for determining a general preference is 22 NYCRR 674.1, absent nonmonetary jurisdictional questions, the test is whether the claims asserted could result in a recovery in excess of a lower court's monetary jurisdiction, and case law holds this to be peculiarly within the court's discretion. No medical affidavits were offered to support the claimed injury to the infants, and the letters submitted in support of the wife's claims establish an insignificant injury and apparent recovery. The total amount of special damages ($ 4,263), absent a severe permanent injury (pain and suffering), indicates these claims are well within the $ 10,000 monetary jurisdiction of the Dutchess County Court.

2. The general preference rule of the Second Department (22 NYCRR 674.1) does not deprive plaintiffs of due process or violate their right to have damages assessed by a jury. There is no taking of "property" within the meaning of the due process clause (i.e., potential maximum recovery reduced) because plaintiffs [***4] never had a vested right in the inchoate prayers for relief to obtain the amount demanded. Nor is there any "access" problem as plaintiffs have the County Court available, where they will receive a jury trial. The screening technique is merely a determination as a matter of law of a facet of their causes of action, a matter solely within the discretion of the court.

3. While CPLR 325 (subd [d]) gives the Appellate Divisions authority to vary monetary limitations on transfers on a county by county basis, the fact that Dutchess County (Ninth Judicial District) has no such rule does not violate equal protection. The no-transfer rule is premised on the congested state of the civil calendars in the lower courts, and this is reasonable and constitutes a valid basis for the monetary distinctions extant in various counties. Jurisdiction has not been renounced, rather the court has exercised restraint and in its discretion, transferred cases to a more appropriate forum, which can be removed back to Supreme Court upon a proper showing.

4. While nonresident individuals of Dutchess County are not subject to jurisdiction of the Dutchess County Court, plaintiffs can commence their actions [***5] in Supreme Court based on nonmonetary jurisdictional considerations. However, it is the policy in the Ninth Judicial District to conditionally deny general preferences provided defendant agrees to waive in personam jurisdictional objections upon the transfer to County Court.

 

1242 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Person-Wolinsky Associates, Inc. v. Nyquist


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


84 Misc. 2d 930; 377 N.Y.S.2d 897; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3219



December 8, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent Commissioner of Education of the State of New York filed a motion to dismiss in point of law petitioner exam review company's request for an order compelling the Commissioner to continue his practice of supplying lists of all applicants for the state's certified public accountant exam, despite the enactment of the Freedom of Information Law, codified N.Y. Pub. Off. Law art. 6.


OVERVIEW: For years, the Commissioner supplied the lists of exam applicants to the exam review company, which used the list for solicitation of the applicants to take its approved review course preparatory to the examination. After the Freedom of Information Law was enacted, the Commissioner declined to supply the list, and the exam review company filed a petition to compel access to the information. The Commissioner filed a motion to dismiss the petition, which the court granted. The court held that N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 88, subd. (3) prohibited the Commissioner from supplying the information because of the commercial character of the exam review company's business. The court also held that the statute was not unconstitutional and that the Commissioner's decision was not arbitrary.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the exam review company's petition.


HEADNOTES

Public officers -- public's right to know -- lists of test applicants -- since Freedom of Information Law (Public Officers Law, art 6) defines in subdivision 3 of section 88 what is meant by "unwarranted invasion of personal privacy" to include release of names and addresses in possession of any agency if they would be used for commercial purposes, Commissioner of Education is prohibited from supplying lists of applicants for State Certified Public Accountant's examination to business that gives approved review courses -- neither State nor agencies may be estopped by acts done in prior years; it cannot be said that commissioner's decision to refuse to supply lists was arbitrary.

1. Prior to the enactment of the Freedom of Information Law (Public Officers Law, art 6), respondent supplied petitioner with lists of applicants for the State Certified Public Accountant's examination, so that petitioner had up-to-date lists of applicants available for solicitation to take petitioner's approved review course preparatory to the examination. Subdivision 3 of section 88 of the Public Officers Law provides that, in the absence of guidelines [***2] by the Committee on Public Access to Records, an agency may delete identifying details to prevent an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy. Upon a petition to compel respondent to continue his former practice, or to allow petitioner access to respondent's records so that petitioner might itself compile the lists for use in its business, the petition is dismissed. Subdivision 3 of section 88 defines what is meant by "an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy" to include in paragraph d "the sale or release of names and addresses in the possession of any agency or municipality if such lists of names would be used for private, commercial or fund raising purposes". The commercial character of petitioner's business brings it within the statutory exception and thereby prohibits respondent from further compliance with his practice of supplying the lists. Lists of applicants for examination purposes specifically are an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.

2. That such was a long-standing practice before the enactment is irrelevant since neither the State nor its agencies may be estopped by acts done in prior years. Nor may paragraph d be said to be unconstitutional. The heavy [***3] burden imposed to reach that result has not been met by petitioner because it cannot be said that respondent's decision to refuse to supply the lists was arbitrary.

 

1243 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Diaz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


85 Misc. 2d 41; 376 N.Y.S.2d 849; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3274



December 4, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Consequently, the defendant's motion to suppress the visual observations of Ms. Mundy, as well as all testimony and physical evidence derived therefrom, is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to suppress security officer's surreptitious observations of her in a store dressing room, and all testimony and physical evidence derived therefrom, contending that these constituted an unlawful search and seizure prohibited by the U. S. Const. amend. IV.


OVERVIEW: Defendant stood accused of petit larceny, and moved to suppress the visual observations of a security officer who, from above a fitting room, saw defendant removing clothing tags and placing garments in a knapsack, and to suppress as well as all testimony and physical evidence derived from the officer's observation, on the grounds that these constituted an unlawful search and seizure prohibited by the U.S. Const. amend. IV. The court granted the motion. Although the U.S. Const. amend. IV applied only to acts committed by government officials, the witnessing security officer was considered one. Whatever a person seeks to preserve as private, even in an area accessible to the public, may be protected. Surreptitious spying on shoppers as they undress and try on various garments infringes on people's reasonable expectation of privacy and, therefore, involves a violation of the U.S. Const. amend. IV. Conduct suspicious and equivocal, without more, did not justify a search.


OUTCOME: Motion to suppress evidence was granted because wherever persons were, they were entitled to know that they would remain free from unreasonable searches and seizures.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- unlawful search and seizure -- where special patrolman in department store positioned herself above ladies' fitting room so as to observe defendant removing tags from garments and placing garments in knapsack, and thereafter bag was searched and items seized, defendant's motion to suppress visual observations, as well as all testimony and physical evidence derived therefrom, is granted; persons using fitting rooms have reasonable expectation of privacy -- special patrolman considered agent of government as such patrolmen in New York City are licensed by city, appointed by police commissioner, and possess powers beyond those of ordinary citizen -- special patrolman lacked probable cause to search based on earlier conduct of codefendant, since such conduct was at most suspicious and equivocal.

1. A "special patrolman" in a department store, whose duties were to prevent theft of merchandise and to apprehend persons who commit, or attempt to commit, larcenous conduct, observed the codefendant as she took [***2] a scarf and put it into her knapsack, which she removed when a sales clerk spoke to her. After watching defendant take several garments into a fitting room, the special patrolman ascended a stairway to a scaffold above the fitting room from which she was able to look down into the room below by means of a grated air vent. She then observed defendant remove tags from the garments and place the garments in the knapsack. Defendant was thereafter detained, the bag searched, and the items seized. Upon defendant's motion to suppress the visual observations of the special patrolman, as well as all testimony and physical evidence derived therefrom, the motion is granted. The protection afforded by the Fourth Amendment against unreasonable searches and seizures depends on an individual's reasonable expectation of privacy. Persons using fitting rooms have an expectation of privacy, since the function of such rooms is to provide a place where a customer can try on items of clothing in private, undisturbed from the observation of others. The surreptitious spying on shoppers as they undress and try on various garments infringes on people's reasonable expectation of privacy and is unconstitutional. 

 [***3] 2. While the Fourth Amendment does not apply to acts undertaken by private persons, a special patrolman must be considered an agent of the government. Special patrolmen in New York City are licensed by the city, appointed by the police commissioner, and possess powers beyond those of an ordinary citizen. (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 434a-7.0.)

3. The special patrolman did not have probable cause to search based on her observation of the codefendant placing a scarf in her knapsack, which she removed when approached by a sales clerk. At most, defendants' conduct was suspicious and equivocal which, without more, did not justify a search.

 

1244 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Richardson v. Starr


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


85 Misc. 2d 476; 378 N.Y.S.2d 248; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3313



December 4, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner tenants brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding challenging the action of respondent administrator fixing "first rents" in their apartment building. The tenants contended that the procedure used by the administrator, which resulted in a drastic increase in their rents, deprived them of due process of law.


OVERVIEW: Respondent landlord obtained a $ 902,000 loan to rehabilitate the apartment building, pursuant to N.Y. Priv. Hous. Fin. Law art. VIII. Following completion of the project, the administrator fixed the "first rents" that the landlord could charge, in many instances at three or four times the amount that the landlord had previously charged. The court held that the administrator had the authority to do so and that he had taken into account the proper factors in arriving at the first rents. The N.Y. Priv. Hous. Fin. Law was not unconstitutional. It resulted in better housing, even if the tenants could not afford it. That was a legislative decision. The administrator was not required to give the tenants notice and an opportunity to be heard before adjusting rents. A hearing was permissive in nature and subject to the administrator's discretion.


OUTCOME: The court denied the tenants' application and dismissed their petition.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- rehabilitation of low-income housing -- following rehabilitation of rent-controlled 54-family low-income apartment house financed by $ 902,300 loan to owners under Municipal Loan Program of City of New York (Private Housing Finance Law, art VIII), respondent Rent Commissioner properly established new "first rents" substantially increasing rents; new rent schedules developed after adversary proceeding have factual and rational basis; court may not overrule judgment of Legislature permitting landlord who borrows public tax funds to improve his property to pass on increases to low-income tenants.

Upon the completion of the rehabilitation of a rent-controlled 54-family low-income apartment house financed under the Municipal Loan Program of the City of New York by a $ 902,300 loan to the owners pursuant to article VIII of the Private Housing Finance Law, respondent Rent Commissioner properly established new "first rents" substantially increasing the rents of petitioners tenants. Petitioners were not entitled to be consulted or otherwise made part of the rehabilitation process which resulted in a substantial increase in their [***2] rentals. Under section Y51-5.0 (subd g, par 1, cl [m]) of the Administrative Code of the City of New York and section 33.9 of the Rent and Eviction Regulations, respondent Rent Commissioner is vested with authority to increase rents in rent-controlled buildings "where he finds that there has been a rehabilitation or improvement of substandard or deteriorated housing accommodations which has been financed under a governmental program providing assistance through loans, loan insurance or tax abatement". The new rent schedules, developed and tested in an adversary proceeding before respondent Rent Commissioner, where the tenants and their lawyers were heard and their views considered, have a factual and rational basis and should not be disturbed. Although petitioners are suffering acute economic distress, the court is without power to overrule the judgment of the Legislature permitting a landlord to borrow public tax funds to improve his private property and then pass on the increases to tenants notwithstanding the fact that the "beneficiaries" of the law, which was intended to enable tenants of limited means to live in better housing "without exorbitant increases" in their rents,  [***3] are now compelled to pay large increases in rent, whether they can afford to do so or not.

 

1245 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hines


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Ulster County


84 Misc. 2d 617; 376 N.Y.S.2d 72; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3189



December 1, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for an order precluding the imposition of a sentence of 15 years to life for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §220.21. Defendant claimed that Penal Law provisions requiring such sentence were violative of the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution, in its prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the first degree, and he filed a motion for an order precluding sentencing under the statutory guidelines. The court denied the motion, holding that the sentencing provisions of the Penal Law were constitutional as applied to defendant's case. The court noted that defendant's case involved a more aggravated crime, declared by the legislature to constitute a higher degree, and justifying a higher minimum period of imprisonment.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- dangerous drugs -- cruel and unusual punishment -- minimum term of from 15 to 25 years and maximum term of life imprisonment upon conviction for class A-I felony does not constitute cruel and unusual punishment for crime of possession of dangerous drug in first degree, since conviction is for more aggravated crime, constituting higher degree and justifying higher minimum period of imprisonment than that held to be not irrationally severe for class A-II and class A-III felonies ( People v Broadie, 37 NY2d 100).

The provision under subdivision 2 of section 70 of the Penal Law of a minimum term of from 15 to 25 years' imprisonment and a maximum term of life imprisonment upon conviction for a class A-I felony does not constitute cruel and unusual punishment for the crime of possession of a controlled substance in the first degree. The conviction is for a more aggravated crime, declared by the Legislature to constitute a higher degree and justifying a higher minimum period of imprisonment than that found by the Court of Appeals to be "relatively severe, but not irrationally so" with respect to class A-II and class A-III felonies [***2] ( People v Broadie, 37 NY2d 100).

 

1246 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rubin v. Hevro Realty Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


84 Misc. 2d 1074; 376 N.Y.S.2d 834; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3265



December 1, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Settle order dismissing the first through fourth causes of action; severing the fifth cause of action and remanding it to the tort trial calendar.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, landlords and city departments, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211, 3212, filed motions to dismiss and for summary judgment of plaintiff tenants' class action regarding problems in the tenants' building.


OVERVIEW: The tenants filed a class action against the landlords and the city departments, which filed a motion to dismiss and a motion for summary judgment. The first cause of action for a permanent injunction to enjoin disconnection of electricity to the premises and for damages was dismissed because the city department's order was not arbitrary or capricious. The second cause of action for a judgment declaring New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B30-20.0 unconstitutional was dismissed because the requirement of an unsafe condition was not vague and did not deprive the tenants of relocation benefits. The third cause of action to compel the abatement of the housing violations or direct civil penalties was dismissed because the cost of removing the violations was excessive and the court was not the proper forum for civil penalties. The fourth cause of action to compel the city department to perform emergency repairs was dismissed because the decision to make the repairs was within the discretion of the commissioner. The fifth cause of action for damages was severed and placed on the tort trial calendar because it involved questions of fact that could not be decided on motions.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the first four causes of action and placed the fifth cause of action for damages on the court's tort trial calendar.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- hazardous building -- plaintiff tenants are not entitled to permanent injunction against vacate order and order of New York City Department of Public Works disconnecting electricity, since violations are undisputed hazard and orders are not arbitrary -- section B30-20.0 of Administrative Code of City of New York is not unconstitutionally vague, since it requires specific condition of unsafeness, and issue of vagueness is rendered moot by undisputed hazardous condition of plaintiffs' building -- plaintiffs are not deprived of right to relocation benefits, since vacate order is required upon electrical disconnection and relocation benefits are thereupon authorized -- landlord cannot be compelled to make extensive expenditures to remove violations -- emergency repairs by Housing and Development Administration are discretionary and may not be compelled -- issue of plaintiffs' damages is factual and cannot be decided on motion.

1. The plaintiff tenants are not entitled to a permanent injunction against a [***2] vacate order and an order of the New York City Department of Public Works disconnecting electricity in their building, since electrical violations constitute undisputed immediate hazards to the lives of the tenants and the orders cannot, accordingly, be considered arbitrary.

2. Section B30-20.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York is not unconstitutionally vague, since it requires the existence of a specific condition of unsafeness, and the conceded hazardous condition in plaintiffs' building renders moot the question of vagueness.

3. The plaintiffs are not deprived of the right to relocation benefits, since a vacate order is required upon disconnection of electrical services and relocation benefits are thereupon authorized.

4. The landlord cannot be compelled to remove the violations on the premises, since the extensive expenditures required would border on confiscation.

5. Emergency repairs by the Housing and Development Administration are discretionary and may not be compelled.

6. The issue of damages to the plaintiffs is factual and cannot be decided on motion.

 

1247 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Amerada Hess Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Bronx County


84 Misc. 2d 1036; 375 N.Y.S.2d 1001; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3257



November 26, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The charge against the defendant corporation is therefore dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant corporation was charged by the State with unauthorized filling in of waterfront property in violation of New York City, N.Y., Department of Ports and Terminals R. & Reg. 3(b). The corporation claimed that it did not "fill in" the land within the meaning of Rule 3(b).


OVERVIEW: An inspector for the Department of Ports and Terminals testified that he discovered broken concrete had been dumped along the bank of a creek and into the water. After ascertaining that no permit had been issued to the corporation authorizing the dumping, the inspector issued a summons for violation of Rule 3(b). The corporation claimed that the concrete was on the bank above the high-water mark, that it was placed to prevent pollution by material silting, that it extended the property line, and that it did not interfere with the navigability of the waterway. The court dismissed the charge. The effect of Rule 3(b) was directed at obstructions to navigation and was an attempt to maintain navigable passageways. The effects of Rule 3(b) could not be to reproach a landowner from fortifying a boundary on a navigable body of water or a waterway. While a riparian owner who sought to improve his property had to do so without obstructing the navigability of a waterway, the owner was entitled to build some form of protection to establish his boundary or to prevent the loss of soil by erosion. The corporation was not required to get permission to reinforce its existing boundary line.


OUTCOME: The charge against the corporation was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- obstructing navigable waterways -- defendant did not violate rule 3(b) of Rules and Regulations of New York City Department of Ports and Terminals, which prohibits "filling in" on or about waterfront property, since regulation of navigable water is directed at obstructions to navigation and cannot be construed to prohibit defendant from fortifying boundary by dumping concrete above water line; accordingly, charge is dismissed.

The conduct of the defendant in dumping concrete along a creek bank above the water line was not in violation of rule 3(b) of the Rules and Regulations of the New York City Department of Ports and Terminals, which prohibits persons from "filling in" on or about any waterfront property without prior permission. Regulation of navigable waters is directed at obstructions to navigation and cannot be construed to prohibit a landowner from fortifying his boundary. Accordingly, the charge is dismissed.

 

1248 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Miller v. Tofany


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Broome County


88 Misc. 2d 247; 387 N.Y.S.2d 342; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3374



November 25, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner driver sought review by a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding of an order of respondent Commissioner of the Department of Motor Vehicles of the State of New York, revoking his driving license for failure to submit to a chemical breath test. He also sought an order granting him the right to apply for a conditional driver's license under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law art. 21.


OVERVIEW: The driver was arrested for driving while under the influence of alcohol. He refused a chemical breath test. The Department held a hearing to determine whether the driver's license should be revoked for failing to take the test. The arresting officer testified but the driver declined to testify, asserting his Fifth Amendment privilege. The criminal case was still pending and the hearing officer denied the driver's request to adjourn the hearing until the conclusion of the criminal trial. The court held that it could not review the revocation. The driver was required to appeal the determination through the administrative process first. The decision to refuse the driver's request for a stay pending appeal was based upon sufficient evidence, namely the testimony of the arresting officer. The court could not grant the driver's request for a conditional license because he had not first asked for it from the administrative agency. The court determined that the statutes providing for the conditional license did not violate the driver's equal protection rights.


OUTCOME: The court denied the driver's petition.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- revocation of licenses -- administrative appeals -- alcohol and drug rehabilitation program.

1. On the basis of petitioner's refusal to submit to a chemical breath test following his arrest on a charge of driving while intoxicated, to which he entered a plea of guilty in now pending criminal proceedings, his license was revoked, and he filed an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Board, requesting a stay of the order of revocation pending the determination of the appeal, which request was denied. The order of revocation is not now subject to judicial review in an article 78 proceeding, since it falls within the scope of section 263 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, providing that such a determination is not reviewable by any court unless an administrative appeal has been filed and determined. However, the board's refusal to grant him a stay is, under that section, final and subject to judicial review, restricted to the issue of whether or not the board's action had a reasonable or plausible basis. The record of the hearing held here contains evidence adequate to sustain the determination, the validity of which is not affected [***2] by his refusal to testify, since that was not the basis for the decision.

2. Since petitioner has not applied for, or been refused, a conditional license under article 21 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which permits persons convicted of alcohol and drug related traffic offenses to obtain such a license during a license revocation period if they participate in a rehabilitation program, he cannot challenge the constitutionality of that article in an article 78 proceeding. Treating the proceeding as an action for a declaratory judgment, the article does not deny him equal protection by denying him a conditional license while permitting persons convicted of more serious offenses to obtain such licenses. The right to a conditional license under the article is not an incident of conviction for an alcohol or drug related traffic offense, but a privilege which emanates from full participation in the rehabilitation program, and to limit participation therein to persons with alcohol or drug problems, which petitioner denies having, is reasonable. Moreover, even if the article were unconstitutional, the court would have authority to declare it void, but no authority to include within its [***3] scope a class of persons excluded by the Legislature.

 

1249 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gibson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Dutchess County


84 Misc. 2d 762; 376 N.Y.S.2d 816; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3229



November 21, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to vacate his judgment of conviction on the ground that it was obtained in violation of his constitutional rights. Defendant claimed that at the time of his sentence he was denied his due process right to be adjudicated youthful offender treatment solely because of the grade or degree of the offense for which he was indicted without any regard for that of which he could be convicted. The People opposed the motion.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with murder. At the time the crime was committed, Code Crim. Proc. § 913-e stated that a youthful offender meant a youth who committed a crime not punishable by death or life imprisonment, who had not previously been convicted of a felony. Subsequent to defendant's conviction, § 913-e was superseded by Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10(2), which provided youthful offender procedure for every youth unless he was indicted for a class A felony, or had previously been convicted of a felony. Defendant claimed that a constitutional infirmity had been found in § 720.10(2) by tying the availability of youthful offender treatment to the indictment, without regard to whether the class A felony charge was sustained. The court denied the motion. The factual setting in the instant proceeding did not present an analogous situation to the constitutional infirmity found in § 720.10(2) because defendant was not only charged, but also was convicted under a statute, which provided ineligibility for youthful offender treatment. It could not be held that the exclusion from youthful offender treatment for the crime of intentional murder was arbitrary, capricious, or irrational.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to vacate his judgment of conviction was denied.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- youthful offenders -- section 913-e of Code of Criminal Procedure, which precludes youthful offender treatment for those who have "committed a crime" punishable by death or life imprisonment, does not unconstitutionally deprive defendant of such treatment on basis of indictment rather than conviction, since term "committed" means "convicted", and ineligibility results from full adversary proceeding before jury, not from ex parte Grand Jury accusation.

Section 913-e of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which precludes youthful offender treatment for a defendant "who has committed a crime" punishable by death or life imprisonment, does not unconstitutionally deprive the defendant of youthful offender treatment on the basis of the crime for which he was indicted without regard to that for which he might be convicted. The term "committed a crime" means "convicted thereof", and ineligibility results from a full adversary proceeding before a jury, not from an ex parte Grand Jury accusation, as in CPL 720.10 (subd 2, par [a]).

 

1250 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gandhi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


84 Misc. 2d 231; 375 N.Y.S.2d 556; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3113



November 20, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, who was in prison serving a sentence on manslaughter and robbery convictions, filed a motion to dismiss a three-and-one-half-year-old second indictment for robbery stemming from the same incident. Defendant contended that he was denied his constitutional and statutory rights to a speedy trial under the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 30.20, and N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 12.


OVERVIEW: The district attorney contended that the word "appeals" in the tolling statute, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 30.30(4)(a), meant that during the time defendant appealed his homicide conviction, the People were not required to proceed in the robbery case. The court rejected the district attorney's claim on the basis that his interpretation of the statute would render it unconstitutional. The court held that the word "appeals" referred to appeals from pre-conviction proceedings and motions and not appeals from a judgment of conviction in an unrelated case. The district attorney also contended that defendant waived his right to a speedy trial by consenting to various adjournments. Defense counsel argued that the adjournments were consented to because the prosecuting attorney said that if the murder case was affirmed on appeal he would dismiss the robbery case. The court held that there was no speedy trial waiver by meaningful consent of defendant because the statutory and constitutional rights to a speedy trial would not be deemed to have been waived on "good faith misunderstandings" informally conducted outside of the court record, while defendant was in the state's prison.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- right to speedy trial -- multiple indictments -- where defendant had two indictments pending, one of which resulted in conviction and sentencing in December of 1973, with affirmance by Appellate Division in June of 1975, motion to dismiss second untried indictment is granted on grounds of denial of speedy trial rights; word "appeals" in CPL 30.30 (subd 4, par [a]), which allows delay resulting from appeals to be excluded from time in which People must be ready for trial, refers to appeals from preconviction proceedings and motions, not appeals from judgment of conviction in unrelated case -- defendant's speedy trial rights are not deemed to have been waived on "good faith misunderstandings" informally conducted outside of court record, while defendant was in prison -- controversy should and could have been avoided by using proper procedures, which are outlined.

1. In 1972 defendant had two indictments pending against him, one charging murder and robbery, the second charged robbery and other crimes. The murder indictment went to trial and defendant was convicted and sentenced on December 3, 1973.  [***2] On June 26, 1975 the conviction was affirmed by the Appellate Division. Upon a motion by defendant to dismiss the indictment charging robbery and other crimes upon the ground that he has been denied his constitutional and statutory rights to a speedy trial, the motion is granted. CPL 30.30 (subd 4, par [a]), which allows a reasonable period of delay resulting from appeals to be excluded from the time in which the People must be ready for trial, does not mean that the People were not required to proceed on the second indictment while defendant appealed his homicide conviction. A rational interpretation of the word "appeals" in the statute, especially in light of statutory ( CPL 450.10, subd 1; 460.20) and constitutional rights to appeal to our higher courts, indicates that it refers to appeals from preconviction proceedings and motions and not appeals from a judgment of conviction in an unrelated case. The District Attorney's interpretation of the statute would render it unconstitutional.

2. Defendant did not waive his speedy trial rights by consenting to adjournments. While an affidavit by defense counsel alleges that he only consented to adjournments because the prosecution [***3] promised to dismiss the second indictment if the Appellate Division affirmed the homicide, the District Attorney denies it. Defendant's constitutional and statutory rights to a speedy trial are not deemed to have been waived by meaningful consent on "good faith misunderstandings" informally conducted outside of the court record, while he was in State prison.

3. The controversy could have been and should have been avoided. When a defendant has been convicted on one charge and has another pending, the untried case should be put on the calendar at the time of sentence. If the untried indictment cannot be disposed of by plea, the District Attorney should announce his position as to whether he intends to try the undisposed-of case. If he will try the case regardless of the outcome of an appeal, the prosecutor should ask the court for a trial date. If the prosecutor decides he will not prosecute in the event of an affirmance, he should announce his position in open court in the presence of counsel and the defendant. A consent under those (or other) circumstances to an adjournment should be expressed by defendant and his counsel in open court. Finally, the court must acquiesce to [***4] any arrangements which could result in prolonged delays.

 

1251 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York v. Kingsview Homes, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


84 Misc. 2d 756; 376 N.Y.S.2d 813; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3227



November 20, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city brought an action against defendant housing corporation to collect a judgment representing management and supervision fees.


OVERVIEW: The city and the housing corporation entered into an agreement for construction of a housing project. The agreement provided that the housing corporation would pay fees to the city related to the construction stages of the development pursuant to the Redevelopment Companies Law, chapter 845 (1942). Subsequently, the legislature modified the statutes to provide for fees for the audit, regulation, and general supervision of the management of the company pursuant to N.Y. Priv. Hous. Fin. Law § 118. The city brought an action to collect a judgment for the unpaid fees for the period from 1962 to 1975. The court found in favor of the city. The court found that the housing corporation was incorporated pursuant to the terms and provisions of the Redevelopment Companies Law. As such, the court held it was always subject to change in the future by amendment of that law. Therefore, the court held that any amendment to the law, as long as such amendments were reasonable, was binding on the housing corporation. The court found that the portion of the fee arrears prior to October 1966, six years before the service of the summons and complaint, was time-barred by N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 213.


OUTCOME: The court found in favor of the city.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- private housing corporation -- management and supervision fees -- although it was not liable to plaintiff city for management and supervision fees when it was incorporated in 1953 pursuant to Redevelopment Companies Law (L 1942, ch 845), defendant housing corporation is nevertheless liable for such fees under successor statute enacted in 1963 ( Private Housing Finance Law, § 118); defendant in its certificate of incorporation agreed to be bound by Redevelopment Companies Law; therefore, any reasonable amendments to said law continue to be binding on it -- six-year Statute of Limitations ( CPLR 213) is applicable to plaintiff's claim for fee arrears.

1. Defendant is a housing corporation organized in 1953 pursuant to the then Redevelopment Companies Law (L 1942, ch 845). In 1963 the Redevelopment Companies Law was repealed and most of its provisions with some modifications were reenacted as the Private Housing Finance Law. Although the predecessor statute only provided for payment of fees to plaintiff City of New York relating to the construction stages of development (L 1942, ch 845, § 19, as amd), defendant must nonetheless pay fees to plaintiff [***2] city for the "audit, regulation and general supervision of the management of the company" ( Private Housing Finance Law, § 118). Defendant, in its certificate of incorporation, agreed to be bound by "the terms and provisions of the Redevelopment Companies Law". Therefore, any reasonable amendments to the law, now the Private Housing Finance Law, continue to be binding on defendant.

2. Plaintiff's claim for fee arrears prior to October 19, 1966 is time-barred by the six-year Statute of Limitations ( CPLR 213). The six-year and not the three-year Statute of Limitations ( CPLR 214, subd 2) is applicable to the remainder of plaintiff's claim for fee arrears.

 

1252 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Nurenberg v. Ward


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Dutchess County


84 Misc. 2d 80; 375 N.Y.S.2d 785; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3054



November 18, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition is granted and the actions of the respondent in attempting to terminate petitioner's employment are hereby declared to be of no force and effect.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employee brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding seeking a judgment declaring respondent Commissioner of the New York State Department of Correctional Services' action terminating his employment without a hearing deemed illegal.


OVERVIEW: The employee was 72 years old. He claimed that N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 70(c), which provided that the service of any employee over the age of 70 could be terminated at any time by the head of the department in which he was employed upon written notice, was illegal. The court agreed and found the last sentence of § 70(c) unconstitutional. The purpose of § 70(c) was to give a department head absolute authority to dismiss an employee over the age of 70 without the benefit of a hearing as provided in N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 75. It was a deprivation of the employee's constitutional right to property and due process to vest such absolute discretion over his livelihood in the hands of a department head. N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 70(c), as written, authorized summary dismissal from public employment without a hearing or inquiry that was required by due process and was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The petition was granted and the action of the Commissioner in attempting to terminate the employee's employment was declared to be of no force and effect.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- continuance in service after age 70 -- termination without hearing -- petitioner psychiatrist, age 72, was unlawfully dismissed from his position at State correctional facility without hearing; subdivision c of section 70 of Retirement and Social Security Law unconstitutionally gives department head absolute authority to terminate services of employee whose employment is continued after age 70 without benefit of disciplinary proceeding; there is no rational basis to conclude that employees who have reached age 70 will become physically or mentally unfit.

Petitioner psychiatrist, a 72-year-old "permanent" employee at the Fishkill Correctional Facility, was retained in his position until March 31, 1976 based on the prior approval of his department, a medical board's finding that he was physically fit to perform his duties, and the finding by the Civil Service Commission that petitioner's continuance in service past the age of 70 would be advantageous because of his expert knowledge and [***2] special qualifications (Retirement and Social Security Law, § 70, subd c). Respondent, Commissioner of the State Department of Correctional Services, unlawfully terminated petitioner's employment without a hearing pursuant to subdivision c of section 70 of the Retirement and Social Security Law. Said section unconstitutionally gives the head of a department the absolute authority to summarily terminate the services of an employee whose employment is continued after age 70 without the benefit of the disciplinary proceeding provided by section 75 of the Civil Service Law. There is no rational basis to afford a hearing to an employee under age 70 and not those who have reached age 70. Nor is there a rational basis to conclude that all or a substantial number of employees who have reached age 70 will become physically or mentally unfit since the relationship between chronological age and functional age varies greatly from one individual to the next.

 

1253 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Glen Cove Urban Renewal Agency


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


84 Misc. 2d 186; 375 N.Y.S.2d 261; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3102



November 13, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner urban agency sought an application, pursuant to N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law art. 15-A, § 555, to condemn real property owned by respondent landowner. The landowner objected to the application on the grounds that the agency's refusal to take bids on the development project for which condemnation was sought denied him equal protection under the law.


OVERVIEW: The landowner's property was adjacent to a parcel owned by the developer to whom the agency sought to sell the landowner's tract. The landowner asserted that the taking of his property was really for a private purpose to benefit the developer and that the developer would be unjustly enriched at the expense of the landowner. The court disagreed and granted the agency's application to condemn the landowner's property. The court noted first that its review was limited to whether the taking was for a public purpose because the question of the necessity of a taking was strictly a legislative not a judicial determination. Next, the court determined that the agency's purpose of the taking was to redevelop the area for industrial use and that such purpose was a public one. The court noted that the fact that the condemned property was to be sold to a private entity to effectuate the redevelopment did not destroy the public use purpose for which the condemnation was sought. The court also found that the landowner's due process complaint regarding the agency's failure to solicit bids for the project was collateral to the condemnation proceeding and, therefore, not properly before the court.


OUTCOME: The court granted the agency's application to condemn the landowner's parcel for the agency's project to redevelop an urban area for industrial uses.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Eminent domain -- taking for public purpose or use -- equal protection -- since purpose of redevelopment of urban area for industrial uses is clearly public one, and fact that condemned property will be sold to private entity to effectuate redevelopment does not destroy that public use, application by urban renewal agency to condemn subject parcel is granted -- objection on equal protection ground is collateral to issues on application for condemnation, and improperly raised; objection is directed at section 507 of General Municipal Law, and typically validity of statute may only be attacked directly -- proper vehicle for objectant's action is either CPLR article 78 proceeding or declaratory judgment action, or both.

1. The Glen Cove Urban Renewal Agency sought to condemn certain real property owned by the objectant Zausmer along with other land to assemble a tract to be sold to private interests for industrial development. After condemnation, the entire plot is to be sold to a designated private developer. The application to condemn the subject parcel is granted. The proposed use or purpose, redevelopment of an urban area for industrial uses, is clearly a public one and [***2] the fact that the condemned property will be sold to a private entity to effectuate the redevelopment does not destroy the public use.

2. Zausmer's objection to the condemnation on the ground that the authority by its announced intent of selling the property to the developer without giving him (Zausmer) an opportunity to bid for the land and its proposed development denied him equal protection of the law, is collateral to the issues on an application for condemnation, and is improperly raised. This objection is directed at section 507 of the General Municipal Law, and typically the validity of a statute may only be attacked directly, which is particularly true in an eminent domain proceeding.

3. The proper vehicle for Zausmer's action would be either a CPLR article 78 proceeding to review the determination of the common council approving the choice of redevelopers under section 507 (subd 2, par [d]) of the General Municipal Law or a declaratory judgment action seeking to review the method of selection of redevelopers under subdivision 2 of the same statute, or both.

 

1254 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mobil Oil Corp. v. Huntington


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


85 Misc. 2d 800; 380 N.Y.S.2d 466; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3331



November 7, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint is denied but the motion to dismiss specific causes of action is granted to the extent that the first, second, third, fifth, eighth, ninth and tenth causes of action are stricken.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant town brought a motion for summary judgment or dismissal of plaintiff oil corporation's action that sought a declaration that the town's oil spillage ordinance was void and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The town's oil spillage ordinance prohibited the transfer of oil in excess of 600 gallons without a permit. The law also provided for the creation of a fund to be used to prevent and clean up spills. The fund was financed by a fee imposed on fuel transferred by the operators of waterfront terminals in the town. The oil corporation, which operated a waterfront terminal, challenged the validity of the tax. The town sought summary judgment or dismissal of the action. The court dismissed all claims except the contentions that the law was an unlawful revenue producing measure and that it violated the equal protection clause. The court held that: (1) the law was not an undue burden on the commerce clause; (2) to the extent that the law required those engaged in transfer operations to obtain permits upon payment of a fee, the law was a licensing or regulatory measure but the apparent purpose of the transfer charges was the accumulation of revenue; and (3) if the trial court found that the revenue aspects of the law constituted a regulatory measure, it would have to resolve the fact issues relative to the rationality of the basis for the classification in the law.


OUTCOME: The court denied the town's motion for summary judgment to dismiss the oil corporation's complaint challenging the validity of the town's oil spillage law. The court granted the town's motion to dismiss specific causes of action as to all claims except the claims that the law violated the equal protection clause, was an illegally excessive exercise of the police power, and was an improper revenue-raising measure.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- imposition of transfer charges upon oil terminals -- Oil Spillage Ordinance of Town of Huntington (Huntington Town Code, ch 60, § 60-30 et seq.), regulating coastal operations involving transfer of oil, does not impose undue burden upon interstate commerce; spillage law requires plaintiff oil terminal operator to obtain transfer permit with annual fee of $ 100 and further creates $ 100,000 fund to be used to remove oil spills financed by imposition of fee of one mill for every five gallons of fuel transferred by waterfront terminal operators; said law does not constitute prohibited impost on imports and exports and was validly enacted (Municipal Home Rule Law, § 27, subd 2) -- however, plaintiff's action to declare law invalid cannot be dismissed; fact issue exists as to whether transfer charges constitute regulatory or license fee which may be imposed within defendant's police power or whether such charges constitute  [***2] unlawful revenue-raising measure.

1. The Oil Spillage Ordinance of the Town of Huntington (Huntington Town Code, ch 60, § 60-30 et seq.), regulating coastal operations involving transfer of oil, does not impose an undue burden upon interstate commerce, is not inconsistent with the Federal Water Quality Improvement Act (US Code, tit 33, § 1151 et seq.) and does not impermissibly infringe upon Federal admiralty jurisdiction (see Askew v American Waterways Operators, 411 U.S. 325; Portland Pipe Line Corp. v Environmental Improvement Comm., 307 A2d 1 [Me], app dsmd 414 U.S. 1035). A prior motion for summary judgment made by plaintiff oil corporation, which operates a waterfront oil distribution terminal in the town, to declare the law invalid was denied on the ground that a fact issue existed as to whether plaintiff's operation was within the purview of interstate commerce (see Mobil Oil Corp. v Town of Huntington, 72 Misc 2d 530). The oil spillage law prohibits the transfer of liquid fuel or oil in excess of 600 gallons for the purpose of storage or use without a permit issued by the town oil spillage control board. Granting of a transfer permit having an [***3] annual fee of $ 100 is predicated upon the installation of safety equipment. The $ 100,000 fund to be used to prevent spills and to clean up those which do occur is financed by imposition of a fee of one mill for every five gallons of fuel transferred by the operators of the three waterfront terminals in the town. No provision is made for either ascertaining the cause of the spills or requiring the polluter to remove the spill or make restitution for the cost thereof.

2. The spillage law does not constitute a prohibited impost on imports and exports. The transfer charges imposed are not taxes on the imports themselves but on activity relative to their importation. The overall effect of the law is the lawful establishment of a regulatory scheme for controlling oil pollution. The town's authority to enact a law affecting the transfer of oil from vessels upon navigable water to waterfront terminal facilities has not been preempted by the State ( ECL 17-1101). The certificate of the Town Attorney appended to the law is presumptive evidence, unrebutted by plaintiff, that proper proceedings have been had or taken for the enactment of a local law (Municipal Home Rule Law, § 27, subd [***4] 2).

3. Plaintiff's action to declare the spillage law invalid cannot be entirely dismissed. A fact issue remains as to whether the law is an unlawful revenue-raising measure. The $ 100 transfer permit fee is a licensing or regulatory measure which is a proper exercise of the town's police power. However, when the sums collected through a licensing or regulatory measure exceed the cost of administration, it may be deemed a revenue act which may not be imposed without an express delegation of authority from the Legislature. Since the apparent purpose of the transfer charges is the accumulation of revenue to be used to remove oil spills no matter what the source of their creation, defendant town, at the trial, will have the onerous task of going forward with further facts which demonstrate that the fees are regulatory in nature and do not constitute an unauthorized tax levy. In addition, a fact issue exists with respect to whether the classification inherent in the spillage law, applicable to only those terminals in the town, has a rational basis.

 

1255 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Jennerson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County
