84 Misc. 2d 56; 375 N.Y.S.2d 240; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3092



November 1, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the court grants the motion for resentence made pursuant to chapter 783 of the Laws of 1975.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law ch. 783 (1975), renewed his motion to set aside his sentence for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the fifth degree.


OVERVIEW: After a jury trial, the court convicted defendant of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the fifth degree. It imposed a sentence of three to six years imprisonment as a second felony offender. Defendant, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law ch. 783 (1975), filed a renewed motion to set aside the sentence. The court granted the motion. It determined that the conviction should be reduced to criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree, which was a class A misdemeanor, because the statute under which defendant was convicted and sentenced was declared unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to set aside the sentence.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- criminal possession of controlled substance -- since in 1975 Penal Law was amended so that acts for which defendant was convicted of in 1974 for criminal possession of controlled substance in fifth degree, if they had occurred after amendments, would then constitute criminal possession of controlled substance in seventh degree (L 1975, ch 785), defendant's motion for resentence pursuant to chapter 783 of Laws of 1975 is granted; Legislature's failure to provide for resentencing of persons convicted of class C felony based upon aggregate weight, while those convicted of class A felonies can be resentenced, is inadvertent oversight since intent was to impose new weight standards in all methadone cases.

Defendant was convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the fifth degree, based upon his possession of a substance with an aggregate weight of one-eighth ounce and more containing methadone, and sentenced in March of 1974 as a second felony offender. In 1975, the Penal Law was amended so that the acts for which defendant was convicted, if [***2] they had occurred after the amendments, would then constitute criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree (L 1975, ch 785). If the acts had occurred prior to the amendment but defendant had not yet been convicted or sentenced, he still would have the benefit of the ameliorating sentencing provisions (L 1975, ch 786). However, in the case of a defendant already sentenced, the 1975 legislation (L 1975, ch 783) provides only for the resentence of those persons convicted of class A felonies and fails to provide for the resentencing of persons convicted of the class C felony based upon aggregate weight. Thus, if literally applied, a defendant convicted of the C felony solely because he possessed less than one ounce would be ineligible for resentence. Defendant's motion for resentence pursuant to chapter 783 of the Laws of 1975 is granted and he is deemed convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree. The failure to provide for the resentencing of persons convicted of a class C felony based upon aggregate weight is an inadvertent oversight since it was the clear intention of the Legislature to impose the new weight standards [***3] across the boards to all methadone cases.

 

1256 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Campbell v. Barraud


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


85 Misc. 2d 97; 376 N.Y.S.2d 380; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3278



October 29, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff citizens sought a declaratory judgment that the action of defendant town board in granting a change of zone which in part sought to limit residency in the area to persons above the age of 52 was invalid.


OVERVIEW: The court first addressed whether or not the citizens had standing to bring such a suit and found that based on the length of the trial and the quality of the testimony, the court assumed that the citizens had standing to proceed. The court found that with the exception of the age restriction, the citizens had not established the unreasonableness of the ordinance. The court held that as to the age restrictions, N.J. Stat. Ann. § 40:55-30 did not grant municipalities the right to regulate ownership of buildings or types of tenancies, and while there was a need for senior housing in the town, and while social preferences were permissible in a private club, they were not relevant to public health, safety, or welfare. The court held that the affect of the age qualification for residency appeared to be an unconstitutional discrimination.


OUTCOME: The court held that the portion of the ordinance which restricted the age of the occupants was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- zoning -- in view of proximity to land in question, plaintiffs are accorded standing to challenge zoning amendment creating residential zone limited to families of persons over age of 55, although all plaintiffs are over 55 -- rezoning of 96 acres for planned retirement community is not spot zoning, since more than small area is affected -- exclusion of persons under 55 is unconstitutionally discriminatory; while provision of adequate housing for aged is within police power, age of users may not be regulated, since such would allow government discretion to regulate where people live, tending toward stratification of society.

1. In view of their proximity to the land in question, the plaintiffs are accorded standing to challenge the constitutionality of a town zoning amendment creating a planned retirement community limited to residency by persons over the age of 55 and their families, although all of the plaintiffs are over 55.

2. The rezoning of 96 acres for a planned retirement community is not spot zoning, since more than a small area is affected.

3. The exclusion of persons under the age of 55 from the residential area unconstitutionally discriminates [***2] against such persons. While the provision of adequate housing for the aged is within the police power to regulate land use, it is impermissible to regulate the age of the users of the land. Such a restriction would allow discretionary government regulation of where people live, tending toward stratification of society.

 

1257 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


860 Executive Towers, Inc. v. Board of Assessors


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


84 Misc. 2d 12; 374 N.Y.S.2d 284; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3077



October 27, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petitioners' motion is granted to the extent that a hearing must be held to determine the extent of the expenses to which they are entitled. The respondent's requests are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner property owners brought an application for an order requiring respondent tax board to pay the reasonable expenses incurred in making proof of the percentage of full value at which other real property was assessed.


OVERVIEW: The tax board required the property owners to make proof of the percentage of full value at which real property was assessed. The property owners proved the ratio demanded by the tax board, and the property owners brought a petition for an order requiring the tax board to pay the reasonable expenses incurred in making the proof. The court granted the petition, concluding that the property owners were entitled to expenses if they proved the ratio demanded, and that a hearing must be held to determine the extent of the expenses to which they were entitled.


OUTCOME: The petition seeking the tax board to pay reasonable expenses was granted.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- real property taxation -- costs of proof of assessment ratio -- petitioners are entitled to determination of their right to expenses incurred in proving that real property assessment ratio was that which they had demanded that respondent county board of assessors admit and which respondent had denied, since such determination is separate from ultimate resolution of ratio issue by appellate courts and delay would be detrimental to both parties -- petitioners are entitled to costs of their successful proof of demanded ratio (Real Property Tax Law, § 716, subd 2), and provision, that expenses will be paid regardless of such proof unless denial was for good and sufficient reason, does not mean that payment of costs is otherwise discretionary -- statute is reasonably intended to alleviate taxpayer's burden of proving unequal assessment of real property -- magnitude of costs does not sustain position that statute was not intended to apply to municipality which will stipulate  [***2] to its self-established equalization rate or that it unconstitutionally underwrites private litigation and fails to give municipality costs when it is successful -- although magnitude of expenses requires full hearing, extensive disclosure requested is delaying tactic and disclosure only of material and necessary evidence is allowed.

1. Pursuant to subdivision 2 of section 716 of the Real Property Tax Law, petitioners are entitled to a determination of their right to the reasonable expenses incurred in proving that the percentage of full value at which real property in the county was assessed was the ratio that petitioners had demanded that the respondent county board of assessors admit and which respondent had denied. The determination of costs should not await an ultimate resolution of the ratio issue by the appellate courts, since the application for costs is a separate, reviewable proceeding, and further delay would be detrimental to both parties.

2. Petitioners are entitled to expenses, since they were successful in proving the accuracy of the ratio which they had demanded that respondent admit, as provided by the Real Property Tax Law, and the provision of the statute,  [***3] that expenses will be paid regardless of such proof unless respondent's denial was for a good and sufficient reason, does not mean that payment of costs is otherwise discretionary.

3. The payment of costs under the statute is not unreasonable, but is intended to alleviate the burden on taxpayers of proving the unequal assessment of their property.

4. Respondent's objection, based upon the magnitude of the costs, is not sufficient to sustain the position that the statute was not intended to apply to a municipality which will stipulate to its self-established equalization rate, or that the statute is unconstitutional because it publicly underwrites private litigation and does not give the municipality the right to costs when it is successful.

5. Although the magnitude of the expenses requires a full hearing, the respondents should not have the extensive disclosure requested of the documents, time records and diaries of 18 individual attorneys, experts and their firms, since the request constitutes a delaying tactic and disclosure only of material and necessary evidence is allowed.

 

1258 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rautine v. Preston


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Chemung County


84 Misc. 2d 156; 374 N.Y.S.2d 280; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3071



October 24, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is granted and the defendants are ordered to disclose their liability policy coverage and the content of their insurance to the plaintiffs within three days following service of the order herein, with notice of entry.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3101(f), plaintiff claimants sought an order directing defendant insureds to divulge the liability insurance coverage available to satisfy part or all of any judgment which might have been entered. The insureds objected on the grounds that such disclosure was premature and would be prejudice settlement negotiations and that the statute was unconstitutional in that it called for disclosure of confidential information.


OVERVIEW: The insureds objected to the claimants' demand to disclose their liability insurance coverage on the grounds that pretrial proceedings had not been completed, but the court held that parties who permitted the contingent filing of notes of issue did so at their own risk. In addressing the insureds' argument that N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3101(f) did not speak in terms of any corporate entity issuing the insurance, the court found the argument contrary to N.Y. Gen. Constr. Law § 37, which provided that the term "person" included a corporation. Further, disclosure of the insurance policy limits was not likely to lead to amendment of the complaint's ad damnum clause because such amendment could only be granted where the claimants showed that the damages they suffered, which were previously unknown, supported an increased demand. The court held that the likelihood of settlement was greater if the policy limits were disclosed prior to the trial, and that Rule 3101(f) was not unconstitutional because there was no confidential relationship recognized by law between an insured and his carrier. The court, therefore, granted the claimants' motion to disclose the insureds' liability policy coverage.


OUTCOME: The court granted the claimants' motion and ordered the insureds to disclose their liability policy coverage and the content of their insurance to the claimants within three days following service of the order.


HEADNOTES

Discovery and inspection -- disclosure of liability insurance coverage -- defendants must disclose their liability insurance coverage and content of their insurance to plaintiffs ( CPLR 3101, subd [f]; L 1975, ch 668, § 1, eff Aug 6, 1975); fact that pretrial proceedings have not been completed is not valid reason for denial of discovery -- corporate entity issuing insurance is required to make disclosure -- disclosure of insurance policy limits will not lead to amendment of ad damnum clause -- it is intention of Legislature that settlement negotiations be conducted with full knowledge of amount of insurance coverage available -- terms of insurance contract are not confidential.

1. Defendants must, pursuant to CPLR 3101 (subd [f]; L 1975, ch 668, § 1, eff Aug 6, 1975), disclose their liability insurance coverage and the content of their insurance to plaintiffs. The fact that pretrial proceedings including physical examinations have not been [***2] completed is not a valid reason for a denial of discovery. The case is on the trial calendar. After a note of issue has been served, unless a motion is made within 20 days thereafter to have the case removed from the calendar on the grounds that the filing of the note of issue is premature, there is no subsequent right to a removal.

2. A corporate entity issuing an insurance agreement is required to make disclosure. The statute requires any "person carrying on an insurance business" to make disclosure. Under section 37 of the General Construction Law, the term "person" includes a corporation.

3. Disclosure of the insurance policy limits will not lead to amendment of the ad damnum clause in the complaint. The fact that there may be more money available to pay a judgment than previously expected is not grounds for amending the demand.

4. Disclosure of the policy limits would not be prejudicial to settlement negotiations. It is the intention of the Legislature that settlement negotiations be conducted with full knowledge of the amount of insurance coverage available. The likelihood of settlement of the action is greater if the policy limits are disclosed prior to the trial.

 [***3] 5. The terms of an insurance contract are not confidential. There is no confidential relationship between an insured and his carrier. Public policy would not support such confidentiality where the disclosure of policy coverage might lead to a disposal of litigation.

 

1259 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Shapiro v. Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


84 Misc. 2d 938; 376 N.Y.S.2d 365; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3221



October 23, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petitioner's motion to quash is denied. The alternative relief requested in the application is granted to the extent of modifying the subpoenas as herein indicated.

Settle order on notice, including proposed modified subpoena and plan for the orderly production of the documents.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A subpoena duces tecum was issued by a special prosecutor for nursing homes. The subpoena duces tecum was served upon respondent bank and required the production of petitioner depositor's bank records. The depositor, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 2304, filed a motion for an order to quash the subpoena duces tecum, or in the alternative, to limit the scope of the subpoena duces tecum.


OVERVIEW: The depositor claimed that the subpoena duces tecum violated his constitutional rights under the First, Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution. The court held that the depositor did have standing to challenge the subpoena duces tecum because the depositor was the party in interest and had a limited expectation of privacy in his bank records and the court should have provided a forum for depositors to challenge third-party process on constitutional grounds. The court determined that a showing of probable cause was not essential as long as valid legal process had been issued. The court held that the subpoena duces tecum was far too sweeping in its scope. The court determined that only the records that were directly relevant to the inquiry were available to the grand jury. Finally, the court held that there was no Fifth Amendment violation because the Fifth Amendment privilege adhered to the person and not to the documents, and there was no First Amendment violation because the government interest in obtaining all relevant testimony before the grand jury outweighed the depositor's reliance on his First Amendment rights.


OUTCOME: The court denied the depositor's motion to quash but modified the scope of the subpoena duces tecum.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- subpoena duces tecum -- Special Prosecutor for Nursing Homes -- petitioner, target of criminal investigation of nursing home industry, has standing under CPLR 2304 to contest validity of subpoena duces tecum issued by Special Prosecutor for Nursing Homes requiring respondent bank to produce all records relating to petitioner's business account; subpoena is not quashed since Special Prosecutor is authorized to issue such process on behalf of Grand Jury (Executive Law, § 63, subd 3); however subpoena is modified so as to limit its application only to production of those bank records which reflect transactions with nursing homes, related businesses or individuals -- petitioner's personal and business records in hands of bank are not protected under Fifth Amendment's privilege against self incrimination -- petitioner is not entitled to transactional immunity ( CPL 190.40, subd 2) with respect  [***2] to evidence revealed by records produced under subpoena -- compliance with Grand Jury subpoena would not have chilling effect upon petitioner's First Amendment rights to freedom of religious, political and personal associations.

1. Petitioner, a target of a criminal investigation of the nursing home industry, as the real party interest, has standing under CPLR 2304 to contest the validity of a subpoena duces tecum properly issued by the Special Prosecutor for Nursing Homes and served upon respondent bank requiring production of all records relating to petitioner's business account, which he operates as a sole proprietorship, "including but not limited to signature cards, corporate resolutions if any, monthly statements, deposit slips, reproduced checks, loan applications, debit and credit memos." Petitioner, as a depositor, has a limited expectation of privacy in the information he discloses to his bank as a result of transacting business in his account. Courts should provide a forum for depositors to challenge third-party process on constitutional grounds. Banks cannot be expected to resist a subpoena by placing themselves in contempt, and compliance by the third-party bank [***3] would clearly frustrate any judicial determination of the issue.

2. Petitioner's motion to quash the subpoena is denied since the Special Prosecutor is authorized under subdivision 3 of section 63 of the Executive Law to issue process on behalf of the New York County Grand Jury presently investigating Medicaid fraud and abuses. A valid Grand Jury subpoena is the proper means by which the government may obtain access to bank records of petitioner's account. A showing of probable cause is not essential as long as valid legal process has been issued. However, the subpoena is modified so as to limit its application only to the production of those records which reflect transactions with nursing homes, related businesses or individuals. The Special Prosecutor is unauthorized to open a full-scale investigation of the personal affairs of anyone who has ever dealt with a nursing home in this State.

3. Petitioner's personal and business records in the hands of his bank are not protected under the Fifth Amendment's privilege against self incrimination. It is the bank, not petitioner, which is the party compelled by subpoena. There is no special circumstance between petitioner and his [***4] bank which would be protected by the Fifth Amendment.

4. Petitioner is not entitled to transactional immunity under CPL 190.40 (subd 2) with respect to the evidence revealed by the records produced under the subpoena. Petitioner, while a target, is not a "witness" before the Grand Jury, nor is he giving any evidence for which immunity may be conferred.

5. Compliance with the Grand Jury subpoena would not have a chilling effect upon petitioner's First Amendment rights to freedom of religious, political and personal associations. The subpoena is limited to only those items involving transactions with nursing homes and related businesses. Invasion of areas protected by the First Amendment is therefore unlikely. The paramount government interest in obtaining all relevant testimony before the Grand Jury outweighs petitioner's reliance on First Amendment rights.

 

1260 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lawson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


84 Misc. 2d 24; 374 N.Y.S.2d 270; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3081



October 22, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss the indictment is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted for the Class A felony of criminal sale of a dangerous drug in the first degree, and filed a motion to inspect and dismiss for legal insufficiency.


OVERVIEW: The only witness before the grand jury was an undercover police officer who testified to one conversation with defendant, 11 months earlier, during which defendant allegedly offered and agreed to sell heroin to the officer. The officer testified, without elaboration, that the actual sale did not occur and he never saw defendant again. The question was whether that evidence of a naked offer or agreement was sufficient to hold defendant upon an indictment charging sale. The court noted that if a mere offer was sufficient to bring a defendant within the definition of "sale," then there would be no need to prove the nature of the substance transferred. Indeed, if the mere offer was sufficient to establish sale, then the introduction of drugs in evidence together with identifying testimony could be dispensed with in every case where a transfer was preceded by negotiation and agreement. The court, therefore, held that where the gravamen of the offense was an offer or agreement, the people were required to establish a specific intent to transfer the drug which was the subject of such offer or agreement. The slight evidence was legally insufficient to support the indictment.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sale of dangerous drug -- although statutes then in force when defendant was indicted for criminal sale of dangerous drug (Penal Law, § 220.00, subd 5; § 220.44), seem on their face to proscribe mere knowing utterance of words constituting offer or agreement, evidence of naked offer or agreement is insufficient to hold defendant -- since Grand Jury testimony was inconclusive and there was absence of any showing of conduct by defendant which would indicate ability or attempt to obtain and deliver drugs, slight evidence is legally insufficient to support indictment -- indictment could also be dismissed because of defect in Grand Jury proceedings arising from failure to instruct Grand Jury that specific intent was required.

1. Before the Grand Jury, the only witness was an undercover police officer who testified to a single conversation with defendant, 11 months earlier, during which defendant allegedly offered and agreed to sell heroin to the officer. The officer also stated that the actual sale did not occur and that he never saw defendant after the conversation. Thereafter, defendant was indicted for the Class [***2] A felony of criminal sale of a dangerous drug in the first degree. Although the statutes then in force (Penal Law, § 220.00, subd 5; § 220.44) seem on their face to proscribe the mere knowing utterance of words constituting an offer or agreement, evidence of a naked offer or agreement is insufficient to hold defendant upon an indictment charging sale. Where the gravamen of the offense is an offer or agreement, the People must establish a specific intent to transfer the drug which is the subject of such offer or agreement. However, there are some factual situations where the People may establish intent without being able to point to any identifiable substance as the subject of the offer or agreement.

2. In the context of the officer's inconclusive testimony and the absence of any showing of other conduct by the defendant which would indicate an ability or attempt to obtain and deliver the drugs, the slight evidence is legally insufficient to support the indictment. Accordingly, the indictment is dismissed.

3. The indictment could also be dismissed because of a defect in the Grand Jury proceedings arising from the failure to instruct the Grand Jury that specific intent was required.  [***3] The necessity for the grand jurors to find reasonable grounds to believe the defendant intended to consummate the sale was not apparent from a mere reading of the definition of sell and the statutory language of the substantive offense.

 

1261 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Q.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Bronx County


83 Misc. 2d 945; 373 N.Y.S.2d 993; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3020



October 21, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner municipal corporate counsel, on behalf of an alleged victim, charged that respondent juvenile committed acts that would have constituted, if they had been committed by an adult, first degree rape. The matter was before the court to determine the proper application of the 1975 amendments to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act §§ 747, 748 pertaining to pretrial detention of juveniles charged with serious delinquencies.


OVERVIEW: In a delinquency proceeding, petitioner sought respondent's pretrial detention for 14 days on the basis of alleged acts constituting first degree rape, N.Y. Penal Law § 130.35, a Class A felony. The court held that the probable cause hearing was conducted within the period permitted by the 1975 amendments to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act §§ 747, 748. Probable cause to believe in respondent's guilt was established under the standards controlling a criminal court preliminary hearing on a felony complaint. Good cause for postponement of the trial was shown, in that petitioner had been unable to comply with respondent's request for the minutes of the alleged victim's testimony for use at trial. The victim's testimony at the probable cause hearing was deemed to be her testimony for trial purposes, with an opportunity for additional direct testimony and for respondent to cross-examine her de novo. The rules of evidence applicable in a fact-finding governed in the probable cause hearing, respondent's rights were not violated by the procedure used at the probable cause hearing, and the judge who presided over the probable cause hearing was not disqualified from conducting the trial on the merits.


OUTCOME: The court held that, at respondent's probable cause hearing, the amended statutory provisions pertaining to pretrial detention of juveniles charged with serious delinquencies were properly applied, good cause was established by petitioner for respondent's detention beyond the three-day period, and the procedure used at the probable cause hearing did not violate respondent's constitutional rights.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Infants -- juvenile delinquents -- pretrial detention -- respondent juvenile, 15 years old, charged with rape, may properly be detained for 14 days prior to trial since "probable cause exists to believe that he is juvenile delinquent" (Family Ct Act, § 747, as amd by L 1975, ch 837); under section 747, "fact-finding hearing to determine whether respondent committed act which would be class A, B or C felony if committed by adult, may commence no later than 14 days after filing of petition"; probable cause hearing must be held three days after filing of petition; said three-day period was properly extended additional three days upon showing of "special circumstances" (Family Ct Act, § 739, subd [b], par [ii], as amd by L 1975, ch 837) -- testimony of petitioner victim at probable cause hearing is properly deemed to be her testimony for fact-finding hearing; fact-finding and probable cause hearings may properly be combined.

1. Respondent juvenile, 15 years old, charged with raping petitioner, a crime which, if committed by an adult, would constitute a Class A felony (Penal Law, § 130.35), may properly be detained for 14 days prior to trial (Family Ct Act, § 747, as amd [***2] by L 1975, ch 837) since "probable cause exists to believe that he is a juvenile delinquent" (Family Ct Act, § 739, subd [b], as amd by L 1975, ch 837). Under section 747, a "fact-finding hearing to determine whether respondent committed an act which would be a class A, B or C felony if committed by an adult, may commence no later than fourteen days after the filing of the petition." In the probable cause hearing required under the 1975 amendments to the Family Court Act for a 14-day detention, "the evidentiary standards applicable to a hearing on a felony complaint in a criminal court" govern (Family Ct Act, § 739, subd [b], par [i], as amd by L 1975, ch 837). The probable cause hearing must be held three days after the filing of the petition. This three-day period was properly extended an additional three days upon a showing of "special circumstances" (Family Ct Act, § 739, subd [b], par [ii], as amd by L 1975, ch 837). The Corporation Counsel had been unable, despite timely and diligent efforts, to comply with respondent's request for trial. Absent good cause for petitioner's delay in commencing trial, respondent would suffer an arbitrary deprivation of liberty,  [***3] in violation of the due process guarantee and a denial of equal protection as compared to other respondents.

2. The testimony of petitioner at the probable cause hearing, which lasted over two hours and was the only testimony offered, is properly deemed to be her testimony for the fact-finding hearing, with an opportunity for her additional direct testimony and for respondent's attorney to cross-examine her de novo. The fact-finding and probable cause hearings may properly be combined (see People ex rel. Guggenheim v Mucci, 32 NY2d 307). Respondent has no right to a repetition of petitioner's testimony. Respondent was in no way prejudiced. The rules of evidence applicable in a fact-finding, where only nonhearsay evidence is admissible ( CPL 180.60, subd 8), governed in the probable cause hearing.

 

1262 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Juan R v. Necta V


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Kings County


84 Misc. 2d 580; 374 N.Y.S.2d 541; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3180



October 21, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the unadjudicated father, brought a petition for visitation of the minor children. Respondent natural mother opposed the petition on the ground that visitation could only be awarded to a father in a paternity proceedings under article 5 of the Family Court Act and that such proceeding could only be commenced by the natural mother. The mother also argued that a writ of habeas corpus was required to obtain visitation.


OVERVIEW: The putative unadjudicated father of the minor children brought a proceeding for visitation. The natural mother opposed the petition. The parties were never married. The father was listed on the birth certificates of both children as their father. The mother contended that the father should have been nonsuited as being without remedy in the court. The mother argued that visitation could only be awarded to a putative father in paternity proceedings under article 5 of the Family Act, proceedings which the statute provided could only be commenced by the natural mother against a putative father and not vice versa. The mother further claimed that, even if custody was awardable in proceedings brought by a putative father against a natural mother by writ of habeas corpus, the father was entitled to bring such proceedings only in the supreme court. The court held that it could act upon and entertain a petition solely seeking visitation. The court concluded that, even without legislative enactment, the right to adjudicate and award custody must certainly include the right to independently adjudicate visitation without the pendency of a prime proceeding for custody.


OUTCOME: The court held that it could entertain and act upon the unadjudicated father's petition solely seeking visitation.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Family Court -- Family Court may entertain petition by putative father solely for visitation rights under subdivision (b) of section 651 of Family Court Act, since grant of power to award weightier relief of custody includes lesser remedy of visitation -- grant to Family Court of powers of Supreme Court in addition to its own power does not confer greater power upon Family Court than that possessed by Supreme Court, since Supreme Court automatically has all powers of Family Court.

1. Pursuant to subdivision (b) of section 651 of the Family Court Act, the Family Court may entertain a petition by a putative father seeking solely visitation rights, thus avoiding a declaration of unconstitutionality of article 5 of the Family Court Act for failure to accord to putative fathers standing equivalent to natural mothers to initiate paternity proceedings and avoiding a judicial reading into such article of that right, since the availability under section 651 of the weightier relief of custody permits the lesser remedy of visitation. Applying the first Talmudic principle of construction, from which principle the common-law rules of construction were in major part derived, the [***2] applicability of a principle of law to a major category requires applicability to every minor category included therein.

2. The grant to the Family Court of "the same powers possessed by the supreme court in addition to its own powers" with respect to custody (Family Ct Act, § 651, subd [b]) does not confer a greater power upon the Family Court to grant primary relief for visitation under section 549 of the Family Court Act upon a petition and order to show cause than that possessed by the Supreme Court in a proceeding upon a writ of habeas corpus, since the Supreme Court automatically has all the powers of the Family Court and a grant of substantive power to the Family Court, absent the adjective tool of habeas corpus, would be meaningless.

 

1263 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Brant


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Erie County


83 Misc. 2d 888; 373 N.Y.S.2d 991; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3008



October 16, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all of the reasons above stated, the court respectfully denies the disclosure of presentence or memoranda or any part thereof and does not feel that it should be required.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for the disclosure of a presentence report, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 390.50 (1975).


OVERVIEW: The court was asked to furnish defendant's attorney with a presentence report. The court denied the request on the ground that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 390.50 (1975), permitting such disclosure, was unconstitutional and unwarranted. The court stated that this was not a constitutional right, liberty, or guarantee afforded a defendant in a criminal proceeding. The court reasoned that the presumption of innocence had long been since removed. Defendant had either been found guilty or had pleaded guilty. The court had asked for a probation department report, which was something that has always been confidential and sacrosanct t the court in making proper disposition on sentence of a defendant. That the confidentiality of the report was always regarded very highly was reflected in case law and N.Y. Code of Crim. Proc. § 931(2). The court concluded that defendant was not entitled to be given information that had no bearing on his innocence or guilt, but was a confidential matter belonging to the court alone.


OUTCOME: The court denied the disclosure of the presentence report.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- disclosure of presentence report -- defendant is not entitled to disclosure of presentence report; CPL 390.50 (subd 2) which mandates such disclosure is unconstitutional; defendant is not entitled to be given information that has no bearing on his innocence or guilt but is confidential matter belonging to court alone.

Defendant is not entitled to the disclosure of a presentence report. CPL 390.50 (subd 2) (L 1975, ch 310, eff Sept. 1, 1975) which provides that the "presentence report or memorandum shall be made available by the court for examination by the defendant's attorney, or the defendant himself", is unconstitutional and unwarranted. The disclosure of a presentence report is not a constitutional right, liberty or guarantee which is afforded to a defendant in a criminal proceeding. Defendant has already been convicted. A probation department report is something that has always been confidential and sacrosanct to the court in making proper disposition on sentence of a defendant.  [***2] Defendant is not entitled to be given information that has no bearing on his innocence or guilt but is a confidential matter belonging to the court alone.

 

1264 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rawlins v. McCaughey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Livingston County


83 Misc. 2d 986; 373 N.Y.S.2d 816; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3026



October 15, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The relief sought by the petitioners is granted and the respondents are prohibited from conducting an election on November 4, 1975 for the vacancy now existing in the office of Judge of the Livingston County Court, and the respondents are further ordered and directed that the election for such vacancy be held in accordance with the law no earlier than the Tuesday after the first Monday of November, 1976.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners commenced an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 in order to prohibit respondents, the County Clerk of Livingston County, and state election officials, from conducting an election on November 4, 1975, in order to fill a vacancy that was left by the resignation of a county judge, and an order directing that an election for the position be held no earlier than the Tuesday after the first Monday of November 1976.


OVERVIEW: A judge submitted his resignation to the Secretary of State on August 4, 1975, effective on that date. The following day, the Secretary received and filed the letter of resignation. Eight days later, and pursuant to N.Y. Elec. Law § 67, the Clerk certified to the board of elections that there was vacancy in the office of the county judge by reason of the judge's resignation. In their Article 78 proceeding, petitioners requested an order to prohibit respondents from conducting an election on the fourth day of November for the vacancy and requested that the election be held no earlier than Tuesday after the first Monday of November 1976. The court granted the petitioners their requested relief. The court did hold that the Clerk's certification was legally and properly made in substantial compliance with N.Y. Elec. Law § 67. However, the court held that the resignation became effective on the date that it was filed and delivered to the Secretary, which was the fifth of August, and thus there was no vacancy in the judge's office existing not less than three months before the general election of November 4, 1975 to be filled under the N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 21(a).


OUTCOME: The court granted the relief that was sought by petitioners.


HEADNOTES

Judges -- vacancy in judicial office -- in letter dated August 4, 1975, and received and filed by Secretary of State on August 5, 1975, incumbent County Judge stated that he resigned effective August 4, 1975 -- County Clerk promptly certified to Board of Elections that vacancy existed in that office which should be voted upon at 1975 general election -- petition for order prohibiting holding of election for that office until 1976 general election is granted -- under State Constitution, vacancy in such office "shall be filled for a full term at the next general election held not less than three months after such vacancy occurs", and, here, resignation which caused vacancy to occur did not become effective until August 5, 1975 -- section 31 of Public Officers Law, providing  [***2] that, if effective date is specified in resignation, it shall take effect upon date specified, must be read to mean specified effective date subsequent to delivery or filing of resignation -- section 67 of Election Law, requiring County Clerk to certify to Board of Elections, at least three months before general election, each officer to be voted for at that election, is directory and ministerial only, and literal compliance therewith is not required when measured against constitutional mandate.

1. In a letter dated August 4, 1975 and addressed to the Secretary of State, the incumbent Livingston County Judge stated that "I * * * hereby resign * * * effective today, August 4, 1975". On August 5, 1975, the letter was received and filed by the Secretary of State, who then informed the County Clerk of the resignation. She promptly certified to the Board of Elections that a vacancy existed in that judicial office and that such office should be voted on at the general election to be held November 4, 1975. A petition for an order prohibiting the holding of an election for that office until the 1976 general election is granted. Under the State Constitution (art VI, § 21, subd a),  [***3] a vacancy in such an office "shall be filled for a full term at the next general election held not less than three months after such vacancy occurs", and, here, the resignation which caused the vacancy to occur did not become effective until August 5, 1975, the date it was filed and delivered to the Secretary of State.

2. Section 31 of the Public Officers Law provides that, "If an effective date is specified in such resignation, it shall take effect upon the date specified", and, if that wording were taken alone, it would appear that the Judge's resignation took effect on August 4, the date he specified, and that his office was, therefore, vacated on that date. However, considering the section as it read before 1953 amendments thereto, material in the bill jacket which accompanied the 1953 amendments, indicating that those amendments were designed to enable a public officer to resign prospectively, and the language of other provisions of the section, the above-quoted provision must be read to mean a specified effective date which is subsequent to the delivery or filing of the resignation.

3. Section 67 of the Election Law, which requires a County Clerk to certify to the Board of [***4] Elections, at least three months before a general election, each county, city, village or town officer to be voted for at that election, is directory and ministerial only, having as its purpose the giving of sufficient time to the board for preparation of ballots and voting machinery, and literal compliance therewith is not required when measured against the constitutional mandate that a vacancy in the office of County Judge be filled at the next general election held not less than three months after such vacancy occurs.

 

1265 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Wein v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


84 Misc. 2d 453; 375 N.Y.S.2d 509; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3149



October 15, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff brought an action against defendant, the State of New York, in order to have declared unconstitutional provisions of the Emergency Act of 1975, specifically 1975 N.Y. Laws 868, §§22, 23, as amended by 1975 N.Y. Laws 870, as being in violation of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 8. The State moved to dismiss the complaint, or, in the alternative, for summary judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3212 declaring the provisions constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The state legislature adopted provisions of the Emergency Act of 1975 (Act), specifically 1975 N.Y. Laws 868, §§22, 23, as amended by 1975 N.Y. Laws 870, which authorized appropriations as an advance to the City of New York for city purposes. Plaintiff filed a complaint complained that those provisions violated the N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 8, which provided that the credit of the state shall not be given or loaned to or in aid of any individual, or public or private corporation. The State moved to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action, or, in the alternative, for summary judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3212 to declare that the provisions were constitutional and valid. The court held that the provisions were constitutional and valid. The court held that the provisions of the Act did not involve a gift or loan of credit of the State, nor did the State undertake to guarantee obligations of the City. Further, the court stated that moneys expended by the State to meet the emergency situations involving the welfare of its citizens did not constitute a dissipation of the State's credit; rather, those moneys were applied essentially for the State's own purposes.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion of the State for summary judgment declaring the provisions of the Emergency Act of 1975 to be constitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- New York City financial emergency -- provisions of statute which appropriated 750 million dollars to be taken from local assistance fund as advance to City of New York to counter its financial emergency (L 1975, ch 868, §§ 22, 23, as amd by L 1975, ch 870), are constitutional and valid; use of short-term borrowing against revenues to obtain funds for transfer involved gift or loan of money, not State's credit, therefore section 8 of article VII of State Constitution not violated -- amelioration of State financial difficulties is proper State purpose which justifies State in borrowing money to meet what Legislature regards as State emergency.

1. To counter New York City's financial emergency, an Extraordinary Session of the Legislature appropriated 750 million dollars to be taken "in the first instance from the local assistance fund" as an advance to the City of New York, for its city purposes. (L 1975, ch 868, §§ 22, 23, as amd by L 1975, ch 870.) At the same time the State entered into a program of short-term borrowing to pay portions of the appropriations. The Laws of 1975 (ch 868, §§ 22, 23, as amd by L 1975, ch 870) are constitutional and valid.  [***2] Although section 8 of article VII of the State Constitution provides that the credit of the State shall not "be given or loaned to or in aid of any individual, or public or private corporation", a clear distinction is made between gifts or loans of "money" to a public corporation, which are authorized, and gifts or loans of "credit" which are prohibited. The use of short-term borrowing against revenues to obtain funds for transfer to the city involved a gift or loan of money and not of the credit of the State. To hold otherwise would endanger all of the State's short-term borrowing, notwithstanding the specific authorizations of section 9 of article VII.

2. In enacting the emergency legislation, the Legislature expressly articulated facts which it regarded as establishing a situation of financial emergency both in the city and the State inasmuch as default "would effectively force the city to stop operating as a viable governmental entity and create a clear and present danger to the health, safety and welfare of its inhabitants" (L 1975, ch 868, § 1). The amelioration of a State financial crisis arising from the city's financial difficulties is a proper State purpose which justifies [***3] the State in borrowing money to meet what the Legislature regards as a State emergency.

 

1266 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Siegel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Erie County


83 Misc. 2d 1062; 373 N.Y.S.2d 812; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3044



October 14, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner executor brought an action for the original probate of the last will and testament of her decedent, who was a Florida domiciliary. The last will and testament had been admitted to probate in Florida, but one of the nominated trustees under the will was not able to qualify as an executor or trustee in that proceeding because it was a New York corporation.


OVERVIEW: In considering the petition for probate, the court noted that the executor had made a diligent search for but was unable to discover whether any creditors or persons claiming to be the decedent's creditors were New York domiciliaries. She had also satisfied the court of her familiarity with the financial affairs of the decedent and of her investigation. The court, noting the Florida probate of the will, ruled that after a probate in another state, N.Y. Surr. Ct. Proc. Act Law § 1605 permitted the original probate of a will in New York only under exceptional circumstances. The court ruled that in accordance with N.Y. Surr. Ct. Proc. Act Law § 1605(2)(c), Florida's discrimination against the New York corporation and the refusal to allow it to qualify as an executor or trustee in Florida constituted an exceptional circumstance. The original probate in New York was thus permissible.


OUTCOME: The court admitted the decedent's last will and testament to probate, and it issued letters of trusteeship to the executor and the New York corporation as nominated trustees under the will.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Wills -- probate -- fiduciaries -- application for original probate of will of nondomiciliary granted where will had been admitted to probate in decedent's domicile but domicile discriminates against appointment of domiciliary of New York as fiduciary.

An application for the original probate of the last will and testament of a nondomiciliary where such will has been admitted to probate in the decedent's domicile is granted where the law of the decedent's domicile, in effect, discriminates against the appointment of a domiciliary of New York as fiduciary (cf. SCPA 1605, subd 2, par [c]), in that, under such law, the nominated trustee, a New York banking corporation, could not qualify as executor or trustee.

 

1267 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Montoroula v. Parry


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


83 Misc. 2d 1034; 373 N.Y.S.2d 980; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3037



October 8, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner father filed an application for financial assistance for medical treatment being rendered to his disabled child at a private psychiatric institution.


OVERVIEW: The father is the parent and guardian ad litem of a 24-year old child, who although never judicially declared incompetent, was receiving in-patient care at a private psychiatric hospital. The local agency denied the father's application for financial assistance for the private medical treatment for his son. After a hearing, respondent Commissioner of Orange County Social Services (commissioner) affirmed the denial. The father filed the instant N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding questioning the constitutionality of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 360.21(e), and the statute upon which § 360.21 was based, N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 365(2). Section 360.21 provided that medical assistance was only available to persons under the age of 21, or age 65 and over. The court held that the age classification contained in § 360.21 and § 365(2) were unconstitutional. There was an invidious discrimination written into N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 365(2) because of its classification based on age and type of illness. The age classification denied the father's son the right to equal protection of the law. The commissioner could offer no rational basis for the arbitrary classification.


OUTCOME: The court held that the age classification and type of illness classification contained in New York's Social Services Law were unconstitutional. The court remitted the matter to the Commissioner of Social Services for further consideration.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Social services -- medical assistance -- mentally disabled persons -- section 365 (subd 2) of Social Services Law and implementing regulation ( 18 NYCRR 360.21 [e]) unconstitutionally restrict medical assistance for mentally disabled persons in need of in-patient care to those who are under 21 or 65 years of age or over -- there is no rational basis for denying it to those between ages of 21 and 64 -- there is also discriminatory classification, based on type of illness and without rational basis, in scheme of medical assistance program, under which physically disabled person who has been receiving medical assistance as inpatient will continue to be eligible therefor regardless of age, while assistance for mentally disabled person in need of in-patient care will be terminated at age 21 or 22 -- Federal legislation dictates nothing other than minimum standards for States to be eligible to receive Federal funds -- even assuming it approved alleged infringement of constitutional rights, it is responsive State legislation which must be scrutinized.

1. Section 365 (subd 2) of the Social Services Law and its implementing regulation ( 18 NYCRR 360.21 [e]) unconstitutionally restrict [***2] medical assistance for mentally disabled persons in need of inpatient care to those who are under 21 or 65 years of age or over. There is no rational basis for denying it to those between the ages of 21 and 64.

2. There is also a discriminatory classification, based on type of illness and without rational basis, in the scheme of the medical assistance program, under which a physically disabled person who has been receiving medical assistance as an inpatient will apparently continue to be eligible for such assistance regardless of his age, while assistance for a mentally disabled person in need of inpatient care will automatically be terminated at age 21 or 22 in some circumstances.

3. Federal legislation providing for reimbursement only for in-patient psychiatric care rendered to those under 21 and 65 or over dictates nothing other than minimum standards for States to be eligible to receive Federal funds, and there is no merit to an argument that a county need not allocate funds for which it will not be reimbursed. Even assuming the Federal legislation approved an alleged infringement of constitutional rights, it is the responsive State legislation which must be scrutinized.

 

1268 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Manieri


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Fulton County


83 Misc. 2d 798; 373 N.Y.S.2d 504; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2985



October 6, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for an order to suppress evidence seized on the grounds that the evidence was obtained as the result of an illegal search and seizure and in violation of the constitutional rights of defendant.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the entry of the police officer was an illegal invasion of the private room of defendant and an unconstitutional invasion of his privacy. The court found that the officer, in the guise of a porter, was invited by defendant into his hospital room for the purpose of permitting the officer, as a porter, to perform the necessary duties thereof. The officer, although unknown by defendant as such, but in the same manner as anyone else authorized and required to enter the room, might have accepted the invitation to enter for the very purposes contemplated by defendant. This did not constitute a breach of privacy nor did the pretense result in breach of privacy. During his visits to defendant's room, the officer neither saw nor heard anything other than what defendant exposed to him nor did the officer engage in any general search. The court held that any statements, acts, or conducts, which one exposed to the "plain view" of outsiders, were not protected because defendant did not exhibit any intention to keep them to himself. The officer did not violate defendant's constitutional right or privilege. The court denied the motion to suppress the seized evidence.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for an order to suppress evidence seized by the officer.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Searches and seizures -- seizure of gambling records in private hospital room -- defendant's taking of bets and recording them in his private hospital room, conducted in presence of police undercover officer legally on premises while disguised as hospital porter, constituted commission of crime in officer's presence, warranting him to immediately place defendant under arrest and to seize contraband on premises as incident to arrest.

Acting on information that defendant was carrying on illegal bookmaking and gambling activities in his private hospital room, an undercover State Police officer was assigned to the hospital with the consent of the hospital authorities and was given hospital duty as a porter. While in the room and in the presence of the defendant, the officer overheard the defendant taking bets over the phone and observed him making notes on slips of paper. The officer revealed his true identity, placed defendant under arrest and seized the gambling records. Upon a motion to suppress the evidence seized on grounds that it was obtained as a result of an illegal search and seizure, the motion is denied. The taking of bets and recording them, conducted in the presence [***2] of an officer legally on the premises, constituted the commission of a crime in his presence, warranting him to immediately place the defendant under arrest and to seize contraband on the premises as an incident to the arrest. While Fourth Amendment protections extend to a man's private room in a hospital, defendant waived his right to privacy by submitting himself to a hospital where it was anticipated that porters would enter his room. This consent was not vitiated by the fact that the porter was an undercover officer since neither precedent, public policy or logic bars the use of deception to gain peaceable entry into a private habitation.

 

1269 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Vernon


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


83 Misc. 2d 1025; 373 N.Y.S.2d 314; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3035



September 30, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The court is not persuaded to disavow the clear mandate of the legislative enactments here applicable and therefore, the motion to preclude is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, who was charged with criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 265.02(1), filed a motion to preclude his being considered a second-felony offender upon conviction.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested for possession of an unloaded pistol. Because he had previously been convicted of a crime, defendant was indicted for criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, a felony. Defendant sought to preclude his being considered a second-felony offender upon conviction, arguing that using the same crime that elevated the charge against him to a felony as the basis of his second-felony offender status violated his constitutional rights. The court held that: (1) the punishment imposed on a second-felony offender was not disproportionate, and the application of the second-felony offender statute did not comprise punishment of a status because defendant had control over such status; (2) application of the statute did not constitute an ex post facto application because the punishment inflicted was not greater than that affixed to the crime when it was committed; (3) the statute was not unreasonable and was rationally related to a legitimate state interest; and (4) double jeopardy did not apply because defendant's crimes were not the same in either law or fact.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to preclude.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- second-felony offender -- using same crime which elevates charge against defendant of criminal possession of weapon in third degree (Penal Law, § 265.02, subd [1]) to felony, as basis for considering him second-felony offender (Penal Law, § 70.06), does not violate his constitutional rights; sentencing defendant as second-felony offender is not cruel and unusual punishment since maximum possible sentence is not grossly disproportionate to gravity of crime -- predicate-felony statute as applied here is not ex post facto law since it is relevant incident to regulation of present situation -- no denial of due process inasmuch as both weapons statute and predicate-felony law as applied to defendant fulfill clear legislative purpose -- use of defendant's prior conviction does not constitute double jeopardy since offense charged in indictment is not same in either fact or law -- nor is contested procedure unconscionable or not in interests of justice.

1. Defendant was arrested for possession of an unloaded pistol.  [***2] Since he had been previously convicted of a felony, he was indicted for criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, a class D felony (Penal Law, § 265.02, subd [1]). Using the same crime which elevates the charge against him to a felony as the basis for considering him a second-felony offender (Penal Law, § 70.06), does not violate defendant's constitutional rights. Sentencing defendant as a second-felony offender would not constitute cruel and unusual punishment since when the gravity of the offense is taken into consideration, the maximum possible sentence he could receive, if convicted, is not so grossly disproportionate to the crime as to render it unconstitutional. Nor does the predicate-felony statute punish a status since a defendant subject to its provisions has not been placed in a position he was powerless to change.

2. Inasmuch as both the elevation of the crime from misdemeanor to felony and the application of the predicate-felony statute comes about as a relevant incident to a regulation of a present situation, the predicate-felony statute as applied here is not an ex post facto law.

3. Since both the weapons statute and the predicate-felony law as applied [***3] to defendant fulfill a clear legislative purpose, and the sentencing procedures are clear and equally applicable to each and every defendant convicted of this crime in this State, there is no denial of due process.

4. The use of defendant's prior conviction in this manner does not constitute double jeopardy since the offense charged in the indictment is not the same in either fact or law.

5. The contested procedure is not unconscionable, nor is it not in the interests of justice. There is no reason to depart from the rationale of prior judicial decisions which have upheld this approach, especially in light of the current legislative concern with the problems of recidivism and gun control.

 

1270 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lombard v. Staszak


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Schenectady County


83 Misc. 2d 1050; 373 N.Y.S.2d 967; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3041



September 30, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] All other requests of the petitioner are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner claimant filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 against respondents, Commissioner of the Schenectady County Department of Social Services (commissioner), state official, and utility company, seeking a judgment directing the commissioner to provide the claimant with an emergency grant to pay overdue utility bills.


OVERVIEW: The claimant had been a recipient of state aid. When the claimant was automatically transferred to the federal supplemental security income (SSI) program, the claimant's utility bills were no longer paid. Fifteen months later the claimant received a bill from the utility company for past due amounts that indicated that the claimant's power would be shut of if the bill wasn't paid. When the commissioner rejected the claimant's application for emergency assistance, the claimant filed the instant action. The court rendered judgment in favor of the claimant and found that under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 303(1)(a), the claimant's impending loss of utility services constituted an unforeseeable catastrophe that warranted emergency assistance. Considering that the claimant was never informed that his utility bill would no longer be paid and that there was no evidence that the utility company sent the claimant any bills before the cut off notice, it was clear that the claimant could not have foreseen the dilemma. Furthermore, compensation for this bureaucratic catastrophe, though not a natural disaster, was consistent with the spirit of § 303(1)(a), which sought to fill the gaps left by SSI.


OUTCOME: The court rendered judgment in favor of the claimant in the claimant's action against the commissioner, a state official, and the utility company, to obtain emergency assistance to pay his overdue utility bills.


HEADNOTES

Social services -- public assistance -- payment of utility bill -- SSI recipient, threatened with shutoff of power because of nonpayment of utility bill, who could not have foreseen his predicament, is entitled to emergency assistance from county, under section 303 (subd 1) of Social Services Law -- aid provided for in that section cannot be limited to those who find themselves in need because of natural catastrophe, but must also be made available to those who find themselves in need because of bureaucratically engendered catastrophe -- until expedited hearing procedure is formulated, applicant for emergency assistance does not have to seek fair hearing before commencing article 78 proceeding -- court will not require State commissioner to advise local districts that emergency assistance must be provided to destitute SSI recipients threatened with utility shutoff -- class action relief is also denied, since subsequent petitioners will be adequately protected under principles of stare decisis.

1. Petitioner, who, prior to January 1, 1974, had been receiving aid to the aged, blind and disabled from the county, which, as part [***2] of that assistance, had paid his utility bills, and who, on that date, was automatically transferred to the Federal SSI program, was notified, in March, 1975, that his power would be shut off if he did not pay his utility bill. The county had not informed him that it would no longer be paying his utility bill after his transfer to the Federal program, nor is there any proof that the utility had sent him any bills before March, 1975, and, therefore, he could not have foreseen his present predicament. He is entitled to emergency assistance from the county, under section 303 (subd 1) of the Social Services Law, which directs social service officials to provide emergency assistance to eligible aged, blind and disabled persons who need replacement of necessities lost as a result of fire, flood or other similar catastrophe which could not have been foreseen by such person.

2. Title 8 of article 5 (§ 300 et seq.) of the Social Services Law was enacted in recognition of the inadequacy of the Federal SSI program and, in enacting it, the Legislature declared that to provide emergency assistance for aged, blind and disabled persons with emergency needs which, if not met, would endanger [***3] their health, safety and welfare, was a matter of State concern and was a necessity in promoting the public health and welfare until such time as the Federal program was expanded to meet this Federal responsibility. In view of the purposes and policy which the Legislature intended to promote by its enactment, and in view of the constitutional mandate that the State and its subdivisions are to care for the needy, and the statutory embodiments of that mandate, the aid provided for in section 303 (subd 1) cannot be limited to those who find themselves in need because of a natural catastrophe, but must also be made available to those who find themselves in need because of a bureaucratically engendered catastrophe.

3. Until an expedited hearing procedure is formulated, an applicant for emergency assistance does not have to seek a fair hearing before commencing an article 78 proceeding.

4. The court will not require the State commissioner to advise local social services districts that emergency assistance must be provided to destitute SSI recipients threatened with utility shutoff, since to do so would constitute an unwarranted judicial intervention into governmental operations.

5. Class [***4] action relief is also denied, on the ground that such relief is not necessary for the fair and efficient adjudication of the controversy, since subsequent petitioners will be adequately protected under the principles of stare decisis.

 

1271 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Woods


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


84 Misc. 2d 301; 375 N.Y.S.2d 750; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3127



September 30, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The application is therefore granted to the extent indicated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with murder in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25. He asserted the affirmative defense that he acted under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance under N.Y Penal Law § 125.25(1)(a). He filed a motion seeking an order declaring the defense unconstitutional because it required him to prove an element of his own case.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted for murder under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25 and asserted the affirmative defense, provided in N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25(1)(a), that he had acted under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance for which there was a reasonable explanation or excuse. Defendant then sought an order declaring the statutory defense unconstitutional because it necessitated his proving an element of a lesser offense. The trial court agreed and declared the affirmative defense portion of the statute invalid. It explained that the affirmative defense statute placed the evidentiary burden on defendant to establish his defense by a preponderance of evidence, as N.Y. Penal Law § 25.00(2) required. Because N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25(1)(a) shifted to defendant the burden of proving a fact critical to criminal culpability, the trial court found that it was defective and violated due process. However, to address the People's considerable burden in proving a negative state of mind, the trial court ordered defendant to serve a notice on the People containing a general statement of the "extreme emotional disturbance" that he claimed.


OUTCOME: The trial court granted the application to the extent that it found the affirmative defense portion of the murder statute unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- murder -- "extreme emotional disturbance" -- burden of proof -- section 125.25 (subd 1, par [a]) of Penal Law which requires defendant charged with murder to prove affirmative defense that he "acted under influence of extreme emotional disturbance" by preponderance of evidence, in order to reduce crime to manslaughter, violates due process; State not defendant must bear total burden of proof beyond reasonable doubt -- defendant must serve notice upon People containing general statement as to nature of "extreme emotional disturbance".

1. Section 125.25 (subd 1, par [a]) of the Penal Law, which requires a defendant charged with murder to prove the affirmative defense that he "acted under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance" by a "preponderance of the evidence" (Penal Law, § 25.00, subd 2) in order to reduce the crime of murder to manslaughter, violates due process by unconstitutionally shifting the burden of proving "extreme emotional disturbance" from the People to defendant (see Mullaney v Wilbur, 421 U.S. 684). It is the duty of the State not defendant to bear the total burden [***2] of proof beyond a reasonable doubt in all criminal cases. Therefore, a defendant has no duty to prove any defense by a preponderance of the evidence and to require him to do so violates due process. Accordingly, the word "affirmative" is deleted from section 125.25 (subd 1, par [a]).

2. Defendant is directed to serve a notice upon the People containing a general statement as to the nature of the "extreme emotional disturbance" (see CPL art 250). Such information which is peculiar to defendant's own knowledge would expedite the progress of trial and prevent delay.

 

1272 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Miller


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Town Court of New York, Webster, Monroe County


83 Misc. 2d 118; 373 N.Y.S.2d 312; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2813



September 29, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The court finds section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law constitutional and denies the defendant's application.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The prosecution charged defendant with driving while intoxicated pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charged upon the grounds that § 1192 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss charges of driving while intoxicated upon the grounds that § 1192 was unconstitutional. The basis of his argument was that there was no legal difference in the definitions between subdivisions § 1192(1), prohibiting operation of a vehicle while the ability to operate such vehicle was impaired by the consumption of alcohol, and § 1192(3), prohibiting operation while the driver was in an intoxicated condition. The court denied the motion because it found that the statute was constitutional. It reasoned that a conviction pursuant to § 1192(1) was appropriate if defendant drove his automobile after consuming sufficient alcohol to lessen or impair his physical or mental control to any significant degree. Pursuant to § 1192(3) a conviction of driving while intoxicated was proper if defendant's judgment and ability to operate his motor vehicle were adversely affected to a substantial degree.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to dismiss the prosecution's charges of driving while intoxicated, on grounds that the applicable statute was unconstitutional, was denied.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- driving while intoxicated -- Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 1192), which (subd 1) prohibits operation of vehicle while ability is impaired and (subd 3) while driver is intoxicated, not unconstitutional.

A motion to dismiss charges of driving while intoxicated upon the ground that section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law is unconstitutional is denied. Subdivision 1 of the statute prohibits operation of a vehicle while "ability to operate such vehicle is impaired by the consumption of alcohol". Subdivision 3 prohibits operation while the driver "is in an intoxicated condition". These distinctions are not unconstitutional.

 

1273 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Delaney


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Nassau County


83 Misc. 2d 576; 373 N.Y.S.2d 477; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2941



September 29, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The accusatory instrument is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought dismissal of a summons received from a member of the police department highway bureau for failure to take a breath test in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193-a.


OVERVIEW: Defendant received a summons from a member of the county police department highway bureau for her failure to take a breath test in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193-a, which stated that any operator of a motor vehicle that had been involved in an accident or which was operated in violation of the vehicle code was required to submit to a breath test. The court held that the attempted imposition of a penalty for failure to take a breath test in accordance with N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193-a violated the rights conferred by U.S. Const. amend. V. Therefore, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193-a was unconstitutional. The obligation to take a breath test created a real and appreciable, and not merely an imaginary and unsubstantial, hazard of self-incrimination.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the summons.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- breath test -- Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 1193-a), which provides that person operating motor vehicle involved in accident or in violation of certain statutory provisions must submit to breath test to determine if operator has consumed alcohol and should take further test under Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 1194), creates hazard of self incrimination and is unconstitutional.

 Section 1193-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which provides that a person operating a motor vehicle involved in an accident or operating the vehicle in violation of certain statutory provisions, must submit to a breath test, at the request of a police officer, to determine if the operator has consumed alcohol and should take a further test under section 1194 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, is unconstitutional. The obligation to take the breath test creates a hazard of self incrimination. Its sole function is to incriminate the operator.

 

1274 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lucifer's Gate, Inc. v. Van Buren


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County


83 Misc. 2d 790; 373 N.Y.S.2d 304; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2982



September 29, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff restaurant brought a declaratory judgment action against defendants, Town of Van Buren and related parties, seeking to invalidate, as unconstitutional, Town of Van Buren, N.Y., Ordinance (May 12, 1975), regulating the amount of clothing to be worn in certain public places.


OVERVIEW: The restaurant provided topless dancing as entertainment to its customers. It filed an action against the town, seeking a declaratory judgment that Town of Van Buren, N.Y., Ordinance (May 12, 1975), which banned topless entertainment in certain public places, was unconstitutional.
