The trial court agreed and invalidated the ordinance. It explained that, although the town claimed that the ordinance had not been intended to ban topless dancing, it was sufficiently broad to proscribe totally such performances in restaurants and bars. While the town could have drawn the ordinance more narrowly to control or prohibit certain undesirable actions by patrons or lewd and obscene performances by entertainers, it had not done so. Instead, the ordinance included within the area of its prohibition or control non-obscene performances or dances, which were a form of expression protected by the First Amendment of the United States Constitution. Thus, the restaurant was entitled to an injunction against the enforcement of the ordinance.


OUTCOME: The trial court declared the ordinance unconstitutional and granted the restaurant an injunction against its enforcement.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- public nudity -- town ordinance regulating amount of clothing to be worn in restaurants and bars violates First Amendment, since it would prohibit protected, nonobscene nude dancing -- ordinance violates Fourteenth Amendment, since it prohibits conduct in bars and restaurants which it fails to regulate in other places of entertainment -- accordingly plaintiff bar owner is entitled to judgment declaring ordinance invalid and to injunction against its enforcement.

1. An ordinance of the Town of Van Buren regulating the amount of clothing to be worn in restaurants and bars violates the First Amendment to the Constitution, since, in addition to regulating conduct which is not protected as expression, it prohibits protected, nonobscene nude dancing.

2. The ordinance violates the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution, since it prohibits conduct in restaurants and bars, while it fails to regulate the same conduct in other places of entertainment.

3. Accordingly, plaintiff bar owner is entitled to a judgment declaring the ordinance invalid and to an injunction against its enforcement.

 

1275 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nelson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Binghamton


83 Misc. 2d 663; 372 N.Y.S.2d 873; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2958



September 15, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendants' motion to dismiss is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant property owners filed this motion to dismiss charges against them alleging that they violated the Housing, Property Maintenance and Rehabilitation Code of the City of Binghamton, N.Y. § 7.8 by refusing and failing to register dwelling units owned by each of them.


OVERVIEW: The property owners were charged with a violation of the Code for having allegedly failed to register dwelling units that they owned as rental property. They moved to dismiss the charges, alleging the Code had been in general disuse for many years, there had been widespread and flagrant violations known to enforcement officials that remained unprosecuted, and prosecution against them was politically motivated; therefore, the action against them was discriminatory. In denying the motion, the court first noted that the evidence showed the Code had been enforced generally within the city, and that rental units had been registered in conjunction with the inspection thereof. Second, although in the past many properties had not been registered or inspected, there was no credible evidence that Code enforcement personnel had knowledge of specific premises in violation and had taken no action. Furthermore, the law did not require a fail-safe system of ascertaining all properties in violation as a condition precedent to the prosecution of any property owners. Finally, the property owners failed to offer any evidence that prosecution against them was politically motivated.


OUTCOME: The motion was denied.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- discriminatory enforcement -- motion of defendants charged with violating Housing, Property Maintenance and Rehabilitation Code of City of Binghamton for refusing to register dwelling units, to dismiss for discriminatory enforcement, is denied; statute has not been in general disuse and any prosecution for failure to register is not ipso facto discriminatory -- while code enforcement personnel performed within limited system, within which enforcement may have been selective, it was not discriminatory -- no evidence to suggest prosecution was politically motivated -- upon motion to dismiss for discriminatory enforcement, burden of going forward and of proof rests on defendants.

1. Defendants, charged with a violation of section 7.8 of the Housing, Property Maintenance and Rehabilitation Code of the City of Binghamton for having "refused and failed to register dwelling units" owned by each of them, as required by the code section, made a motion to dismiss on grounds of discriminatory enforcement. The motion is denied. The statute has not been in general disuse for many years and any prosecution for failure to register [***2] is not ipso facto discriminatory. The distinction between "registration", and inspection and issuance of a certificate for rental units is merely technical.

2. Efforts of the Code Enforcement Bureau to comprehensively enforce the provisions of the code have not been inadequate. The law does not require a fail-safe system of ascertaining all properties in violation as a condition precedent to the prosecution of any property owners, and while code enforcement personnel performed within a limited system, within which enforcement may have been selective, it was not discriminatory.

3. There is no evidence to suggest that the prosecution was politically motivated. It was not the failure to register alone that prompted the prosecution, but the failure to comply with a formal written request which allowed a sufficient and reasonable time for compliance.

4. Upon a motion to dismiss or quash the information on grounds of discriminatory enforcement, the burden of going forward and of proof properly rests on defendants.

 

1276 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Merced v. Fisher


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


83 Misc. 2d 755; 372 N.Y.S.2d 855; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2977



September 10, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner indigent initiated a proceeding to have the court declare N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §§ 332, 336 unconstitutional and to nullify an order of respondent Commissioner of Motor Vehicles (New York). The Commissioner had suspended the indigent's driver's license because of his failure to satisfy a judgment against him.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to §§ 332, 336, the Commissioner suspended the indigent's driver's license due to his failure to satisfy a judgment against him. The indigent then commenced a proceeding to have the court declare §§ 332, 336 unconstitutional and to nullify the Commissioner's order. The court denied without prejudice the relief sought by the indigent. The court held that in the indigent's case, the Commissioner was required to have first placed before him a certified copy of the transcript of the outstanding judgment with the clerk's certification that 15 days had elapsed since the judgment became final and that the judgment had not been otherwise stayed or satisfied. In the court's opinion, the certification by a disinterested public official provided an adequate basis for a conclusion by the Commissioner that the facts as stated therein were probably true, and thus prima facie established the basic fact on which depended his jurisdiction to take action pursuant to § 336.


OUTCOME: The court denied the indigent's request to have it declare two statutes unconstitutional and to nullify the Commissioner's suspension of the indigent's driver's license.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act -- failure to satisfy judgment by reason of indigency -- respondent Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, pursuant to provisions of Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act (Vehicle and Traffic Law, §§ 332, 336), properly suspended petitioner's driver's license as result of petitioner's failure to satisfy judgment against him; State may constitutionally prohibit operation of motor vehicles on State highways by drivers, who, because of their indigency, are unable to comply with financial security provisions of Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act -- statute does not violate due process since commissioner may only act upon clerk's certification that 15 days have elapsed since judgment became final; certification by disinterested public official provides adequate basis to conclude that facts stated therein are probably true -- constitutional requirements of due process have been met since statute permits petitioner to obtain prompt stay of suspension pending complete hearing on validity of suspension (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 330, subd [d]).

1. Respondent Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, pursuant to sections 332 and 336 [***2] of the Vehicle and Traffic Law properly suspended petitioner's driver's license as the result of petitioner's failure to satisfy a judgment against him. The judgment, on account of which the suspension was ordered, was the result of an action brought following an accident which occurred on May 10, 1969. Judgment by default was entered on April 30, 1970. Petitioner currently owes the judgment creditor $ 564.85 with interest. The Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act is not rendered unconstitutional solely by reason of the fact that petitioner may have failed to pay the judgment because of his indigency. The State may prohibit the operation of motor vehicles on State highways by drivers who, because of their indigency, are unable to comply with the financial security provisions of the Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act.

2. The statute did not unconstitutionally authorize respondent commissioner to suspend petitioner's license solely upon an affidavit executed by the judgment creditor's attorney. Before respondent commissioner may act, he is required by section 336 to have first placed before him a certified copy of the transcript of the judgment, with the clerk's certification [***3] that 15 days have elapsed since the judgment became final and that the judgment has not been otherwise stayed or satisfied. This certification by a disinterested public official provides an adequate basis for a conclusion by the commissioner that the facts stated therein are probably true, and thus, prima facie, establish the basic fact on which depends his jurisdiction to take action pursuant to the statutory mandate.

3. Since the provisions of the Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 330, subd [d]), permit petitioner to obtain a prompt stay of the suspension pending a complete hearing on the validity of the suspension, the constitutional requirements of due process have been met. Petitioner, by exercising his opportunity to obtain a prompt stay has not yet been required to surrender his license.

 

1277 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Thompson v. Chemical Bank


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, New York County


84 Misc. 2d 721; 375 N.Y.S.2d 729; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3205



September 10, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly the respondent's motion for summary judgment is denied and petitioner's cross motion for summary judgment for the relief demanded in the petition is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner judge and respondent banks each sought summary judgment on the judge's request to vacate all default judgments entered against debtors who were required to pay a percentage of their bad debts to the banks as liquidated attorney fees. The judge alleged that this practice constituted both the unauthorized practice of law and fee-splitting, under N.Y. Jud. Law §§ 491 and 495, as well as usury under N.Y. Banking Law §§ 108(4) and (5).


OVERVIEW: Banks that were collecting on bad debts were also attempting to enforce contract provisions regarding attorney fees. The provisions allowed them to assess 15 percent of the unpaid balance of cash loans or overdraft loans, or 20 percent of the unpaid balance for credit card cash advances, as liquidated attorney fees, regardless of the fact that the banks used in-house counsel. The court held that such a practice constituted usury under N.Y. Banking Law §§ 108(4)(c) and (5)(e) because the sums, if collected in full, would grossly over-reward the banks as unreasonable fees. The court noted that attorney fees could represented only actual services in a particular case. In addition, the court pointed out that N.Y. Pers. Prop. Law § 413(5), enacted later, explicitly disallowed credit agreements from containing attorney fees provisions for salaried in-house counsel. Finally, the court agreed that the practice also constituted the unauthorized practice of law by the banks and fee-splitting with the attorneys, violations of N.Y. Jud. Law §§ 491 and 495.


OUTCOME: The court denied the order of the banks' motion for summary judgment, and granted the judge's cross-motion for summary judgment, vacating the default judgments entered against the debtors for attorney fees.


HEADNOTES

Banks and banking -- collection of attorney's fees -- consumer loans -- where respondent bank made different types of consumer loans, each of which contained provision stating that in event of default and suit to collect unpaid amount, there would be additional 15 or 20% of unpaid balance added for attorney's fees, and amounts collected on default judgments were far in excess of what was paid salaried in-house counsel, in proceeding to vacate default judgments petitioner's cross motion for summary judgment is granted; bank engaged in unauthorized practice of law in violation of section 495 of Judiciary Law, conduct violative of section 491 of Judiciary Law, and acted in concert with its salaried employees in fee splitting in violation of canon 3 and disciplinary rule 3-102 of Code of Professional Responsibility -- bank engaged in misrepresentation by setting forth in its complaints against consumer debtors specific item of recovery as attorney's fees -- bank engaged in usury by seeking to recover charge in  [***2] excess of charges permitted by subdivisions 4 and 5 of section 108 of Banking Law -- bank's practice also leads to discriminatory and unethical results which would render enabling statute unconstitutional.

1. Pursuant to provisions of the Banking Law ( § 108, subd 4, par [c], cl [iii]; subd 5, par [e], cl [iii]), respondent Chemical Bank made different types of consumer loans, each of which had a form agreement containing a provision stating that in the event of default and suit to collect the unpaid amount, there would be an additional 15 or 20% of the unpaid balance added for attorney's fees, the percentage depending on the type of loan. In 1973 the bank collected $ 70,752 in excess of what it collected in defaulted consumer obligations over what it paid its salaried in-house counsel, and in 1974 the figure was $ 37,795 plus, for each year, uncollected judgments for much more. The excess was used for the bank's legal department's office overhead. In a proceeding pursuant to section 217-a of the Judiciary Law to vacate the default judgments, petitioner's cross motion for summary judgment is granted. The policy of section 108 of the Banking Law is that interest is to [***3] cover the general expense of lending money, with an exception to permit the collection of the actual necessary expenditures for processing a case including reasonable attorney's fees. The bank's construction of the statute, that it may recover attorney's fees in each case although no actual attorney's fees were paid for the services rendered in that particular case, provided that it uses sums so collected towards defraying the expenses of its legal department, leads to unethical and illegal results. By its practices, the bank has engaged in the unauthorized practice of law in violation of section 495 of the Judiciary Law. Further, the bank has engaged in conduct violative of section 491 of the Judiciary Law (sharing of compensation by attorneys prohibited) and has acted in concert with its salaried attorneys in fee splitting in violation of canon 3 and disciplinary rule 3-102 of the Code of Professional Responsibility.

2. The bank's printed uniform complaint stated that an additional percentage of the balance had become due and payable as attorney's fees, but in no case did the bank allege that it actually expended a particular sum in payment of an attorney's fee to process the [***4] papers in that particular case or furnish any proof that such fee was reasonable or necessary. Therefore the bank engaged in a misrepresentation by setting forth in its complaints against consumer debtors a specific item of recovery as attorney's fees.

3. The bank routinely charged and recovered default judgments of 15 and 20% of the balance due, a rate so far in excess of what is reasonable as an attorney's fee for a default judgment that it can only be construed as a hidden charge to avoid the usury laws. Therefore the bank engaged in usury by seeking to recover a charge in excess of the charges permitted by subdivisions 4 and 5 of section 108 of the Banking Law.

4. The bank's practice also leads to discriminatory and unequal results which would render the enabling statute unconstitutional. By expressly stating in subdivision 5 of section 413 of the Personal Property Law that "(t)he credit agreement may provide for the payment of attorney's fees * * * if it is referred to an attorney not a salaried employee of the seller or holder for collection", the 1957 Legislature clearly indicated what it understood the 1937 statute (Banking Law, § 108, subds 4, 5) to mean, and more artfully [***5] delineated the limitations upon the collection of attorney's fees in accordance with existing laws and ethical standards.

 

1278 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Housing & Development Administration v. Community Housing Improv. Program, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, Kings County


83 Misc. 2d 977; 374 N.Y.S.2d 520; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3025



September 9, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff Housing and Development Administration of the City of New York (housing administration) and defendants, membership corporation of real property owners, and officers and members of its board of directors, filed various motions in response to the housing administration's action to enjoin defendants from a planned shutdown of boilers for maintenance purposes.


OVERVIEW: The housing administration sought to enjoin defendants from a planned shutdown of boilers for maintenance purposes. Defendants agreed not to promote the shutdown. The court found that the proposed shutdown was organized by defendants to dramatize certain housing issues not directly related to boiler maintenance. Accordingly, the court held that the boiler shutdowns were illegal and a potential threat to the tenants' welfare, and the court permanently enjoined the shutdowns. The court dismissed various counterclaims filed by defendants. The court granted defendants' motion to amend to conform to the proof thereby raising constitutional questions about the rent control and rent stabilization laws. The court concluded that the rent control and rent stabilization laws had become unconstitutional as administered because they resulted in the deprivation of the owners' property without due process of law and denied the owners equal protection under the laws.


OUTCOME: The court granted a permanent injunction against defendants and granted the housing administration's motions to dismiss several counterclaims brought by defendants. The court also allowed defendants to plead the unconstitutional administration of the rent control and rent stabilization laws and found that the laws were unconstitutional as administered.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- constitutionality -- although rent control and rent stabilization laws were constitutional ab initio, they have now become unconstitutional as administered, and are therefore declared unconstitutional; however, implementation of decision is stayed for 60 days to afford opportunity for presenting plan for administering laws so as to cure constitutional defects -- permanent injunction granted to enjoin defendants from planned shutdown of boilers for "maintenance" purposes -- defendants' motion to conform pleadings to plead unconstitutional administration of rent control and rent stabilization laws is granted -- counterclaim seeking "pass-along" of increased fuel costs to tenants in rent-controlled apartments is denied since alleviation of that burden is primarily legislative matter.

1. In a proceeding to enjoin defendants, a group primarily composed of owners of real property in New York City, from a planned shutdown of boilers for "maintenance" purposes, a permanent injunction is granted. The tactic was organized by defendants to dramatize certain housing issues not directly related to boiler maintenance, is a potential threat to tenants'  [***2] welfare, and is legally impermissable.

2. Since access to the courts is meaningless if constitutional issues are prohibited to parties by the recognition of highly technical objections and the New York City Civil Court has jurisdiction to hear any defense to a cause of action or claim (CCA, § 905), defendants' motion to conform the pleadings to plead the unconstitutional administration of the rent control and rent stabilization laws is granted.

3. Although the rent control and rent stabilization laws were constitutional ab initio, they have now become unconstitutional as administered, and are declared unconstitutional. The evidence clearly establishes that the administration of these laws has resulted in wholesale deprivation of property without due process of law, as well as a denial of equal protection. Procedures to protect property rights of both landlords and tenants as hardship applications and MBR (Maximum Base Rents) protests have become a mockery due to years of delay and total inaction in processing remedial applications. A huge rent gap has led to a deterioration in housing units, causing total abandonment of valuable property, and the City of New York has been [***3] deprived of some 600 million dollars in defaulted real estate taxes. However, implementation of the decision insofar as it declares said laws to be unconstitutional is stayed for 60 days to afford an opportunity for presenting a plan for administering the laws so as to cure the constitutional defects.

4. Although the court takes judicial notice of the fact that fuel costs have increased enormously in the previous 18 months and added a tremendous burden to already beleaguered property owners, alleviation of that burden is primarily a legislative matter, and therefore a counterclaim seeking a "pass-along" of increased fuel costs to tenants in rent-controlled apartments is denied.

 

1279 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hausman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Onondaga County


82 Misc. 2d 1032; 372 N.Y.S.2d 503; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2772



September 4, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment is reversed and a new trial granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from an order of the City Court of the City of Syracuse (New York), which entered judgment on a jury verdict convicting him of the crime of obscenity, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 235.05(1), and which sentenced him to pay a fine.


OVERVIEW: After a jury trial, defendant was found guilty of the crime of obscenity, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 235.05(1), which stemmed from the exhibition of an allegedly pornographic film in a local theater. Defendant was sentenced to pay a fine. Defendant appealed, and, upon review, the court reversed the judgment in the interest of justice and remitted the case to the city court for a new trial. The court held that the city court committed reversible error in its charge regarding the community standard of obscenity because the city court failed to define what "community" was meant. The court stated that by failing to define "community" to jury was allowed to define the term in accordance with its connotation as a local as opposed to a State-wide area. Thus, because there was neither a legal definition nor a factual showing as to the applicable community standard, the jury was confused, and defendant was entitled to be judged by a jury properly instructed as to the element of a contemporary State-wide community standard.


OUTCOME: Judgment is reversed and a new trial granted.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- obscenity -- compulsion to preserve evidence -- community standards -- defendant was properly restrained by order to show cause from removing allegedly obscene film from jurisdiction, based upon judicial inquiry into probable cause -- compulsion to preserve film did not violate Fifth Amendment rights, since film is physical evidence and defendant was compelled to preserve rather than produce evidence -- failure to object at trial to court's instructions regarding community standards was not waiver of appeal rights, since case law thereon was not sufficiently evolved -- contemporary State-wide community standard should be applied retroactively on appeal -- court's mention of State-wide citizenship fails to comply sufficiently with case law and prosecution failed to offer evidence on applicable community standard -- accordingly, judgment of conviction should be reversed in interests of justice and case remitted for new trial.

1. The defendant was properly restrained by order to show cause from removing allegedly obscene film from the jurisdiction pending an adversary hearing. The order was signed only after judicial [***2] inquiry into probable cause to find the film obscene, based upon an affidavit of a police investigator who viewed the film.

2. The defendant's Fifth Amendment rights were not violated by compulsion to preserve the film, since the film constituted physical rather than testimonial evidence and since the defendant was compelled to preserve rather than produce the evidence. Accordingly, the film was properly admitted into evidence.

3. The defendant's failure to object at trial to the court's instructions regarding the community standard by which the film was to be judged does not constitute a waiver of appeal of the issue, since case law thereon was not yet sufficiently evolved to support the defendant's present position, and the question may be reviewed under CPL 470.15 with a view to reversal in the interests of justice.

4. A contemporary State-wide community standard should be applied to films and such standard should be applied retroactively on appeal.

5. The trial court's mention of State-wide citizenship of the jury did not sufficiently comply with recent case law requiring full explanation and definition of the applicable community standard, and the prosecution offered no evidence [***3] as to such standard. Accordingly, the judgment of conviction should be reversed in the interests of justice and the case remitted to City Court for a new trial.

 

1280 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Ogilvie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Rockland County


83 Misc. 2d 896; 373 N.Y.S.2d 281; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3010



September 3, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a male and female, filed a motion pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 13-b for an order waiving the 10-day waiting period between the taking of serological tests to the date of solemnization of the parties' proposed marriage.


OVERVIEW: The male was a resident of New York and the female was resident of New Jersey. Section 13-b permitted a judge of the county in which the woman to be married resided to waive the 10-day waiting period. The court ruled that it could not be said that the residence of the female rather than of the male had any relationship, let alone a significant one, to the legislative intent of liberal granting of relief to prospective couples adversely affected by the statutory limitation on the natural and constitutional right to marry. A classification had to be reasonable, not arbitrary, and had to rest upon some ground of difference having a fair and substantial relation to the object of the legislation, so that all persons in similar circumstances would be treated alike. The court ruled that the effect of § 13-b denied the male the equal protection of the laws. The court further ruled that if a man and a woman were residents of New York or the woman was a resident of New York and the man was not, then the statutory provision was applicable. If, however, the man was a resident of New York and the woman was not, then a court in the county of the man's residence could waive the 10-day period.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioners' motion.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Marriage -- waiting period for blood test -- section 13-b of Domestic Relations Law, which allows Judge of county in which woman to be married resides, to issue order waiving 10-day waiting period from time of taking of blood specimens to solemnization of marriage, denies equal protection to petitioning male, resident of New York, who intends to marry New Jersey resident.

Petitioners moved pursuant to section 13-b of the Domestic Relations Law for an order waiving the 10-day waiting period from the time blood specimens are taken until solemnization of the marriage. While the statute allows "a judge or justice of the supreme court of this state or the county judge of the county in which the woman to be married resides" to make such an order, the petitioning male herein is a resident of New York and the petitioning female is a resident of New Jersey. Since the effect of the statute is to deny the male the equal protection of the laws, the motion is granted. Only a most compelling State interest will justify a statutory classification based on sex, and it cannot be said that the residence of the woman rather than of the man has any relationship, let alone a significant one,  [***2] to the legislative intent of liberal granting of relief to prospective couples adversely affected by the statutory limitation on the natural and constitutional right to marry.

 

1281 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Passantino


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester


83 Misc. 2d 409; 372 N.Y.S.2d 451; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2916



September 2, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed motions that challenged the constitutionality of a city ordinance that required the posting of retail price signs on gasoline pumps, subsequent to his arrest and arraignment for its violation.


OVERVIEW: The city adopted an ordinance that required the posting of the retail sale price of gasoline, kerosene, or diesel fuel. The ordinance was intended to prohibit fraudulent practices in the retail sale of gasoline. A county where the city was located also adopted a sign ordinance that made the requirements uniform through the county. Defendant operated a retail gasoline station in the city. As a station owner and an officer of a local gasoline dealer's association, he objected to the passage of the ordinance. The defendant sought arrest in order to test the validity of the ordinance. The court held that: (1) the ordinance was constitutional because there was no denial of due process or discrimination where the requirement that a sign be posted over every pump was not an arbitrary interference with defendant's property rights and did not violate the state or federal constitutions; and (2) the ordinance was a proper subject of the inherent police power of the city absent a showing of arbitrary action by a city council or that the ordinance did not bear any relation to the public welfare.


OUTCOME: The court held that the city ordinance was constitutional and a proper subject matter of the city's police powers.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- sign ordinance -- city ordinance which requires posting of gasoline selling price on pumps does not violate due process and equal protection clauses of New York and United States Constitutions, since ordinance legitimately protects public from possibility of fraud and affects all gasoline retailers equally -- absent showing of arbitrary action, ordinance is proper subject of police power, since it is related to the public health, safety and welfare.

1. Section 53-138.8 (B) of the Ordinances of the City of Rochester, which requires the conspicuous posting on gasoline pumps of a 12-square-inch sign showing the selling price of the fuel, does not violate the due process and equal protection clauses of the State of New York and United States Constitutions, since the ordinance legitimately protects the public from the possibility of fraud and affects all gasoline retailers equally.

2. Absent a showing of arbitrary action, the ordinance is a proper subject of the police power, since it has the purpose of preventing fraud and is, accordingly, related to the public health, safety and welfare.

 

1282 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Long


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


83 Misc. 2d 14; 372 N.Y.S.2d 389; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2792



August 25, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion to make entrapment an ordinary defense with the burden of disproving the same upon the People is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged in a five-count, consolidated indictment with the crime of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree and related crimes. On the date of trial, defendant filed a motion and sought to have the statutory imposition of a burden of proof upon him, should he raise an entrapment defense, declared unconstitutional. The matter was before the court following oral argument.


OVERVIEW: Defendant reserved his right to raise the affirmative defense of entrapment in his trial for the criminal sale of a controlled substance. He contended that the provisions of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 25.00 and 40.05 violated his due process rights as guaranteed under the Fourteenth Amendment because they improperly imposed a burden of proof on him. The court noted that the affirmative defense was created by the statute, as well as the shifting of the burden of proof to defendant. It noted further that before the affirmative defense was presented to the jury for its consideration, the State was required to prove all the elements of the crime. It distinguished a Maine statute that had been declared unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court because it impermissibly shifted the burden of disproving the elements of a crime onto a defendant. The Maine statute required a defendant charged with murder to prove that he acted in the heat of passion on sudden provocation in order to reduce the homicide charge to manslaughter. The Maine statute at issue did not require the prosecution to prove beyond a reasonable doubt every fact necessary to constitute the crime charged.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to make entrapment an ordinary defense with the burden of disproving the same upon the People. It held the statute pertaining to the affirmative defense of entrapment and its shifting of the burden of proof was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- entrapment -- placing burden of proof upon defendant who raises entrapment defense (Penal Law, § 40.05) does not violate due process clause; defendant's motion to make affirmative defense of entrapment ordinary defense with burden of disproving same upon People is denied.

Upon a trial for criminal sale of a controlled substance and related crimes, defendant's motion to make the affirmative defense of entrapment (Penal Law, § 40.05) an ordinary defense with the burden of disproving the same upon the People is denied. Placing the burden of proof upon a defendant who raises the entrapment defense does not violate the due process clause, and therefore section 40.05 of the Penal Law is constitutional. This case is to be distinguished from Mullaney v Wilbur (421 U.S. 684) where the Supreme Court examined a Maine statute which required a defendant charged with murder to prove that he acted in the heat of passion on sudden provocation in order to reduce the homicide to manslaughter, and found it unconstitutional. Raising the entrapment [***2] issue in no way affects the prosecution's duty to prove beyond a reasonable doubt every element of the crime charged, and the jury does not reach the entrapment question unless it finds defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt of all the elements of the crime before them. Also, the shift of the burden of proof does not increase the chances of an erroneous conviction. Since the burden of proof of criminal sale of a controlled substance is left with the District Attorney, the entrapment defense does not increase the possibility that an innocent man will be convicted or that one guilty of a lesser crime will be sentenced as a more serious offender.

 

1283 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Repetti v. Gil


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


83 Misc. 2d 75; 372 N.Y.S.2d 840; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2806



August 25, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, an arrestee, filed a motion that challenged the constitutionality of the civil arrest remedy provisions of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6101. He was arrested as a result of a motion for civil arrest as a provisional remedy filed by plaintiff, a joint venturer with the arrestee, in a commercial law claim for the collection of a debt allegedly owed.


OVERVIEW: The parties formed a joint venture for the importation and distribution of brush handles and broomsticks. The joint venturer filed a civil suit against the arrestee for fraud and conversion and sought an accounting. He filed a motion for attachment of the arrestee's property in the state and claimed the arrestee was about to sell his house and move to another state, which would effectively avoid the state courts' jurisdiction. The court granted an attachment. That same day the joint venturer filed a notice to attach real property. Two days earlier the arrestee sold his house. The joint venturer moved for an arrest so the arrestee would be available to be sued civilly. The court ordered an arrest, set bail, and directed a sheriff to bring the arrestee in for a hearing mandated by N.Y. C.L.P.R. 6111. The court tentatively continued the arrest order but released the arrestee in the custody of his attorney. The court held that: (1) a clause of the civil arrest provision violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment because it subjected the arrestee as a man to arrest while it flatly exempted all women; and (2) it was not proven that the arrestee violated any order.


OUTCOME: The court vacated the arrestee's arrest and released him for the custody of his attorney.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Arrest -- constitutionality of civil arrest statute -- subdivision 1 of CPLR 6101, which provides for civil arrest where there is cause of action to recover damages for conversion or for fraud or deceit "and the person to be arrested is not a woman", is unconstitutionally discriminatory -- in action for damages for fraud and conversion, and also for accounting, plaintiff moved to have defendant arrested on basis of subdivision 2 of CPLR 6101, providing for civil arrest where plaintiff would be entitled to judgment requiring performance of act, neglect or refusal to perform which would be punishable by court as contempt, but he claimed only that defendant had already committed contempt -- if there was contempt, remedy would have been to seek immediate punishment -- civil arrest, essentially security device, should only be employed when essential and appropriate -- while plaintiff's demand for accounting could support civil arrest order, he did not mention accounting aspect of case or show facts sufficient to establish his entitlement to accounting -- constitutionality of subdivision 2 of CPLR 6101 need not be decided, but its desirability is questioned by court.

1. Subdivision [***2] 1 of CPLR 6101, which provides for civil arrest "where there is a cause of action to recover damages for the conversion of personal property, or for fraud or deceit, and the person to be arrested is not a woman", is unconstitutionally discriminatory. The sex of a person has no rational relationship to the objectives of the statute, and no compelling State interest requires the sex distinction.

2. In an action for damages for fraud and conversion, and also for an accounting, plaintiff moved to have defendant arrested, on the basis, not only of CPLR 6101 (subd 1), but subdivision 2 of CPLR 6101, which provides for civil arrest "where the plaintiff has demanded and would be entitled to a judgment or order requiring the performance of an act the neglect or refusal to perform which would be punishable by the court as a contempt and where the defendant is not a resident of the state or is about to depart therefrom, by reason of which non-residence or departure there is a danger that such judgment or order will be rendered ineffectual". In his affidavit in support of the motion, he had not claimed that defendant's arrest was necessary to protect the efficacy of an anticipated court order [***3] or to keep defendant within the court's coercive jurisdiction, but that defendant had already committed a contempt. However, there is no satisfactory proof of defendant's commission of a contempt, and, in any event, the proper remedy would have been to seek immediate punishment for it. Civil arrest as a provisional remedy is essentially a security device, and should only be employed, if at all, when essential and appropriate.

3. While plaintiff's demand for an accounting could support a civil arrest order, since the failure to comply with a court-ordered accounting is an act ultimately punishable by the court as a contempt, his affidavit did not mention the accounting aspect of his case, nor does it show facts sufficient to establish his entitlement to an accounting.

4. While the constitutionality of subdivision 2 of CPLR 6101 need not be decided here, its desirability is questioned by the court.

 

1284 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


O'Connor v. Levitt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


82 Misc. 2d 806; 372 N.Y.S.2d 406; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2688



August 22, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, police officers and firefighters who were Korean War veterans, brought a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 for an order enjoining respondent, the Comptroller of the State of New York and Administrator of the New York State Policemen's and Firemen's Retirement System, from administrating N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law §§ 302, 341(k). Petitioners also sought a declaration that §§ 302 and 341(k) were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners contended that they were being denied equal protection of the law by being excluded from the additional service credits towards retirement benefits that were provided under § 341(k) for police officers and firefighters who were World War II veterans. N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 341(g) provided credit for service in war after World War I, and therefore both Korean War and World War II veterans were eligible for credit under § 341(g). In dismissing the petition, the court found that from a clear reading of the statutes involved, the legislature decided that World War II veterans were to be afforded extra service credits. The legislature did not exclude any war veterans from credit benefits, but merely provided World War II veterans with additional credit opportunities. The court presumed that the legislature investigated for and found facts necessary to support the legislation. The court noted that statutes conferring benefits or preferences on one group of veterans and not other groups had been consistently upheld by the courts. Petitioners did not carry their burden of establishing that the statutes were unconstitutional beyond a reasonable doubt.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- retirement -- petition by Korean War veterans attacking constitutionality of sections of Retirement and Social Security Law which provide additional service credit towards retirement benefits for those policemen and firemen who are World War II veterans, but not for those who are veterans of other wars, is dismissed.

A petition by Korean War veterans attacking the constitutionality of sections 302 and 341 (subd k) of the Retirement and Social Security Law, which provide additional service credit towards retirement benefits for those policemen and firemen who are World War II veterans, but not for those who are veterans of other wars, is dismissed. It is to be presumed that the Legislature has investigated for and found facts necessary to support this legislation, and petitioners have not overcome the heavy burden upon one who attacks the constitutionality of a statute to establish its unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt.

 

1285 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Balogun


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


82 Misc. 2d 907; 372 N.Y.S.2d 384; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2843



August 19, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with attempted murder and assault in the second degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 110.00, 125.25, 120.05. The court adjourned the trial date in order to determine the constitutionality of § 125.25.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with attempted murder and assault in the second degree and indicated that he proposed to plead the affirmative defense that he had acted under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance. The court on its own motion adjourned the trial date in order to consider the constitutionality of § 125.25, which required defendant to affirmatively prove the defense, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 25.00, by a preponderance of the evidence. The court evaluated a recent Supreme Court interpretation of a Maine statute and concluded that the portion of § 125.25 that required defendant to prove the defense was unconstitutional. The Fourteenth Amendment's due process clause required the prosecution to prove, beyond a reasonable doubt, the absence of the influence of extreme emotional disturbance when the issue was properly presented in the trial of an indictment. The prosecution was required to prove, beyond a reasonable doubt, every fact necessary to constitute the crime charged, and the reasonable doubt standard applied to the degree of an offense as well as to the fact of its commission. The invalid provision was struck from the statute but was not retroactive.


OUTCOME: The court held that the portion of a statute that required defendant on trial for attempted murder to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that he acted under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance was unconstitutional and that the prosecution had the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the influence of extreme emotional disturbance was lacking.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- murder -- "extreme emotional disturbance" -- burden of proof -- when defense of "extreme emotional disturbance" is pleaded to murder indictment, People must prove absence of influence of such "extreme emotional disturbance" beyond reasonable doubt; section 125.25 (subd 1, par [a]) of Penal Law, which requires defendant, on issue of degree of culpability, to prove affirmative defense of "extreme emotional disturbance" by preponderance of evidence, is unconstitutional (see Mullaney v Wilbur, 421 U.S.   , 43 U.S. Law Week 4695).

Section 125.25 (subd 1, par [a]) of the Penal Law, which requires a defendant charged with murder to prove the affirmative defense that he "acted under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance", by a preponderance of the evidence in order to reduce a murder charge to manslaughter, is unconstitutional (see Mullaney v Wilbur, 421 U.S.   , 43 U.S. Law Week 4695). When the defense of "extreme emotional disturbance" is pleaded to a murder indictment, the People must prove the absence of the influence of such "extreme emotional disturbance" beyond a reasonable doubt. The prosecution has the burden of proving an affirmative defense [***2] on the issue of the degree of culpability.

 

1286 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Beneficial Finance Co. v. Bond


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


83 Misc. 2d 9; 372 N.Y.S.2d 374; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2791



August 14, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, two finance companies, filed a motion for a declaratory judgment that the wage assignment statutes provided in N.Y. Pers. Prop. Law art. 3-A and N.Y. Banking Law art. 9 were not violative of the Fourteenth Amendment or N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6. Defendants, two borrowers, opposed the motion and filed a cross-claim to dismiss the complaint. The New York Attorney General appeared and urged that the statutes were constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The same parties were involved in a civil rights federal court action involving the issue of the constitutionality. Defendants in that action sought a judgment declaring the New York Wage Assignment statute to be unconstitutional as violative of the Fourteenth Amendment in respect to due process clause. A federal court declared the statute unconstitutional. On appeal, a federal appellate court reversed and held that plaintiffs' action in filing the assignments with defendants' employers was a private action, and not State action, to which the due process clause would be inapplicable. As to defendants' motion to dismiss, the court held that there still existed a judicable controversy based upon the stipulation between the parties to stay the execution of the wage assignment pending the completion of the litigation. As to the merits, the court held that there was state involvement in the wage assignment field. The court concluded that there was no Federal question involved because the federal appellate court unequivocally found no State action. The court, however, found that the statutes in question did not violate the New York State Constitution.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment, in part, in favor of plaintiffs and denied defendants' motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional law -- wage assignment statutes -- article 3-A of Personal Property Law and article 9 of Banking Law, wage assignment statutes, do not violate any provision of New York State Constitution -- Federal court action involving same parties resulted in refusal to review issue of due process, based upon finding that there was no State action to which due process clause of United States Constitution would be applicable -- however, on basis of findings made by court in present action, statutes comply with United States Constitution.

1. Article 3-A of the Personal Property Law and article 9 of the Banking Law, the wage assignment statutes, ensure that the borrower shall have adequate notice and an opportunity to be heard before a wage assignment pursuant thereto can be enforced, and do not violate any provision of the New York State Constitution.

2. A Federal court action involving the same parties resulted in a refusal to review the issue of due process, based upon a finding that the State was not actively involved in wage assignment agreements between lenders and borrowers and, therefore, there was no State action to which the due process clause of the United States [***2] Constitution would be applicable. This ends State court inquiry in respect to any Federal question. However, on the basis of findings made by the court in the present declaratory judgment action, including a finding that the Legislature has involved the State in the wage assignment field and, during the pendency of the Federal litigation, enacted amendments to the statutes assuring due process for the borrower, it is adjudged that the statutes also comply with the United States Constitution.

 

1287 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


McCormick v. Lawrence


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Essex County


83 Misc. 2d 64; 372 N.Y.S.2d 156; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2804; 5 ELR 20650



August 11, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Respondents' motion to dismiss the petitioners' complaint and for summary judgment is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowners filed a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 817 and N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 seeking a modification or rescission of the decision from respondent Adirondack Park Agency, which prohibited boathouses. The Agency filed a motion for a summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 809, the landowners applied to the Agency for permission to develop 32 lots. The Agency approved the project subject to the condition that no boathouses be constructed on the shore of the lake. The landowners filed a complaint pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 817 and N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 seeking a modification or rescission of the Agency's decision contending that the prohibition against the construction of boathouses was arbitrary, capricious, discriminatory, unreasonable, unlawful and unconstitutional. The Agency filed a motion for a summary judgment arguing that the decision was valid on the basis of aesthetic, scenic and visual considerations. On consideration, the court granted the Agency's motion for a summary judgment and dismissed the landowners' complaint. The court held that the Agency's decision to prohibit boathouses was not arbitrary or unreasonable, because the Agency had the authority to impose reasonable requirements and conditions with respect to land use. Aesthetic considerations were a valid subject of legislative concern and a permissible exercise of the state's police power.


OUTCOME: The court granted the Agency's motion for a summary judgment and dismissed the landowners' complaint.


HEADNOTES

Environmental conservation -- shoreline restrictions -- decision of Adirondack Park Agency prohibiting boathouses on shoreline of Oseetah Lake was properly based on aesthetic considerations pursuant to police power and constituted proper exercise of discretion -- boathouses may be restricted despite absence of setback requirements therefor, since decision is based upon consideration of all factors -- restriction is not unlawful since almost all zoning laws curtail use of property to promote general welfare and, accordingly, petitioners' complaint is dismissed and summary judgment is granted to agency.

1. A decision of the Adirondack Park Agency prohibiting boathouses on the shoreline of Oseetah Lake was properly based on aesthetic, scenic and visual considerations pursuant to the police power, and constituted a proper exercise of discretion in view of the relatively undeveloped and pristine lakefront property.

2. Boathouses may be restricted despite the absence of setback requirements therefor, since restriction is on a case basis and depends upon consideration of all factors [***2] involved.

3. Petitioners may not be heard to complain that they are subject to an unlawful and unreasonable restriction in the use and enjoyment of their property, since almost all zoning laws curtail use of property to promote the general welfare, and petitioners' complaint is accordingly dismissed and summary judgment is granted to the respondent agency.

 

1288 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York City Housing Authority v. Commissioner of Environmental Conservation Dep't


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


83 Misc. 2d 89; 372 N.Y.S.2d 146; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2808



August 8, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, New York Housing Authority (authority), sought review of a decision of respondent, Commissioner of Environmental Conservation Department (commissioner), which found that the Authority's property was subject to the Tidal Wetlands Act (act), N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 25-0602.


OVERVIEW: The authority sought to sell land to a private developer that it had acquired through a condemnation by the city. The authority requested the commissioner to determine whether the land was subject to the act. The commissioner determined that it was. The authority applied for a moratorium permit to allow alterations otherwise prohibited by the act, and the commissioner only allowed alterations to a portion of the property. The private developer withdrew its offer to purchase and the authority filed an action. The court denied the commissioner's motion to dismiss and held that the sale of land to a private developer did not, on its face, further the ends of the authority, under N.Y. Pub. Hous. Law § 2. The court held that moratoriums would be upheld as valid and not a taking of property so long as they were for a reasonable purpose and of a reasonable duration. The court held that § 25-0602 was constitutional on its face and as applied to the authority, and therefore, did not sanction a taking of property without just compensation.


OUTCOME: The court denied the commissioner's motion to dismiss. The court held that the authority's land, acquired through eminent domain, was not exempt from the act. The court further held that the act was constitutional, on its face and as applied to the authority, and did not sanction a taking of property without just compensation.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Environmental conservation -- Tidal Wetlands Act -- New York City Housing Authority is not agency of State and, therefore, property acquired by it through condemnation is not exempt from provisions of Tidal Wetlands Act -- intention of act is to establish comprehensive system of land-use regulations after inventory of all tidal wetlands, and, since regulations have not yet been promulgated, any challenge to constitutionality of act as a whole is premature -- moratorium provided for in act, prohibiting any person from altering state of any tidal wetland prior to effective date of land-use regulations, except by special permission, is reasonable and, up to now, has been of reasonable duration -- article 78 proceeding, attacking applicability of act to property acquired by New York City Housing Authority through condemnation and also constitutionality of act is treated as action for declaratory judgment.

1. The New York City Housing Authority is not an agency of the State, and, therefore, property acquired by it through condemnation is not exempt from the provisions of the Tidal Wetlands Act ( ECL art 25), section 25-0602 of which exempts from the provisions of the act "any lands [***2] now or hereafter appropriated by the state or any agency or department thereof under the power of eminent domain".

2. The intention of the Tidal Wetlands Act is to establish a comprehensive system of land-use regulations after an inventory of all tidal wetlands. Since the regulations have not yet been promulgated, any challenge to the constitutionality of the act as a whole is premature.

3. Section 25-0202 of the Tidal Wetlands Act provides for a moratorium, prohibiting any person from altering the state of any tidal wetland prior to the effective date of the land-use regulations, except by special permission from the commissioner. Such moratoriums have been upheld as valid and not involving an unconstitutional taking of property so long as they are for a reasonable purpose and of a reasonable duration. The subject one is reasonable, since alteration of property while the inventory required for formulation of the land-use regulations is in progress may irreparably damage wetlands, and thereby render the regulation academic before it is even effectuated. Nor may it be said that it has, up to now, run for an unreasonable period of time. It has been in effect for slightly less [***3] than two years, and the inventory is feasible only during the summer growing season, when the wetlands can be identified. Moreover, the act contemplates public hearings and conferences with local government officials, prudent measures considering the many interests which may be affected by the regulations.

4. The present proceeding was initiated by the New York City Housing Authority as one under CPLR article 78, but, since it attacks the applicability of the Tidal Wetlands Act to property acquired by the authority through condemnation and also the constitutionality of the act, thus attacking the commissioner's very power to act and not merely the propriety of his action, it is treated as an action for a declaratory judgment.

 

1289 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wrench


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Suffolk County


83 Misc. 2d 95; 371 N.Y.S.2d 833; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2809



July 30, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with having violated N.Y. Penal Law § 235.05. The matter was before the court on a trial without a jury upon defendant's waiver.


OVERVIEW: At issue was the purchase by a police officer from defendant of an adult magazine. The premises wherein the officer purchased the allegedly obscene book was an ordinary bookstore entered from the street in a shopping center. The store contained a variety of reading materials. In the front portion of the store, the material displayed was the usual material one would expect to find in a bookstore. There was a separate rear section, physically separated from the rest of the bookstore by walls and a door. There were signs posted restricting the admission into this section of the bookstore to persons over the age of 21. Defendant raised the defense provided by N.Y. Penal Law § 235.15(1), urging that to preserve the constitutionality of § 235.15(1), it had to be interpreted as authorizing sales to all adults. In order to sustain the constitutionality of the statute, the court read the affirmative defense afforded under § 235.15(1) as authorizing sales to all adults and not a limited few. The court further held that defendant had proved his defense under § 235.15(1) by a preponderance of the evidence. Accordingly, the court found defendant not guilty.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment in favor of defendant.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- obscenity -- scientific, educational or governmental justification -- defendant charged with obscenity in second degree (Penal Law, § 235.05) has established affirmative defense that material was disseminated to persons having scientific, educational or governmental justification for possession (Penal Law, § 235.15), since material was displayed in separate room with signs informing customers of contents thereof and stating that purchasers represent that material is for scientific or educational purposes; defense is based on disseminator's good faith at sale and must apply to individuals conducting own education and not only to formal educators, students and scientists; defendant showed intent to come within law and adopted unsuggestive manner of presentation preventing foisting of material on unwilling or underage public and is accordingly found not guilty.

The defendant, charged with obscenity in the second degree under section 235.05 of the Penal Law, has met the burden imposed by the affirmative defense of section 235.15 of the Penal Law that the material was disseminated to persons having scientific, educational or governmental justification for possessing [***2] it. The defense cannot be construed to apply only to formal educators, students or scientists but must apply also to individuals conducting their own educations and must be based upon the disseminator's good faith at the time of sale. The material was displayed in a separate back room of the defendant's bookstore with appropriate signs informing customers of the contents of the room and stating that purchasers represent that the material is only for scientific or educational purposes. The defendant has, by posting the notices, shown his intent to come within the law, and he adopted an unsuggestive manner of presentation preventing the foisting of the material upon an unwilling or underage public and is accordingly found not guilty.

 

1290 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Weber


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Elma, Erie County


82 Misc. 2d 593; 371 N.Y.S.2d 361; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2739



July 30, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Based upon the above, the defendant's motion is denied, and the defendant is to appear for sentencing on August 5, 1975.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was arrested and charged with a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2), (3). At the close of the State's evidence in a trial by jury, defendant filed a motion to dismiss on several grounds. The court denied the motion in part and reserved decision of the question of the constitutionality of § 1192.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's vehicle was stopped after two officers witnessed defendant's erratic behavior. He was then arrested based on the officers' opinions that defendant was intoxicated. An alcotector test later revealed that defendant was intoxicated under legal standards. The jury found defendant guilty under § 1192(2). In his motion to dismiss, defendant challenged the constitutionality of the statute. The court, in dismissing the motion and rejecting defendant's arguments, held that the section under which defendant was found guilty was not a separate new crime as contended. The court held that each subsection under the statute differed only in the manner of proof of intoxication. Subdivision two of § 1192 required that the State show, by the results of a chemical test administered within two hours of an arrest, that the defendant had greater than .10 of one per centum of alcohol in his blood. The end result of all the subsections of the statute would be the same, a conviction for driving while intoxicated. The court noted that some additional proof was necessary that defendant had greater than the minimum quantity of alcohol in his bloodstream at the time of driving.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- driving while intoxicated -- subdivision 2 of section 1192 of Vehicle and Traffic Law, providing that no person shall operate vehicle while he has .10 of one per centum or more by weight of alcohol in his blood, does not define separate crime from that defined in subdivision 3 of that section, providing that no person shall operate motor vehicle while he is in intoxicated condition, but merely offers another definition for driving while intoxicated -- manner of proof is only difference -- violation of subdivision 3 would be shown by characteristics of defendant -- violation of subdivision 2 would be shown by results of chemical test administered within two hours of arrest, and some additional proof, along line which would sustain conviction under subdivision 3 but not to degree necessary to sustain such conviction, is required to convince trier of fact that there is no reasonable doubt that, at time of driving, defendant had greater than minimum quantity of alcohol in his blood.

Subdivision 2 of section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic [***2] Law, providing that no person shall operate a motor vehicle while he has .10 of one per centum or more by weight of alcohol in his blood, does not define a separate crime from that defined in subdivision 3 of that section, providing that no person shall operate a motor vehicle while he is in an intoxicated condition, but merely offers another definition for driving while intoxicated, that definition being that a man is intoxicated for purposes of driving when he has .10 of one per centum or more of alcohol in his blood. A violation of either subdivision results in a conviction for driving while intoxicated, and the manner of proof is the only difference. A violation of subdivision 3 would be shown by the characteristics of the defendant. A violation of subdivision 2 would be shown by the results of a chemical test administered within two hours of arrest and, in view of the fact that a reading of alcohol content taken any time after the driving may be higher or lower than the content at the time the defendant is first stopped or involved in an accident, some additional proof is required to convince the trier of fact that there is no reasonable doubt but that defendant had greater [***3] than the minimum quantity of alcohol in his blood at the time of driving. Such additional proof would be along the line which would sustain a conviction under subdivision 3, but not to the degree necessary to sustain a conviction under that subdivision.

 

1291 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Collier


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


85 Misc. 2d 529; 376 N.Y.S.2d 954; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3319



July 28, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In summary, the defendant's aforesaid motion to suppress the physical evidence seized in this case is granted. The defendant's aforesaid motion to dismiss the indictments, pursuant to CPL 210.20 (subd 1, par [1]), on the ground specified in CPL 210.40 (subd 1), is also granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, claiming to be aggrieved by an unlawful or improper acquisition of evidence, filed a motion to suppress evidence and a motion to dismiss the indictments filed against him pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 710.20(1) and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.40. Defendant was charged with misdemeanor conspiracy, misdemeanor possession of stolen property, and possession of a handgun.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with misdemeanor conspiracy, misdemeanor possession of stolen property, and possession of a handgun. Defendant filed a motion to suppress arguing that the evidence was discovered by way of an unlawful search and seizure and that the search warrant was constitutionally invalid. Defendant also filed a motion to dismiss the indictments pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20 on the grounds that prosecution of defendant would constitute an injustice because of the gross impropriety of the undercover detective. The court agreed and granted the motions. The court held that the infiltration of defendant's community, without any cause or guidelines whatever for a two-year period, with daily and indiscriminate spying on a multitude of citizens and community groups, was an unconstitutional invasion of privacy. The court held that the unfair police tactics posed a real and serious threat to civilized notions of justice and that the sweeping, free-wheeling, penetrating, and extremely protracted infiltration of the entire community presented a different situation from that in which an undercover officer infiltrated a conspiracy of international drug dealers.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to suppress the physical evidence seized and defendant's motion to dismiss the indictments.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- unlawful search and seizure -- dismissal in interests of justice -- evidence against defendant was obtained unlawfully and should be suppressed, since there was no basis under warrant for seizure of four out of five items and evidence presented in support of warrant is conflicting, weak and incredible -- indictment should be dismissed in interests of justice, since obtained in consequence of gross abuse of police power, jeopardizing rights of public through general disregard for constitutional rights; detective had infiltrated city neighborhood without cause, spying upon citizens, community groups and particularly defendant over two-year period, obtaining duplicate keys to private premises, conducting illegal searches and seizures, monitoring minutiae of defendant's daily life, removing private property and infiltrating public meetings.

1. Evidence obtained against the defendant should [***2] be suppressed upon the ground that it was obtained through an unlawful search and seizure. There was no basis under the search warrant for seizure of four out of five items, there being no reason whatsoever to believe that the property was stolen, and the evidence presented in support of the warrant is too conflicting, weak and incredible to accept. The warrant application was submitted one day after a previous application was rejected for staleness, although it was stated that no prior application had been made, and the evidence was found in the place specified by the earlier application while the basis for the information was as stale as in the earlier application.

2. The indictment against the defendant is dismissed in the interests of justice. The Bureau of Special Services of the City of New York improperly assigned an undercover detective to infiltrate a city neighborhood, arbitrarily and without cause or guidelines, which detective engaged in daily, indiscriminate spying upon citizens and community groups over a two-year period, particularly and impermissibly focusing on the defendant, a highly reputable civic leader, and his associates. The detective surreptitiously obtained [***3] duplicate keys to private premises, conducted illegal searches and seizures, feigned crimes to induce confidence, monitored the defendant's state of mind and minutiae of his daily life, removed private property, and infiltrated public meetings, acting with a general disregard for and in derogation of constitutional rights. Such gross abuse of the police power jeopardizes the rights of all and is beyond judicial toleration.

 

1292 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


860 Executive Towers v. Board of Assessors


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


84 Misc. 2d 525; 377 N.Y.S.2d 863; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3171



July 24, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent, a county board of assessors, filed motions to dismiss the proceedings brought by petitioners, property taxpayers, and strike the testimony of an expert witness and to strike state equalization rates as applied to the county.


OVERVIEW: The state adopted equalization rates for its counties to establish a just relationship between the valuation of all tax districts within a county. The phase of the action concerned the methodology used by a state board of equalization and assessment to arrive at the state equalization rate for the county. The state board interpreted N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law art. 12 as having limited protests to only taxing districts and that the county was not a district. The court held that: (1) under article 12, the state board was required to establish a rate for that portion of the county roll that was within a city; (2) the state board's function was to determine a fair rate for the distribution of benefits and if there was disagreement, the remedy was an article 78 proceeding or a protest at the state board's annual hearings; (3) a refusal to recognize the county as an assessing unit was a denial of equal protection of the law to the county's citizens; and (4) the state rates were statistically adequate, legally operative, and fairly representative when weighed against any other known method because it permitted a petitioner to have sought relief in the courts without prohibitive cost.


OUTCOME: The court denied the board's motions. The court decided the applicable equalization ratios to be applied for each year that was under review.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- real property tax assessment -- petitioner real property owners are not required to appraise all selected sample parcels in inequality proceeding against respondent Board of Assessors of County of Nassau pursuant to subdivision 3 of section 720 of Real Property Tax Law and may use State Board of Equalization and Assessment (SBEA) ratios after 1969 or cross-examination or rebuttal, and adequacy of method of proof is within discretion of court -- applicable SBEA rates are presumptively correct unless shown to be completely biased or improperly obtained -- SBEA denied respondent due process in excluding it from formal appearance in hearings to protect rates, since respondent is taxing district entitled to standing -- SBEA sampling of only 80% of property classifications and rule requiring resampling of no more than two-thirds thereof results in downward bias, as does procedure of increasing number of appraisals when there is substantial difference between market value and SBEA estimates; downward bias is offset to degree by use of increasing market values two to three years prior to SBEA rate formulation -- while SBEA methodology has many deficiencies, it is as sound as  [***2] has been possible and is sanctioned by Court of Appeals, and State rates are, accordingly found to be statistically accurate and legally operative.

1. The failure of petitioner real property owners to appraise all selected sample parcels as provided in subdivision 3 of section 720 of the Real Property Tax Law is not fatal to petitioners' inequality proceeding against respondent Board of Assessors of the County of Nassau, in which establishment of the ratio of assessment to full value of all other properties in the tax district is necessary. The sample parcel method is costly and time consuming, and litigants in an inequality proceeding may use either sample parcels, State Board of Equalization and Assessment (SBEA) ratios after 1969 or may rely upon cross-examination or rebuttal with respect to the parcels. Neither side may dictate the method of proof, the adequacy of which is within the discretion of the trial court.

2. Unless the SBEA rates applicable to a tax district are shown to be completely biased or improperly obtained, such rates are presumptively correct and there is, accordingly, no burden on petitioners to show that the rates were validly established.

3. The respondent [***3] has been improperly excluded from formal appearances at hearings according taxing districts an opportunity to protest SBEA equalization rates. The contention of the SBEA that respondent is not a taxing district entitled to standing misinterprets article 12 of the Real Property Tax Law and fails to recognize the Nassau County Government Law. Respondents assess all real property in the county and represent the taxing district, since town assessors have been abolished. Denial of a hearing violates due process.

4. The SBEA rule, that only classifications of property comprising 80% of the total assessed values of the taxing unit will be sampled, results in a downward bias in ratio by excluding high ratio properties, as does the "two-thirds rule", which requires that not more than two thirds of the parcels sampled be parcels sampled in a previous survey. The procedure of using an increased number of appraisals when there is a substantial difference between market value and the SBEA's estimated new value forces a further preconception of increased market value. Nevertheless, such bias is offset to a degree by the use of increasing market values two to three years prior to formulation [***4] of the State rate.

5. While the SBEA methodology has many deficiencies, it is as sound as has been possible and has been sanctioned by the Court of Appeals ( Guth Realty v Gingold, 34 NY2d 440). Accordingly, the State rates are found to be statistically accurate, legally operative and fairly representative compared to any other known method.

 

1293 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Keystone Associates v. State


Claim No. 49592


Court of Claims of New York
