82 Misc. 2d 620; 371 N.Y.S.2d 814; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2741



July 23, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant lessees sought a determination of damages and legal fees on its claim of a de facto taking by defendant state, which had resulted from the state's enactment of a statute that established a corporation to acquire an old building on the lessee's property and refused to issue a permit to demolish it.


OVERVIEW: The 50-year term lease provided that the lessees were to demolish the old building and erect a new one, but the state withheld issuance of the demolition permit for eight months. The court determined that the state's unauthorized action resulted in damages that included the loss of rent for the eight month period of the taking, plus the additional cost of construction occasioned by the delay, plus the loss of profit from the new building for the period of the delay in its completion. Because the objective was to make the lessees whole, the state's damages were mitigated by the higher rents that the lessees subsequently received due to the delay. The court exercised its discretion and awarded legal fees incurred by the lessees in challenging the state's taking based on a lack of valid authorization.


OUTCOME: The court awarded damages to the lessees for the loss of rental value, the increased cost of construction of a new building, and loss of profit from the new building for the period of the demolition delay. The court also awarded legal fees incurred in having the statute that authorized the taking declared unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] State -- temporary appropriation of property -- measure of damages -- claimants, which under lease with Metropolitan Opera Association, agreed to demolish "Old Met" and erect 40-story office building on site, were improperly delayed eight months in proceeding with demolition and construction work as result of unconstitutional legislative act whereby corporation was created with powers of condemnation for purposes of acquiring and preserving "Old Met" (L 1966, ch 691); claimants are entitled to compensation for increased cost of construction and its loss of profits for period of delay; measure of damages is not limited to rental value of vacant land (see Keystone Assoc. v State of New York, 39 AD2d 176, affd 33 NY2d 848) -- State's damages are mitigated since delay in completion of building caused claimant to benefit from higher rental market -- claimant is awarded $ 150,000 for legal fees incurred in having statute authorizing taking declared unconstitutional; legal expenses incurred with respect to instant claim are not allowable.

1. In 1966, the Metropolitan Opera Association moved its opera performances from its old opera house in New York City to the new facility at Lincoln [***2] Center. The association then entered into a 50-year lease for the "Old Met" wherein the lessees agreed to demolish the old building and erect a large office building on the site. Demolition was to start within six months of delivery of possession to the lessee and completion of the 40-story building was to be within three years of such delivery. The association was to receive stipulated rentals and at the end of the lease, it would own the building as well as continue its ownership of the land. The rental for the first four years was $ 200,000 per year. Claimants, a limited partnership, are the assignees of the lease. Claimants obtained possession on May 10, 1966, and made an application for a demolition permit to the Superintendent of Buildings of the City of New York on May 16, 1966. However, as the result of an unconstitutional legislative act whereby a corporation was created with powers of condemnation for the purpose of acquiring and preserving the "Old Met" (L 1966, ch 691), the demolition permit was not issued until January 17, 1967, eight months after application had been made. Claimants received $ 154,700 of the $ 200,000 deposited by the corporation as security.  [***3] Claimants are entitled to damages for the eight month appropriation of their property by the State (see Keystone Assoc. v State of New York, 39 AD2d 176, affd 33 NY2d 848). The measure of damages is not limited to the rental value of the vacant land; therefore, claimants were not adequately compensated by the receipt of $ 154,700 from the $ 200,000 deposited by the corporation as security. Claimants are entitled to compensation for the increased cost of construction and its loss of profits for the period of the delay in completion of its building which were caused by the unauthorized action of the State.

2. However, the State's damages are mitigated since claimants, as the result of a higher rental market during the eight-month delay in completion of the building, received higher rentals than would have been received if the building had been completed eight months earlier. The basic object is to make claimants whole. The eight-month profit loss plus the increased cost of construction total $ 4,988,300. From this figure the computed present value of the additional rental income over a 10-year lease term of $ 4,361,492, is subtracted leaving an award rounded to $ 626,800. From [***4] such $ 626,800, the $ 150,000 principal sum which claimant received from the security deposit must be subtracted. The resultant award figure is $ 476,800 plus 6% interest from January 1, 1970.

3. Claimants are awarded $ 150,000 as reasonable counsel fees and legal expenses incurred in having the statute authorizing the taking declared unconstitutional, including expenses incurred in finally obtaining the demolition permit. Counsel fees and legal expenses incurred with respect to the instant claim are not allowable.

 

1294 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Circle Cinema, Inc. v. Colonie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


82 Misc. 2d 527; 371 N.Y.S.2d 344; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2722



July 22, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion of the plaintiff is granted and the defendants are ordered to return the seized items to the plaintiff.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a theater, filed a motion brought on by an order to show cause for a preliminary injunction enjoining defendants, a town and certain officials, from continuing the seizure of certain films and projectors and from seizing any additional film or equipment of plaintiff in use at said premises. Defendants had acted under the aegis of N.Y. Penal Law § 410.00.


OVERVIEW: The court granted a motion of plaintiff, a theater, brought on by an order to show cause for a preliminary injunction enjoining defendants, a town and certain officials, from continuing the seizure of certain films and projectors seized at plaintiff's premises. The court found that the seizure by police officers without the authority of a constitutionally sufficient warrant was plainly a form of prior restraint and unreasonable under U.S. Const. amend. XIV. Here, the procedure outlined in N.Y. Penal Law § 410.00 and followed by defendants under which the police officers viewed the films in question and found them to be pornographic allegedly showing acts of sexual intercourse or acts of sexual perversion as violating the statute, without any inquiry by judicial authority into the factual basis for the officers' conclusion, was a procedure which fell short of the constitutional requirements demanding the necessary sensitivity to freedom of expression.


OUTCOME: The motion of plaintiff was granted and the defendants were ordered to return the seized items to plaintiff because the seizure of the items without the authority of a constitutionally sufficient warrant was a form of prior restraint.


HEADNOTES

Searches and seizures -- seizure of movie films -- acting pursuant to authority of section 410.00 of Penal Law, police officers viewed films at movie theatre, concluded they were pornographic, seized them, and delivered them to District Attorney -- seized items must be returned to owner of theatre -- such seizure by police officers without authority of constitutionally sufficient warrant is form of prior restraint and unreasonable under Fourth Amendment standards -- procedure outlined in section 410.00 of Penal Law falls short of constitutional requirements.

Acting pursuant to the authority of section 410.00 of the Penal Law, police officers viewed certain films at a movie theatre, concluded that they were pornographic, and, without obtaining a warrant, seized them and delivered them to the District Attorney. The seized items must be returned to the owner of the theatre. Such a seizure by police officers without the authority of a constitutionally sufficient warrant is a form of prior restraint and unreasonable under Fourth Amendment standards. The procedure [***2] outlined in section 410.00 of the Penal Law falls short of the constitutional requirements demanding necessary sensitivity to freedom of expression.

 

1295 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hall v. Hall


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Schenectady County


82 Misc. 2d 814; 372 N.Y.S.2d 344; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2692



July 22, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After petitioner former wife obtained an order that modified the parties' divorce decree so as to obligate respondent former husband to pay the wife alimony until she remarried, the husband filed an action to have the alimony provision annulled, under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 248, on the grounds that the wife had been habitually living with another man and holding herself out as his wife.


OVERVIEW: The parties separation agreement provided for support payments to the wife and was incorporated in the divorce decree. In the wife's subsequent enforcement proceeding, the separation agreement was abrogated and the decree was modified to provide for alimony payments to the wife until she remarried. In the husband's § 248 action, the court ruled that by showing that the wife and her live-in companion executed a lease together as husband wife and were in fact living together, the husband clearly established the factual elements required to invoke § 248. The court rejected the wife's claim that the husband was barred from invoking § 248 because he voluntary stipulated to the modification of the divorce decree. The court ruled that the stipulation merged with the judgment and did not bar further modification of the modified decree. The court reduced the husband's alimony obligation after it balanced the statutory grounds for annulment and the wife's use of the payments for her and her companion's joint living expenses with the wife's inability to support herself and the fact that the separation agreement, had it remained in effect, would have barred annulment.


OUTCOME: The court reduced the husband's alimony obligation.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and wife -- alimony and allowances -- respondent established factual elements for annulment of alimony under section 248 of Domestic Relations Law, upon showing that alimony payments are being applied to joint living expenses of petitioner and man with whom she is living as man and wife -- voluntary stipulation, in prior enforcement proceeding, to pay alimony until petitioner's death or remarriage does not constitute binding contract, since pretrial stipulation merges in judgment -- fair balancing of statutory grounds under section 248 of Domestic Relations Law with length of marriage, inability of petitioner to support herself and fact that nonmerger of separation agreement would have barred annulment of alimony requires that alimony be reduced under section 236 of Domestic Relations Law rather than annulled.

1. Respondent has established the requisite factual elements to invoke the applicable discretionary provisions of section 248 of the Domestic Relations Law in a proceeding to annul the alimony provision of a prior divorce decree, having shown that the alimony payments are being applied to the joint living expenses of petitioner and the man with whom she is living [***2] as man and wife.

2. Respondent's voluntary stipulation, in a prior enforcement proceeding, to pay alimony until petitioner's death or remarriage, does not constitute a binding contract barring modification under section 248 or 236 of the Domestic Relations Law, since a pretrial stipulation merges in the judgment and does not survive it.

3. A fair balancing of the statutory grounds under section 248 of the Domestic Relations Law with the inability of petitioner to support herself, the fact that nonmerger of the separation agreement would have barred annulment of alimony and the length of the marriage requires that, under the broad discretion granted in section 236 of the Domestic Relations Law, alimony be reduced rather than annulled.

 

1296 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Ellis v. New York State Comm'r of Motor Vehicles


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


83 Misc. 2d 224; 372 N.Y.S.2d 134; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2881



July 21, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner driver brought a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 by an order to show cause to declare N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 332 unconstitutional and, specifically, to reverse an order of respondent State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, suspending the driver's operator license and automobile registration for his failure to pay a default judgment for property damage that arose out of the operation of his automobile.


OVERVIEW: Three years after the accident, the default judgment was obtained and two months thereafter, the driver was served an order of suspension of his operator's license. The driver contended that § 332 was unconstitutional because it did not serve a legitimate governmental purpose in the regulation of vehicular traffic on state highways and further, procedurally, was unlawful in that its sanctions became operative without any requirement of a hearing before the Commissioner. Finding that the statute was entitled to a strong presumption of regularity and validity as an enactment of the legislature and that its predecessor designation had expressly been held constitutional by the United States Supreme Court, the court upheld the statute and dismissed the driver's petition seeking a declaration of its unconstitutionality. In so doing, the court found that the cases upon which the driver relied were inapposite and that the driver could have obtained a hearing of his liability by answering the civil judgment cause. By his failure to defend in the civil case, the driver forfeited his right to a hearing on the merits and the Commissioner was not obligated to provide such a hearing.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the driver's petition.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- suspension of license for failure to pay judgment -- statute (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 332) which permits suspension of operator's license and automobile registration for failure to pay judgment for property damage resulting from operation of motor vehicle is not unconstitutional -- not proper case for class action.

1. A petition in a proceeding to reverse an order of the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles suspending petitioner's operator's license and automobile registration because of his failure to pay a certain judgment for property damage arising out of the operation of his motor vehicle is dismissed. The statute which permits such suspension in those circumstances (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 332) is not unconstitutional. It is not unreasonable to enforce a public policy that irresponsible drivers shall not be permitted to injure others using the highway without responding in compensation or damages.

2. The judgment was taken by default. In such case petitioner forfeited his right to a hearing on the merits.

3. In any event, this is not a proper case for class action.

 

1297 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Shing


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


83 Misc. 2d 462; 371 N.Y.S.2d 322; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2924



July 17, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, pursuant to CPL 710.60 (subd 3), the motions to suppress the seized articles are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed motions to dismiss the informations charging them with crimes of promoting gambling and possession of gambling devices in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 225.05, 225.30, alleging that the statutes were unconstitutional and the state was guilty of discriminatory prosecution. Defendants also filed motions for preliminary hearings pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.75 and for the suppression of evidence.


OVERVIEW: After a series of raids in Chinatown carried out by police officers armed with search warrants, defendants sought to dismiss the accusatory instruments charging them with crimes of promoting gambling and possession of gambling devices. In the alternative, they filed motions for preliminary hearings and the suppression of evidence. The court refused to dismiss the informations on the ground that the statutes were unconstitutional, holding that they were not vague because they gave notice to defendants of the forbidden conduct. The court also denied the motions to dismiss on the grounds of discriminatory prosecution because defendants failed to present evidentiary facts in support of their claim. However, the court granted defendants' motions for a preliminary hearing, holding that the portion of § 170.75 that excluded those charged with gambling crimes from the right to a hearing to determine reasonable cause was unconstitutional as violative of the Equal Protection Clause. Finally, the court denied the motions to suppress evidence after determining that the search warrants and accompanying affidavits were not too indefinite.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions to dismiss informations charging them with crimes of promoting gambling and possession of gambling devices and denied the motions to suppress evidence seized pursuant to warrants. However, the court granted the motions for preliminary hearings to determine reasonable cause.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- gambling -- defendants' motions to dismiss accusatory instruments charging them with promoting gambling and possession of gambling devices (Penal Law, §§ 225.05, 225.30), are denied since statutory definition of advancing gambling activity is not void for vagueness -- no evidentiary facts were submitted to support defendants' charge that People were guilty of selective and discriminatory prosecution -- defendants have right to preliminary hearings since that part of CPL 170.75 which excludes such hearings to those charged with gambling offenses is violative of equal protection -- motion to suppress evidence is denied since search warrants and accompanying affidavits are not too indefinite regarding phrase "any other person present" in warrants.

1. Arrested in a series of raids and charged with promoting gambling and possession of gambling devices (Penal Law, §§ 225.05, 225.30), defendants made omnibus motions seeking determinations that the statutes are unconstitutional and that the People were guilty of selective enforcement, or in the alternative, that they [***2] be granted a preliminary hearing and that the evidence seized be suppressed. With the exception of a finding of a right to a preliminary hearing, the motions are denied. The statutory definition of advancing gambling activity (Penal Law, § 225.00, subd 4), which is found in both of the statutes under which defendants were charged, is not void for vagueness. The term "materially aids" has its everyday meaning, is therefore not unconstitutionally vague, and the conduct penalized is sufficiently identified.

2. The motion to dismiss upon the grounds that the People were guilty of selective and discriminatory prosecution is denied. To invoke the defense of discriminatory prosecution one must prove that the selection of the defendants for prosecution was deliberately based on their race or religion, and no evidentiary facts were submitted in support of this.

3. Defendants have a right to a preliminary hearing since that part of CPL 170.75 which excludes such hearings to those charged with violating article 225 of the Penal Law (gambling offenses), while not violative of the Fourth Amendment, is in violation of the equal protection clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions. All [***3] persons accused of misdemeanors, regardless of type, volume or punishment imposed, are similarly situated with respect to the primary statutory objective of CPL 170.75, which is to grant defendants an early hearing to see if there is reasonable cause to believe that they have committed a crime. Whatever differences to exist between gambling crimes and other crimes, they are not reasonably related to the purposes of this act.

4. The motion to suppress evidence seized in the raids is denied since the search warrants and accompanying affidavits are not too indefinite regarding the phrase "any other person present" in the warrants. The location of the premises, the descriptions, and the type of activity alleged to have been observed clearly reduced any risk that an innocent person would be swept up. A hearing to determine the truthfulness of the affidavits upon which the warrants were issued is denied since defendants' allegations of facts are not supported as required by CPL 710.60 (subd 1).

 

1298 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re H.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Bronx County


83 Misc. 2d 55; 371 N.Y.S.2d 335; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2802



July 17, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the Commissioner of the Department of Social Services, filed an action on behalf of respondent mother's children, seeking relief for the mother's neglect of the children.The corporation counsel requested the court to issue a warrant of arrest, and the mother's attorney sought the issuance of a stayed warrant.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner filed a neglect petition, alleging that the mother's four children were neglected. After the mother was served with two summons, the court issued a stayed warrant of arrest for the mother. Several days later, the court ordered that the warrant be executed. Several days later, the warrant was vacated. The mother later appeared, and the petition was served on her. After the matter was adjourned to another date, the mother failed to appear. The maternal grandmother appeared, and the children were paroled to her custody. The corporation counsel requested the court to issue a warrant of arrest for the mother, and the mother's attorney sought the issuance of a stayed warrant. In declining to issue a stayed warrant, the court held that stayed warrants were unconstitutional because there was no legal authority or jurisdiction for them and they amounted to judicial blackmail.


OUTCOME: The court declined to issue a stayed warrant. The court signed an order for a warrant of arrest.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Arrest -- "stayed" warrant -- Family Court Act ( § 153) provides for warrants of arrest to compel attendance at court hearing -- no statutory provision for "stayed warrant" -- such warrants would contravene constitutional rights -- court will not sign one.

The Family Court Act ( § 153) provides for warrants of arrest "to secure or compel the attendance of an adult respondent or child or any other person whose testimony or presence at a hearing or proceeding is deemed by the Court to be necessary". Nowhere in the law is there provision for a "stayed warrant", which is issued as a threat to force a witness to appear after letters and summonses have been ignored. A "stayed warrant" contravenes respondent's constitutional rights and will not be signed by the court. The court does, however, sign a warrant of arrest.

 

1299 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Pendleton v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Wyoming County


83 Misc. 2d 503; 371 N.Y.S.2d 316; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2930



July 16, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, it is ordered, that the petition is granted and the relator is ordered discharged from custody forthwith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus on the grounds that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 450.20, which allowed the state to appeal as of right from a trial order of dismissal, was unconstitutional, and, accordingly, an original appeal by the state and a subsequent retrial after the first dismissal constituted double jeopardy.


OVERVIEW: The court granted relator's petition for a writ of habeas corpus on the grounds of double jeopardy and relator was ordered discharged from custody. N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 450.20, which had been used by respondent, the district attorney, to appeal as of right a trial judge's dismissal of murder charges against relator and to subsequently obtain conviction in a second trial, had recently been ruled unconstitutional on double jeopardy grounds. Respondent's original appeal and subsequent retrial after the first dismissal was double jeopardy. Accordingly, relator's conviction and sentence were illegal and void. The court found that relator could not have intelligently and voluntarily waived a double jeopardy claim since neither he nor the various judges involved in the case knew that he had such a defense. Habeas corpus was the proper remedy on relator's claim of double jeopardy.


OUTCOME: The court granted relator's petition for a writ of habeas corpus and relator was ordered discharged from custody because respondent's original appeal and the retrial constituted double jeopardy.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- former jeopardy -- where defendant was tried for murder and Trial Judge dismissed charges on ground of insufficient proof to corroborate defendant's confession, People could not appeal since new trial would result in double jeopardy ( United States v Jenkins, 420 U.S. 358; People v Goldfarb, 213 NY 664) -- CPL 450.20 which allowed prior appeal is unconstitutional.

1. The Trial Judge dismissed the charges, where defendant was tried for murder, on the ground there was insufficient proof to corroborate defendant's confession. Upon appeal, the Appellate Division found that there was sufficient evidence for the case to go to the jury and the Court of Appeals affirmed that decision. Defendant was retried and found guilty of manslaughter in the first degree and has appealed to the Appellate Division. In the meantime the United States Supreme Court ruled ( United States v Jenkins, 420 U.S. 358) that, if there is a Judge's dismissal following a trial, the People cannot appeal since the new trial would result in double jeopardy. A petition for a [***2] writ of habeas corpus is granted and relator is ordered discharged from custody. Upon the prior appeal to the Court of Appeals, the question of double jeopardy was not passed upon. Since 1912 it has been a New York rule that a trial order of dismissal bars any appeal by the People because of double jeopardy. (Cf. People v Goldfarb, 213 NY 664.) CPL 450.20 which allows the prior appeal is unconstitutional.

2. Defendant did not waive the right to raise the defense of double jeopardy.

3. Habeas corpus is the proper remedy.

 

1300 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. South Shore Amusements, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Second District, Nassau County


82 Misc. 2d 892; 370 N.Y.S.2d 844; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2838



July 11, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged in eight separate informations with operating certain mechanical rides in violation of Town of Hempstead, N.Y., Ordinances § 105-3(D).


OVERVIEW: Defendant obtained a special event license for the purpose of operating a cerebral palsy fair. Defendant operated certain amusement rides at the fair. Defendant was charged with violating § 105-3(D), which prohibited amusement rides. The prohibition did not apply to the location and site of a certain coliseum. The court held that § 105-3(D) was unconstitutional because it was unreasonable and confiscatory and thus, it violated defendant's due process right to run a legitimate business enterprise.


OUTCOME: The court found the ordinance of which defendant was charged with violating to be unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- ordinance prohibiting operation of mechanical amusement rides -- town ordinance which not only requires that license must be obtained before holding of special event, defined as including bazaar, carnival and fair, but also completely bans mechanical amusement rides, except at specified site, is constitutional insofar as it provides for licensing but unconstitutional insofar as it prohibits operation of mechanical amusement rides.

A town ordinance which not only requires that a license must be obtained before the holding of a special event, defined as including a bazaar, carnival, fair and other amusement of like kind and nature, but also completely bans mechanical amusement rides, except at a specified site, is constitutional insofar as it provides for licensing but is unconstitutional insofar as it prohibits the operation of mechanical amusement rides. That ban is violative of the right to engage in a lawful business, is confiscatory and unreasonable, and cannot be justified as having been imposed in a proper exercise of the town's police power.

 

1301 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Monroe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Bronx County


82 Misc. 2d 850; 370 N.Y.S.2d 1007; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2823



July 8, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the quashing motions are granted for all purposes.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State of New York filed motions to quash the subpoenas of defendants on newspaper reporters and television stations during the evidentiary hearing and trial of defendants for felony gun possession.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were arrested with their boss, a notorious figure in the illegal drug trade, and charged with felony gun possession. The arrests received extensive publicity. Defendants filed subpoenas for various news reports for the purpose of impeaching the statements of police officers during both an evidentiary hearing to suppress evidence and the trial. The State filed motions to quash the subpoenas. The court granted the motions to quash. The court found that the press did not have a testimonial privilege under the First Amendment or under the N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8. The court found that N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 79-h purported to protect the newspapers from contempt, but it still did not grant immunity and, although the court did not reach the issue, the section might be unconstitutional. The court found, however, that the First Amendment provided an inherent right of confidentiality for the gathering and reporting of news. The court found that this right of confidentiality could be overcome by a showing of a defendant's need for a fair trial, but defendants had not made such a showing. The court found that defendants failed to lay a proper foundation for impeachment evidence.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motions to quash defendants' subpoenas for information from the news agencies.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- right of confidentiality of newsmen -- testimonial privilege -- subpoenas served by defendants on reporters for various newspapers and broadcasting stations seeking materials relating to interviews with police officers for purposes of obtaining impeachment evidence are quashed; First Amendment inherent right of confidentiality here outweighs defendants' attempts to impeach prosecution's witnesses; alleged prior inconsistent statements made by police officers were collateral to issues and irrelevant -- right of confidentiality does not rise to level of exemption from testimonial compulsion; newsmen are not entitled to absolute testimonial privilege under free press clause of First Amendment (see Branzburg v Hayes, 408 U.S. 665); New York Shield Law ( Civil Rights Law, § 79-h) does not create privilege exempting reporters from complying with compulsory process.

1. Defendants, the alleged bodyguards of a notorious figure in the illicit drug trade, were arrested on felony gun possession charges. The arrests were widely publicized in the print and broadcast news media. In connection with [***2] this widespread publicity, several police officers, now prosecution witnesses, were interviewed by reporters for the various newspapers and broadcasting stations. Subpoenas served by defendants on various reporters seeking materials such as notes, memoranda and unused television tapes, relating to the interviews with the officers, for the purpose of obtaining impeachment evidence, are quashed. There resides within the First Amendment and its freedom of the press clause an inherent right of confidentiality which attaches to the gathering and reporting of the news. A free press, protected by a moderate amount of privilege of confidentiality of news information and source, insures a free flow of information to the people, and is indispensable to the continued maintenance of our form of Government. This right of confidentiality does not rise to the level of an exemption from testimonial compulsion. Rather, it is a factor which must be taken into account whenever it comes into conflict with the demand of a party for production of evidence in a judicial proceeding. The privilege of confidentiality here outweighs defendants' attempts to impeach the prosecution's witnesses. Defendants [***3] failed to lay a proper foundation for the reception of such impeachment evidence. The alleged prior inconsistent statements made by the police officers were collateral to the issues. The information in the hands of the media was irrelevant.

2. Newsmen are not entitled to an absolute testimonial privilege under the free press clause of the First Amendment immunizing them from the obligation to appear and testify in response to a subpoena issued on behalf of a defendant in a criminal action (see Branzburg v Hayes, 408 U.S. 665). In addition, the New York Shield Law ( Civil Rights Law, § 79-h), which protects members of the press who assert a testimonial privilege from liability to the sanction of contempt, does not create a privilege exempting reporters from complying with compulsory process in trials and hearings. To do so would be to improperly hold that the First Amendment right to gather and publish news is paramount to the rights of an accused in a criminal case to due process, a fair trial and to have compulsory process to obtain evidence in his favor.

 

1302 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kizer


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


83 Misc. 2d 58; 370 N.Y.S.2d 827; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2803



July 7, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion herein is therefore granted to the extent of precluding the District Attorney from offering the prior testimony of the witness at the preliminary hearing to the extent that it identifies the defendant herein as the perpetrator. The motion is denied as to the balance of the testimony for which there was a full and adequate opportunity for cross-examination.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted for the crimes of burglary in the first degree and assault in the first degree. The victim testified at a preliminary hearing, after which he died. The state notified defense counsel of its intention to offer the testimony of the victim at the trial pursuant to the provisions of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 670.10. Before the court was defendant's motion to preclude use of the testimony.


OVERVIEW: At the preliminary hearing, defense counsel had the opportunity to and did fully examine the victim as to the pertinent issues within the scope of the hearing, but was limited concerning the question of identification of his assailants. The court granted defendant's motion to preclude the testimony in part. The court held that to the extent that the opportunity to cross-examine existed within the scope of inquiry at the preliminary hearing, whether or not the defendant availed himself of that opportunity, the testimony was admissible at a subsequent trial. Where, on the other hand, the opportunity for cross-examination was limited by the scope of the proceedings, and cross-examination was restricted on an issue outside the scope of the proceeding, any testimony related to that point in issue would be redacted. Here, the only area in which defense counsel did not have the opportunity for cross-examination was the identification of his assailants. The court ordered that the victim's testimony was admissible, but that any reference to identification of defendant had to be redacted for use at trial.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to preclude the deceased victim's prior testimony to the extent of precluding the people from offering the prior testimony of the victim that identified defendant as the perpetrator. The motion was denied as to the balance of the testimony for which there was a full and adequate opportunity for cross-examination.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- use of testimony after witness' death -- where victim of crime testifies at preliminary hearing, but thereafter dies, and defense counsel had opportunity to and did examine him as to pertinent issues within scope of hearing but was limited concerning question of identification of assailants, defendant's motion to preclude use of testimony at trial is granted to extent of precluding testimony to extent that it identifies defendant as perpetrator -- where testimony relating to identification is to be precluded, admissible testimony is to be redacted so that where defendant is referred to, term "person" will be substituted.

1. Defendant was indicted for burglary and assault and a preliminary hearing was held at which time the victim testified; thereafter the victim died. Defense counsel had the opportunity [***2] to and did fully examine the victim as to the pertinent issues within the scope of the hearing but was limited concerning the question of identification of the assailants by the victim. Upon a motion by defendant to preclude the District Attorney from using the victim's testimony at trial, the motion is granted to the extent of precluding the testimony to the extent that it identifies the defendant as the perpetrator. The motion is denied as to the balance of the testimony for which there was a full and adequate opportunity for cross-examination. Although CPL 670.10 allows testimony given by a witness at the hearing upon a felony complaint to be read into evidence at a subsequent proceeding when the witness has since died, the constitutional right to confrontation must be applied in determining the application of the statute. Thus prior testimony which has been subjected to the test of cross-examination will be admitted to the exclusion of testimony not so endowed.

2. Since "redact" is defined as bringing into presentable literary form, or to revise or edit (as opposed to eliminating), where any testimony relating to the question of identification is to be precluded, the admissible [***3] testimony is to be redacted so that where the defendant is referred to, the term "person" will be substituted. Prior to trial, the court will meet and review the testimony in the presence of counsel for this purpose.

 

1303 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Armani


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Hamilton County


83 Misc. 2d 252; 371 N.Y.S.2d 563; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2889



July 3, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Movant, an attorney who represented defendant by court appointment in a criminal case, filed an application for an allowance of compensation in excess of statutory limits contained in N.Y. County Law § 722-b due to extraordinary circumstances.


OVERVIEW: The attorney was appointed to represent an indigent defendant who had been indicted on various charges that ranged from the unauthorized use of a vehicle to murder. The indictments followed a manhunt that received national and international publicity after a man armed with a gun had four young campers tied to trees in a secluded area of a county. Early in the representation, defendant disclosed to the attorney that he had committed three other murders and knew where bodies of two of those victims were located. This information was disclosed at trial. These circumstances led to a subsequent investigation and charges against the attorney and had a disastrous effect on the attorney's practice. The attorney contended that the events constituted extraordinary circumstances that justified an allowance of compensation in excess of the limits in § 722-b, The court held that the statutory limitation as applied to the circumstances were so grossly unjust as to be unthinkable. The court made a recommendation for disposition of the attorney's claims subject to review of a presiding judge of an appellate court and corrected certain totals of hours spent by the attorney in the petition.


OUTCOME: The court recommended approval of certain payments to the attorney. It directed that its decision was to be forwarded to an appellate court for its action as required by law.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Attorney and client -- compensation -- assigned counsel -- extraordinary energy, time and talent devoted by assigned counsel to defendant's case, circumstances of having to defend themselves against charges resulting from maintaining confidentiality of disclosures of defendant's victims' bodies, and resulting injury to attorneys' law practices constitute extraordinary circumstances justifying compensation exceeding $ 500 limits of section 722-b of County Law.

The extraordinary energy, talent and time devoted by assigned counsel to the defendant's case, the circumstances of having to defend themselves against charges resulting from maintaining confidentiality of the defendant's disclosures of the location of his victims' bodies, and the resulting injury to the attorneys' law practices constitute extraordinary circumstances justifying compensation at the statutory hourly rates exceeding the $ 500 limit of section 722-b of the County Law.

 

1304 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Conroy v. Melton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


82 Misc. 2d 750; 371 N.Y.S.2d 75; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2670



June 30, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petitioner's application is therefore granted to the extent that the court hereby declares null and void respondent's revocation of petitioner's driver's license without prejudice to respondent's right to conduct an administrative hearing, on notice to petitioner, at which he should receive evidence regarding the alleged violation of section 318 of the enactment.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner driver challenged the revocation of his registration and driver's license by respondent, the commissioner of the state department of motor vehicles.


OVERVIEW: The driver was operating a tractor to plow snow from his driveway when an automobile on the adjacent highway went out of control and collided with the tractor. The force of the impact drove the tractor out onto the highway. The driver and the operator of the automobile were cited for violations of the New York Vehicle and Traffic Law and the driver pleaded guilty to driving an unregistered vehicle. The commissioner then revoked the driver's registration and driver's license without a hearing. The driver filed an action challenging the revocation. The court noted that the commissioner routinely relied on unsworn evidence to support his issuance of mandatory revocation notices, so a licensee was forced to seek a postrevocation hearing in the context of a judicial review pursuant to N.Y.C.P.L.R. art. 78. The court held that to interpret N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §§ 318(2)(a), 318(3), 318(5) as authorizing summary revocation of a driver's license on the basis of unverified hearsay evidence without providing the benefit of a prior hearing was violative of a licensee's right to due process.


OUTCOME: The court granted the driver's application to the extent that it declared null and void the commissioner's revocation of his driver's license, without prejudice to the commissioner's right to conduct an administrative hearing.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- revocation of operator's license -- proof of financial security -- due process -- subdivisions 2, 3 and 5 of section 318 of Vehicle and Traffic Law are unconstitutional insofar as Commissioner of Motor Vehicles may revoke driver's license for operating vehicle on public highway while financial security is not in effect prior to receipt of evidence at administrative hearing.

The only time a licensee may be entitled to a hearing before revocation of his license and registration for operating a vehicle on a public highway while financial security is not in effect, in violation of section 318 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, is if he first raises a lack of knowledge that such security was not in effect and the commissioner then exercises his discretion to call a hearing. The commissioner is vested [***2] with authority to revoke a registration and a license upon the receipt of any hearsay evidence. Since continued possession of a driver's license may be essential to a citizen's livelihood, revocation thereof involves State action that adjudicates important interests of the licensee and under the circumstances a license may not be taken away without procedural due process. Accordingly, subdivisions 2, 3 and 5 of section 318 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law are unconstitutional insofar as the commissioner may revoke a license prior to the receipt of evidence at an administrative hearing.

 

1305 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Blount


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


82 Misc. 2d 964; 370 N.Y.S.2d 437; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2859



June 27, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is granted to the extent that the defendant's sentence on June 21, 1974 as a second felony offender is vacated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for an order setting aside a sentence on the grounds that it was illegally imposed. Defendant was sentenced as a second felony offender in accordance with the provisions of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of arson in the second degree. At sentencing under an information alleging a predicate felony conviction, it was established that defendant had been convicted in South Carolina of an assault and battery upon his wife, a felony. Defendant was sentenced as a second felony offender in accordance with § 70.06. Defendant filed a motion for an order setting aside the sentence on the grounds that it was unconstitutional or, at least, not applicable to him. The court granted the motion to the extent that defendant's sentence as a second felony offender was vacated and ordered that defendant be returned to the court for resentencing as a first felony offender. The court, bound by the principles of stare decisis, held that § 70.06, insofar as it provided that a second felony sentence had to be imposed when defendant was previously convicted in any other jurisdiction of an offense for which a sentence to a term of imprisonment in excess of one year or a sentence of death was authorized irrespective of whether such sentence was imposed, was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to the extent that defendant's sentence as a second felony offender was vacated. The court ordered that defendant be returned to the court for resentencing as a first felony offender.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sentence -- second felony offender status -- defendant may not be sentenced under section 70.06 of Penal Law as second felony offender based upon South Carolina conviction for assault and battery committed upon his wife, since minimum conduct constituting such offense would be within exclusive original jurisdiction of Family Court if committed in State of New York; while court is not in accord with reasoning that such status constitutes denial of equal protection, where conduct would not be felony within State, it must follow holding of Third Department of Appellate Division to that effect in People v Morton (48 AD2d 58) in absence of holding by Second Department.

The defendant may not be sentenced under section 70.06 of the Penal Law as a second felony offender based upon a prior South Carolina conviction of the felony of committing assault and battery upon his wife, since the minimum conduct constituting such offense would in New York State be within the exclusive original jurisdiction of the Family Court. Notwithstanding that the court [***2] is not in accord with the argument that grounding second offender status upon out-of-State felony convictions, where the conduct would not have been a felony in New York, constitutes a denial of equal protection, and notwithstanding that the court would be required to look to the minimum conduct necessary to violate the South Carolina statute, rather than to the alleged conduct, the court must follow the holding to that effect of the Third Department of the Appellate Division in People v Morton (48 AD2d 58) in the absence of a holding by the Second Department.

 

1306 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mackey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Suffolk County


82 Misc. 2d 766; 371 N.Y.S.2d 559; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2676



June 26, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment is granted, with leave to the People to resubmit to another Grand Jury.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted in a nine-count consolidated instrument for perjury, N.Y. Penal Law § 210.15; larceny, N.Y. Penal Law § 155.35; and forgery in the second degree. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment for the state's failure to have properly charged the grand jury, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 190.25, subd. 6; 210.20, subd. 1, para. c; 210.35, subds. 1, 5.


OVERVIEW: The grand jury had been read the definition of perjury in the first degree. As to each of the seven counts of larceny, the grand jury was charged that at a specified time, defendant, as attorney for an estate, stole certain monies from the estate. There were no charges as to the degrees of grand larceny, or the definition of specific words used in the statute defining degrees of larceny. There were no charges setting out defendant's rights, powers, or duties as executor. As to the forgery count, the charge given the grand jury consisted of a reading two statutes regarding forgery and portions of a third forgery statute. The court held that under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 190.25, subd. 6 the grand jury had to have received an adequate statement of the law to guide its determination. Although the record showed sufficient evidence to support the indictment, the state failed to prove that a proper charge was given the grand jury. That failure was a substantive prejudicial denial of due process rendering the grand jury proceedings defective, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.35, subd. 5.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment with leave to the state to resubmit to another grand jury.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- instructions to Grand Jury by District Attorney -- failure of District Attorney to properly instruct Grand Jury constituted substantive prejudicial denial of due process rendering Grand Jury proceedings defective; indictment dismissed with leave to resubmit to another Grand Jury -- Grand Jury not unconstitutionally constituted by systematic exclusion of women.

1. On the presentation against defendant of seven counts of grand larceny, one count of perjury and one count of forgery, the District Attorney instructed the Grand Jury by giving brief statements with respect to the first eight counts, reading a definition of perjury and reading three statutes regarding forgery. There were no instructions concerning the degrees of larceny or corroboration of perjury and no instructions covering defendant's rights and duties in his capacity as executor of an estate from which he allegedly stole money. Although the record established that the subsequent indictment was not induced by prosecutorial zeal or misconduct and the evidence was sufficient to [***2] support the indictment, a proper charge was not delivered. The failure to properly instruct the Grand Jury constituted a substantive prejudicial denial of due process rendering the Grand Jury proceedings defective. Accordingly, a motion to dismiss the indictment is granted, with leave to resubmit to another Grand Jury.

2. The contention that the Grand Jury was unconstitutionally constituted by the systematic exclusion of women is without merit.

 

1307 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Duryea


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


82 Misc. 2d 1049; 371 N.Y.S.2d 555; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2776



June 23, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to reargue the portion of an earlier decision that denied his motion to dismiss the indictment against him on the ground that the aggregate weight standard, as applied to methadone, was unconstitutional. Defendant also sought to reargue the issue of cruel and unusual punishment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, a methadone patient, alleged that the aggregate weight standard, as applied to that substance, was unconstitutional. The trial court denied his motion to dismiss the indictment against him on that ground. Thereafter, defendant filed a motion for reargument. The court granted reargument and adhered to its original decision. Defendant asserted that the aggregate weight standard, as applied to the unauthorized possession or sale of small amounts of treatment methadone by patients in the process of rehabilitation, deprived him of equal protection. The court noted that methadone patients had the right to legally possess controlled substances that were the subject of abuse. Moreover, the government and programs functioning under its regulation were the primary suppliers of that substance. Therefore, the government, in order to prevent itself from becoming the unwitting partner of those in whom it had reposed its trust, was allowed to exact a higher penalty from those who trafficked in methadone. Moreover, the punishment prescribed for violations of N.Y. Penal Law art. 220 was not cruel and unusual punishment.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to reargue the issue of the aggregate weight standard, as applied to methadone, and adhered to its earlier decision in that regard. With regard to the issue of cruel and unusual punishment, the court denied defendant's request for reargument.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- dangerous drugs -- aggregate weight standard of article 220 of Penal Law is not irrational in that it results in more stringent penalties for rehabilitation patient seller of single dose of methadone than for seller of single dose of heroin, since contrary result would deny equal protection to other methadone sellers and, since rehabilitation patients are entrusted with legal possession of methadone, there is rational basis to distinguish them from sellers of totally illicit contraband; accordingly, court adheres on reargument to original decision denying defendant's motion to dismiss indictment.

The aggregate weight standard of article 220 of the Penal Law is not irrational in that it results in more stringent penalties for the seller of a single dose of methadone than for the seller of a single dose of heroin. To distinguish rehabilitation patients who sell a single dose of treatment methadone would deny equal protection of the law to other sellers of methadone, while the fact that rehabilitation patients are entrusted by the government with legal possession of methadone provides a rational basis for exacting a higher penalty from them than from those dealing in [***2] totally illicit contraband. Accordingly, the aggregate weight standard is constitutional in its application to methadone, and the court adheres on reargument to its original decision denying the defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.

 

1308 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Green


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


83 Misc. 2d 583; 371 N.Y.S.2d 271; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2943



June 19, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant took an interlocutory appeal from the prosecution's attempt to obtain reciprocal discovery in defendant's trial on charges of attempted assault in the third degree, obstructing governmental administration, and harassment.


OVERVIEW: The prosecution sought discovery of information relating to whom defendant would call to testify at trial and what those witnesses would say. Defendant challenged, contending that the prosecution had no legal entitlement to such data. The court held that: (1) N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 240.20(4) did not provide for unrestricted reciprocal discovery; (2) N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 250.10 and 250.20 imposed duties of notice upon defendant if he intended to rely on certain defenses; (3) the information that the prosecution sought did not constitute "property" exempt from discovery under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 240; (4) the information that the prosecution sought was not discoverable under a bill of particulars; (5) the protections against discovery abuse which N.Y. Crim. Law § 240.20 afforded to defendant meant that he would suffer no constitutional violation by being compelled to disclose the information requested; and (6) because the prospective defense witnesses' birth dates and pretrial statements were equally ascertainable by the prosecution, the prosecution's request was denied as to that information.


OUTCOME: The court granted the prosecution's motion for discovery of the names and addresses of defendant's prospective trial witnesses, but denied the request as to their birthdates and pretrial statements.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- reciprocal discovery -- since pretrial statements of witnesses intended to be called at trial are exempt property within CPL 240.10 (subd 3, par [b]), People's motion for discovery of defendant's witnesses' statements is denied and court modifies its previous order with respect to defendant's motion for discovery to exclude pretrial statements of witnesses made to law enforcement officials; People's request for names and addresses of defendant's witnesses is granted -- requirements that information sought be material to preparation of case and that request be reasonable ( CPL 240.20, subds 3, 4), are not to be strictly construed -- names and addresses of witnesses are "tangible personal or real property" within CPL 240.10 (subd 2) -- grant of reciprocal discovery is not abuse of discretion, nor does it violate constitutional rights of either defendant or codefendant -- court adopts American Bar Association's Project on Standards for Criminal Justice, Standards Relating to Discovery and Procedure Before Trial, so far as consistent with New York law.

1. After defendant entered a plea of not guilty and made a motion for a bill of particulars, the People moved, pursuant [***2] to CPL 240.20 (subd 4), for reciprocal discovery of the names, addresses, birthdates and pretrial statements of witnesses whom the defendant intended to call at trial. Since CPL 240.10 (subd 3, par [b]) defines exempt property to include "records of statements made to such parties, attorneys, or agents by witnesses or prospective witnesses in the case", the court modifies its previous order with respect to defendant's motion for discovery to exclude the pretrial statements of witnesses made to law enforcement officials, and accordingly, the People's demand for statements is also denied. Defendant's request for the names and addresses of witness may be withdrawn if he has not yet received a list of the names and addresses of the People's witnesses. The People's motion for the names and addresses of defendant's witnesses is granted, therefore the request for birthdates is denied.

2. The requirements that the information sought be material to the preparation of the case, and that the request be reasonable ( CPL 240.20, subds 3, 4), are not to be strictly construed since this would put a great burden on both parties.

3. Names and addresses of witnesses are "tangible personal or real [***3] property" within the meaning of CPL 240.10 (subd 2) and thus discoverable under CPL article 240. The courts have never considered a demand for names and addresses of witnesses to belong in a motion for a bill of particulars.

4. Granting reciprocal discovery here is not an abuse of discretion, nor does it result in a deprivation of defendant's constitutional rights, since if defendant is concerned with the possibility of his witnesses being intimidated from testifying by police or prosecutorial interrogation, his remedy is to apply to the court for protective order pursuant to CPL 240.20 (subd 5).

5. The disclosure of the names and addresses of defendant's witnesses does not violate constitutional and statutory rights of the codefendant since he is not deprived of any rights to which he would otherwise be entitled by defendant's having to disclose specified items, as the codefendant is not bound or precluded in any way thereby.

6. The court adopts the American Bar Association's Project on Standards for Criminal Justice, Standards Relating to Discovery and Procedure Before Trial, so far as consistent with New York law.

 

1309 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Skibinski


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


85 Misc. 2d 908; 380 N.Y.S.2d 836; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3333



June 19, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly the motion to dismiss the indictment is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed notice of a motion seeking a verified bill of particulars that specified factual information set forth in the indictment against him. Defendant filed a motion for the dismissal of the indictment against him on the grounds that the grand jury that issued the indictment was illegally and unlawfully constituted and that it was not competent to administer an oath or enter into an investigation.


OVERVIEW: The court granted defendant's motion for a bill of particulars because the time periods involved in the indictment concerned events that had occurred seven or eight years before. Defendant testified before a county grand jury. A judicial decision was rendered that struck the county grand jury pool as it existed at the time of defendant's testimony because there was a systematic exclusion of students as a class and the deliberate exclusion of women, which constituted illegal discrimination. Defendant asserted that he was entitled to dismissal of the indictment because the jury pool was invalidly constituted, although he provided no basis for the claim that he had been deprived of constitutional rights or had been discriminated against. Later, the validity of the grand jury was upheld on the grounds that women had been included in the grand jury and the exclusion of students as a class was insignificant, and an appellate court held that review of the later judicial decision was not proper until an accused was convicted. A new grand jury was empaneled to continue the investigation of the challenged grand jury. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion for a bill of particulars. The court denied defendant's motion for a dismissal of the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- improperly constituted Grand Jury -- upon motion by defendant to dismiss indictment upon ground that since jury pool from which Grand Jury before which he testified was found to have been improperly constituted, that his Grand Jury was also improperly constituted and therefore without authority to administer oath or enter upon investigation, motion is denied; validity of Grand Jury at issue was upheld and that decision has been further upheld as decisional law of forum -- defendant's motion for verified bill of particulars with regard to discovery of names of witnesses and periods of time involved in alleged crimes is granted.

1. In October of 1973, defendant testified before an Erie County Grand Jury. In June of 1974, the jury pool from which that Grand Jury was drawn was declared to have been improperly constituted inasmuch as there had been a systematic exclusion of students as a class and deliberate exclusion of women, which constituted unlawful discrimination ( People v Attica Bros., 79 Misc 2d 492). Upon a motion by defendant to dismiss the indictment against him upon the ground that since [***2] the jury pool was found to be improperly constituted, the Grand Jury before which he testified was also improperly constituted and therefore without authority to administer the oath or enter upon the investigation, the motion is denied. The validity of the Erie County Grand Jury at issue was upheld on August 26, 1974 in People v Wroblewski, and that decision has been upheld as the "decisional law of the forum". Further, the First Department has stated that the retroactive application of Taylor v Louisiana (419 U.S. 522) would do little to vindicate the Sixth Amendment interests at stake, and would have a substantial impact on the administration of criminal justice. ( Alessi v Nadjari, 47 AD2d 189, 192.)

2. Defendant's motion for a verified bill of particulars with regard to discovery of names of witnesses and the periods of time involved in the alleged crimes is granted since some of the periods of time involved in the indictment may be events which occurred seven or eight years ago.

 

1310 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Moke Realty Corp. v. Whitestone Sav. & Loan Asso.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


82 Misc. 2d 396; 370 N.Y.S.2d 377; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2647



June 18, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff mortgagee sought to recover the proceeds of a fire insurance policy under a standard fire insurance loss payable clause on the grounds that the price it paid for the mortgaged property at a foreclosure sale was less than the total indebtedness of the mortgagor to the mortgagee. The mortgagee asserted that it was entitled to the deficiency between the sale price of the property and the mortgagor's indebtedness.


OVERVIEW: The mortgagor owned a building, which carried fire insurance and was located on the mortgaged property. The building was destroyed by fire. The mortgagor defaulted on its payments to the mortgagee. The mortgagee foreclosed on the property. The mortgagee purchased the building and property at a foreclosure sale, but there remained a large difference between the value of the property discharged by the sale and the mortgagor's indebtedness. The mortgagee did not move for a deficiency judgment within 90 days of the delivery of the deed, as required by N.Y. Real Prop. Acts. Law § 1371, but sought recovery of the insurance proceeds. The court held that the mortgagee's failure to comply with the deficiency judgment provision of § 1371 was fatal to its claim. The mortgagee was not necessarily entitled to the proceeds, even if it complied with § 1371, because if the property was determined to be worth at least the value of the mortgagor's total indebtedness, the mortgagee was not entitled to a deficiency judgment, regardless of the price paid at the foreclosure sale. Section 1371 did not violate U.S. Const. art. I, § 10 because it did not wipe out a debt that was due.


OUTCOME: The court denied the mortgagee's claim to the insurance proceeds. The court held that the mortgagor was entitled to the proceeds.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Insurance -- fire insurance -- insurable interest -- failure on part of mortgagee who, at mortgage foreclosure sale held subsequent to fire in mortgaged premises, purchased property for less than amount of mortgage debt, to timely move for entry of deficiency judgment, resulted in full satisfaction of mortgage debt, by operation of section 1371 of Real Property Actions and Proceedings Law, and consequently, in termination of mortgagee's insurable interest -- said section 1371 is not violative of constitutional prohibition against impairment of contractual obligations.

1. At a mortgage foreclosure sale held subsequent to a fire in the mortgaged premises, the mortgagee purchased the property for less than the amount of the mortgage debt, and failed to timely move for entry of a deficiency judgment, as provided for in section 1371 of the Real Property Actions and Proceedings Law, which also provides that, if no such motion is made, "the proceeds of the sale regardless of amount shall be deemed to be in full satisfaction of the mortgage debt and no right to recover any deficiency in any action or proceeding shall exist". Its failure to make such a motion resulted in full satisfaction [***2] of the mortgage debt by operation of law, and, consequently, in termination of the mortgagee's insurable interest. The owner of the property is entitled to the fire insurance proceeds.

2. Section 1371 of the Real Property Actions and Proceedings Law is not violative of the constitutional prohibition against impairment of contractual obligations. Under the fire insurance contract, loss is payable to the mortgagee "as interest may appear", and the mortgagee's interest is coextensive with the debt it is owed. The statute did not wipe out that debt, but, rather, specified the remedy for enforcing it, and, by failing to use that remedy, the mortgagee, in effect, acknowledged that its debt had been satisfied by its taking the property.

 

1311 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Nassau Ins. Co. v. Ebin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


82 Misc. 2d 513; 369 N.Y.S.2d 994; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2717



June 18, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The petitioner's motion for leave to renew and for reconsideration is granted and, on renewal and reconsideration, the original decision denying the motion to stay arbitration is adhered to.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner filed a motion for leave to renew and reconsider its prior motion to stay arbitration of a no-fault insurance claim by respondents, which had been denied by lower court pursuant to N.Y. Ins. Law §§ 675(2),672,21, arguing that policy notice requirements and regulations were not complied with by respondents.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner insurer was involved in arbitration with respondents, and filed a motion to stay arbitration of a no-fault insurance claim filed by respondents. Lower court determined that threshold questions relating to alleged conditions precedent to recovery under no-fault insurance policies were to be decided by arbitration rather than by the courts, pursuant to N.Y. Ins. Law §§ 675(2),672,21. Petitioner then filed for leave to renew and reconsider its prior motion. Court held that the previous determination that the questions raised by petitioner were to be resolved by arbitrators would stand. Further, court held that the arbitration provisions involved in the case were not unreasonable and fit in with one of the acknowledged purposes of the no-fault law, which was to relieve the courts of the congestion caused by automobile cases. Thus, court granted petitioner's motion for leave to renew and for reconsideration, and on renewal and reconsideration, affirmed original decision.


OUTCOME: Court granted petitioner's motion for leave to renew and reconsider, but affirmed lower court's decision to deny petitioner's motion for stay of arbitration, holding that questions raised by petitioner were properly decided by arbitrator and arbitration provisions in case were reasonable.


HEADNOTES

Arbitration -- no-fault insurance -- questions relating to conditions precedent to recovery under no-fault insurance policies are to be decided by arbitration -- arbitration provisions under statute and approved form policy are not unreasonable and do not deprive petitioner insurance company of due process.

1. Based on the arbitration provision of the Insurance Law ( § 675, subd 2) and the arbitration clause in the approved policy form promulgated pursuant to the Insurance Law ( §§ 21, 672), question relating to alleged conditions precedent to recovery under no-fault insurance policies, including compliance with notice requirements, are to be decided by arbitration rather than by the courts.

2. Under the police power, the State may regulate the insurance business and the contents of insurance contracts so long as such regulation is reasonable and does not deprive an insurance company of due process of law. The present arbitration provisions are not unreasonable and fit in with one [***2] purpose of the no-fault law, i.e., to relieve the courts of congestion caused by automobile cases. In addition, petitioner insurance company's constitutional right to reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard are protected ( CPLR 7511).

 

1312 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. S.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


82 Misc. 2d 884; 370 N.Y.S.2d 385; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2835



June 18, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a juvenile, contested the imposition of a sentence of five years' probation for a class A-III felony conviction. Defendant asserted that the sentence was improper in light of the fact that he had been adjudicated a youthful offender.


OVERVIEW: The court had previously determined that defendant was a youthful offender but that he was not an eligible youth. The court had determined that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10, insofar as it removed youthful offender status solely on the basis of the crime charged in the indictment, was unconstitutional. The court reviewed the relevant provisions of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.20(3) and N.Y. Penal Law §§ 60.01, 60.02, 60.03, 65.00(1) to determine if five years' probation was a proper sentence. The legislative intention of N.Y. Penal Law § 60.02 was to limit the previous discretion to sentence a youthful offender as though he was an adult. Lifetime probation under N.Y. Penal Law § 65.00(3)(a)(ii) was not applicable to defendant. The court imposed five years' probation on defendant although § 65.00(3)(a)(i) permitted the sentence for felonies other than class A-III. Sentencing under § 65.00(3)(a)(i) was appropriate because there was no other applicable sentencing provision suitable in light of the determination that it was unconstitutional to sentence defendant as an adult based on the crime charged in the indictment.


OUTCOME: The court sentenced defendant to a period of five years' probation.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- dangerous drugs -- youthful offender -- sentence of probation -- defendant, who has been adjudicated youthful offender with underlying narcotics class A-III felony conviction (see People v. Ruben S., 81 Misc 2d 305), may properly be sentenced to term of probation for five years (Penal Law, § 65, subd 3, par [a], cl [i]); since there is no underlying sentence statute that would be applicable to defendant youthful offender, whose underlying offense rests upon sale of narcotics, only proper approach is to apply maximum five-year probationary period which can be considered for conviction of felony.

Previously, CPL 720.10, which eliminated consideration for youthful offender at the time of indictment for a class A-III felony, was declared unconstitutional (see People v Ruben S., 81 Misc 2d 305). Defendant, who was thereafter adjudicated a youthful offender with an underlying narcotics A-III felony conviction, may properly be sentenced to a term of probation for five years under section 65.00 (subd 3, par [a], cl [i]) of the Penal Law which permits a period of probation for five years for felonies other than class A-III. Since there is no underlying sentencing [***2] statute that would be applicable to youthful offenders whose underlying offense rests upon the sale of narcotics, conviction of which would be a class A-I, A-II or A-III felony, the only proper approach is to apply the maximum five-year probationary period which can be considered for the conviction of a felony. The sentence of five years' probation for cases that properly meet the criteria recited in section 65.00 (subd 1, par [a]) is consistent with a fair interpretation of existing and available law.

 

1313 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York State Hairdressers & Cosmetologists Asso. v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


83 Misc. 2d 154; 369 N.Y.S.2d 965; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2869



June 16, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, licensed hairdressers and beauty shop owners, sought a judgment in the declaratory judgment action against defendants, Secretary of State of New York, and a barber association, to declare N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 401(5) unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs brought a declaratory judgment action against defendants to declare N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 401(5) unconstitutional. Plaintiffs contended that the restrictions against hairdressers cutting male's hair violated state and federal equal protection laws. The court found that the restrictions were unconstitutional. The court held that the classification made was not based upon any reasonable distinction and was illusory. The court held that no rational basis existed for the restriction.


OUTCOME: The court found the restriction of a statute against the cutting of hair of males by hairdressers and cosmetologists, unconstitutional in plaintiffs' declaratory judgment action against defendants.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Licenses -- haircutting of males by licensed hairdressers -- statutory scheme which authorizes licensed barbers to cut hair of both males and females ( General Business Law, § 431, subd 4, par [a]) while restricting licensed hairdressers and cosmetologists to cut hair of females only ( General Business Law, § 401, subd 5) is unconstitutional; male who wishes to have his hair cut by hairdresser and is compelled by law to have barber cut his hair suffers infringement upon his personal rights as result of statutory classifications which are not based upon any reasonable distinctions; fact that barbers must take 400 hours in haircutting in barber school while beauty school curriculum only allocates 92 hours to haircutting, is not significant on issue of constitutionality; hairdresser who is trained and qualified to cut hair of female is qualified to cut chemically similar hair of male -- statutory classifications do not promote health of patrons; rules and regulations governing sanitation in barber shops and in beauty parlors are identical.

1. The New York statutory scheme which authorizes licensed barbers to cut the hair of both males and females ( General Business Law, § 431,  [***2] subd 4, par [a]) while restricting licensed hairdressers and cosmetologists to cut the hair of females only ( General Business Law, § 401, subd 5) is violative of the equal protection guarantees of the Federal and State Constitutions since the classification made is not based upon any reasonable distinction and is illusory. The male who wishes to have his hair cut by a hairdresser and is compelled by law to have a barber cut his hair, suffers an infringement upon his personal rights.
