In order to be licensed as a cosmetologist, a person must attend a duly licensed beauty school and take 1,000 hours of instruction including 92 hours of haircutting. In order to be licensed as a barber, a candidate must take 1,000 hours of instruction at a duly licensed barber school, and thereafter fulfill an 18-month apprenticeship. In lieu of going to barber school, a candidate may extend his apprenticeship for six months. The fact that barber courses include 400 hours on haircutting while beauty schools only allocate 92 hours to haircutting, is not significant on the issue of constitutionality. If a hairdresser is trained and qualified to cut the hair of a female, he is qualified to cut the [***3] chemically similar hair of males. One who has been employed in barbering in a barber shop for at least two years may become a full-fledged licensed barber without attending any barbering school and without proving that he has any experience in the cutting of hair of either a male or a female. The 400-hour requirement does not mean that a barbering school student is required to cut the hair of a single female. In addition, hairstyling very frequently accompanies the cutting of hair of females, as well as the cutting of hair of males with long hair. Yet the barbers' curriculum does not include a single moment of study of hair styling while the hairdresser has devoted 291 hours of schooling to that subject.

2. The statutory restrictions on haircutting placed upon hairdressers do not serve the function of promoting the health of patrons. The New York rules and regulations governing sanitation in the barber shops and in beauty parlors are identical. The laws which seek to protect the health of those who patronize barber shops and beauty parlors are also identical (see General Business Law, §§ 404, 407, subd 4; § 433, subd 3; § 434, subd 1, par [c]).

3. The fact that a male would [***4] receive a haircut in a beauty salon in the presence of other males and females would have no adverse effect upon the morals of anybody.

 

1314 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Estate of Agioritis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, New York County


84 Misc. 2d 83; 378 N.Y.S.2d 208; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3055



June 13, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner widow brought an action against respondents, beneficiaries of joint accounts or Totten trusts, to obtain a determination as to the validity and effect of an election to take an elective share of an estate. The beneficiaries sought an order releasing certain funds. A determination was required as to which and how much of the accounts were deemed a testamentary substitute.


OVERVIEW: In New York, the legislature changed the law relating to a spouse's elective share of a decedent's estate. Previously, assets outside the decedent's estate, such as joint bank accounts, were not subject to the spouse's election. N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-1.1(b) was changed to provide that assets in the form of testamentary substitutes were also subject to the spouse's election if the transaction was made after marriage and after the law's effective date. The widow brought an action to determine which of the intestate decedent's assets were subject to the election. The court held that accounts the decedent funded and held in trust for others or as joint owner were exempt from the election if all deposits had been made prior to the law's effective date and no significant changes were made to the account after that date. When the form or site of the account was changed after the law's effective date, the changes were mere formalities. However, when the decedent changed the account's beneficiary, that change was significant and subjected the funds to the widow's election. Accounts owned in survivorship with the spouse were the widow's property.


OUTCOME: The court found that some of the decedent's property in the form of testamentary substitutes were subject to the widow's election while others were exempt from the widow's election in the widow's action to determine the decedent's assets subject to the widow's elective share.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and wife -- spouse's right of election -- testamentary substitutes -- in proceedings to obtain determination as to validity and effect of wife's election to take elective share of husband's intestate estate, where beneficiaries of joint accounts and Totten trusts seek order releasing decedent's assets and central question is which and how much of funds are testamentary substitutes, general observations may be made; transfers completely effectuated prior to August 31, 1966 are exempt from widow's election -- change in beneficiary after August 31, 1966 brings account out of exempt status and makes it testamentary substitute -- where some money was deposited prior to August 31 date, and some subsequently, only prior deposited funds are exempt -- transfers from one bank to another for same beneficiary are not "deposits" made after August 31, 1966 and are therefore exempt.

1. Decedent and the surviving spouse were married in 1950, and he died intestate and without issue in June, 1973. Prior to his death, decedent had set up several varied forms of joint accounts and Totten trusts to persons other than his wife. The wife's right to elect against testamentary substitutes [***2] is governed by EPTL 5-1.1 (subd [b]), and transactions which fall within its purview may qualify as testamentary substitutes if decedent made the transaction subsequent to the marriage and after August 31, 1966. In proceedings to obtain a determination as to the validity and effect of her election to take an elective share of the estate, beneficiaries of joint accounts and Totten trusts seek an order releasing approximately one half of decedent's assets, and the central question is which and how much of these funds are deemed testamentary substitutes. Some basic situations present themselves regarding changes in the dispositions prior and subsequent to August 31, 1966, and general observations may be made. Transfers completely effectuated prior to August 31, 1966 remain untouched by the present statute and therefore all money deposited prior to that date and where no significant change in the account was made subsequent to that date is exempt from the widow's election.

2. A change in beneficiary after August 31, 1966 brings the account out of the exempt status and makes it a testamentary substitute, since a change in beneficiary cannot be said to be "merely formal", as it completely [***3] changes the disposition that will be made at the death of the depositor. Therefore, as to accounts where the beneficiary was changed after August 31, 1966, the funds are testamentary substitutes subject to the right of election of the surviving spouse.

3. Regarding accounts where some money was deposited prior to the August 31 date, and some subsequent to it, only a portion is exempt. Moneys taken from a Totten trust and deposited in a savings account subsequent to August 31, 1966 are not exempt and considered testamentary substitutes. Portions deposited prior to the date are exempt and are not to be included in decedent's estate for the purpose of the widow's right of election.

4. Deposits of money by decedent in joint savings accounts prior to August 31, 1966, which accounts were thereafter closed and the funds contained therein redeposited by decedent subsequent to the date in other savings banks without a change of beneficiary in the form of Totten trust accounts, are not testamentary substitutes. Transfers from one bank to another for the same beneficiary are not "deposits" made after August 31, 1966 and are therefore exempt.

5. Similarly, deposits in Totten trust accounts [***4] subsequent to August 31, 1966, with beneficiaries unchanged, from funds withdrawn from Totten trust accounts maintained at other savings banks, are also exempt.

 

1315 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Patterson v. Carey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


83 Misc. 2d 372; 370 N.Y.S.2d 783; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2912



June 13, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The preliminary injunction granted herein by Honorable George L. Cobb restraining the defendants from enforcing section 153-c of the Public Authorities Law is hereby vacated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, park board and bank trustee, initiated a case against defendants, governor, comptroller and associated individuals, challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 153-c. Plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment for an order declaring § 153-c unconstitutional and void.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs adopted a resolution that raised the parkway toll. In response, defendants passed § 153-c that rolled back the parkway toll. Plaintiffs initiated a case against defendants asserting that the passage of § 153-c was unconstitutional. Plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment and argued that § 153-c violated U.S. Const. art. I, § 10 in that the contract between the state and bondholders for the operation of the parkway was a contract and that § 153-c impaired the contractual obligation. The court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment to the extent that § 153-c restored the parkway toll because the provision was unconstitutional as it impeded a contractual obligation. The court declared that all other aspects of § 153-c concerning the procedures to be followed before the parkway toll could be increased were constitutional because they were reasonably related to serving the public interest.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment in part and denied it in part.


HEADNOTES

Public authorities -- tolls on State parkway -- provision in section 153-c of Public Authorities Law, enacted after Jones Beach State Parkway Authority raised toll on Southern State Parkway to 25 cents, rolling that toll back to 10 cents, is unwarranted impairment of State's pledge to Authority's bondholders not to limit or alter rights vested in Authority to collect revenues in order that Authority may fulfill terms of agreements with bondholders, nor may impairment be justified as reasonable exercise of State's police power -- other provisions of section 153-c, establishing public disclosure procedure for any future toll increases, do not impair State's contractual obligation to Authority's bondholders, since ultimate and final power to set toll rate remains in Authority, but, even assuming there is theoretical or technical impairment, they constitute reasonable exercise of State's police power to safeguard vital interests of community -- since toll rollback provision and disclosure provisions have  [***2] separate objects and there is no mutual interdependence, rollback provision may be stricken and remainder of section allowed to remain in full force.

1. Section 153-c of the Public Authorities Law, which was enacted after the Jones Beach State Parkway Authority had raised the toll on the Southern State Parkway from 10 cents to 25 cents, rolled that toll back to 10 cents, and established a public disclosure procedure for any future toll increases, requiring, inter alia, that a detailed report explaining the need for a proposed increase is to be submitted to the Comptroller not less than 120 days prior to the effective date of such proposed increase; that the Comptroller is to make public his recommendations concerning the proposed increase within 60 days; that the Authority shall hold a public hearing upon the proposed increase not less than 15 days prior to its effective date, and that, after that hearing, the Authority shall reconsider the proposed increase and then take such action on a toll increase as it then deems necessary and advisable. The provision therein for a rollback of the toll is unconstitutional, but the other provisions are constitutional.

2. The toll rollback [***3] provision is an unwarranted impairment of a pledge made by the State to the Authority's bondholders, contained in section 158-a (subd 1) of the Public Authorities Law, "that it will not limit or alter the rights hereby vested in the authority * * * to collect revenues * * * in order that the authority may fulfill the terms of any agreements made with the holders of such bonds". Nor may the impairment be justified as a reasonable exercise of the State's police power designed to cure the traffic congestion on local streets caused by motorists attempting to avoid the 25-cent toll. No allusion to any such traffic emergency is contained in the language of section 153-c. And the section only has the effect of postponing the inevitable toll increase for 120 days. But, even conceding a legislative intent to alleviate the traffic situation, the provisions of the section are not reasonably related to that end.

3. The full disclosure provisions of the section do not impair the State's contractual obligation to the Authority's bondholders. The ultimate and final power to set the toll rate still remains in the hands of the Authority. But, even assuming that those provisions are a theoretical [***4] or technical impairment, they constitute a reasonable exercise of the State's police power to safeguard the vital interests of the community.

4. Since the unconstitutional toll rollback provision and the constitutional disclosure provisions have separate objects and there is no mutual interdependence, the rollback provision may be stricken and the remainder of the section allowed to remain in full force.

 

1316 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Bartley


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Cattaraugus County


83 Misc. 2d 672; 370 N.Y.S.2d 990; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2960



June 12, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent surviving spouse (spouse) timely filed a right of election under N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-1.1. Petitioner executor filed an application seeking a determination of the validity of the spouse's right of election.


OVERVIEW: The deceased wife's will was executed in 1953 and bequeathed to the spouse a sum, in trust, equal to the minimum amount allowed to a surviving spouse under the provisions of the New York State Decedent's Estate Law at the time of the wife's death. Subsequently, but prior to the wife's death, § 5-1.1 was enacted. N.Y Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-1.1(c) and (b) enlarged a surviving spouses elective rights. But, N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-1.1(a), which applied to wills drawn before September 1, 1966, limited the spouse's right of election to the amount available under the prior law. The court found the wife intended that changes in the law enacted subsequent to the will applied to fix the standard to measure her bequest. Also, the more expansive provisions of § 5-1.1 controlled over the application of § 5-1.1(a). The court concluded that the right of election was a nullity so far as altering the amount of property passing to the spouse. However, because the bequest was in trust, the court treated the right of election as a limited right of election under N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-1.1 (c)(1)(D), entitling the spouse to take $ 10,000 from the trust's principal.


OUTCOME: The court found that the spouse's right of election should be treated as a limited right of election.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Wills -- construction -- in her will, executed prior to 1966, testatrix, who died after 1966, bequeathed to her husband, in trust, "sum equal to and not in excess of the minimum amount allowed to a surviving spouse pursuant to the provisions of the New York State Decedent's Estate Law at the time of my death relative to the right of election of such spouse to take his or her share of the estate as in intestacy" -- this provision is construed as direction that there be set over to testatrix' husband, in trust, amount equivalent to spouse's elective share, which is to be computed under subdivision (c) of EPTL 5-1.1, which permits surviving spouse, for purpose of election against wills executed after September 1, 1966, to share not only in decedent's net estate but also in estate consisting of testamentary substitutes, and, where he receives life estate under will, corpus of which is equal to elective share, gives him right to withdraw $ 10,000 outright.

1. In her will testatrix, who died survived by her husband and two issue, bequeathed to her husband, in trust, "a sum equal to and not in excess of the minimum amount allowed to a surviving spouse pursuant to the provisions of [***2] the New York State Decedent's Estate Law at the time of my death relative to the right of election of such spouse to take his or her share of the estate as in intestacy". This provision is construed as a direction that there be set over to testatrix' husband, in trust, an amount equivalent to a spouse's elective share.

2. At the time testatrix executed her will, prior to 1966, there was only one amount provided by statute for an elective share, one third of the net estate where decedent was survived by one or more issue, and, where the surviving spouse received a life estate under decedent's will, the corpus of which was equal in amount to the elective share, he had the limited right to withdraw $ 2,500 outright (Decedent Estate Law, § 18). However, in her bequest to her spouse, testatrix employed the phrase "at the time of my death", thus indicating that the law as to elective rights which was extant at the time of her death would fix the standard to be applied in measuring the quantum of the bequest, and, by the time she died, EPTL 5-1.1 had been enacted, subdivision (a) of which provides that, as to wills executed prior to September 1, 1966, a surviving spouse has the same right [***3] of election as he had had under section 18 of the Decedent Estate Law, but subdivision (c) of which permits a surviving spouse, for the purpose of election against wills executed after September 1, 1966, to share not only in the decedent's net estate but also in an estate consisting of specified inter vivos transactions, testamentary in nature and denominated testamentary substitutes, and, where the surviving spouse receives a life estate under the will, the corpus of which is equal to the elective share, gives him the right to withdraw $ 10,000 outright. This enlargement of elective rights was the result of social legislation designed to prevent a decedent from impoverishing a surviving spouse and to give a legislatively determined equitable portion of a decedent's property to the surviving spouse, and the exception made for wills drawn prior to September 1, 1966 was reluctantly inserted into the statute only because of a fear that the new testamentary substitutes doctrine might run afoul of due process provisions and be held unconstitutional if made applicable where the will antedated the effective date of the statute. To conclude that this was within the contemplation of testatrix [***4] would be unreasonable. Therefore, and viewing EPTL 5-1.1 in its entirety and considering its purpose, inter alia, the provision containing testatrix' bequest to her husband is construed to bequeath to him, in trust, an amount equal to his elective share computed under subdivision (c) of EPTL 5-1.1, and he has the limited right to take $ 10,000 absolutely from the principal of the trust.

 

1317 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gould v. Gould


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


82 Misc. 2d 835; 371 N.Y.S.2d 267; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2820



June 11, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the reasons heretofore set forth, the motion for an order of arrest is accordingly denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff wife brought an action against defendant husband, alleging a conversion of her personal property by the husband. The wife filed a motion for an order of civil arrest of the husband, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6101.


OVERVIEW: According to the wife's affidavit in support of her motion for civil arrest, she turned over her personal jewelry to the husband to place in a hotel's safety deposit box. The following week, after she arrived home, she discovered that the husband had appropriated the jewelry to himself. She also claimed that he refused to return the jewelry, despite her repeated requests, as well as the requests of their children. The husband, in response to the statements made in the wife's affidavit, denied that the jewelry was her personal property. He also claimed that she exaggerated the value of the jewelry. The husband did, however, admit he had possession of the jewelry. The court denied the wife's motion for civil arrest because the language of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6101(1), restricting the availability of orders of civil arrest to men, was discriminatory, and thus, R. 6101(1) was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied the wife's motion for an order of arrest of the husband.


HEADNOTES

Arrest -- conversion of personal property -- discrimination on basis of sex -- plaintiff wife is not entitled to order of civil arrest of defendant husband based upon his alleged conversion of her jewelry; CPLR 6101 (subd 1), which provides that order of arrest may be granted where there is cause of action to recover damages for conversion of personal property and "person to be arrested is not woman", unconstitutionally discriminates on basis of sex alone -- even if statute were constitutional, plaintiff would not be entitled to civil arrest of defendant in exercise of discretion; civil arrest is drastic remedy not looked upon with favor.

1. While the parties were at a hotel on vacation, plaintiff wife turned over her jewelry, which she claims to have received as gifts, to defendant husband to place in the hotel's safety deposit box. Instead, defendant allegedly appropriated the jewelry to himself having refused to return said jewelry to plaintiff. Plaintiff is not entitled to an order of civil arrest of defendant pursuant to CPLR 6101 based upon his alleged conversion of the [***2] jewelry. CPLR 6101 (subd 1), which states that an "order of arrest as a provisional remedy may only be granted: where there is a cause of action to recover damages for the conversion of personal property * * * and the person to be arrested is not a woman", unconstitutionally discriminates on the basis of sex alone. Women as a class may not be excluded or given automatic exemptions based solely on sex.

2. Even if the statute was constitutional, plaintiff would not be entitled to the civil arrest of defendant in the exercise of discretion. "Arrest in a civil action is a drastic remedy, penal in nature, and because of its severity, is not looked upon with favor".

 

1318 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Choops


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Buffalo


83 Misc. 2d 580; 372 N.Y.S.2d 777; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2942



June 9, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion to dismiss the information is hereby granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant gasoline service station operator brought a motion to dismiss an information charging the operator with having a sidewalk portable sign advertising the price of gasoline, which did not conform with the prescribed size requirements of Buffalo, N.Y., Ordinance ch. VII, art. V, §§ 90, 92.


OVERVIEW: The operator alleged that the ordinances at issue were invalid because the operator's right to do business was unconstitutionally infringed upon. In particular, the operator argued that his gasoline station was close to another town that did not limit the size of advertising signs and that in order to remain in business he had to effectively compete, but was prevented from doing so due to the ordinances. On consideration of the operator's motion, the court granted the operator's request to dismiss the information against him after determining that part of the ordinances were unconstitutional. Specifically, the court held that parts of §§ 90 and 92, regarding the maximum size of gasoline advertising signs, were unconstitutional, oppressive, and an undue burden on the operator's right to conduct his business despite the purpose of the ordinances to apprise consumers of product prices. In addition, the court noted that it was more reasonable to require a minimum size to prevent deception, but to place a limit on a maximum sign, without specifying the minimum size of the numbers and lettering, was clearly unreasonable and entirely failed to accomplish the purpose of the ordinances.


OUTCOME: The court granted the operator's motion to dismiss the information.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- gasoline price signs -- ordinance of City of Buffalo (art. VII, § 90) which provides for gasoline price signs on gasoline pumps no less than 7 inches high and 8 inches wide, nor more than 12 inches high and 12 inches wide, is valid ( People v Arlen Serv. Sta., 284 NY 340 controlling) -- however, ordinance (§ 92) which prohibits any larger signs than those specified is invalid and unconstitutional.

1. Article VII (§ 90) of the Ordinances of the City of Buffalo provides that anyone selling gasoline must keep signs on gasoline pumps, indicating the prices charged, "not less than seven (7) inches in height and eight (8) inches in width nor more than twelve (12) inches in height and twelve (12) inches in width". Article VII (§ 92) provides that no other sign indicating price may be displayed. The requirement of price signs, in order to protect the consumer by permitting him to know the price of gasoline he is purchasing, is valid ( People v Arlen Serv. Sta., 284 NY 340 controlling).

2. However, the ordinance (§ 92) prohibiting any signs larger than those specified in section 90 [***2] of the Ordinances is invalid and unconstitutional. It is an invalid exercise of the police power. It cannot be defended on the power to legislate on aesthetic grounds.

 

1319 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Burgos


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


82 Misc. 2d 353; 369 N.Y.S.2d 327; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2637



June 5, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants moved to dismiss charges against them for jostling on the ground that the statute under which they were charged, N.Y. Penal Law §165.25, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: One defendant was observed placing his hand into the pocket of another man and removing a wallet therefrom and the other defendant was observed placing his hand next to the pocket of one man and touching the purse of a woman. Section 165.25 stated that a person was guilty of jostling when, in a public place, he intentionally and unnecessarily placed his hand in the proximity of a person's pocket or handbag. Defendants argued that the statute was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad in that it failed to give proper notice as to what conduct was prohibited, that it failed to fix an ascertainable standard of guilt, and that it had no requirement of a culpable mental state. The court held that it was unclear what the statute meant by "proximity" and that the statute relied heavily upon a police officer's discretion because placing one's hands in the proximity of another person's handbag in a crowded subway could be equally consistent with guilt or innocence. However, the court was bound to hold the statute constitutional based on a decision of the Court of Appeals affirming convictions in an unrelated case in which the identical constitutional issues were raised.


OUTCOME: The court held that the jostling statute was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- jostling -- constitutionality of statute defining crime of jostling is upheld on authority of People v Clark (27 NY2d 512), wherein Court of Appeals affirmed jostling convictions, without opinion, in cases where identical constitutional issues were raised -- however, it is noted that, unfortunately, no appellate authority in this State sets forth rationale of upholding constitutionality of statute.

Two defendants, one of whom was observed placing his hand into another man's pocket and removing a wallet therefrom, and the other of whom was observed, on a crowded subway, placing his hand next to a man's pocket and touching a woman's purse, were arrested and charged with jostling, which is defined in section 165.25 of the Penal Law, providing that "A person is guilty of jostling when, in a public place, he intentionally and unnecessarily: 1. Places his hand in the proximity of a person's pocket or handbag; or 2. Jostles or crowds another person at a time when a third person's hand is in the proximity of such person's pocket or handbag". On a defense motion to dismiss on the ground that this jostling statute is unconstitutional, its constitutionality is upheld on the [***2] authority of People v Clark (27 NY2d 512), wherein the Court of Appeals upheld convictions of jostling, without opinion, in cases where identical constitutional issues were raised. However, it is noted that it is unclear what the statute contemplates by the use of the word "proximity"; that it apparently relies heavily upon a police officer's discretion in ascertaining whether a person's conduct is criminal; that a Federal District Court has declared a nearly identical statute unconstitutional for vagueness and overbreadth; that other States, which have adopted verbatim the theft offenses of New York's Penal Law, have intentionally excluded the jostling statutes from their laws, and that, therefore, it is unfortunate that no appellate authority in this State sets forth the rationale of upholding the constitutionality of the statute.

 

1320 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Peetz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Rensselaer County


83 Misc. 2d 890; 374 N.Y.S.2d 247; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3009



June 5, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition of James W. Van Auken, Chief Fiscal Officer, and the County of Rensselaer is dismissed. The petition of Edward W. Pattison for the judicial settlement of his accounts as administrator is granted and commissions in the amount of $ 733.45 are approved and the same shall be paid to the administrator.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner administrator, a former county treasurer, sought a judicial settlement of his accounts as administrator of the estate of a decedent. Petitioner county treasurer sought to be substituted as the public administrator of the estate.


OVERVIEW: The administrator, a former county treasurer, instituted a proceeding for judicial settlement of his accounts as administrator of a decedent's estate. The county treasurer filed a petition whereby he requested to substituted as public administrator of the estate. The administrator contended that a county treasurer who was appointed administrator of an estate should be allowed to collect and keep commissions as an administrator in addition to the salary he received as county treasurer. The county treasurer contended that the commissions should be paid to the county. The court held that the language of N.Y. Surr. Ct. Proc. Act Law § 1219 was quite clear in stating that the county treasurer should be allowed the same commissions as an administrator and that the commissions would be in addition to the county treasurer's salary and fees allowed by law.


OUTCOME: The court granted the administrator's petition and denied the county treasurer's petition.


HEADNOTES

Public officers -- County Treasurer -- administrator's commissions -- petitioner, former County Treasurer of Rensselaer County, is entitled to collect sum of $ 733.45 as public administrator's commissions in addition to his salary as County Treasurer (SCPA 1219); SCPA 1219 controls over conflicting provisions of section 201 of County Law which provide that salaries of county officers are in lieu of all other fees, payable for services rendered in performance of official duties.

Petitioner, the former County Treasurer of Rensselaer County, was appointed public administrator of the subject estate during his term of office. He continued to serve as administrator after the expiration of his term of office. Petitioner, and not the County of Rensselaer, is entitled to keep and collect the sum of $ 733.45 as administrator's commission fees pursuant to SCPA [***2] 1219 which states that the "chief fiscal officer of a county appointed administrator of an estate * * * shall be allowed the same commissions as an administrator, which commissions shall be in addition to the salary and fees now allowed by law". SCPA 1219, a special act, controls over the conflicting general provisions of section 201 of the County Law which provide that "[notwithstanding] the provisions of any general law other than this chapter or any special law to the contrary" the salaries of county officers "shall be in lieu of all fees, percentages, emoluments or other form of compensation payable for services rendered in the performance of the powers and duties of the office". The Legislature reviewed SCPA 1219 in 1971 and substituted the words "Chief Fiscal Officer" for the words "County Treasurer", yet saw no reason to address itself to the seeming conflict contained in section 201 of the County Law. It was the intent of the Legislature that such commissions be paid over to the administrator personally.

 

1321 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Stacy v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


82 Misc. 2d 181; 368 N.Y.S.2d 448; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2596



June 3, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff president sought a temporary injunction within the framework of his action for a declaratory judgment to restrain defendant State, and its agent, the State Tax Commission, from proceeding against him personally to collect the sum of $ 54,436 assessed against the president as a person who was required to collect sales and use taxes for a corporation. The corporation had been adjudicated a bankrupt.


OVERVIEW: The president's complaint alleged that the corporation transferred its accounts, inventories, and other assets to another company under security liens and factoring agreements, thereby relieving the president from any such liability. The only notice the president claimed that he received of the assessment was a notice and demand for payment of sales and use taxes due. The notice was followed by a subpoena that required the president to appear and explain how the assessed amount would be paid by him personally under penalty of contempt. It was this enforcement proceeding that the president sought to restrain in the motion. The State filed a cross motion for a dismissal of the action and the motion. The court concluded that: (1) the action was proper in form as a declaratory judgment; (2) the declaratory judgment action brought against the State did not have to be dismissed for failure to name the Tax Commission as a party defendant; and (3) the tax assessment had to be decided in the president's declaratory judgment action as an issue of fact. The court ordered the State to answer the action within 10 days of the date of the order herein with notice of entry.


OUTCOME: The court granted the president's request for a preliminary injunction restraining the collection of the taxes against him personally.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- liability for collection of sales and use taxes -- plaintiff, former president of bankrupt corporation, who is personally assessed sum of $ 54,436.80 by State Tax Commission as "person required to collect sales and use taxes" on behalf of corporation (Tax Law, § 1131, subd 1; § 1133), may properly challenge jurisdiction of taxing commission on grounds of his nonpersonal liability in declaratory judgment action rather than in article 78 proceeding; administrative proceeding would be inappropriate since Tax Commission is not empowered to hold hearings to determine who is personally liable -- failure to name Tax Commission as party defendant does not warrant dismissal of declaratory judgment action against State.

1. After the bankrupt corporation of which plaintiff was president transferred its accounts, inventories and other assets to another corporation under security liens and factoring agreements, the State Tax Commission proceeded against plaintiff personally to collect the sum of $ 54,436.80 assessed against him as "a person required to collect sales and use taxes" on behalf of his corporation (Tax Law, § 1131, subd 1; § 1133). Despite the provisions of [***2] the taxing statute (Tax Law, §§ 1138, 1140) providing that the method of judicial review by article 78 is exclusive, an action for a declaratory judgment is proper where plaintiff is challenging the jurisdiction of the taxing authority on the grounds that he was relieved from personal liability. Since there are no statutory administrative procedures empowering the Tax Commission to hold hearings to determine who is personally liable as a "person required to collect taxes", any administrative proceeding would be inappropriate.

2. The failure to name the Tax Commission as a party defendant does not warrant dismissal of a declaratory judgment action brought against the State. Plaintiff is entitled to a preliminary injunction restraining the collection of the taxes against him personally.

 

1322 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. McNelly


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


83 Misc. 2d 262; 371 N.Y.S.2d 538; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2891



June 2, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was tried for crimes that arose from the firing of a gun in a restaurant upon a certification that he had sufficiently recovered from his mental illness to understand the charges against him and assist in his defense. Defendant claimed that at the time of the incident he lacked the capacity to understand the consequences of his acts and that they were wrong, and raised an equal protection issue.


OVERVIEW: Defendant fired at four people and did substantial damage. Charged with the shooting and possession of a weapon, defendant was found to be incapacitated and was committed for care and treatment. In three months he was certified as a controlled schizophrenic having recovered sufficiently to understand the proceedings against him and assist in his defense, and he was tried. Defendant contended that he was not guilty because of his lack of capacity at the time, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 30.05, and to commit him afterward without proof of a current mental disability was a denial of due process and equal protection. The court held that: (1) N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 330.20(1) required commitment upon a verdict of acquittal by reason of mental disease or defect, but it was unenforceable as written and the trial court was left to apply it in a constitutional manner; (2) a brief period of hospitalization, for examination and report whether defendant could be released without danger to himself or to others, was no invasion of his rights; and (3) equal protection did not require that all persons be dealt with identically, but that a distinction be relevant to its purpose.


OUTCOME: The court ordered the commitment of defendant until it was certified that he could be released on condition without danger to himself or to others, and directed that the commissioner report to the court.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Insane and other incompetent persons -- commitment of acquitted defendant -- following his acquittal on criminal charges as result of suffering from mental disease or defect (Penal Law, § 30.05), defendant is properly committed to custody of Commissioner of Mental Hygiene ( CPL 330.20) for purpose of determining whether he "may be discharged or released on condition without danger to himself or others" or whether he is presently afflicted with mental disease or defect "which is likely to result in serious harm to himself or others" (Mental Hygiene Law, § 31.37, subd [a]) thereby requiring "involuntary care and treatment" (Mental Hygiene Law, § 31.27); commitment without prior adjudication of need thereof and without proof of current "mental disease or defect" is not unconstitutional; statute requires commissioner to examine defendant only so long as shall be reasonably necessary to examine him and to report his findings to court -- it is not required that commitment procedures following acquittal by reason of mental disease or defect be identical with civil commitment procedures.

1. Defendant was indicted for various crimes after shooting a pistol at the premises of a well-known [***2] restaurant in New York City. Defendant was subsequently acquitted of all criminal charges since, "as the result of mental disease or defect he lacked substantial capacity to know or appreciate the nature and consequence of his acts" (Penal Law, § 30.05). Consequently, pursuant to CPL 330.20, defendant is properly committed to the custody of the Commissioner of Mental Hygiene for the purpose of determining whether he "may be discharged or released on condition without danger to himself or others" or whether he is presently afflicted with mental disease or defect "which is likely to result in serious harm to himself or others" (Mental Hygiene Law, § 31.37, subd [a]) thereby requiring "involuntary care and treatment" (Mental Hygiene Law, § 31.27). Defendant's commitment to the custody of the commissioner without prior adjudication of need thereof and without proof of current "mental disease or defect", is not a denial of due process or equal protection of the laws. A "commitment" of indefinite duration without hearing or proof of necessity would be an unconstitutional invasion of defendant's rights, particularly where such safeguards are available in all other involuntary hospitalizations.  [***3] However, the "commitment" called for by CPL 330.20 (subd 1) only means commitment "for detention examination and report as to sanity". Where the need appears to exist, a brief period of hospitalization for the purposes of examination is no invasion of a patient's constitutional rights. The statute requires the commissioner to detain defendant only so long as should be reasonably necessary to examine him and report his findings to the court. If the commissioner determines that defendant should continue to be detained, he shall petition for the retention of the patient (Mental Hygiene Law, § 31.33). Similarly, if he determines that defendant should be discharged or released on condition, he shall petition for such discharge or release in his report ( CPL 330.20, subd 2).

2. The fact that some civil commitments are based on the allegedly more stringent commitment standard of whether a person is "mentally ill and in need of involuntary care and treatment", while the only allegedly more lenient commitment standard the commissioner must apply pursuant to CPL 330.20 is whether the patient "may be discharged or released on condition without danger to himself or others", does not result [***4] in a denial of equal protection. It is not required that commitment procedures following an acquittal of a crime by reason of mental disease or defect be identical to commitment procedures in noncriminal cases so long as variation is reasonably required by variation in circumstance. Defendant endangered the lives of four people. Reasonable precaution must be taken so that others shall not be furthered endangered by him ( CPL 330.20, subd 2).

 

1323 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Emmanuel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Queens County


82 Misc. 2d 298; 368 N.Y.S.2d 773; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2626



May 28, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511, operating a motor vehicle on the public roads while his operator's license was suspended.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that his license was suspended without notice. The court determined that even a temporary suspension of a valuable property right, such as a license, without notice and an opportunity for a hearing was violative of due process. Furthermore the court determined that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §510(3) was unconstitutional. The court concluded that defendant was never notified as to the suspension of his license and thus was not guilty of the charge of operating a motor vehicle while his license was suspended.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant not guilty of operating a motor vehicle while his license was suspended.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- suspension of driver's license -- notice -- defendant is not guilty of operating motor vehicle while his license was suspended (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 511), which resulted from five prior unanswered traffic infractions, since he never received proper notice of suspension of his license (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 510, subd 4-a); traffic summons providing for suspension of license for nonappearance is insufficient notice of suspension -- section 510 (subd 3, par [i]) which permits temporary suspension of license without notice is unconstitutional; temporary suspension of driver's license without notice and opportunity for hearing is violative of due process.

1. Defendant is not guilty of the charge of operating a motor vehicle while his operator's license was suspended (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 511), which resulted from five prior unanswered traffic infractions, since he never received proper notice of the suspension of his license as required by subdivision 4-a of section 510 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law. The part of the traffic summons which provides for suspension of a license if no appearance is made by the licensee charged with the offense [***2] is not sufficient notice for suspension under subdivision 4-a of section 510.

2. Section 510 (subd 3, par [i]), which states that "a license * * * may * * * be temporarily suspended without notice pending any prosecution, investigation or hearing", is unconstitutional since a temporary suspension of a driver's license, a valuable property right, without notice and an opportunity for a hearing is violative of due process.

 

1324 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Schoonmaker v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Ulster County


82 Misc. 2d 16; 368 N.Y.S.2d 384; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2546; 90 L.R.R.M. 2523



May 27, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is denied and summary judgment is granted to the defendants declaring the challenged provisions constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff worker brought a declaratory judgment action against defendant State seeking to declare unconstitutional terms of an agreement between the State and a union. The worker filed a motion for summary judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3212.


OVERVIEW: The State and the union entered into a collective bargaining agreement that provided for, among other things, disciplinary proceedings for workers charged with misconduct. The worker brought an action challenging the agreement and filed a motion for summary judgment. The court denied summary judgment in favor of the worker and granted summary judgment in favor of the State. The court held that the agreement was entitled to a presumption of validity and constitutionality and that every reasonable presumption was to be indulged in favor of the agreement. The disciplinary procedures under N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law art. 33 were valid because they provided workers charged with misconduct the notice and right to be heard protections that were required by due process.


OUTCOME: The court denied the worker's motion for summary judgment in his action to declare the terms of the agreement unconstitutional and the court granted summary judgment in favor of the State.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- disciplinary proceedings -- binding arbitration -- provisions of collective bargaining agreement between State and Civil Service Employees' Association, for settlement of disciplinary matters by grievance procedures and binding arbitration instead of by disciplinary and appeal procedures of sections and 75 and 76 of Civil Service Law, are constitutional.

Provisions of a collective bargaining agreement between the State and the Civil Service Employees' Association, for the settlement of disciplinary matters by grievance procedures and binding arbitration instead of by the disciplinary and appeal procedures of sections 75 and 76 of the Civil Service Law, are constitutional.

 

1325 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York State Asso. of Chiefs of Police v. Municipal Police Training Council (MPTC)


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


82 Misc. 2d 289; 368 N.Y.S.2d 438; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2623



May 20, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The petition is dismissed, and accordingly, it is not necessary to reach the merits.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police and the police officials, alleged that 13 causes of action were brought pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, and four causes of action alleged that declaratory judgments were sought relating to height, weight, and physical standards and tests set by respondent Municipal Police Training Council (MPTC) for the selection of police officers.


OVERVIEW: The Association and officials sought a judgment setting aside and annulling the standards and tests set forth by the MPTC as arbitrary and capricious. They also alleged that the standards and tests constituted an arbitrary and unlawful barrier to employment of women as municipal police officers in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, and N.Y. Exec. Law § 296. The MPTC filed a cross motion for dismissal of the petition pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a) in that the Association and officials did not have legal capacity to maintain the proceeding. The MPTC argued that the action brought pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 was time barred and the petition failed to state facts that would entitle the Association and officials to relief. The court held that the MPTC, in prescribing the height, weight, and physical fitness requirements for police officers the MPTC, acted pursuant to the statutory authority with which it was vested. Where the officials and Association failed to show they were personally aggrieved by the actions and statutes complained of, the court held petitioners lacked standing to maintain the proceeding.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the Association and the officials' petition.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- police -- standing to sue -- petition in proceeding by New York State Association of Chiefs of Police, police chiefs and police commissioners, challenging height, weight and physical fitness standards set for selection of municipal police officers by Municipal Police Training Council ( 9 NYCRR Part 6000), and validity of statutes vesting council with authority to prescribe such requirements, is dismissed on ground that petitioners lack standing, either as citizen-taxpayers or police officials, to maintain proceeding.

A petition in a proceeding brought by the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police, police chiefs and police commissioners, challenging height, weight and physical standards set for the selection of municipal police officers by the Municipal Police Training Council, and also challenging the validity of the statutes vesting the council with the authority to prescribe height, weight and physical fitness requirements for municipal police officers, is dismissed on the ground that petitioners lack standing to bring the proceeding. They have not shown that [***2] they are personally aggrieved by the actions and statutes complained of, and, therefore, have no standing as citizen-taxpayers, nor do they have standing as police chiefs and commissioners, since the matters under attack have no effect on their duties or rights as police officials.

 

1326 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Regnell v. Page


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


82 Misc. 2d 506; 369 N.Y.S.2d 936; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2716



May 19, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff union fund trustees filed suit against defendant employers, seeking to recover for the employers' fraud in breach of collective bargaining and trust agreements. The court entered judgment in favor of the trustees and issued an order of attachment. The employers filed a motion for vacatur of the order of attachment. The motion was denied, and the employers filed a motion to reargue.


OVERVIEW: In their complaint, the trustees alleged the deliberate submission of false reports by the employers, causing the union pension and welfare funds administered by the trustees to become substantially underpaid. In denying the employer's motion for vacatur of the order of attachment, the court declined to hold N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 62 unconstitutional to the extent that it permitted attachment without prior notice in actions to recover a money judgment on the grounds of fraud and deceit. In their motion for reargument, the employers contended R. 6201 and 6211 were unconstitutional to the extent they collectively permitted attachment merely upon a claimant's ex parte allegation of fraud. The court held adherence to its prior determination was appropriate because the trustees affirmatively established a valid basis, without contradiction by the employers, to uphold the ex parte issuance of the order of attachment, and the possession of the property by the employers was not affected.


OUTCOME: The court deemed the employers' motion to reargue a motion for renewal, granted the motion so designated, and adhered to its original determination sustaining the order of attachment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Attachment -- constitutionality of New York attachment statute -- on prior motion by defendants to vacate order of attachment obtained by plaintiffs, trustees of welfare and pension funds who seek to recover for fraud on part of defendants in submitting false reports, with result funds became substantially underpaid, court declined to hold New York attachment statute unconstitutional, finding it met requisites of procedural due process laid down in Mitchell v Grant (416 U.S. 600), wherein validity of Louisiana sequestration statute was upheld -- on present motion for reargument, defendants cite Sugar v Curtis Circulation Co. (383 F Supp 643), wherein court, observing that New York statute was similar to Louisiana statute upheld in Mitchell in all respects but one, invalidated New York statute for failure to guarantee defendant opportunity for immediate post-seizure hearing, with burden of proof on plaintiff -- original determination sustaining order of attachment is adhered to.

In an action by the trustees of welfare and pension funds, to recover for fraud on the part of defendants, who, under collective bargaining and trust agreements, were required to make payments to those [***2] funds based upon the number of employee hours worked, and who, as alleged by plaintiffs and not contradicted by defendants, submitted false reports detailing employee hours and the amount due, with the result that the funds became substantially underpaid, defendants move for reargument of a prior motion by them to vacate an order of attachment obtained by plaintiffs. In denying the motion to vacate, the court had declined to hold the New York attachment statute ( CPLR art 62) unconstitutional to the extent it permitted attachment without prior notice in an action to recover a money judgment for fraud, finding that the New York attachment statute met the requisites of procedural due process laid down in Mitchell v Grant (416 U.S. 600), wherein the validity of a Louisiana sequestration statute was upheld. On their present motion for reargument, defendants cite Sugar v Curtis Circulation Co. (383 F Supp 643), decided subsequent to the denial of their motion to vacate, wherein a three-Judge Federal court, observing that the New York attachment statute was strikingly similar to the Louisiana statute, upheld in Mitchell, in all respects but one, invalidated the New York statute [***3] on the ground that it did not guarantee a defendant an opportunity for an immediate post-seizure hearing, at which the plaintiff must prove the grounds upon which the writ was issued. The original determination sustaining the order of attachment is adhered to. The decision in the Sugar case, which has been stayed pending appeal to the United States Supreme Court, is not controlling. Moreover, the New York statute does afford a defendant an opportunity for an immediate post-seizure hearing, since a motion to vacate may be made and a hearing obtained where the facts asserted are challenged, which is not the case here. And that due process is necessarily violated by imposing upon a defendant the burden of proof on a motion to vacate is not nearly as clear as Sugar suggests, nor are the New York authorities as definitive with respect to the burden of proof as it suggests. But, even assuming that the prevailing case law does impose the burden upon the defendant, such rule is neither implicit in nor directed by the New York statute, and, therefore, should not affect its constitutionality.

 

1327 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Sigety v. Hynes


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


83 Misc. 2d 648; 372 N.Y.S.2d 771; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2954



May 19, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Respondent thus may not proceed under authority of subdivision 8 of section 63 of the Executive Law, and accordingly, petitioner's application to restrain the respondent from so proceeding and to quash the respondent's subpoena dated April 7, 1975 issued pursuant to that section is granted in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner nursing home sought a judgment from the court restraining respondent Deputy Attorney-General of New York from proceeding in excess of his lawful jurisdiction and quashing a subpoena ad testificandum and duces tecum.


OVERVIEW: The deputy attorney general had subpoenas issued against the nursing home to compel discovery. The court granted the nursing home's application to restrain respondent and quashed subpoenas. The court found little doubt that the deputy attorney general's function was intended to be primarily prosecutorial rather than generally investigative. Even if his appointment were deemed to be both prosecutorial and generally investigative, the prosecutorial role sufficiently tainted any general investigation so as to preclude the use of subpoena power pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(8), especially where both the prosecution and the general investigation were conducted simultaneously. The court held that the deputy attorney general might not utilize § 63(8) as a vehicle to circumvent the rights and protection traditionally afforded an accused in a grand jury investigation.


OUTCOME: The court granted the nursing home's petition to restrain the deputy attorney general from proceeding in excess of his lawful jurisdiction and quashed subpoenas.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- subpoenas -- appointment of respondent as Special Prosecutor relates primarily to prosecutorial rather than investigative activities with respect to nongovernmental nursing homes -- impaneling of Grand Jury and prosecutorial role of respondent preclude his use of subpoena power for general investigation under subdivision 3 of section 8 of Executive Law, since such use is beyond authority of such statute and would, by virtue of limited rights protecting party thereunder, circumvent rights which would be traditionally accorded petitioner nursing home operator before Grand Jury.

1. The appointment of respondent as Special Prosecutor relates primarily to prosecutorial rather than generally investigative activities with respect to the operation of nongovernmental nursing homes. The appointment was characterized by the Attorney-General as the commencement of a criminal [***2] investigation, and the decretal provision of the Executive Order of February 7, 1975 ( 9 NYCRR 3.4) specifies that possible criminal violations were to be investigated.

2. In view of the impaneling of a Grand Jury and of respondent's prosecutorial role he is precluded from using the subpoena power for general investigation into matters concerning the public peace, safety and justice under subdivision 8 of section 63 of the Executive Law, since such use is beyond the authority of the statute and would, by virtue of the limited rights protecting a party subpoenaed thereunder, circumvent the rights which would traditionally be accorded petitioner nursing home operator before a Grand Jury.

 

1328 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Price v. Hoyle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Rockland County


82 Misc. 2d 174; 368 N.Y.S.2d 126; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2594



May 13, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff is granted. ( CPLR 3212, subd [e]; Blye v Globe-Wernicke Realty Co., 33 NY2d 15 (n. 3 on p. 176.) The defendants' cross motions are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff tenant moved for partial summary judgment on her claims of conversion against defendant landlord. Thereafter, defendant moved for summary judgment on its claims for past due rent and for dismissal of tenant's complaint.


OVERVIEW: The tenant filed an action for conversion, alleging that the landlord took possession of her personal property and locked her out of her dwelling unit. The landlord raised an affirmative defense and counter claim, contending that the tenant abandoned the premises upon her failure to tender rent and that the removal of property was authorized under the lease. The court granted the tenant's motion for partial summary judgment on her claims and determined that regardless of whether the tenant abandoned the premises or was locked out, the landlord had no right to her personal property. The court concluded that the landlord's seizure of the tenant's personal property, which was based upon the alleged non-payment of rent, and was prohibited by N.Y. Aband. Prop. Law § 1310. The court denied the landlord's motion for summary judgment on its claims for past-due rent and expenses related to the removal and storage of the tenant's possessions upon a finding that the tenant was not a party to the lease agreement and that the tenant asserted ownership of the property by filing an action in conversion.


OUTCOME: The court granted partial summary judgment in favor of the tenant on her claim of conversion and denied the landlord's cross motions for summary judgment and dismissal of the tenant's complaint.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- distress for rent -- landlord seizure of personal property of plaintiff, occupant of allegedly abandoned dwelling unit, for alleged accrued rent, was illegal -- it was distress for rent, and exercise or enforcement of remedy of distress is constitutionally prohibited -- assuming there was abandonment and that no alleged right was sought to be enforced by landlord, seizure would still be illegal -- one who holds unclaimed property has statutory obligation to have it declared abandoned and paid to comptroller -- plaintiff was not party to lease which gave landlord right to remove effects in event of desertion of premises -- in any event, she cannot be deemed to have abandoned property since her present action, in conversion, is assertion of ownership.

1. Whether, as alleged by plaintiff in this action for conversion, she and the lessee of a dwelling unit were locked out of it or, as alleged by the landlord, they abandoned it, the landlord's seizure [***2] of her personal property because of alleged accrued rent was illegal. It was distress for rent, and the exercise or enforcement of the remedy of distress, i.e., the taking of personal property to enforce an alleged right or satisfy a wrong, is constitutionally prohibited.

2. Assuming that there was an abandonment and that no alleged right, such as the right to rent, was sought to be enforced by the landlord, the seizure would still be illegal. One who holds unclaimed property of another has a statutory obligation to have it declared abandoned and paid to the comptroller for the benefit of all the people of the State. Moreover, although there is a provision in the lease which gave the landlord the right to remove effects in the event of desertion of the premises, plaintiff was not a party to the lease. And, in any event, she cannot be deemed to have abandoned the property, since her present action, in conversion, is an assertion of ownership.

 

1329 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Schenectady Urban Renewal Agency v. Bucci


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Schenectady County


89 Misc. 2d 763; 394 N.Y.S.2d 502; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3384



May 8, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner urban renewal agency filed a condemnation proceeding against respondent property owner, who alleged that the agency had no valid public use for his property and, used unconstitutional methods and procedures. He further claimed that the agency did not negotiate the acquisition of his property in good faith and that a planning commission's vote was void because a member should have disqualified himself.


OVERVIEW: The property owner disputed the agency's decision to include his property in an expanded urban renewal zone. The court noted that N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 668 (1968) established the agency and there was no contention that the it lacked authority or that statutory requirements were not met. Rather, the property owner contended that an amended urban renewal plan, which extended the original boundary to include the property owner's building, was illegal and improper. The court held that the decision to expand the renewal area and the agency finding of a public purpose were authorized acts that were not justiciable on the record presented. The proof suggested no reason for the agency to pursue negotiations with the property owner, who had in effect locked them out. There was no merit to the contention that the agency was not properly constituted under § 668 and N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 553(4). Finally, a planning commission vote was not void because of a member's prior confrontation with the property owner. The challenged member was presumed to have acted properly in the public interest in the absence of facts that showed otherwise. The agency was directed to submit a judgment.


OUTCOME: The court directed entry of a judgment favorable to the agency.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Eminent domain -- urban renewal.

1. It is not necessary that a plan for the use of property included within an urban renewal project be formulated prior to its condemnation.

2. The elimination of slums, unsanitary and blighted areas has been declared to be a public purpose and, once the local authorities who have been constitutionally and statutorily empowered to determine that an area is substandard and insanitary have made their finding, not corruptly, irrationally or baselessly, it is not subject to judicial review.

3. In determining what properties should be included within the boundaries of an urban renewal project, or subsequently annexed to the project, the test is as to the area as a unit, and not as to any one or more particular structures. It could be found that a particular property was necessary to the project by reason of a prominent setting or key location, or other factors.

4. As to a claim that an urban renewal agency did not negotiate in good faith for the purchase of property now sought to be condemned, since it purchased an adjacent building for a sum greater than it offered for the subject property, and still had an unexpended appropriation, there is [***2] no evidence that the two structures were of comparable value, nor does the proof suggest any reason for it to have pursued negotiations further, particularly when the owner told it that the property was not for sale.

5. An urban renewal agency which, as mandated by the statute creating it (General Municipal Law, § 668), consists of the members of the city council and the Mayor, is legally constituted. The statutory scheme of the Urban Renewal Agency Act (General Municipal Law, art 15-A) itself provides that any one or more of the members of an urban renewal agency may be an official or employee of the municipality.

6. As to a claim that a member of the planning commission which approved the boundaries of an urban renewal project "should have disqualified himself", there is no showing that he was, in fact, disqualified or that any legal basis for his disqualification existed. Despite an alleged "severe personality clash" between him and the owner of property included within the project, there is a presumption he performed his public duty honestly and in accordance with law, and no evidence rebuts that presumption. Moreover, the landowner did not make any challenge to the member's [***3] qualification at a time when the issue, if he really considered there was one, could have been promptly met and disposed of or preserved for judicial consideration.

 

1330 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Union Nat'l Bank v. First Merrick Constr. Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Rensselaer County


81 Misc. 2d 658; 367 N.Y.S.2d 434; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2441



April 24, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff bank filed an interpleader action seeking a determination of rights to defendant debtor's funds on deposit. The interpleader action was converted by the court into a special garnishment proceeding and the court was required to determine defendant judgment creditor and defendant note holder's claims to the funds.


OVERVIEW: The debtor and the judgment creditor contracted for the construction of low-rent housing. The debtor issued an advance note to the note holder in exchange for money, securing the note by pledging a portion of contract proceeds and receipts of the housing project, and by issuing a declaration of trust. The judgment creditor then obtained a judgment against the debtor. As there were conflicting claims to the debtor's funds on deposit with the bank, the bank filed an interpleader action. The court issued a judgment denying the judgment creditor's claim and vacating its levy on the funds. The debtor had authority under N.Y. Pub. Hous. Law § 47 to issue the advance note and to provide security for the note. As the security was pledged to the note holder before anyone else obtained claims against the debtor, and as under § 47 the note holder's security interest could not be diminished by the uniform commercial code, the note holder's security interest in the funds was superior to the judgment creditor's interest in the funds.


OUTCOME: The court entered a judgment denying the judgment creditor's claim against the debtor's funds and directed that the judgment creditor's levy against the funds be vacated.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Public housing -- pledge of Housing Authority's bank deposits to United States -- defendant United States of America, Department of Housing and Urban Development, by virtue of advance note and declaration of trust executed by defendant Housing Authority, has established perfected security interest prior in time to interest of defendant judgment creditor in funds on deposit in plaintiff bank in account of defendant Authority (US Code, tit 42, § 1401 et seq.; Public Housing Law, § 47) -- pledge of bank deposits of defendant Authority to United States is not fraudulent conveyance -- section 47 of Public Housing Law is not unconstitutional.

1. Plaintiff bank commenced an interpleader action to determine adverse claims to funds on deposit in the account of defendant Housing Authority. In November, 1969 the Housing Authority entered into a contract with defendant judgment creditor for construction of low-rent housing in the City of Troy. Defendant judgment creditor may not satisfy its judgment, filed May 30, 1973, from the funds on deposit in the account of the Authority, since defendant United States of America, Department of Housing and Urban Development, in accordance with [***2] the provisions of section 1401 et seq. of title 42 of the United States Code and section 47 of the Public Housing Law, has established a perfected security interest prior in time to the interest of defendant judgment creditor in said funds. On March 12, 1969, in furtherance of the powers delegated to it by section 47 of the Public Housing Law, the Housing Authority lawfully executed and delivered to the United States an advance note in the amount of $ 1,848,075 secured by a first pledge of and lien on residual receipts of the low-cost housing project. As additional security, said note pledged, mortgaged, conveyed and granted unto the United States an interest in all the real and tangible property owned or to be owned by the Authority. The Authority also executed and filed a declaration of trust creating a trust in the project in favor of the United States, including rent revenues, annual contributions and other receipts. Such action by the Authority granted to the United States a security interest prior to everyone else in the world, incapable of being diminished by the provisions of the Uniform Commercial Code ( § 9-104).

2. The declaration of trust containing a covenant [***3] against alienation of the corpus is not void since inalienability of principle is not forbidden when the purpose of such restraint is to protect the beneficiary.

3. The pledge of the Authority's bank deposits to the United States as a bondholder is not fraudulent as to defendant judgment creditor. All expenditures by the Housing Authority must have the prior approval of the United States, therefore, leave by the United States to permit necessary expenditures by the Authority immunizes those expenditures from the charge of being fraudulent conveyances.

4. Section 47 of the Public Housing Law is not unconstitutional.

 

1331 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Sibila


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Nassau County


81 Misc. 2d 1028; 367 N.Y.S.2d 193; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2522



April 23, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the defendant's motion is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved for a reconsideration of the court's order, which declared defendant to be a prior felony offender, and for an order that defendant's prior conviction under Md. Ann. Code art. 27, § 139 was not a predicate felony within the meaning of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of felony escape in the State of Maryland, under Md. Ann. Code art. 27, § 139. Because of defendant's age at the time of the escape, defendant would have been eligible for youthful offender treatment if the offense had taken place in New York. When defendant was later found guilty of a crime in New York, he was declared to be a prior felony offender, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06(1), and sentenced accordingly. The court held that § 70.06 was constitutional. The court held that it could change its decision based on the weak argument that the situation might have been different if the escape had occurred in New York because defendant might have been granted defendant youthful offender treatment.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion in all respects.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- second felony offender -- defendant, who, because he was 18 years, 6 months old, was not accorded youthful offender status and was thereupon convicted of predicate felony of escape in State of Maryland, is properly sentenced as prior felony offender (Penal Law, § 70.06) despite fact that he would have been eligible for treatment as youthful offender ( CPL art 720) had he committed same crime in New York at that time; section 70.06 is not unconstitutional.

Defendant was 18 years, 6 months old when he was convicted of the predicate felony of escape in the State of Maryland. He was not accorded youthful offender status in Maryland because he was not under age 18 at the date of the crime. Although defendant, had he committed the same crime in New York, would have been eligible for treatment as a youthful offender pursuant to CPL article 720 thereby negating the use of the prior conviction as a predicate felony, defendant is, nevertheless, properly sentenced as a prior felony offender within the meaning of section 70.06 of the Penal Law. Section 70.06 is not unconstitutional. Defendant's argument is [***2] premised upon sheer speculation that he would not be a prior felony offender if the court, in its discretion, granted him youthful offender treatment if the crime was committed in New York at that time. It would be inappropriate for a nunc pro tunc determination to be made concerning defendant's eligibility for youthful offender treatment for a foreign crime.

 

1332 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re T.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


81 Misc. 2d 911; 367 N.Y.S.2d 427; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2492



April 22, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Since respondent has no right to object to such reliance, the seizure of the guns was legal and the motion to suppress their use in evidence is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a juvenile delinquency proceeding in the Family Court of New York, New York County, respondent juvenile filed a motion to suppress firearms seized by petitioner detective from his apartment. The juvenile claimed that the seizure of the evidence violated his U.S. Const. amend. IV rights. The detective had learned of the guns when he searched another boy and found photos that showed the juvenile standing in a room and holding some firearms.


OVERVIEW: The juvenile and the boy belonged to the same gang. The detective was not looking for evidence against the juvenile. However, after he found the photos, the detective located the juvenile on the street, showed him the photos, and stated that he wanted the guns. The juvenile told him he did not have those guns, but that he had some others. The juvenile let the detective in his apartment, and showed him some revolvers. The detective then seized those guns. On appeal, the court held that the juvenile did not have standing to contest the search of the other boy's person. The court also held that, having seen the photos, the detective had probable cause to "stop and frisk" the juvenile and to ask him a reasonable number of questions related to the guns. The court ruled that the juvenile was not entitled to a Miranda warning, or to have a parent present, when the detective questioned him briefly on the street about the guns. Further, the court held that because the detective had a reasonable fear that the guns would disappear if he took the time to get a search warrant for the apartment, exigent circumstances existed that justified his warrantless search of the apartment.


OUTCOME: The court denied the juvenile's motion to suppress the evidence of the firearms seized by the detective in the search of the juvenile's apartment.


HEADNOTES
