Infants -- juvenile delinquents -- searches and seizures -- police, presumably unlawfully, searched four boys on street and seized from one of them some apparently recent snapshots showing another one of them sitting in living room and holding two guns -- photographed boy cannot object to search of, and seizure from his companion -- such seized photographs showed probable cause to arrest photographed boy and to question him briefly, without warning -- he took detective to his home and indicated that guns were in dresser drawer -- since guns were easily removable, no time to apply for search warrant -- detective properly seized those guns -- in juvenile delinquency proceeding against photographed boy, his motion to suppress seized guns is denied.

1. Police in a patrol car saw, in front of a "club", a juvenile whom they had a warrant to arrest for possession of a gun. He, and all the others hereinafter mentioned, were members of a juvenile gang under police surveillance. He disappeared into the club, whereupon the police [***2] waited at the back door; and soon four other boys emerged into the street. The police searched all four, presumably illegally. They found and seized, in and from the pocket of one of them, six apparently recent snapshot photographs showing another one of those four boys sitting in a living room and holding a revolver and a sawed-off shotgun. Under the circumstances, it does not matter who owned the photographs; the photographed boy does not have any standing to dispute the lawfulness of the search of his companion.

2. The photographs showed probable cause to arrest the photographed boy, and to stop and frisk and question him then and there, briefly, without a warrant, and without advising him of constitutional rights ( CPL 140.50; Administrative Code of City of New York, § 436-5.0, subd g).

3. When the detective said to the boy, "I want those guns", the boy said he had guns in his home. There was no time to apply to a court for a warrant to search the boy's home for guns, since meantime his companions could easily have removed the guns. The detective was not abusive to this 14-year-old boy and did not use force. He merely accompanied the boy home, and there the boy unlocked [***3] the apartment door and indicated that he had guns in the top drawer of a dresser; and thereupon the detective properly found in that drawer, and properly seized, two loaded revolvers.

4. Accordingly, in this juvenile delinquency proceeding against the photographed boy, his motion to suppress the two seized revolvers from evidence is denied.

 

1333 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Montgomery v. Daniels


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


81 Misc. 2d 373; 367 N.Y.S.2d 419; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2392



April 21, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motions of the defendants and the Attorney-General, the intervenor defendant, dismissing the complaints is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court were motions by defendant tortfeasors and intervenor Attorney-General for an order dismissing the complaint on the merits and plaintiff injured parties' motions for summary judgment, in three cases which were consolidated for the purpose of determining the validity of article XVIII of the Insurance Law, the No-Fault Insurance Law. The Attorney-General also moved to dismiss for lack of the injured parties' capacity to sue.


OVERVIEW: The challenged statute precluded a action against the tortfeasor in automobile accidents, unless the economic loss exceeded $ 50,000. In all three cases, the economic loss was less than $ 500.00. Thus, under the statute, the right of access to the court so that an individual could recover for noneconomic losses was eliminated unless the party sustained a serious injury or had an accident with a noncovered person. In determining that the statute was invalid in its entirety, the court held that the legislature had no authority to take away the rights of the public, without its consent, to recover for tort injuries without at least constitutional amendment. New or supplemental legislation could not contradict or contravene the state Constitution itself, to which such legislation must be subordinate. The classification contained in the law as to serious injury was arbitrary and unreasonable. The court found that the statute did not provide a new system of benefits, but only a barred the rights of some individuals to sue in tort with absolutely nothing in return.


OUTCOME: The motions of the tortfeasors and the Attorney-General dismissing the complaints were denied.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- no fault automobile insurance -- article XVIII of Insurance Law is unconstitutional and invalid in its entirety; said law is unwarranted deprivation of rights of automobile accident victims to recover their actual damages from tort-feasors in trial by jury -- classifications contained in "No Fault" law as to "covered" and "noncovered" persons are arbitrary and unreasonable -- threshold "serious injury" (Insurance Law, § 671) requirement is arbitrary and unreasonable; definition of terms "serious injury" and "significant disfigurement" are void for vagueness -- $ 500 medical expense threshold does not rest on rational basis.

1. The "No Fault" automobile insurance law (Insurance Law, art. XVIII), which provides for compulsory vehicle insurance to compensate "covered" persons for basic economic loss up to $ 50,000 for injuries without regard to fault, and which also eliminates the right of an individual to recover for noneconomic loss unless a "serious injury" (Insurance Law, § 671) is sustained, is unconstitutional and invalid in its entirety.  [***2] Article XVIII is an unwarranted deprivation of the rights of automobile accident victims to recover their actual and long-recognized bodily injury damages from tort-feasors in a trial by jury.

2. The classifications contained in the "No Fault" law as to "covered" and "noncovered" persons are arbitrary and unreasonable. The statute creates a discriminatory system of coverage wherein persons who are injured by "covered" persons may not have access to the courts while a person injured by "noncovered" persons may commence an action for damages and seek recovery for pain and suffering. There is further no rational reason why an individual who is injured in a nonautomobile tort may have access to the courts while a person sustaining the same injury and effects in an automobile accident is barred therefrom, if the "serious injury" test requirement is not met.

3. The classification contained in the law as to the threshold "serious injury" requirement is arbitrary and unreasonable and is therefore invalid as a denial of equal protection of the laws. The definition of the terms "serious injury" and "significant disfigurement" are void for vagueness and violate the fundamental requisites [***3] of due process.

4. Section 671 which defines a personal injury as a "serious injury" if reasonable medical costs would exceed $ 500, does not rest on a rational basis. Medical expenses vary substantially from one area of the State to another and even within areas with respect to all classifications of medical treatment.

 

1334 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Thomas


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Erie County


81 Misc. 2d 891; 367 N.Y.S.2d 182; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2489



April 18, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner prospective administrator sought general letters of administration as requested by the decedent's intestate distributees, six sisters and four brothers. Cross-petitioner alleged daughter also sought letters of administration for the estate, which included a cause of action for personal injury and wrongful death.


OVERVIEW: The alleged daughter claimed she was the decedent's legitimate child under a Florida common-law marriage and had priority to be awarded letters of administration. The court rejected the alleged daughter's claim and granted the prospective administrator the letters of administration. The alleged daughter failed to prove a common-law marriage under Florida law, where her proof at most inferred that she was born from a meretricious relationship and out of wedlock. She also failed to produce an order or filiation declaring paternity. The alleged daughter was not entitled to inherit under Florida law because all parties, including the deceased, were domiciled in New York on the date of death. New York law determined the descent and distribution of the deceased's estate because that was the alleged daughter's place of residence at the time of the deceased's acknowledgment that determined her status as to his eligibility to inherit. Under New York law, she was ineligible to inherit.


OUTCOME: The court granted the prospective administrator's petition for limited letters of administration on the condition of remittance to the court of any wrongful death settlement for allocation.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children born out of wedlock -- letters of administration -- petitioner, illegitimate daughter of decedent, is not awarded letters of administration; petitioner has failed to prove that valid common-law marriage existed between her mother and decedent at time of her birth in State of Florida -- New York law, under which petitioner is ineligible to inherit from decedent, determines petitioner's status as to eligibility to inherit.

1. Petitioner, born in Florida, is the out-of-wedlock daughter of decedent. Petitioner's mother and decedent cohabited in Florida for three years until decedent moved to Buffalo, New York, where he died on October 13, 1974. Petitioner's mother refused to marry decedent in Florida subsequent to the birth of petitioner. Since petitioner has not sustained her burden of proving that a valid common-law marriage, as defined by the State of Florida, existed between her mother and decedent at the time of her birth, she is not the legitimate daughter of decedent and is therefore not awarded letters of administration. The proof infers that petitioner is a child born from a meretricious relationship which does not support the common-law marriage relationship [***2] under Florida law.

2. Since no order of filiation declaring paternity was made by a court of competent jurisdiction, petitioner is not the distributee of decedent ( EPTL 4-1.2, subd [a], par [2]) and is therefore not entitled to letters of administration.

3. Decedent, in an insurance policy, acknowledged petitioner as his daughter, which under Florida law would make petitioner an heir of decedent entitled to inherit from him. However, since petitioner was a New York resident at the time that the acknowledgment was made, New York law, under which petitioner is ineligible to inherit, determines her status as to the eligibility to inherit.

 

1335 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Scarola v. Goldman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, Trial Term, New York County


81 Misc. 2d 977; 367 N.Y.S.2d 186; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2508



April 18, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendants' motion for summary judgment is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved for summary judgment in plaintiff's personal injury action.


OVERVIEW: The court denied defendant's motion for summary judgment in plaintiff's insurance claim against defendant insurer. Plaintiff could not be prejudiced by the decision in an arbitration proceeding to which she was not a party. This would have been unconstitutional, and would have violated the intention of the no-fault law. The trial court was to determine whether plaintiff's medical charges were reasonable and necessary.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for summary judgment, as plaintiff could not be barred from her right to trial by an inter-carrier arbitration award.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- no-fault automobile insurance -- first party carrier paid injured person's $ 510 medical bills, but, in arbitration conducted only between it and other party's carrier, was awarded only $ 401; this did not bind injured person; she may sue all owners and drivers involved for her "non-economic loss" (Insurance Law, §§ 671, 674).

The medical bills of a person who was injured in a collision of two automobiles amounted to $ 510 and were paid by the insurer of the owner of the automobile in which she was a passenger; however, only $ 401 was allowed and awarded to said insurer in an arbitration which was conducted only between it and the insurer of the other automobile. The injured person was not a party to such inter-carrier arbitration and she is not bound by it. She may maintain this action against the owners and drivers of both automobiles to recover her "non-economic loss"; and the reasonableness of her $ 510 bills will be a question of fact to be determined at the trial (Insurance Law, § 671, subd 3; § 671, subd 4, par [b]; § 674; 11 NYCRR 65.10).

 

1336 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Niles


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Rensselaer County


81 Misc. 2d 937; 367 N.Y.S.2d 173; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2497



April 15, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner guardian brought an action to have an infant declared the sole heir of the decedent. Petitioner administrator requested an order authorizing him to compromise and settle a pending action for decedent's wrongful death and declaring him and his wife the sole distributees.


OVERVIEW: The decedent, a 21-year-old male, was killed in an automobile accident. His father was appointed administrator of the decedent's estate. The administrator brought a wrongful death action. In the year before the decedent's death, a filiation proceeding had been commenced. The decedent appeared before the family court and freely acknowledged paternity of the as yet unborn. Shortly after the decedent's death, the family court signed an order declaring the decedent as the father of the child. In addition, a second order declaring the decedent to be the father of the child as of a certain date was issued. Subsequently, the guardian, who represented the interests of the infant, and the administrator sought guidance as to the distribution of the proceeds of a settlement offered in the wrongful death action. The court found the decedent's admission of paternity before the family court was satisfactory proof of the infant's claim. The court then instructed the guardian to examine the facts of the decedent's death and provide a report regarding the proposed settlement.


OUTCOME: The court held the infant was the lawful distributee of the decedent. The court, however, instructed the guardian to examine the facts of decedent's death and provide a report regarding the proposed settlement.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children born out of wedlock -- right to wrongful death proceeds -- although order of filiation was not signed until after decedent's death, decedent's illegitimate daughter is, nonetheless, pursuant to EPTL 4-1.2 (subd [a], par [2]), sole lawful distributee of decedent entitled to receive proceeds of wrongful death action; requirements of EPTL 4-1.2 were satisfied by Family Court factual determination of paternity made in filiation proceeding prior to decedent's death -- decedent's admission of paternity is satisfactory proof of illegitimate daughter's claim.

1. Decedent was killed in an automobile accident on August 22, 1970. Pursuant to EPTL 4-1.2 (subd [a], par [2]), which states that an illegitimate child can inherit from its father if a court of competent jurisdiction during the lifetime of the father made an order of filiation, decedent's illegitimate daughter born January 17, 1970, is the sole lawful distributee of decedent entitled to the proceeds of the wrongful death action. Although the order of filiation was not actually signed until after decedent's death, the requirements of EPTL 4-1.2 (subd [a], par [2]) were satisfied by the factual determination [***2] of the Family Court, made in a filiation proceeding prior to decedent's death wherein decedent admitted paternity, that decedent was the father of the as yet unborn child. The signing of the order was merely a ministerial act. An injustice would occur if EPTL 4-1.2 were to be applied literally.

2. Even if there had been no prior Family Court determination regarding paternity, decedent's admission of paternity is satisfactory proof of the infant's claim.

 

1337 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Johnson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Erie County


97 Misc. 2d 905; 412 N.Y.S.2d 721; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3391



April 14, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Order of the Judge of the City Court of Buffalo herein dismissing the information is vacated and the information is hereby reinstated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People appealed from an order of the City Court of Buffalo (New York), which dismissed an information charging defendant with violating N.Y. Penal Law § 130.38. The trial court found that § 130.38 was unconstitutional because it denied equal protection of the law to citizens not married to each other in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11.


OVERVIEW: The trial court found that the statute would make criminals of some citizens, but not others, on the basis of an unsupportable distinction and would constitutionally wrongfully deny to the former the equal protection of the law. The court rejected that conclusion. The court noted that traditionally, the system of jurisprudence in New York had recognized discriminate application and enforcement of laws as they affected certain classes of citizens such as minors and married persons. The court vacated the order and agreed with a federal court's statement that a rational foundation existed for the state's discrimination between acts of consensual sodomy committed by married and unmarried persons. No matter who the participants were, such deportment in public violated the prohibition of § 130.38. The court noted that if the participants had been married to each other, they could have been prosecuted under New York State's public lewdness statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 245.00.


OUTCOME: The court vacated the trial court's order and reinstated the information.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Consensual Sodomy -- Constitutionality

 Section 130.38 of the Penal Law, which makes it a crime to engage in deviate sexual intercourse with another person, is not unconstitutional as a denial of equal protection to citizens not married to each other in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution and section 11 of article I of the New York Constitution, since discriminate application and enforcement of laws as they affect certain classes of citizens such as minors and married persons has been recognized and a rational foundation exists for the State's discrimination between acts of consensual sodomy committed by married and unmarried persons; the argument that it is criminal for unmarried people to engage in sodomy in public, but not for married people to do so is rejected, since if the participants had been married to each other they could be prosecuted under the public lewdness statute (Penal Law, § 245.00), and preventing a violation of public decency is a legitimate concern of the Legislature.

 

1338 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Pellnat v. Buffalo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Buffalo


80 Misc. 2d 849; 367 N.Y.S.2d 672; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2420



April 10, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: An action was brought by plaintiff taxpayer in small claims against defendant city court for moneys had and received regarding taxes paid under protest. A non-jury trial was held, and the court ordered the parties to appear for the purpose of offering additional proof as to the amount of damages and additional argument on the questions of law involved.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Local Fin. Law § 11.00(a)(42-a) was previously declared unconstitutional insofar as it excluded the City of Buffalo's future annual requirement for pension and retirement liabilities from the tax limit provided in N.Y. Const. art. VIII, §§ 10, 11. The taxpayer was faced with a tax bill, part of which was unconstitutionally imposed and the nonpayment of which rendered his property subject to a lien. Defendant paid his bill while preserving his rights via a protest so as to protect his property against encumbrance. The city's contention was that once N.Y. Local Fin. Law § 11.00(a)(42-a) was declared unconstitutional, and a nonretroactivity doctrine was adopted, the New York Court of Appeals rendered the vehicle of protest impotent and effectively barred recovery of overpayment notwithstanding timely protest. The court granted judgment in favor of the taxpayer and rejected the city's theory. Illegal taxes, voluntarily paid were not recoverable, but illegal taxes involuntarily paid were recoverable; and, in enunciating the nonretroactivity doctrine, the New York Court of Appeals did not annul or abrogate a citizen's right to pay disputed taxes and filing a protest to the same.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that the taxpayer be granted a money judgment against the city.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- constitutional limitation on real property taxes -- timely protest -- plaintiff, who paid his real property taxes under protest, after defendant city's real property tax was declared unconstitutional ( Hurd v City of Buffalo, 41 AD2d 402, affd 34 NY2d 628), is entitled to recover unconstitutionally imposed portion of his tax bill in sum of $ 112.10; nonretroactivity doctrine does not bar plaintiff's recovery since timely protest was made.

1. After paragraph 42-a of subdivision a of section 11.00 of the Local Finance Law was declared unconstitutional insofar as it excluded defendant City of Buffalo's future annual requirement for pension and retirement liabilities from the tax limit provided in sections 10 and 11 of article VIII of the State Constitution ( Hurd v City of Buffalo, 41 AD2d 402, affd 34 NY2d 628), plaintiff, to protect his property against encumbrance, paid, under protest, his real property taxes which were imposed by defendant city for the year commencing July 1, 1973 and ending June 30, 1974. Since plaintiff preserved his rights by paying his tax bill under protest, he is entitled to recover the unconstitutionally imposed portion of his tax bill [***2] in the sum of $ 112.10. Illegal taxes involuntarily paid are recoverable. Where protest has been interposed, the municipality is notified that it may be obligated to refund the taxes and is required to be prepared to meet that contingency. The nonretroactivity doctrine enunciated in Hurd does not abrogate the right of citizens of this State who, recognizing their obligation to pay taxes, chose an orderly way to meet that obligation while objecting to a denial of their rights.

2. Plaintiff was not required to commence an action enjoining defendant from collecting taxes as a prerequisite for his recovery.

 

1339 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York Auction Co. v. Belt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


81 Misc. 2d 1032; 368 N.Y.S.2d 98; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2523



April 4, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant debtors sought reargument of their motion for partial summary judgment dismissing the complaint and vacating an attachment by which plaintiff creditor obtained jurisdiction and/or renewal of the motion to vacate the attachment on the grounds that it was obtained unconstitutionally.


OVERVIEW: The motion for reargument was made on the assumption that the differences between the facts alleged in the complaint and those in the creditor's opposing affidavits were so great as to require dismissal of the complaint. However, notwithstanding the possible differences in technical legal theory between the complaint and the creditor's affidavits, it was clear that both referred to the same transaction, an indebtedness arising from an allowance of a credit by the creditor to a buyer of the debtor's goods based upon a claim of breach of warranty. The creditor, acting as a selling agent, sold the debtor's goods, advancing to the debtor a sum of money with the expectation of being reimbursed from the net proceeds of the sale. The books were kept on an accrual basis. The buyer, a Canadian, was dissatisfied with the goods, obtained a credit against the creditor, who in turn sought reimbursement from the debtor. The balance due was in accordance with the complaint. The court would not vacate the attachment, which it held to be constitutional and valid, as the creditor had a meritorious complaint and attachment was necessary to secure jurisdiction over a nonresident.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motions to the extent only of granting reargument and on reargument, the original decision denying summary judgment and vacatur of the attachment was adhered to.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Attachment -- jurisdiction over nonresident -- in action for balance due on loan, plaintiff selling agent, which, after advancing sum of money to nonresident defendants, allowed credit in amount of $ 10,009.38 to buyer of defendants' furs based upon claim of breach of warranty, properly obtained jurisdiction over nonresident defendants by means of valid attachment -- attachment statute ( CPLR 6223) is not unconstitutional; attachment without prior notice is constitutional where said attachment was obtained against nonresident for purposes of jurisdiction (cf. Sugar v Curtis Pub. Co., 383 F Supp 643).

1. Plaintiff selling agent properly obtained jurisdiction over nonresident defendants by means of a valid attachment. Plaintiff, acting as selling agent engaged in the practice of selling defendants' furs, after advancing to defendants a sum of money with the expectation that it would be paid out of the net proceeds of the sale, allowed a credit of $ 10,009.38 to a Canadian buyer of defendants' furs based upon a claim of breach of warranty and thereupon charged the amount of said credit back to defendants. The attachment is not vacated since the complaint sufficiently states that [***2] the sum of $ 10,009.38 is the balance due on the loan, representing the moneys advanced by plaintiff to defendants.

2. The New York attachment statute ( CPLR 6223) is not unconstitutional. Sugar v Curtis Pub. Co. (383 F Supp 643) is inapplicable since attachment without prior notice is constitutional, where the attachment was obtained against a nonresident for purposes of jurisdiction. Attachments may be vacated not only where the attachment is unnecessary for security purposes, but also where it appears that plaintiff does not have a meritorious case.

 

1340 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Akari House, Inc. v. Irizzary


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


81 Misc. 2d 543; 366 N.Y.S.2d 955; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2422



April 3, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, plaintiffs' motion is denied and defendants' motions for summary judgment are granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, city and insurer, and intervenor state brought a motion to dismiss the complaint of plaintiff taxpayers and for summary judgment, in the taxpayers' action for a declaration that N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 423 violated the New York and United States Constitutions, and for a permanent injunction. The taxpayers filed a motion for leave to take legislators' depositions, and for a continuance.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers alleged that § 423 violated the state and federal Constitutions, as it (1) did not further the slum clearance purpose set forth in N.Y. Const. art. XVIII, (2) established an arbitrary classification bearing no rational relation to its stated legislative purposes, and (3) was intended exclusively as a private local law for the benefit of the insurer and tenants of two areas. The court held that while the taxpayers has standing to bring the action, their motions were denied, and defendants' summary judgment motions were granted. The court held that N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 423 was within the category of tenant protection legislation, was part of an ongoing scheme of neighborhood rehabilitation, and was not required to be interpreted in contradiction of the legislature's stated purpose. The taxpayers failed to show that the legislators had any exclusive knowledge of facts bearing on the intention of the legislature. The court held that § 423 did not violate N.Y. Const. art. XVIII or the Equal Protection Clauses of the state or federal constitutions and was not a private law in violation of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 17 or N.Y. Const. art. XVI, § 1.


OUTCOME: The court denied the taxpayers' motions, and granted defendants' motions for summary judgment, in the taxpayers' suit for a declaration that a state statute authorizing community redevelopment violated the New York and United States Constitutions, and for a permanent injunction.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- redevelopment company projects -- tax abatement -- section 423 of Real Property Tax Law (L 1974 ch 941) granting tax abatements and other benefits to redevelopment projects is not unconstitutional; section 423 is part of on-going scheme of neighborhood rehabilitation and is therefore within authorized slum clearance purpose of article XVIII of State Constitution -- redevelopment projects represent rational classification for tax abatement; section 423 does not violate Equal Protection Clauses of State or Federal Constitutions.

1. Section 423 of the Real Property Tax Law (L 1974, ch 941) granting tax abatements to redevelopment company projects, without income limitations, and further subjecting the rents in said projects to rent ceilings and guaranteeing the tenants' rights to lease renewals pursuant to the Rent Stabilization Law of 1969 (Administrative Code of City of New York, tit YY, ch 51), is not unconstitutional. The purpose of section 423 is the prevention of undue hardship and dislocation to the projects, the persons and families residing therein and [***2] the municipalities in which such projects are located. The statute provides that the real property taxes payable on redevelopment projects upon the expiration of the 25-year tax exemption granted to such projects pursuant to section 125 of the Private Housing Finance Law (Redevelopment Companies Law of 1942), will be phased out over a 10-year period, at which time they will be fully taxable. Although the subject redevelopment projects, owned by defendant insurance company, are no longer slum areas in need of physical rehabilitation, the tax abatements granted defendant under section 423 are nevertheless lawful since section 423 is part of an on-going scheme of neighborhood rehabilitation and is therefore within the authorized slum clearance purpose of article XVIII of the State Constitution. Article XVIII is permissive and flexible and was not intended to deprive the State of its otherwise inherent power to achieve valid purposes in the field of housing. The 25-year program of neighborhood rehabilitation of the Redevelopment Company Law was not conceived or carried out only as a narrow program of physical reconstruction and is not required to be interpreted as such in contradiction [***3] of the Legislature's determination that 10 years more is required to maintain stability of neighborhoods.

2. Redevelopment projects represent a rational classification for tax abatement. Therefore, section 423, which is a general law applicable to all redevelopment company projects in the State, does not violate the Equal Protection Clauses of the State or Federal Constitution and is not an unlawful private bill.

3. Plaintiffs, as real estate taxpayers of the City of New York affected by the exemption bestowed on defendant insurance company, have a sufficiently concrete aggrievment to bring this action against both the city and the State. The fact that plaintiffs' economic stake is small and their tax rate not demonstrably affected, does not deprive them of standing to bring suit.

 

1341 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Faulkner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Westchester County


81 Misc. 2d 764; 366 N.Y.S.2d 965; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2470



April 3, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the indictment is dismissed, defendant is discharged and his bail is exonerated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss his indictment on charges of reckless endangerment, attempted assault, menacing, prohibited use of a weapon, criminal mischief, and leaving the scene of an accident on the ground that he had been denied his constitutional right to a speedy trial.


OVERVIEW: Defendant had requested that the county court dismiss the indictment against him after a delay of more than two years. That court denied the motion, finding that the delay was due to congestion of the court system and that defendant was not prejudiced by the delay because his expert witness had died. Defendant renewed his motion seven months later when the case was transferred to the Supreme Court of New York for trial. The court granted the motion, holding that the additional delay on top of the prior period of delay was presumptively prejudicial. The court said that the prior ruling could not be revisited, but based its decision on the period of additional delay since the prior court's ruling. The court applied a four-part test to determine if defendant's constitutional right to a speedy trial had been violated, considering the length of delay, the reason for the delay, defendant's assertion of his right, and prejudice to defendant. The court found that for four months the case was not brought to trial although other cases were moved through the system in that time. Prejudice to defendant was found from the inability to resume his career due to the trial delay.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment against him because a delay of seven months on top of a prior delay of more than two years was presumptively prejudicial. Defendant's loss of an opportunity to resume his career demonstrated prejudice from the delay.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- right to speedy trial -- prosecutor's delay in bringing defendant's case to trial seven months after defendant first asserted his speedy trial rights, coupled with previous two-year delay in bringing defendant's case to trial, warrants dismissal of indictment; congestion of court calendars and priority given to jail cases over bail cases did not excuse prosecutor's failure to bring defendant's case to trial -- defendant, suspended police officer, was prejudiced by loss of opportunity to resume his job.

1. A felony complaint was filed against defendant, a New York City police officer, in the City Court of New Rochelle on May 17, 1972. Defendant was immediately suspended from duty by virtue of the criminal charges filed against him. Defendant was indicted on September 26, 1972, arraigned in County Court on October 4, 1972 and then released on bail. Defendant's attorney served the District Attorney with written notice of an insanity defense on January 3, 1973. Defendant's psychiatrist died before the case was to be tried. On June 12, 1974, two years and one month after [***2] the criminal prosecution had been commenced, the County Court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment on speedy trial grounds finding that there had been no undue delay and that the death of his psychiatrist caused no prejudice to defendant. However, the prosecution's subsequent seven-month delay in bringing defendant's case to trial after he first asserted his speedy trial rights, coupled with the previous two-year delay, warrants a dismissal of the indictment. Congestion of court calendars and the priority given to the trial of jail cases over bail cases is not an acceptable excuse for the prosecution's failure to bring defendant's case to trial. The prosecutor failed to demonstrate that it would not have been possible to bring defendant to trial between June 12, 1974 and January 20, 1975, when the case was called in.

2. The decision of the County Court that the death of defendant's psychiatrist did not impair his defense, is binding. However, defendant has nevertheless been prejudiced by the delay. Defendant's only chance to return to service with the police department was to exonerate himself in an early trial. Defendant's chances for exoneration have grown slimmer [***3] because of the delay. The loss of an opportunity to resume a career in law enforcement is prejudicial to defendant. The remedy of absolute discharge is the only remedy that effectively protects the individual's right to a speedy trial. Accordingly, the indictment is dismissed, defendant is discharged and his bail is exonerated.

 

1342 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rochester Gas & Electric Corp. v. Chatterton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Monroe County


81 Misc. 2d 522; 366 N.Y.S.2d 323; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2417



April 1, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The order appealed from is reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant utility corporation sought review of a decision from the Rochester City Court (New York), which vacated an order of seizure issued against respondent customer upon an application by the corporation for such an order, stemming from the customer's failure to pay for the utility service supplied by the corporation. The corporation sought to seize its utility meter from the premises rented by the customer.


OVERVIEW: The corporation supplied utility service to the customer, and when the customer failed to make payments for such service, the corporation notified the customer of the corporation's application for an order of seizure of the corporation's utility meter from the premises rented by the customer. The customer received the notice but failed to appear before the city court, and the order of seizure was issued. The customer filed a motion to vacate the order, and the city court held that the corporation's failure to allege a demand for the return of the meter and a refusal by the customer constituted a jurisdictional defect in the corporation's affidavit supporting its application for the order and such failure precluded the granting of the order. The corporation appealed, and the court reversed, holding that the customer had notice of the corporation's application for an order of seizure and an opportunity to be heard prior to the issuance of the order of seizure and thus, demand and refusal were not required in the corporation's application for the order under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7102.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the city court's order, which vacated an order of seizure applied for by the corporation and issued against the customer.


HEADNOTES

Replevin -- demand and refusal -- public utilities -- plaintiff public utility company, after giving defendant customer, who is in arrears for payment of gas and electric service, prior notice and opportunity to be heard, properly obtained order of seizure ( CPLR 7102) directing Sheriff to enter defendant's premises and seize meters located therein; failure to allege due demand and refusal does not preclude granting of order of seizure; due process only requires prior notice and opportunity to be heard.

Defendant customer, who is in arrears for the payment of gas and electric service, denied plaintiff public utility company access to meters located inside his premises. Plaintiff, after giving defendant prior notice of its intention to apply for an order of seizure and an opportunity to be heard, properly obtained an order of seizure ( CPLR 7102) from the Rochester City Court directing the Sheriff to break open, enter defendant's premises and seize the meters. Defendant did not avail himself of the opportunity for a hearing. Plaintiff's failure to allege, in the affidavit supporting the application for the order of seizure, that a demand [***2] for return of the meters was made and that defendant refused to honor the demand, does not constitute a jurisdictional defect precluding the granting of the order of seizure. An order of seizure may only be granted "upon such terms as may be required to conform to the due process of law requirements of the fourteenth amendment to the constitution of the United States" ( CPLR 7102, subd [d], par 1). The critical requirement of due process is prior notice and opportunity to be heard, both of which were afforded defendant, and not due demand and refusal.

 

1343 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Halpern v. Lomenzo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


81 Misc. 2d 467; 367 N.Y.S.2d 653; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2408



March 31, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, racehorse owners and the Horseman's Benevolent Association, Inc (racehorse owners) brought an action against defendants, state officials charged with supervising thoroughbred horse racing, the New York Racing Association (NYRA), the Jockey Club, and various racing officials employed at NYRA tracks. Plaintiffs alleged that certain statutes and the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The racehorse owners filed a complaint against state officials, NYRA, the Jockey Club, and various racing officials, alleging that, as a result of the enactment of various statutes, thoroughbred horse racing was conducted as a public enterprise whose conduct was delivered by the state into the hands of the racehorse owners' competitors who operated racing for their private benefit thereby depriving the racehorse owners equal protection of the laws. The court determined that the horseracing conducted by NYRA was not a governmental activity but that a "symbiotic relationship" existed as a result of the financial structure of NYRA so as to require equal protection of the laws. The court found that, although the racehorse owners were entitled to equal protection, the racehorse owners had failed to demonstrate that the difference in allocation of stall space resulted from other than reasonable business judgment exercised with the intention of attracting the best available horses. The court determined, however, that certain regulations allowing the Jockey Club to suspend a jockey or disqualify an owner were an unconstitutional delegation of the state's licensing authority.


OUTCOME: The court found that the statutes creating NYRA were constitutional and that, although NYRA had a symbiotic relationship to the state and NYRA's actions, therefore, constituted state action, the racehorse owners were not denied equal protection because any discrimination was based on business judgments. The count determined, however, that certain regulations constituted an unconstitutional delegation of the state's licensing authority.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Horse racing -- rules of racing -- certain Rules of Racing (19 NYCRR 22.12, 22.13, 22.17, 24.1, 25.4, 26.3, 26.7, 26.15, 26.18) are adjudged invalid or unconstitutional in whole or in part.

1. Since practically all thoroughbred horse racing in New York State is conducted or controlled for State purposes by a board of three stewards -- one appointed by a private club (The Jockey Club), one appointed by a private stock corporation (the New York Racing Association, Inc.), and one appointed by the New York State Racing Commission (19 NYCRR 22.3; L 1926, ch 440, § 9-a, as amd; L 1934, ch 310, § 5, as amd; N. Y. Const., art I, § 9, par 1) -- and is largely controlled by the secretary of the New York Racing Association, Inc., who is known as "the racing secretary", constitutional principles of due process, fair play and equal opportunity must control the New York State Racing Commission's Rules of Racing (19 NYCRR Part 20; now in 9 NYCRR Part 4020).

2. The following Rules of Racing are adjudged invalid or unconstitutional, in whole or in part, for arbitrariness, unfairness, or lack of standards: 19 NYCRR 22.12 (power to exclude and suspend); 19 NYCRR 22.13 (imposition of civil [***2] penalty); 19 NYCRR 22.17, 25.4 (disqualification); 19 NYCRR 24.1, 26.15, 26.18 (registration and fees to be paid to the Jockey Club); 19 NYCRR 26.3 (report and fee to the Jockey Club); 19 NYCRR 26.7 ("The Jockey Club may disapprove").

 

1344 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fur-Lex Realty, Inc. v. Lindsay


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


81 Misc. 2d 904; 367 N.Y.S.2d 388; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2491



March 31, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is granted and the complaint as against said defendants is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city officials filed a motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint that plaintiff former property owners filed contending that the city's exercise of its power to condemn a lot was unconstitutional. The former property owners contended that they were personally aggrieved by the lease agreement between the city and tenant and that the terms of the agreement contravened public policy.


OVERVIEW: The former property owners filed a complaint that contended that the lease agreement between the city and tenant and that the terms of the agreement was contrary to public policy by failing to provide for adequate financial security to the city in the event of the tenant's default. Further, the former property owner claimed that the city's exercise of its power was unconstitutional and that the former property owners were personally aggrieved by the lease agreement. The city filed a motion for summary judgment. The court granted the motion and dismissed the complaint as to the city. The court reasoned that there was no tenable basis whatever for any claim that the former property owner was personally aggrieved by the lease agreement between the city and the tenant. Additionally, the court held that there was not any merit to the claim that the terms of the agreement contravened public policy by failing to provide for adequate financial security. The court concluded that the decisions of the city officials were within their sound discretion. Therefore, the court held that the former property owners failed to sustain their charges of illegality.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city's motion for summary judgment dismissing the former property owners' complaint that claimed the terms of the agreement between the city and the tenant contravened public policy.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- bids and bidders -- under New York City Zoning Resolution, "single ownership" of "Zoning lot" is created when lot owner acquires 75-year lease of adjoining lot -- adjoining lot (with courthouse), in this case, is owned by City of New York -- 75-year lease and sublease of city's lot and courthouse, from which city will realize about $ 46,000 yearly rent and about $ 175,000 yearly additional realty taxes, is valid -- such lease was let at "public auction" (New York City Charter, § 384), even though, in practical effect, such auction was limited to adjoining lot owners.

1. A lot owner in Manhattan was erecting an office building, but was limited to erecting 400,000 square feet of floor space, since the New York City Zoning Resolution limits the floor area and height to which a building can be erected, by the size of the lot and by the floor area ratio assigned to such a lot. However, the "Definitions" section (§ 12-10) of the zoning resolution provides, in paragraph (c) of the (unnumbered) definition of a "Zoning lot", that a "single ownership"  [***2] is created when a lot owner acquires a lease of the adjoining lot "of not less than 75 years duration". Here, the adjoining lot (on which is a courthouse) was and is owned by the City of New York. After negotiations and bidding, the city leased its lot and courthouse to this adjoining lot owner for 75 years at a rental averaging $ 46,000 a year; and the city took back a sublease, at no rental, for 74 years and 364 days, of its courthouse and of all air space or floor space above its courthouse exceeding 100,000 square feet in area. Thus the city can, if it ever wishes, increase the height of its courthouse by the allowable square feet of floor space which exceed 100,000. Meantime, the city will realize a profit consisting of about $ 46,000 a year rent plus additional real estate taxes of about $ 175,000 a year.

2. This transaction is in the public interest of all taxpayers and is valid and lawful.

3. This transaction is not so-called "spot zoning".

4. The "public auction" (New York City Charter, § 384, subd. b, par. 1) for this lease and sublease was limited, in practical effect, to bids by this adjoining lot owner and by any persons who had the ability to acquire his lot;  [***3] but this is the practical effect of the following provision in the above-cited paragraph 1: "Any lease may provide for the restriction of the use of such real property to purposes determined by the board of estimate".

5. Accordingly, this suit challenging the legality of this lease and sublease is dismissed.

 

1345 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Jeter v. Ellenville Cent. School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Ulster County


81 Misc. 2d 511; 366 N.Y.S.2d 783; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2415



March 27, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] All motions and cross motions inconsistent with this opinion are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, foster children, parents, and state agencies, filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to compel respondent school district to permit the foster children residing within its jurisdiction to attend its school in the upcoming term. The school district had refused admittance to the foster children because it had not received tuition payment for the foster children's instruction pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 3202(5).


OVERVIEW: The school district refused to permit the foster children to attend school for the upcoming term because the school had not received tuition reimbursement payments. Section 3202(5) mandated that the cost of instruction should be borne by the school district in which the foster child resided at the time the social services district or state agency assumed responsibility for the foster child. The state agencies argued that the statute was unconstitutional. The court issued a declaratory judgment finding the statute constitutional because it did not create an invidious distinction between classes of citizens. The foster children were not denied a free public education. The statute merely allocated responsibility for payment of the foster children's tuition. The classification was found to be rational and it accomplished a legitimate state purpose. The court held that it would be unduly burdensome to require the school district to ascertain who was responsible for tuition payments. Therefore, the school district in which the foster child resided immediately prior to his transfer to the school district would be the body responsible for the tuition payment under the statute.


OUTCOME: The court entered a judgment declaring that the statute was constitutional, that all social services districts and state agencies were to forward tuition reimbursement, that no school district could refuse to admit any pupil because if its failure to receive reimbursement, and that the school district in which each foster child resided immediately prior to his transfer was responsible for the child's tuition costs.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- cost of instruction of foster children -- subdivision 5 of section 3202 of Education Law, which places liability for tuition costs of foster children upon school district of residence at time child came into care of social services district, is not unconstitutional; however, to assist school district of present residence, school district in which foster child resided immediately prior to his transfer to school district of present residence is body responsible for tuition payment -- no school district may refuse to admit any pupil because of its failure to receive reimbursement for cost of instruction.

1. Respondent, a small and rural school district without a large school tax base, is ordered to permit petitioners, 56 foster children, to attend school within the district. Petitioners had resided in a variety of school districts prior to their placement in foster homes within respondent school district by outside social services districts or State agencies. Subdivision 5 of section 3202 of the Education Law, which places liability for tuition costs of foster children upon the school district [***2] of residence at the time the child came into the care of a social services district, is not unconstitutional. However, the school district of present residence should not have the burden of ascertaining the responsible district or agency. Accordingly, a presumption should be read into the statute that, unless another school district, social services district, State department or State agency has assumed responsibility for tuition payment, the school district in which the child resided immediately prior to his transfer to the school district of present residence is the body responsible for the tuition payment under subdivision 5 of section 3202. The school district of residence immediately prior to the transfer to the district of present residence may in turn seek redress against the school district in which the pupil resided at the time the social services district or State agency assumed responsibility for his support.

2. No school district in this State may refuse to admit any pupil to a full course of elementary or secondary education because of its failure to receive reimbursement for the cost of instruction as mandated by subdivision 5 of section 3202.

 

1346 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


IDS Leasing Corp. v. Hansa Jet Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


82 Misc. 2d 741; 369 N.Y.S.2d 922; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2668



March 21, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion by plaintiff is denied.

Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff lessor instituted an action against defendant lessee to recover the aircraft under an agreement to lease the aircraft. The lessor filed a motion pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211 to dismiss defenses asserted by the lessee under N.Y. Lien Law § 184.


OVERVIEW: The lessor entered an agreement with the lessee for the lessee to acquire an aircraft. The lessor hangared the aircraft at a location and defaulted on lease payments. When the lessor sought to regain the aircraft, the service personnel asserted a lien under N.Y. Lien Law § 184. The lessor provided a cash bond and acquired possession of the aircraft. The lessor asserted that § 184 was unconstitutional because it deprived a person of property without due process of law. The lienholders asserted that the services were provided pursuant to the request of the lessor so that it was aware of the lien at the time it authorized the services. The court determined that § 184 was not an unconstitutional deprivation of property without due process since the owner, in directing that the lessee have the aircraft services, was on notice that the service would obligate the possessor of the aircraft to pay for the service or lose possession.


OUTCOME: The court determined that the possessory mechanic's lien did not deprive the lessor of its property without due process.


HEADNOTES

Liens -- garageman's Bliens upon aircraft -- defendant lienors, upon default by defendant lessee under agreement with plaintiff owner, validly asserted garagemen's liens for services performed and fuel supplied to plaintiff's aircraft at request of defendant lessee and were therefore lawfully entitled to maintain possession of said aircraft ( Lien Law, § 184); section 184 does not unconstitutionally deprive plaintiff of possession of said aircraft without due process of law; defendant lienors at no time seized plaintiff's property; they only retained possession which was voluntarily surrendered to them -- since plaintiff both authorized and required defendant lessee to service and repair said aircraft, it impliedly consented to work performed by defendant lienors.

1. Plaintiff owner leased an aircraft to defendant lessee pursuant to an agreement which both authorized and required defendant lessee to furnish normal repairs and services to the aircraft. When defendant lessee defaulted under the lease, plaintiff demanded return of the aircraft which was located at the Westchester County Airport in the possession [***2] of defendants, aircraft service and leasing corporations. However, defendant corporations validly asserted garagemen's liens pursuant to section 184 of the Lien Law totaling $ 80,000 or services performed and fuel supplied to the aircraft at the request of defendant lessee and were therefore lawfully entitled to maintain possession of the aircraft. Section 184, which provides that a garageman who "stores, maintains, keeps or repairs any * * * aircraft of furnishes gasoline or other supplies therefore at the request or with the consent of the owner * * * has a lien upon such * * * aircraft for the sum for such storing * * * and may detain such * * * aircraft at any time it may be lawfully in his possession until such sum is paid", does not unconstitutionally deprive plaintiff of possession of the aircraft without due process of law. Defendants at no time arbitrarily seized plaintiff's property. Rather they retained possession which was voluntarily surrendered to them. The lawful State action under the statute is the granting of a lien to the garageman in possession for work done on the aircraft surrendered. A garageman performs services and does repairs to the very item on which [***3] he asserts a lien. Thus the obligation for which he seeks to maintain possession arises out of the work done to the aircraft and does not involve the seizure and holding of property to secure the payment of services rendered to an individual (cf. Blye v Globe-Wernicke Realty Co., 33 NY2d 15).

2. Section 184 has been applied in a constitutional manner. Plaintiff both authorized and required defendant lessee to service and repair the aircraft. Therefore, it must be deemed to have impliedly consented to the work performed by defendant lienors.

 

1347 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Hewitt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Tompkins County


81 Misc. 2d 202; 365 N.Y.S.2d 760; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2360



March 20, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought to remove his charge of a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192 for driving while intoxicated from the Town Court of Dryden to a superior court under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.25.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with driving while intoxicated under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192. The charge was set for trial in a town court. Defendant sought to remove the charge to a superior court under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.25, claiming trial before the town court justice would deprive him of due process, conviction would deprive him of substantial property rights, and he would not get a fair trial because the town justice was antagonistic. The court denied removal because defendant would receive a fair trial since a different town justice had been elected to the town court, the case did not present any far-reaching results that would present or become a precedent, the case did not present questions that were beyond the town justice's comprehension, defendant would not be deprived of his property without due process, and the laws allowing operation of the town courts were constitutional.


OUTCOME: Defendant's request to remove his driving while intoxicated charge from the town court to a superior court was denied because defendant would receive a fair trial, defendant would not be deprived of his property without due process, and the laws allowing operation of the town courts were constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Town Justice Court -- removal -- defendant, who is charged with driving while intoxicated, may not have said charge removed from Town Justice Court to superior court ( CPL 170.25); questions of law which may arise on trial are not beyond capacity of Town Justice to understand or rule upon -- trial in local criminal court on misdemeanor charge does not deprive defendant of his property without due process of law.

1. Defendant, who is charged with driving while intoxicated (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1192), may not, pursuant to CPL 170.25, have said charge removed from Town Justice Court to be tried in a superior court. Defendant has failed to present any evidence that questions of law which may arise in the trial are beyond the capacity of the Town Justice to understand or rule upon. The admissibility of the results of breathalyzer tests has become fairly standardized and is not too difficult for a Town Justice to comprehend.

2. A trial in a local criminal court, carrying the potential loss of a driver's license, a property right, does not deprive defendant of his property without due process of law. Whether the local Justice Courts are incompetent [***2] to act as tribunals for the trial of misdemeanors is a question for the Legislature to decide.

 

1348 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Karns


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester, Criminal Branch, Monroe County


81 Misc. 2d 186; 365 N.Y.S.2d 725; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2358



March 18, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed pre-trial motions challenging the constitutionality and validity of the ordinance under which they had been charged, Rochester, N.Y., Municipal Code § 44-8, which prohibited indecent advertisements or acts in a street or public place.


OVERVIEW: After defendants were arrested in a nightclub where they worked as nude dancers, they were charged with violating § 44-8. Defendants filed pre-trial motions that challenged the constitutionality and validity of the ordinance. The court denied the motions, holding that § 44-8 was not vague and ambiguous because a reasonable person would be made aware of the activity that the ordinance prohibited. Section 44-8 did not violate the First Amendment because although dancing was a form of expression protected by the First Amendment, the city could proscribe expression that was directed toward an end that it declared to be illegal. Further, nude dancing was a proper subject of the state's police power. Defendants' due process rights to earn a livelihood were not violated because nude dancing was a form of illegal activity not protected by the Fourteenth Amendment. The ordinance had a substantial relation to matters within the field where legislative power was vested and it was reasonably calculated to achieve a legitimate purpose. Finally, the court noted that the legislature, not the judiciary, was empowered to change the law to match changing times.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's pre-trial motions that challenged the constitutionality and validity of the ordinance prohibiting indecent advertisements or acts in a street or public place.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- nude dancing -- female defendants were lawfully arrested for performing nude dancing in nightclubs; local ordinance of City of Rochester which prohibits persons from appearing nude in "public place" is not unconstitutional for vagueness -- nude dancing is not form of free expression protected under First Amendment -- enabling act (Penal Law, § 245.01) is not ex post facto in nature; said act ratified already existing valid ordinance -- nude dancing is illegal livelihood not protected by rights of Fourteenth Amendment.

1. Female defendants were lawfully arrested for dancing and performing in the nude in various nightclubs in violation of subdivision B of section 44-8 of the Municipal Code of the City of Rochester. Said ordinance which prohibits a person from appearing "in a state of nudity * * * in a street or public place where others are present", is not unconstitutional for vagueness. Nightclubs, cocktail lounges and similar establishments, by virtue of their accessibility to the public, fall within the statutory definition of a "public place" (Penal Law, § 240.00, subd 1). A reasonable person would be fully aware of the content and extent of the [***2] law. The ordinance is constitutional having full force and effect.

2. Dancing in the nude is not a form of free expression protected under the First Amendment of the United States Constitution. All forms of speech and the content therein were never intended by the framers of the Constitution or the United States Supreme Court as a protected right in deference to the greater good necessary to protect society. The restrictions on public nudity imposed by the ordinance are within the regulatory powers of the City of Rochester.

3. The enabling act of 1970 (Penal Law, § 245.01) is not ex post facto in nature. Said act ratified the already existing valid ordinance and did not require a repassage of it.

4. The fines imposed by the ordinance may properly exceed the fines imposed under the enabling statute (Penal Law, § 80.05, subd. 4).

5. Nude dancing is an illegal livelihood not protected by the rights of the Fourteenth Amendment. The City of Rochester may restrict the occupational activities of defendants in the same way and manner that it restricts other illegal activity such as housing code violations and gambling.

6. The ordinance should not be declared unconstitutional because [***3] of changing times and mores. If the law should be changed, the proper forum would be the City Council of the City of Rochester.

 

1349 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Wein v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


80 Misc. 2d 894; 365 N.Y.S.2d 955; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2280



March 12, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment is granted to the defendants.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city and related parties moved to dismiss plaintiff taxpayer's complaint under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51, which challenged a legislative financing mechanism, on the grounds that the taxpayer lacked the capacity to bring the action under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(3) and that the complaint failed to state a cause of action under N.Y. C.P.L.R 3211(a)(7).


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer's complaint alleged that The New York City Stabilization Reserve Corporation Act (SRCA), 1974 N.Y. Laws 594, and bonds and notes to be issued by the Stabilization Reserve Corporation (SRC) pursuant to the SRCA violated the New York constitution and constituted an illegal debt of the city that exceeded the N.Y. Const. art. VIII debt limit. The court denied the city's motion to dismiss on the ground that the taxpayer lacked standing because N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51conferred a preventive right of action on the taxpayer who needed no personal right to address alleged constitutional wrongs. However, an analysis of the SRCA revealed that the obligations of the SRC were a contingent liability to the extent of current revenues and were not chargeable to the city as a debt under N.Y. Local Fin. Law § 135.00. Accordingly, in the absence of outright illegality the taxpayer's speculative challenge had failed to state a cause of action and the complaint had to be dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court granted judgment to the city and dismissed the taxpayers action.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- New York City debt limitations -- bonds and notes of Stabilization Reserve Corporation as established by New York City Stabilization Reserve Corporation Act (Public Authorities Law, tit. 26; L. 1974, ch. 594), are not debts of City of New York; city has not pledged its credit to public corporation (N. Y. Const., art. X, § 5) or failed to pledge its faith and credit for its debt (N. Y. Const., art. VIII) -- plaintiff taxpayer has standing to challenge expenditure of municipal funds (General Municipal Law, § 51).

1. The New York City Stabilization Reserve Corporation Act (SRCA) (Public Authorities Law, tit. 26, as added by L. 1974, ch. 594), established the Stabilization Reserve Corporation (SRC) as a public benefit corporation to assist the City of New York in providing essential services on a sound financial basis during a period of fiscal crisis (Public Authorities Law, § 2533.) The SRC is authorized to sell its own bonds and notes and to pay over the sale proceeds to the city Comptroller for deposit in the city's general fund (§ 2536). The bonds and notes are SRC obligations payable solely from SRC [***2] revenues (§ 2542). The payment of the principal of the notes is to be made out of the capital reserve fund which is to be maintained by the city provided that it first appropriates funds for such purpose (§ 2537, subd. 1, par. [a]). The city is to pay the operating expenses and debt services of the SRC within the appropriations available (§ 2540, subd. [a]). If the city does not make such appropriations, the State maintains the fund out of State aid to New York City funds. Plaintiff's taxpayer's suit is dismissed. The bonds and notes of the SRC are not debts of the City of New York; therefore, the city has not pledged its credit as security for the obligations of a public corporation in violation of section 5 of article X of the State Constitution, or failed to pledge its faith and credit for its debt in violation of article VIII of the State Constitution. The payments from the city or the State are permissive and not mandatory regardless of the practical or moral obligation of the city to make the necessary appropriations. The money can only be provided by the city if it is appropriated out of current revenues. The city is not authorized to issue its own obligations [***3] to maintain the SRC fund nor is it the guarantor of the SRC notes and bonds. The contingent obligation of the city does not constitute a debt.

2. Plaintiff, as a taxpayer, has standing under section 51 of the General Municipal Law to challenge the expenditure of municipal funds and need not demonstrate any individual interest.

 

1350 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Young


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, New York County


80 Misc. 2d 937; 365 N.Y.S.2d 695; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2288



March 12, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner executors instituted a proceeding against respondent publisher pursuant to N.Y. Surr. Ct. Proc. Act § 2103 to discover property.


OVERVIEW: The executors began an action against the publisher under N.Y. Surr. Ct. Proc. Act § 2103 to discover property. The executors claimed that there was a sum in royalty earnings owed to the decedent's estate in the possession of the publisher, and the executors sought delivery of that sum. The publisher contended that the court lacked jurisdiction to grant the executors' application because the proceeding was one to collect a common debt or contract obligation. The court accepted jurisdiction over the case. The court held that: (1) although the Supreme Court of New York could have taken concurrent jurisdiction over the contract claim, in its discretion, if the executors had resorted to the supreme court, it would be patently unconstitutional for the legislature to forbid exercise of jurisdiction by the surrogate's court over such obviously surrogate's business as the probate of wills; (2) jurisdiction in discovery had been assumed in the surrogate's court even though debts and contract obligations might be involved.


OUTCOME: The court accepted jurisdiction over the proceeding in which the executors sought to discover property held by the publisher.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Surrogate's Court -- discovery proceeding -- Surrogate's Court has jurisdiction under section 12 of article VI of State Constitution to entertain discovery proceeding (SCPA 2103) to determine whether respondent publisher is required to pay to decedent author's estate $ 53,452.58 in unpaid royalties which had been credited to decedent's account.

Respondent publishing company owed decedent author $ 53,452.58 in unpaid royalties. Pursuant to section 12 of article VI of the State Constitution, which gives the Surrogate's Court jurisdiction "over all actions and proceedings relating to the affairs of decedents, probate of wills, administration of estates and actions and proceedings arising thereto or pertaining thereto", the Surrogate's Court has jurisdiction to entertain a discovery proceeding (SCPA 2103) to determine whether respondent must pay to decedent's estate the $ 53,452.58 in unpaid royalties or whether the estate is bound by the express language of the publishing agreement limiting the amount respondent is required to pay in any one calendar year to $ 3,000. A preliminary jurisdictional inquiry is discretionary for the purpose of determining whether in fact [***2] a major asset of the estate was earmarked by crediting such money to the account of decedent.

 

1351 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kessler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Dutchess County


81 Misc. 2d 492; 365 N.Y.S.2d 946; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2411



March 10, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reasons, the motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that, pursuant to N.Y. Jud. Law § 665, women were systematically excluded from the grand jury panel from which the grand jury indicting defendant was selected.


OVERVIEW: In a certain county, the petit jury list was obtained exclusively from the latest voter registration list utilizing a computer to continually supplement and update the list of qualified petit jurors. To qualify as a grand juror, a person was required to be a qualified petit juror, and the source of names from the grand jury list necessarily derived from the petit jury list. Service on the grand jury was voluntary, and the county jury board had never rejected a name submitted to the grand jury. Defendant sought to dismiss his indictment on the ground that the exemption provided by § 665 systematically excluded women from the grand jury panel from which the grand jury that had indicted him was selected. The court held that: (1) application of § 665 did not lead to the exclusion of women from jury venires so as to deprive defendant of a jury venire drawn from a source fairly representative of the community; (2) the mere showing of disparity in the percentage of men and women represented on a grand jury list was insufficient to show an intentional and systematic discrimination against women; and (3) defendant was not entitled to a jury of any particular composition.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Jury -- exemption of women from jury service -- section 665 of Judiciary Law, which entitles women to claim exemption from service as jurors, does not deprive defendant of jury venire drawn from source representative of community; women are not systematically excluded from service on petit jury or Grand Jury in Dutchess County.

Section 665 of the Judiciary Law, which entitles women to claim an exemption from service as jurors, does not lead to the exclusion of women from jury venires so as to deprive defendant of a jury venire drawn from a source fairly representative of the community. Defendant has not sustained his burden of proving that women are systematically and arbitrarily excluded from service on the petit jury or the Grand Jury in Dutchess County. Women comprise a significant portion of petit jury and Grand Jury venires in Dutchess County thus refuting any contention that such bodies "are almost entirely male". The annual selection of the petit jury venire in Dutchess County is predicated solely on the basis of random selection of prospective members by computer programming to make a random selection of names [***2] from the most recent voter registration list. There is no evidence that the computer was programmed to reject or sort out in any way the names of women. No effort is made by the Dutchess County Jury Board to exclude women from the Grand Jury venire which is composed solely of volunteers from the petit jury list. Everyone who has volunteered for such service has been put on the Grand Jury list.

 

1352 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cioffi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


81 Misc. 2d 1; 365 N.Y.S.2d 434; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2323



March 7, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought to suppress a warrantless seizure of 1,700 cartons of untaxed cigarettes by the State, from his business establishment, on the grounds that the warrantless search violated his constitutional rights under the Fourth Amendment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant owned a hosiery business. State inspectors came into the store and observed 3 packs of untaxed cigarettes. The officer told defendant the cigarettes were illegal and asked defendant for the rest of them. In response, defendant asked to see the officer's badge. Upon being shown the badge, defendant unlocked a door to another room in which the 1,700 cartons of untaxed cigarettes were located. Defendant sought to suppress the evidence as illegally obtained. The court denied the motion to suppress, holding that the search in question was not accompanied by any unauthorized force, the inspectors had a statutory right to inspect the premises, defendant had consented to the search, and defendant's will had not been overcome by force, threat of force, or coercion, and, therefore, the search was legal.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to suppress.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- unlawful search and seizure -- consent -- defendant who, in response to investigators' request, unlocked door at rear of his store and let investigators into room where they seized 1,700 cartons of untaxed cigarettes, cannot have such seized evidence suppressed.

Two New York State Tax Department plainclothes investigators entered defendant's retail hosiery shop at noon and saw, on the counter, three cigarette packs bearing North Carolina seals but no New York State tax stamp. One of the investigators said to defendant that the cigarettes were illegal. This was not so, since one may possess two cartons of untaxed cigarettes (Tax Law, § 471-a). The investigator also said: "I would like to have the rest of them." Defendant asked the investigator to identify himself, and so the investigator exhibited his shield. The investigators did not assert that they were demanding the rest of the cigarettes under section 474 of the Tax Law. They did not question or coerce the defendant. The defendant simply walked to the rear of the store, unlocked a door leading to another room, and let the investigators in. There they found and lawfully seized 1,700 cartons of untaxed cigarettes,  [***2] and thereupon they arrested the defendant. The seized evidence will not be suppressed.

 

1353 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Schulman v. Simins


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Richmond County


81 Misc. 2d 227; 365 N.Y.S.2d 675; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2363



March 7, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner applicant filed a petition initiating proceedings pursuant to N.Y.
