C.P.L.R. 78 seeking to compel respondents, the commissioner of the public works department and the chairman of the department's license board, to issue him a master electrician's license. The license board had recommended that issuance of the license should be denied, and the commissioner had denied issuance of the license for lack of candor for failure to disclose.


OVERVIEW: When he was 16 years old, an applicant enlisted in the merchant marine and received an honorable discharge. Thereafter, he enlisted in the army and re-enlisted in the merchant marine and served honorably. Twenty-eight years later, he filed an application for a master electrician's license. The license board recommended issuance thereof should be approved, subject to receipt of the applicant's fingerprints. The applicant later contacted the chairman informing him of an incident in the army for which he was arrested but not charged. The board then recommended denial of a license, and the commissioner denied issuance of the license for lack of candor in failing to disclose. The applicant then initiated proceedings under art. 78 to compel the chairman and the commissioner to issue the license. The court held that: (1) the applicant's action in bringing the matter to the board's attention before the fingerprint record was received, strongly demonstrated lack of deliberate intent to conceal or suppress the incident; and (2) it was not in the interest of justice to deny him the means of making a livelihood in his chosen profession because of the action taken by him in his youth.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the commissioner's determination, which had denied the application of the applicant for a master electrician's license, and directed the commissioner to issue the applicant such a license forthwith.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Licenses -- master electrician -- failure to disclose -- petitioner, who, in 1947, while in Army, shipped guns and ammunition to Israel, but who was never formally arrested or convicted, was wrongfully denied master electrician's license for failure to disclose his 1947 gun running activities; there was no deliberate intent to conceal or suppress 1947 matter.

Petitioner who qualified in the written and practical examination, was wrongfully denied a master electrician's license for failing to disclose the fact that in 1947, at the age of 19, while in the Army, he took guns and ammunition captured from the German Army and shipped them to Jewish people in Israel in order to aid them in their fight to become a free and independent country. Respondent commissioner received a fingerprint record indicating that defendant was arrested by the F.B.I. in 1947 for larceny and received one year. However, there is no evidence that petitioner was ever formally arrested for gun running or that he ever served time for the commission of a Federal offense. Petitioner was only confined in barracks for his gun running activities and was subsequently given an honorable discharge. There was no [***2] deliberate intent to conceal or suppress the 1947 matter. Petitioner is 46 years of age, married and supports two children and undoubtedly possesses the skills needed to qualify as a master electrician. It would not be in the interests of justice to deny petitioner the means of making a livelihood because of actions taken by him in his youth to help create a spiritual homeland for all Jews. Accordingly, respondent is directed to issue petitioner a license forthwith.

 

1354 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Texaco, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Nassau County


81 Misc. 2d 260; 365 N.Y.S.2d 661; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2367



March 7, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is denied and the defendant is found guilty as charged and will appear for sentencing on March 21, 1975.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with unloading a barge containing gasoline without using a floating boom of sufficient length to contain the barge in violation of Art. III, § 3.4(D)(IV) of the Nassau County Fire Prevention Ordinance. At the conclusion of trial, defendant moved for an order of dismissal.


OVERVIEW: Defendant unloaded a barge containing gasoline without using a floating boom of sufficient length to contain the barge, and it did not request an exception to boom. Defendant contended, inter alia, that the ordinance was an unconstitutional exercise of police power because the booming of barges discharging gasoline, as opposed to kerosene, diesel oil, or fuel oil, actually enhanced the risk of fire and that therefore, booming was unnecessary to accomplish the purpose of the ordinance. Although the court opined that the ordinance needed revision, it declined to declare the ordinance void because debatable questions as to reasonableness were for the legislature and not for the courts. Expert testimony established that even a small spill would be subject to ignition over an area of 600 to 800 feet for a period of 15 to 20 minutes, and the court found that the ordinance, to a certain extent, fulfilled its purpose as a safety measure. The court also held that the county had jurisdiction over its contiguous waterways, and it declined to review the constitutionality of the ordinance's exception clause because it would not be dispositive of the issue before the court.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for dismissal and found it guilty of violating the ordinance requiring booming of its barge.


HEADNOTES

Waters and watercourses -- navigable and tidal waters of Nassau County -- booming of gasoline barges -- defendant corporation is guilty of unloading barge containing gasoline without using floating boom in violation of Nassau County Fire Prevention Ordinance; Nassau County has right to regulate its abutting navigable and tidal waters -- ordinance which requires booming of barges except "whenever certain conditions would render it impractical or ineffective", does not deny defendant equal protection of law for failure to set forth proper guidelines -- fact that need to boom gasoline is debatable is not sufficient to render ordinance void.

1. Defendant corporation is guilty of unloading a barge containing gasoline without using a floating boom of sufficient length to contain the barge in violation of section 3.4 of article III of the Nassau County Fire Prevention Ordinance. The Nassau County Fire Marshal has jurisdiction over the waters contiguous to Nassau County. The State Legislature, by not including "all tidewaters bordering on and lying within the boundaries [***2] of Nassau and Suffolk counties" within the definition of navigable waters of the State ( Navigation Law, § 2, subd 4), either expressly or impliedly conferred upon Nassau County the right to regulate its abutting navigable and tidal waters.

2. The ordinance, which requires a floating boom to be positioned "prior to discharge of any flammable or combustible liquid from any boat, barge or vessel", except whenever the Fire Marshal determines that "certain conditions" would render such positioning "impractical or ineffective", does not deny defendant equal protection of the law for failure to set forth proper guidelines for the determination of the Fire Marshal. Since striking the "exception" clause would leave a complete constitutional act requiring booming at all times and under all conditions, there is no need to decide whether the "exception" clause is unconstitutional.

3. Defendant has not shown that the required booming of barges discharging gasoline imposes unusual and unnecessary restrictions on its business. The fact that the need to boom gasoline is debatable, necessitating a review and revision of the ordinance, is not sufficient to render said ordinance void as an unconstitutional [***3] exercise of police power. Defendant has not overcome the presumption of reasonableness which attaches to the ordinance. The ordinance does, to some extent, fulfill its purpose as a safety measure.

 

1355 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Di Cocco


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Schenectady County


80 Misc. 2d 854; 364 N.Y.S.2d 990; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2276



March 6, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Two grand jury witnesses filed objections to questions raised in the course of their testimony and motions to suppress testimony and to quash their subpoenas in an action before the Schenectady County Grand Jury (New York) which was impaneled to investigate allegations of organized crime.


OVERVIEW: A grand jury was impaneled to investigate allegations of ongoing organized crime. Two witnesses raised objections to the nature of the questions and the authority of the prosecutor. The witnesses also filed motions to suppress testimony and to quash their subpoenas. The reviewing court denied the witnesses' motions and ordered them to answer the questions posed by the prosecutor. The court determined that the arguments to quash the subpoenas were without merit as the grand jury had a right to the testimony of these witnesses because they were associated, directly or indirectly, with the businesses and persons under investigation. The court determined that because the witnesses failed to sustain their burden of demonstrating any bad faith or patent invalidity in the grand jury investigation the court would not review challenges to the grand jury's authority until it had acted as dictated by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.35.


OUTCOME: The court refused to review challenges to a grand jury's authority in an investigation into organized crime activities. It ordered two complaining witnesses to answer the questions asked that were pertinent to the proceedings before the grand jury.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Grand jury -- motions to suppress evidence -- witnesses before Grand Jury must answer generally pertinent questions, without awaiting hearings and decisions on motions which attack constitutionality of Executive Law ( § 70-a) or of warrants for electronic surveillance.

Until a Grand Jury has handed up an indictment, its subpoenas and its generally pertinent questionings cannot be interrupted or suspended to await the outcome of hearings and decisions on motions which attack the constitutionality of section 70-a of the Executive Law or of eavesdropping warrants or of questions based on allegedly illegal electronic surveillance. The witnesses may state their objections, but they must answer the questions, unless they can demonstrate the bad faith of the questions.

 

1356 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. S.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


81 Misc. 2d 305; 365 N.Y.S.2d 426; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2376



March 6, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the conviction is vacated and a youthful offender adjudication is substituted in its stead.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, who was aged 16 at the time of the crime, filed a motion for the granting of youthful offender treatment after he pleaded guilty to criminal sale of a controlled substance as a class A-III felony.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted on one count of criminal sale of a controlled substance for selling a minimal quantity of cocaine to an undercover agent. Upon defendant's application for youthful offender treatment, the court held that: (1) N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10(2), which denied to an otherwise eligible youth the privilege of youthful offender status if he had been indicted for a class A-III felony, violated the due process clause because it gave conclusive weight to the untested allegations of the indictment by tying the availability of youthful offender treatment to the indictment, without regard to whether the charge was sustained by a verdict and (2) the statute violated the equal protection clause because it irrationally discriminated against those youths who had been charged with class A felonies but were ultimately convicted of lesser felonies and there was no rational basis for treating differently youths who were convicted of the same offense merely because one of them had originally been charged with a higher grade of offense; and (3) defendant was deserving of the privilege of youthful offender status because he had no prior record and had previously been a model student.


OUTCOME: The court vacated defendant's conviction and substituted a youthful offender adjudication in its stead.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- youthful offender treatment -- CPL 720.10 (subd. 2), insofar as it arbitrarily denies youthful offender treatment in all class A felony cases, is unconstitutional -- court vacates class A-III felony plea and conviction, and grants youthful offender treatment to deserving youth.

A 16-year-old boy sold a minimal quantity of cocaine to an undercover agent for a $ 15 profit. He was indicted, and he has pleaded guilty, of this class A-III felony of selling a controlled substance. He has had no previous involvement with the law. The presentence probation report states that he fell in with some bad associates and committed this crime thoughtlessly, but that he is a good son and is now a high school senior and a model student. In the interests of justice, the court vacates the judgment of conviction and directs that this youth be accorded youthful offender treatment. CPL 720.10 (subd. 2), insofar as it arbitrarily denies youthful offender treatment in all class A felony cases, is unconstitutional.

 

1357 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lofton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


81 Misc. 2d 572; 366 N.Y.S.2d 769; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2428



March 6, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendant's motion is, in all respects, denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved for a declaration that N.Y. Penal Law § 65.00(1)(b) was unconstitutional and for a hearing with respect to the refusal of the prosecutor to recommend lifetime probation under § 65.00(1)(b) after she pleaded guilty to three counts contained in three indictments that included two class A-III felony counts.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pleaded guilty to three counts in three indictments that included two class A-III felony counts. The prosecutor refused to recommend that the court sentence defendant to a period of probation on the ground that she had not been of sufficient material assistance in the investigation, apprehension, or prosecution of a person charged with drug violations. He also refused to accept what defendant had to offer. Defendant sought a declaration that § 65.00(1)(b) was unconstitutional and a hearing on the prosecutor's refusal to recommend lifetime probation. The court held that § 65.00(1)(b) was constitutional under due process and equal protection measures, that it was not vague, and that it sufficiently set forth the requirements for a recommendation of probation based on material assistance to the prosecution. The court denied defendant's request for a hearing because the prosecutor, as a court officer, was vested with wide discretion that would not be disturbed in the absence of evidence of the arbitrary or improper use of that discretion. The court noted that the existence of a potential for a recommendation of probation was not a guarantee that it would be forthcoming.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to declare a discretionary probation statute unconstitutional and for a hearing as to the refusal of the prosecutor to recommend lifetime probation.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- dangerous drugs -- recommendation of lifetime probation -- section 65.00 (subd 1, par [b]) of Penal Law sufficiently sets forth what is required to procure recommendation of lifetime probation from District Attorney for class A-III felonies and is therefore constitutional -- defendant is not entitled to hearing; judiciary should not impose its standard of "material assistance" on domain of discretion given to prosecutor.

1. Section 65.00 (subd 1, par [b]) of the Penal Law which permits a sentence of probation to be imposed for a class A-III drug felony if the prosecutor so recommends upon a finding that defendant has provided "material assistance" in the investigation, apprehension or prosecution of a person charged with a narcotics violation (Penal Law, art 220), sufficiently sets forth what is required to procure a recommendation of lifetime probation from a District Attorney and is therefore constitutional.

2. Defendant is not entitled to a hearing to determine whether the withholding of the recommendation of lifetime probation by the prosecution is an abuse of discretion. There is no substantive [***2] right to probation for an A-III felony. Such a recommendation by the District Attorney is discretionary and the mere existence of the potential for such a recommendation does not confer the right to it. The statute is intended to provide the prosecutor with a source of information for narcotics prosecutions, and if the prosecutor chooses not to avail himself of the assistance offered by a defendant it is within his well-established discretion. The judiciary should not seek to impose its standard of "material assistance" on the domain of discretion given to the prosecutor where there is no evidence of an arbitrary or improper exercise of discretion.

 

1358 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bates


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Nassau County


81 Misc. 2d 531; 365 N.Y.S.2d 653; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2419



March 5, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The court feels this argument merits no discussion and this phase of the motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an original action defendant filed a motion for an order to inspect a grand jury's minutes, and to dismiss an indictment pursuant to N.Y. Jud. Law § 665-a.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the grand jury proceedings were defective because the grand jury was unconstitutionally selected from a group intentionally excluding a specific segment of the population. One of the jurors' qualification questionnaires inquired as to whether the jurors met the disqualification criteria enumerated in § 665-a. Exclusion was based upon membership in the communist party or related groups advocating overthrowing the government. The court held that: (1) the constitution did not forbid the States to prescribe relevant qualifications for their jurors, so long as the source reasonably reflected a cross-section of the population suitable in character and intelligence for that civic duty; (2) implicit in the jurors' qualification questionnaire, and likewise in § 665-a, was scienter; (3) mere knowing membership without a specific intent to further the unlawful aims of an organization was not a constitutionally adequate basis for exclusion for jury positions; and (4) defendant failed to meet his burden of persuading the court to disregard the principle of judicial restraint applying to attacks on statutes on constitutional issues in nisi prius courts.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to inspect the grand jury minutes, and denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment under that phase of the motion. After reading the grand jury's minutes, the court was satisfied that the evidence presented was legally sufficient to sustain the indictment. The court respectfully suggested that the legislature amend the statutes by repealing the law in question.


HEADNOTES

Jury -- exclusion of members of Communist Party from jury service -- section 665-a of Judiciary Law, which excludes members of Communist Party from serving as jurors, is not unconstitutional; grand jury proceedings are not defective; defendant has failed to overcome strong presumption of constitutionality which attaches to statute -- section 665-a should, however, be repealed.

1. Section 665-a of the Judiciary Law, which excludes members of the Communist Party and other organizations from serving as jurors, is not unconstitutional and did not render the grand jury proceedings defective. Defendant has failed to overcome the strong presumption of constitutionality which attaches to a statute. A statute should not be set aside as unconstitutional by a court of original jurisdiction unless such conclusion is inescapable and the invalidity of the act is apparent on its face.

2. However, in view of recent decisions construing the constitutionality of exclusion and restrictions upon jury eligibility (see Peters v Kiff, 407 U.S. 493; Taylor v Louisiana, 419 U.S. 522), it is suggested [***2] that section 665-a be repealed.

 

1359 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bon--R Reproductions, Inc. v. Gift Mate, Ltd.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, Special Term, New York County


81 Misc. 2d 630; 365 N.Y.S.2d 645; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2437



February 27, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, plaintiff's motion vacating the judgment dated and entered January 16, 1975 by the defendant is granted, as hereinabove indicated. Furthermore, for the reasons previously cited, plaintiff's motion for an order of arrest of the defendant Marvin Markowitz is granted. Bail shall be fixed in the sum of $ 3,500.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff filed a motion to vacate a judgment from the trial court (New York), which granted the motion of defendant for entry of judgment for plaintiff following the filing of a motion for an order of arrest, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6101(1), by plaintiff. Plaintiff had filed an action against defendant alleging fraud and deceit and had obtained a money judgment against defendant.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff filed a fraud and deceit action against defendant for the issuance of a check that was drawn from an account that had insufficient funds, and the trial court entered an award for plaintiff, which then filed a motion for an order of arrest pursuant to Rule 6101(1), and, to forestall the issuance of an order of arrest, defendant moved under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 5017(a) for an entry of a judgment in favor of plaintiff. Plaintiff then sought to vacate the judgment. The court held that: (1) although either party could move for an entry of judgment, regardless of whether a party had prevailed in the action, the court had inherent power to set aside the entry of judgment in the interest of substantial justice because defendant's use of such judgment was to thwart plaintiff's substantive right to an order of arrest and the court's judicial prerogative to render a decision on the motion; (2) there was no rational or reasonable basis for the sex-based classification of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6101(1), which rendered women immune from civil arrest upon certain designated causes of action; however, (3) the constitutionality of Rule 6101(1) was best left to the appellate courts.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiff's motion to vacate the order granting defendant's motion for entry of judgment and granted plaintiff's motion for an order of arrest of defendant.


HEADNOTES

Arrest -- entry of judgment -- sex discrimination -- defendant may not thwart plaintiff's substantive right to order of arrest by entering judgment against himself on basis of CPLR 6111, which provides for arrest prior to judgment, and, in view of defendant's actual fraud, judgment is vacated -- although there has been no cogent demonstration of rational basis for exemption of women from arrest under CPLR 6101 and although it is clear that male and female must be accorded equal treatment, court of limited jurisdiction should not declare statute unconstitutional unless such conclusion is inescapable; accordingly, plaintiff's motion for order of arrest is granted.

1. On the basis of CPLR 6111, which provides that an order of arrest may be granted "before judgment", the defendant entered judgment in favor of the plaintiff to forestall issuance of such order.  [***2] The court cannot permit the defendant to thwart the plaintiff's substantive right to an order of arrest or the court's prerogative to render a decision on the motion. Since, in view of the defendant's actual fraud and deceit, customary supplementary proceedings would be inadequate, the judgment is vacated in the interests of justice.

2. A court of limited jurisdiction should not declare CPLR 6101 unconstitutional, since the expressed will of the Legislature should be upheld unless the conclusion that a statute is unconstitutional is inescapable. Although there has been no cogent demonstration that a rational classification based upon sex exists with respect to the exemption of women from arrest provided in CPLR 6101, and although it is clear that male and female must be accorded equal treatment under the law, the constitutionality of the statute must await appellate decision, and the plaintiff's motion for an order of arrest is granted.

 

1360 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cook


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Onondaga County


81 Misc. 2d 235; 365 N.Y.S.2d 611; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2365



February 24, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The defendant's motion is therefore denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss an indictment charging him with crimes stemming from his and other tribal members' forceful removal of non-Native American families from the reservation. Defendant argued that the indictment was insufficient, that jurisdiction and venue were improper, that state and federal laws were invalid, that the grand jury was prejudiced, and that he was immune from arrest and prosecution.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was a member of a Native American tribe on a reservation. Defendant and other tribe members decided to remove white people living on the reservation. The tribe passed a law to bar non-Native Americans and served removal notices on them. Although it was determined that the state would effect the removal, defendant and others physically removed families of non-Native Americans. That action, and threats and forceful entries, resulted in an indictment against six Native Americans. Defendant appeared, was arraigned, and filed a motion to dismiss the indictment. The court denied the motion, holding that the indictment was proper, as was jurisdiction and venue. 25 U.S.C.S. § 232 was constitutional, and the allegations in the indictment were within N.Y. Penal Law §§ 135, 140. The grand jury's composition from voter registration lists did not violate defendant's Fourteenth Amendment rights. Defendant was not prejudiced by adverse publicity in the local media, and defendant failed to comply with N.Y. Indian Law § 8. Defendant was not immune from arrest and prosecution even though he was acting on the mandate of his counsel of chiefs in evicting intruders from the reservation.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss an indictment against him for various crimes stemming from his and other members of his tribe's forceful removal of non-Native American families from the reservation.


HEADNOTES

Indians -- criminal prosecution for eviction of non-Indians -- after Council of Chiefs of Onondaga Nation passed law to bar all non-Indians from Onondaga Indian Reservation, warriors and others proceeded to physically remove non-Indians, allegedly making threats and forcible entries which resulted in indictments of six individuals -- motion to dismiss is denied -- factual allegations of indictments are sufficient -- State has jurisdiction over offenses committed by or against Indians on reservations within State, and County Judge has jurisdiction over disputes arising from intrusions on tribal lands in county -- Congress may constitutionally enact legislation controlling Indian affairs and delegate portion of that control to State -- there is no showing of systematic exclusion of Indians from grand jury service, either because of their nonvoting or because of their race -- there is no showing of prejudicial news coverage -- failure to comply with statute prescribing alternate manners of making complaints as to intrusions precludes claim based on District Attorney's alleged authority to evict intruders and failure to do so -- fact  [***2] that defendant was evicting intruders pursuant to mandates of Council of Chiefs does not immunize him from arrest -- questions as to his mental state or culpability, including intent, and all other aspects of his conduct as it relates to elements of crimes charged are matters to be raised at trial.

1. After the Council of Chiefs of the Onondaga Nation passed a law to bar all non-Indians from the Onondaga Indian Reservation, which is located entirely in Onondaga County, warriors and others proceeded to physically remove the non-Indians, allegedly making threats and forcible entries which resulted in the indictment of six individuals. It was thereafter agreed that, of those six, the present defendant would appear and be arraigned, and the points raised by him in support of dismissal of the indictments would be considered. After consideration of those points, the motion to dismiss is denied.

2. The indictments allege facts which fall within the provisions of articles 135 and 140 of the Penal Law, and they comply with CPL 200.50 (subd. 7), requiring that an indictment contain a plain and concise factual statement in each count which asserts facts supporting every element of the [***3] offense charged and defendant's commission thereof with sufficient precision to clearly apprise him of the conduct which is the subject of the accusation.

3. As to claimed lack of jurisdiction, section 232 of title 25 of the United States Code vests in the State of New York jurisdiction over offenses committed by or against Indians on Indian reservations within the State. As to claimed improper venue, section 8 of the New York Indian Law vests jurisdiction over disputes arising from intrusions on tribal lands in the County Judge of the county in which those lands are situated.

4. Section 232 of title 25 of the United States Code is constitutional. Congress may constitutionally enact legislation controlling the affairs of Indians, with or without their consent, and, in the exercise of that power, may lawfully delegate a portion of that control to the States, including the exercise of criminal jurisdiction over crimes committed on Indian reservations by Indians.

5. The use of voter registration lists to select possible grand jurors is constitutionally permissible, and, if, as has been alleged, Indians do not choose to vote, they are not being unconstitutionally discriminated against [***4] when their nonvoting excludes them from grand jury panels. Nor has there been a showing of systematic exclusion from grand jury service of Indians because of their race. They may not only register to vote to avail themselves of the opportunity to be chosen as jurors, but they may respond to the invitations, issued to the general public in various ways, such as in newspapers and on television, to sign up for jury duty. And, under the jury selection process, there is no way of knowing the race or color of those whose names are on the master list of prospective jurors or of those whose names are drawn from that list.

6. There has been no showing that news coverage of the events involved in this case was such as to make the Grand Jury biased and prejudiced against defendant, but merely a conclusory allegation as to bias and prejudice without any factual support therefor and without specific reference to particular news articles from which a logical inference of prejudice could be drawn.

7. Under section 8 of the Indian Law, complaints about intruders on tribal lands may be made to the County Judge or a request may be made to the District Attorney by a majority of the Chiefs of the [***5] Onondaga Nation and, upon such request, the District Attorney shall make complaint as to any intrusions, and cause the intruders to be removed. Defendant did not comply with the statute in either of the two manners provided, and, therefore, cannot claim that the District Attorney should not have appeared before the Grand Jury because he had possessed the authority to evict the intruders and failed to do so. Moreover, under CPL 190.55, the District Attorney of the county, or his assistants, must present the evidence to the Grand Jury relating to any crimes allegedly committed within the county.

8. The fact that defendant was evicting intruders pursuant to mandates of the Council of Chiefs does not immunize him from arrest. While the Indians have a right to govern their internal affairs, and, in doing so, may designate who is an intruder, the act of evicting those intruders goes beyond the concept of self-government and into an area which Congress and the State Legislature have pre-empted in order to avoid injury to person and property.

9. Questions as to defendant's mental state or culpability, including his intent, and all other aspects of his conduct as it relates to the elements [***6] of the crimes charged, are matters to be raised at the trial.

 

1361 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Robinson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


86 Misc. 2d 939; 385 N.Y.S.2d 696; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3369



February 21, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [**1] The motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant made a motion to set aside the People's demand for the names and addresses of his alibi witnesses on the ground that the statute providing for the demand was unconstitutional. Defendant's attack was directed against N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 250.20.


OVERVIEW: The court noted that § 250.20 was amended in response to the United States Supreme Court's decision that invalidated an Oregon "notice of alibi" statute on the ground that it did not provide for reciprocal discovery. The court found that the New York statute was patterned on a Florida statute that withstood an attack before the United States Supreme Court. Section 250.20(2) provided that within a reasonable time after receipt of defendant's witness list but not later than 10 days before trial, the People had to serve upon defendant or his counsel a list of the witnesses the People proposed to offer in rebuttal to discredit defendant's alibi. The court found that the only essential difference from the Florida statute was the inclusion in § 250.20(2) that a witness who would testify that defendant was at the scene of the crime was not such an alibi rebuttal witness. However, the court concluded that this distinction did not affect the statute's constitutionality, for such disclosure was not intended to reveal eyewitnesses to the crime. Thus, the court concluded that the statute was not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- discovery of alibi witnesses -- CPL 250.20 which requires defendant to produce names and addresses of alibi witnesses is constitutional since it provides for reciprocal discovery; People must provide defendant with list of witnesses it proposes to offer in rebuttal to discredit defendant's alibi at trial; fact that eyewitness to crime is not deemed alibi rebuttal witness does not affect constitutionality of statute.

 CPL 250.20 which requires a defendant to produce the names and addresses of alibi witnesses is constitutional since it provides for reciprocal discovery requiring the People to provide defendant with the names, addresses and the places of employment of witnesses the People propose to offer in rebuttal to discredit defendant's alibi at trial. The fact that CPL 250.20 (subd 2) provides that a "witness who will testify that defendant was at the scene of the crime is not such an alibi rebuttal witness" does not affect the statute's constitutionality since the disclosure of alibi rebuttal witnesses was not intended to reveal eyewitnesses to the crime. Otherwise every defendant would assert an alibi in order to obtain such disclosure.

 

1362 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. La Plante


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Tonawanda


81 Misc. 2d 34; 365 N.Y.S.2d 392; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2328



February 18, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with driving while intoxicated in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(3).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was involved in an automobile accident and was found sitting behind the wheel of the car when an officer came to investigate. Before the officer noticed defendant's slurred speech and staggered walk, defendant admitted to the officer that he was driving at the time of the accident. Defendant was ultimately arrested and given a breathalyzer test that indicated a blood alcohol content of .21. Defendant filed a motion to suppress his admission that he was driving because it occurred prior to the giving of Miranda warnings. The court denied that motion and held that where the officer was asking general questions about the accident, such warnings were not required. The court also found defendant guilty of driving while impaired, a traffic infraction, rather than driving while intoxicated. The court determined that the intoxication statute, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(3), was unconstitutionally vague following various amendments by the legislature.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant guilty of driving while impaired.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- driving while ability impaired -- on charge of crime of driving while intoxicated, defendant is found guilty of traffic infraction of driving while his ability was impaired -- subdivision 3 of section 1192 of Vehicle and Traffic Law ("intoxicated") is vague, unconstitutional and void.

1. Driving while "ability * * * is impaired" ( Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1192, subd 1) is only a traffic infraction. Driving while "intoxicated" ( Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1192, subd 3) is a misdemeanor, and, under certain circumstances, it is a felony. The difference between "impaired" and "intoxicated" is too vague to be enforceable with justice. Therefore, subdivision 3, on account of which defendant was arrested and charged, is unconstitutional and void.

2. However, based on the policeman's observation of defendant at the scene of the accident, and based on a breathalyzer test which the court finds was properly administered at the police station shortly after the arrest and which showed 0.21 of 1% of alcohol in defendant's blood (cf. Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1195), the Justice Court finds defendant guilty of the traffic infraction of driving while his ability was [***2] impaired ( Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1192, subd 1).

 

1363 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Buffalo v. New York State Public Employment Relations Board


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


80 Misc. 2d 741; 363 N.Y.S.2d 896; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2250; 88 L.R.R.M. 3372; 77 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P53,774



February 4, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is denied and judgment shall be entered in favor of the defendant dismissing the complaint herein and declaring section 209 of the Civil Service Law in all respects, constitutional and valid.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city filed a motion for summary judgment in its action against defendant, Public Employment Relations Board, for a declaration that N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 209(4) was unconstitutional and to prevent the board from acting thereunder.


OVERVIEW: The city sought a declaration that § 209(a), which mandated binding arbitration of wage disputes between the city and its fire and police forces, was unconstitutional and to enjoin the board from proceeding thereunder. The court denied the city's motion for summary judgment and entered judgment in favor of the board. The court stated that the legislature had the authority to enact general legislation with respect to any area of general state concern and that § 209(a) represented general legislation. The court stated that the health, safety, and well-being of the state's populace were clearly matters of state concern. The court stated that consideration of public safety required that disputes between local governments and their police and fire forces were to be promptly resolved therefore procedures for the resolution of such disputes were appropriate subjects for state legislation.


OUTCOME: The court denied the city's motion for summary judgment in the city's action for a declaration that a statute that mandated binding arbitration was unconstitutional. The court entered judgment in favor of the board.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- Public Employees' Fair Employment Act -- police and fire officers -- mandatory binding arbitration -- subdivision 4 of section 209 of Civil Service Law, which mandates binding arbitration of wage disputes between municipality and its duly organized fire and police force is constitutional and valid; procedures for resolution of such disputes are appropriate subjects for State legislation -- delegation of authority to arbitration panel does not render statute invalid since powers of such panel are strictly limited -- statute does not violate due process since determination of arbitration panel must be deemed subject to judicial review.

1. The provisions of subdivision 4 of section 209 of the Civil Service Law which mandate binding arbitration of wage disputes between a municipality and its duly organized fire and police forces are constitutional and valid. The statute requires that disputes which cannot be resolved through [***2] negotiation or mediation be referred to a three-member ad hoc arbitration panel ( Civil Service Law, § 209, subd. 4, par. [c]) whose members are selected by the parties and the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB). The determination of the panel is made "final and binding on the parties". Although the Municipal Home Rule Law and State Constitution recognize the right of municipalities to govern their own affairs and determine the compensation and conditions of employment of their employees, the procedures for the resolution of disputes between local governments and their municipal police and fire forces are appropriate subjects for State legislation since such disputes involve the health, safety and well-being of the State's populace which are clearly matters of State concern.

2. The delegation of authority to the arbitration panel is not such a total delegation of legislative discretion and authority as would render the statute invalid. The power of the panel is strictly limited and the reasonable and precise standards and guidelines to which the panel must adhere are set out in express detail.

3. The statute, which proscribes review of the panel's determination by [***3] any local legislative body or municipal authority ( Civil Service Law, § 209, subd. 4, par. [a], cl. [vi]), does not violate constitutional due process since such determination must be deemed subject to judicial review.

 

1364 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Carter


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


80 Misc. 2d 1081; 363 N.Y.S.2d 887; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2321



February 4, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss Count III, charging criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree, is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment against her on the basis that the statutes upon which the charges were founded were unconstitutional. The indictment charged defendant with criminal sale of a controlled substance in the first degree, criminal possession of a controlled substance in the second degree, and criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant sold over an ounce of a substance containing 30 milligrams of methadone to an undercover officer, and she was charged with three counts, counts one and two related to the possession and sale of a substance based on aggregate weight and count three related to possession with intent to sell regardless of weight. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment and claimed that it was unconstitutional to hold her criminally liable based on the aggregate weight of the material sold. The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss counts one and two of the indictment and held that the N.Y. Penal Law §§ 220.43 and 220.18 were unconstitutional to the extent they treated the sale and possession of methadone in an aggregate weight of one ounce or more as class A-I and A-II felonies. The court found that there was no rational basis for treating 30 milligrams of therapeutic methadone with the same degree of criminality and sanction as the same weight of more potent, illicit narcotics possessed or sold in dosage quantities at least one hundred times as great. The court held that the third count of the indictment was not unconstitutional because it was not based on weight.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the third count of the indictment, granted defendant's motion to dismiss the first and second counts of the indictment, and held that N.Y. Penal Law §§ 220.43 and 220.18(1)were unconstitutional to the extent that they treated the sale and possession of methadone in an aggregate weight of one ounce or more as class A-I and A-II felonies, respectively.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- controlled substances -- sale and possession of merely therapeutic diluted dose of methadone cannot constitutionally be classified as class A-I and class A-II felonies punishable by maximum of life imprisonment -- accordingly, counts of indictment (under Penal Law, § 220.43 and § 220.18, subd. 1) are dismissed -- People may resubmit those counts as sale of controlled substance in third degree and as possession of controlled substance in seventh degree.

1. Defendant appears to be a former narcotic addict who is now receiving, from a methadone maintenance clinic, take-home therapeutic doses consisting of a little more than one ounce of orange juice in which there are mixed and diluted merely 30 milligrams of methadone plus a few grains of filler and binder. She allegedly sold one of her therapeutic doses to an undercover policeman. Such a diluted therapeutic dose might well be classified as a "narcotic preparation", rather than as a "narcotic drug" from which over 100 narcotic doses can be made from the same quantity (cf. Penal Law, § 220.00,  [***2] subds. 7, 8; Public Health Law, § 3306). Certainly, to the extent that the Penal Law ( § 220.43; § 220.18, subd. 1) classifies the sale and possession of a mere therapeutic dose of methadone as a class A-I and a class A-II felony respectively, punishable by a maximum of life imprisonment (Penal Law, § 70.00, subds. 2, 3), the statutes contravene constitutional principles of due process and equal protection of the laws.

2. Accordingly, the first two counts of this indictment (under Penal Law, § 220.43 and § 220.18, subd. 1) are dismissed, but not the third count (under Penal Law, § 220.16, subd. 1). The People may resubmit the first two counts as a sale of a controlled substance in the third degree (Penal Law, § 220.16) or a lesser included offense, and as possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree (Penal Law, § 220.03), respectively.

 

1365 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Becker v. Levitt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


81 Misc. 2d 664; 366 N.Y.S.2d 940; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2442



February 4, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a village mayor and trustees, brought an action against defendants, a state commissioner and comptroller, for a declaration that the "additional city apportionment" provisions of N.Y State Fin. Law § 54 were unconstitutional. The commissioner and comptroller brought a motion to dismiss, based on res judicata, failure to state a cause of action, and lack of standing.


OVERVIEW: Other than the addition of an allegation that § 54 violated the state constitution, the complaint by the mayor and trustees raised the same issues asserted in a previous action in the federal court, which was dismissed. The mayor and trustees asserted that § 54, which granted more state aid proportionately to cities than to villages abridged their privileges and immunities, deprived them of due process, and denied them equal protection. The court dismissed the complaint. The court held that res judicata barred the complaint at least insofar as alleged violations of the Federal Constitution. The court noted that while the federal court dismissed on the ground of failure to present a federal question, it did so only after finding each of the arguments for the village utterly lacking in legal substance. The court held that the federal ruling addressing identical equal protection language in the Federal Constitution was not dispositive, but was highly persuasive on the state constitutional claim. The court adopted the federal court's view that cities bear greater statutory burdens and costs, thus the distinction drawn by the Legislature was rational.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion by the commissioner and comptroller to dismiss an action by the mayor and trustees for a declaration that the "additional city apportionment" provisions of the state Finance Law were unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- State aid apportionment -- res judicata -- claim of plaintiffs, Mayor and Trustees of Village of Lynbrook, challenging constitutionality of additional State aid apportioned to cities (State Finance Law, § 54), under Federal Constitution, is barred by res judicata; same claim against same defendants was dismissed in prior Federal action -- section 54 does not deprive plaintiffs of equal protection of laws under State Constitution.

1. The action commenced by plaintiffs, the Mayor and Trustees of the Village of Lynbrook, challenging the constitutionality under the Federal Constitution, of the additional State aid city apportionment provisions of section 54 of the State Finance Law, is barred by res judicata since the same claim brought by plaintiffs against the same defendants was dismissed in a prior Federal action upon the ground that plaintiffs failed to present a substantial Federal question. The fundamental principle underlying the doctrine of res judicata is that, in the public interest, a party shall not be heard a second time on an issue which has been settled previously by litigation between the same parties before a court of competent [***2] jurisdiction. The Federal court, in dismissing plaintiffs' first complaint, found each of plaintiffs' arguments to be utterly lacking in legal substance.

2. Plaintiffs' claim that section 54 deprived them of equal protection of the laws under the State Constitution (art I, § 11) is dismissed. Federal decisions in cases of this kind are of highly persuasive effect as authorities in State courts, and only rarely will a statute held by the Federal courts not to be in conflict with the Federal Constitution fail to survive a State court test against a similar constitutional provision.

 

1366 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Fuhrmann


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Nassau County


80 Misc. 2d 751; 363 N.Y.S.2d 883; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2253



February 4, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an original action respondent state tax commission challenged an original order fixing the tax on a decedent's gross estate. The matter was argued orally before a surrogate and submitted for decision. Petitioner executor had filed the estate's return, upon which a federal audit was conducted, and had deducted certain of the decedent's securities of two Canadian corporations.


OVERVIEW: The original order was marked "Subject to Federal audit" on its face. The commission contended that the Canadian securities were assets of the decedent constituting intangible personal property includable in the New York gross estate and therefore fully taxable. The executor contended that Canada created a situs for the securities and the United States recognized such Canadian jurisdiction over shares of stock. Therefore, the executor argued, the securities should have been treated in New York as tangible personal property of the decedent located outside New York and thereby excluded from the New York gross estate, pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 956(a). The court held that: (1) the final federal determination had a binding effect upon the commission, pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 961; (2) deductions were matters of legislative grace and the executor failed to show that the deduction was clearly allowed; and (3) the decedent's Canadian stocks constituted intangible personal property as a matter of New York law and were thereby includable and taxable in his New York gross estate without regard to Canadian tax law and without any foreign death tax credit.


OUTCOME: The court amended its supplemental order to include the Canadian securities at the values fixed in the final federal determination. In the original action the commission challenged the original order fixing the tax on the decedent's gross estate. The executor had filed the estate's return and deducted certain of the decedent's securities of two Canadian corporations. The matter was argued orally before the surrogate and submitted for decision.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- estate tax -- imposition of foreign death tax on transfer of securities -- Canadian securities which were owned by decedent New York resident and which were included in decedent's Federal gross estate and which were also subject to death tax in Canada, are nevertheless includable and taxable in decedent's New York gross estate since such securities constitute intangible personal property as matter of New York law -- omission by New York of any credit for foreign death tax is not unconstitutional -- appeal by tax commission was properly noticed within 60 days from original order.

1. Decedent was a New York resident whose tax was fixed by order, at $ 99,450 on a gross estate of $ 1,541,819. The order was marked "Subject to Federal audit". The New York State Tax Commission filed a notice of appeal and objected to the exclusion from decedent's gross estate of certain securities of two Canadian corporations, which had been included in decedent's Federal gross estate by the Internal Revenue Service. The final Federal determination set the value of the securities at $ 27,731.25 which determination is binding upon the tax commission ( Tax Law, § 961). Although Canada [***2] also imposed a tax on the transfer of the securities upon decedent's death, which results in the multiple taxation by different jurisdictions of decedent's intangible personal property, the Canadian stocks constitute intangible personal property as a matter of New York law and are thereby includable and taxable in decedent's New York gross estate without regard to Canadian tax law. New York cannot change or adjust the imposition of the tax law of a foreign sovereignty which defines and taxes intangible personal property of a nonresident differently than New York does.

2. The omission by New York from its tax law of any credit for a foreign death tax is not unconstitutional. New York taxes only the real property and tangible personal property of nonresidents situated in New York over which New York has exclusive jurisdiction, and therefore does not grant credits for foreign death taxes ( Tax Law, § 249-p). The rule regarding reciprocity of exemptions from certain death taxes between the States ( Tax Law, § 249-p-A) has no effect upon the imposition of Canadian tax law against the estate of decedent.

3. The appeal was properly noticed within 60 days from the original order ( Tax [***3] Law, § 249-x), and the grounds upon which the appeal was taken were properly stated. In any event, the tax commission has the right to move for a supplemental determination in respect to any increase in the taxable estate resulting from the Federal audit and final determination ( Tax Law, § 962).

4. Accordingly, the supplemental order should be amended to include the Canadian securities at the values fixed in the final Federal determination.

 

1367 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Tabb


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


80 Misc. 2d 431; 364 N.Y.S.2d 357; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2192



February 3, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motion to declare subdivision 7 of section 665 of the Judiciary Law void as a violation of the Federal Constitution is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss his indictment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss his indictment on the ground that he was indicted by a grand jury selected by standards, which violated the equal protection of the Constitution. Defendant contended that he was deprived of his constitutional right to a fair trial by a jury of a representative segment of the community. On consideration, the court denied defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment. The court held that N.Y. Jud. Law § 667(7), which provided exceptions from jury service for women, was not unconstitutional. However, the court indicated that the statute was outdated and that women should be required to serve as jurors, as well as men, subject to any special right of exemption to women based upon good reason.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment.


HEADNOTES

Jury -- exemption of women from jury service -- subdivision 7 of section 665 of Judiciary Law, which allows women exemption from otherwise automatic requirement of jury service upon claim therefor, is not unconstitutional, since actual percentage of service by women cannot be said to be unfair representation of cross section of community -- ruling of United States Supreme Court in Taylor case (419 U.S. 522) is not retroactive and does not apply to indictment which preceded that decision.

1. Subdivision 7 of section 665 of the Judiciary Law, which allows women an exemption from jury service upon claim therefor, does not unconstitutionally deprive the defendant of the equal protection of the law. The United States Supreme Court in Taylor v. Louisiana (419 U.S. 522) stated that it was setting no particular standards for the State to follow, so long as the result provided a jury system that fairly represented a cross section of the community. Unless a demand for an exemption is made, a woman in New York State is automatically required to [***2] serve as a juror, and the actual percentage of service by women cannot be said to be an unfair representation of the community. The indictment herein issued from a Grand Jury with a fair representation of women and the defendant has no standing to claim that he was aggrieved.

2. The ruling of the United States Supreme Court is not retroactive and does not apply to the indictment, which preceded the decision in the Taylor case.

 

1368 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Moss


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


80 Misc. 2d 633; 366 N.Y.S.2d 522; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2226



February 3, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to challenge the jury panel in his case, and argued that the automatic exemption from jury service granted to women violated his due process and equal protection rights.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with a crime. Under N.Y. Jud. Law § 599, women were granted an automatic exemption from jury service if even they were qualified as jurors. Defendant filed a motion to challenge the panel from which his jury was to be chosen, and argued that the automatic exemption violated his due process and equal protection rights because he would not receive a jury drawn from a panel representing a fair cross-section of the community. The court granted the motion. The court held that the Sixth Amendment mandated that a jury be drawn from a pool which reflected a fair cross-section of the community. After reviewing statistics from the clerk's office, the court confirmed that women were substantially underrepresented on juries in relation to the proportion of women in the population. The court held that an automatic exemption for women created a suspect sex-based classification. Because there was no legitimate state interest in the exemption, the exemption violated the Equal Protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion challenging the panel from which his jury would be drawn and ordered that defendant 's jury be drawn from a panel which represented a fair cross-section of the community.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Jury -- exemption of women from jury service -- exemption of women from jury service upon claim therefor pursuant to Judiciary Law results in substantial prejudice to defendant, and motion challenging jury panel is granted, since panel does not reflect representative cross section of community, depriving defendant of right to impartial jury, and since no compelling State interest has been shown to justify statute under equal protection clause -- decision should not be applied retroactively and will not affect case unless motion to challenge has been made.

1. The exemption from jury service accorded to women who claim such under section 599 of the Judiciary Law results in substantial prejudice to the defendant, and his motion challenging the jury panel pursuant to CPL 270.10 is granted. It is constitutionally mandated that juries be drawn from panels which reflect a representative cross section of the community, and, although the Judiciary Law makes it easier for women to serve as jurors than does the Louisiana statute declared unconstitutional in Taylor v. Louisiana (419 U.S. 522), women are nevertheless substantially underrepresented in proportion to their actual [***2] numbers in the population. Such underrepresentation would deprive the defendant of his right under the Sixth Amendment to an impartial jury trial. Since the statutory classification solely on the basis of sex is inherently suspect and deals with fundamental rights, it is subject to strict scrutiny requiring a showing of a compelling State interest to justify its use under the equal protection clause. The only possible such interest is that the care of young children would be neglected if women were required to serve on juries, a view totally without foundation and an interest which could have been achieved by a grant of an exemption to persons actually occupied in the care of young children. The historical justification for relegating women to an inferior status, based upon a rigid and empirically unsupported view of a single societal role, is no longer valid or acceptable, and the State has not met its burden. Since the consequences will be severe and the damage irreparable if the defendant must risk his liberty by being tried by a jury drawn from a panel not conforming to constitutional requirements, the court should not hesitate to determine the constitutionality of the statute. 

 [***3] 2. This decision should not be applied retroactively and will affect no case unless a motion to challenge has been made. A defendant who pleads guilty waives jury trial and the right to object to the jury panel.

 

1369 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Morehouse


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Westchester County


80 Misc. 2d 406; 364 N.Y.S.2d 108; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2188



January 29, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the third branch of defendant's omnibus motion is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted on a single count of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the fifth degree in violation of § 220.09(10). In pretrial proceedings, defendant filed an omnibus motion seeking in part an order declaring that N.Y. Penal Law § 220.09(10) was unconstitutional because it deprived defendant of equal protection of the law and violated the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's indictment was based on possession of marijuana. Defendant attacked § 220.09(10) as unconstitutional. The court held the motion in abeyance and directed, sua sponte, that the attorney-general be brought in, pursuant N.Y. Exec. Law § 71, to defend the constitutionality of the statute. The attorney-general briefed and argued the constitutional question. The court denied the part of defendant's omnibus motion that sought a declaration that § 220.09(10) was unconstitutional. Noting that defendant failed to brief or support his argument even though he had the burden of demonstrating the statute's invalidity, the court held that § 220.09(10) did not violate defendant's equal protection rights because the placement of marijuana in the same schedule with heroin and other opium derivatives was not a controlling factor in the scheme of punishment for marijuana possession. The court also held that § 220.09(10) did not provide for cruel and unusual punishment merely because the penalties for defendant's offense and narcotics offenses were class C felonies warranting similar punishments.


OUTCOME: The court denied the branch of defendant's omnibus motion that sought an order declaring the statute under which defendant was indicted to be unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- dangerous drugs -- possession of marijuana -- subdivision 10 of section 220.09 of Penal Law which proscribes possession of marijuana is not unconstitutional; classification and sentencing provisions relating to marijuana violations draw a rational distinction between marijuana and "hard" narcotics -- grouping marijuana in same schedule with heroin and other opium derivatives does not deprive defendant of equal protection since such grouping is not controlling factor in scheme of punishment for marijuana violations -- penalties prescribed for marijuana violations do not constitute cruel and unusual punishment.

1. Subdivision 10 of section 220.09 of the Penal Law, criminal possession of a controlled substance (marijuana) in the fifth degree, is not unconstitutional. In proscribing the sale, possession and distribution of marijuana, the Penal Law has not classed marijuana with various narcotic drugs in violation of defendant's due process and equal protection rights since marijuana has been removed from the narcotic drug category. (Cf. Penal Law, § 220.00, subds. 6 and 7; Public [***2] Health Law, § 3302, subds. 20 and 21 and § 3306, Schedule I, subds. [a], [b], [c] and [d]; Schedule II, subds. [a] and [b]; Penal Law, former § 220.00, subds. 1 and 4, and § 220.02; Public Health Law, former arts. 33, 33-A and 33-B.)

2. Grouping marijuana in the same schedule with heroin and other opium derivatives which are generally thought to be more dangerous or harmful (Public Health Law, § 3306, Schedule I), does not deprive defendant of equal protection since such grouping is not a controlling factor in the scheme of punishment for marijuana violations. Punishment for marijuana violations is treated differently from the punishment for violations involving other more dangerous drugs. While conviction under any of the first nine subdivisions of section 220.09 requires imposition of a prison sentence pursuant to subdivision 3 of section 60.05 of the Penal Law, a marijuana possession conviction under subdivisions 10 and 11 of section 220.09 need not result in a prison sentence. An offender convicted under subdivision 10 or 11 can receive a probationary sentence or a sentence of conditional or unconditional discharge.

3. The penalties prescribed for marijuana [***3] violations do not constitute cruel and unusual punishment since the classification and sentencing provisions relating to marijuana violations draw a rational distinction between marijuana and the "hard" narcotics.

 

1370 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Nydick v. Suffolk County Legislature


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


81 Misc. 2d 786; 367 N.Y.S.2d 632; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2479



January 29, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, an individual and the governor's appointee, sought to prevent respondent Suffolk County Legislature from filling a vacancy that existed from the Eleventh Legislative District pursuant to § 206 of the Suffolk County Charter, 1958 Law 278. Petitioners, Suffolk County Legislature and its appointee, sought to prohibit respondent governor from appointing the legislator pursuant to N.Y. County Law § 400(7). The petitions were consolidated.


OVERVIEW: The governor's appointee argued that the county charter was unconstitutional and ultra vires since it conflicted with N.Y. County Law § 400(7), a general law. The legislature's appointee argued that the county charter superceded N.Y. County Law § 400(7). The court ruled in favor of the legislature's appointee, holding that § 400(7) was not a general law because it did not apply to all counties. The court found it particularly noteworthy that neither the County Law nor the Public Officers Law was included among the chapters which "charter" counties were prohibited from superseding by N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 34. Moreover, there was no express statement in N.Y. County Law § 400 that it was to be superior to any alternate county government law. The court concluded that the legislative grant of power contained in N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2 was properly effectuated by the legislature through N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 33 and that § 206 of the Suffolk County Charter was duly enacted pursuant to the power conferred upon the county by N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 33(2). Therefore, the court issued a writ of prohibition against the governor.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petition of the governor's appointee and issued a writ of prohibition against the governor and his appointee, prohibiting the governor from making any appointment to fill the vacant position of County Legislator from the Eleventh Legislative District and prohibiting the appointee from purporting to exercise any authority pursuant to such appointment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- filling vacancy in office of County Legislator -- Suffolk County Legislature may lawfully fill vacancies in office of Suffolk County Legislator pursuant to subdivision (a) of section 206 of Suffolk County Charter; section 206 is not in conflict with general law of State and is therefore not ultra vires -- subdivision 7 of section 400 of County Law does not give respondent Governor power to fill vacancies in office of County Legislator.

1. The Suffolk County Legislature may lawfully fill a vacancy in the office of Suffolk County Legislator from the Eleventh Legislative District pursuant to subdivision (a) of section 206 of the Suffolk County Charter. Subdivision 7 of section 400 of the County Law which provides that "a vacancy in an elective county office, shall be filled by the governor by appointment", is not a general law of the State and is therefore not controlling over the provisions of the Suffolk County Charter. Section 206 was duly enacted pursuant to the power conferred upon the county by subdivision 2 of section 33 of the Municipal Home Rule Law. Since section 206 is not in conflict with a general law, it is not ultra vires and is [***2] therefore a proper subject of local government legislation.

2. Since the office of County Legislator is not enumerated in subdivision 1 of section 400 of the County Law, respondent Governor, in any event, lacks the power under subdivision 7 of section 400 to appoint to vacancies in said office.

 

1371 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Vath v. Israel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


80 Misc. 2d 759; 364 N.Y.S.2d 97; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2256



January 28, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] On the facts and law of this case defendant's motion is granted to the extent that the order of attachment is vacated and the complaint dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant non-resident moved to vacate an order of attachment of the nonresident's insurance policy in plaintiff driver's personal injury suit.


OVERVIEW: The driver and the nonresident were involved in an automobile accident outside the forum. Subsequently, the driver filed suit in the forum and an order of attachment issued against the nonresident's insurance policy, from which jurisdiction was obtained. However, the court granted the nonresident's motion to vacate the order of attachment. The court held that N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6201(1) from which the attachment was premised was unconstitutional as applied to nonresidents and non-domiciliaries because it failed to provide an immediate post-seizure hearing in which a plaintiff was required to prove the grounds on which the attachment order issued.


OUTCOME: The court granted the nonresident's motion and vacated the order of attachment on the nonresident's insurance policy.


HEADNOTES

Attachment -- attachment of property of nonresident or nondomiciliary -- in personal injury action arising out of collision in New Jersey, instituted in New York by attaching insurance policy issued to defendant, New Jersey resident, order of attachment is vacated and complaint dismissed, on ground that, as applied to causes of action having substantive issues of fact, portion of CPLR 6201 (subd. 1) which provides for granting of order of attachment of property of defendant who is not resident or domiciliary of New York, is unconstitutional as violative of due process, in failing to accord such defendant immediate postseizure hearing -- this holding does not extend to that portion of statute which pertains to foreign corporations -- in event holding is reversed, complaint is dismissed, on conditions, on ground of forum non conveniens -- alleged nonresidence of plaintiffs would not warrant vacating order of attachment.

1. A personal injury action arising out of a collision between two vehicles in New Jersey was instituted in [***2] New York by attaching an insurance policy which had been issued to defendant, a New Jersey resident, by a company with a New York office. The order of attachment is vacated and the complaint is dismissed, on the ground that, as applied to causes of action having substantive issues of fact, that portion of subdivision 1 of CPLR 6201 which provides for the granting of an order of attachment of the property of a defendant who is not a resident or domiciliary of New York, is unconstitutional. It is violative of due process, in that it fails to accord such a defendant an immediate postseizure hearing at which plaintiff must prove the grounds on which the order issued.

2. Since different controlling factors may be involved, this holding does not extend to that portion of CPLR 6201 (subd. 1) which pertains to foreign corporations.

3. In the event this holding of unconstitutionality is reversed, the complaint is dismissed, on conditions, on the ground of forum non conveniens, since New York has only tenuous connections with the operative factors involved in the action, and New Jersey is the more appropriate forum.

4. The facts, as alleged by defendant, that one plaintiff is not a [***3] resident of New York and the other plaintiff, who claims to be a New York resident, holds a New Jersey operator's license, while relevant to forum, would not warrant vacating the order of attachment.

 

1372 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Estrada


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


80 Misc. 2d 608; 364 N.Y.S.2d 332; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2224



January 27, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendant's motion for youthful offender consideration is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, who was before the court for sentencing for his convictions for the criminal sale of a controlled substance in the second degree, criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree, and criminal possession of a controlled substance in the fifth degree, made an oral motion for consideration as a youthful offender. Defendant also sought a declaration that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10(2) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Two of defendant's convictions were for class A felonies, and as a result, defendant would be denied youthful offender status under § 720.10(2). In his motion for consideration as a youthful offender, defendant asserted that § 720.10(2) was unconstitutional because it violated both due process and equal protection in its exclusion of youths indicted for class A felonies. The court denied defendant's motion, holding that the classification in § 72.010(2) was constitutional and did not violate due process or equal protection. The court first noted that there was a presumption of constitutionality surrounding legislative enactments, which could be rebutted by a showing of invalidity beyond a reasonable doubt. Moreover, a legislative classification would be upheld if there was some reasonable basis for it. The court found that § 720.10(2) established different classifications among youthful offenders based upon previous criminal records and the gravity of the crimes. The court found that the exclusion from youthful offender eligibility for those indicted for class A felonies was reasonably related to the object of § 720.10(2) to punish those who committed more serious crimes.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for youthful offender consideration.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- youthful offender treatment -- one indicted for class A felony is not eligible for youthful offender treatment ( CPL 720.10, subd. 2); statute is constitutional.

A youth (that is, one over 16 and less than 19 years old) who is indicted for a class A felony -- in this case, a class A-II and a class A-III felony -- is not eligible for youthful offender treatment ( CPL 720.10, subd. 2, par. [a]). The cited statute is constitutional.

 

1373 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Seasons Realty Corp. v. Yonkers


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


80 Misc. 2d 601; 363 N.Y.S.2d 738; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2223



January 24, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlords instituted an action against defendant city for a declaratory judgment that the Declaration of Housing Emergency (Declaration) passed by the city council was invalid, illegal, and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The city council passed the Declaration on the basis that there was a vacancy rate of less than five percent across rentals. The landlords sought a declaratory judgment that the Declaration was invalid, illegal, and unconstitutional. The court entered a declaratory judgment that the Declaration was constitutional and valid pursuant to the delegation of power authorized under the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974 (ETPA). The ETPA authorized the city to issue the declaration if the vacancy rate for the housing accommodations within the municipality were not in excess of five percent. The court held that the city council's resolution was a legislative act. The court held that the ETPA's delegation of power to the local unit of government was plainly constitutional. The legislature could pass a statute that conferred rights upon a restricted locality but became operative only in the event of an affirmative vote. A presumption of validity attached when the city enacted the ordinance, and the landlord had the burden of questioning the ordinance. The court had to sustain the ordinance if the propriety of its enactment was fairly debatable.
