OUTCOME: The court granted judgment for the city in the landlord's action seeking a declaratory judgment that the Declaration passed by the city council was invalid, illegal, and unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and tenant -- Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974 -- Yonkers City Council validly, legislatively and constitutionally declared housing emergency based on vacancy rate of 5% or less.

The Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974 (L. 1974, ch. 576) provides that it shall take effect in any city in Westchester County (and in cities in two other counties) when the local legislature declares that a housing emergency exists because the vacancy rate is 5% or less. Such a declaration was legislatively, constitutionally and validly made by the Yonkers City Council on June 28, 1974. Declaratory judgment is granted accordingly.

 

1374 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


McWilliams v. Staszak


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Schenectady County


82 Misc. 2d 546; 370 N.Y.S.2d 307; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2729



January 23, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner recipient of supplemental security income (recipient), filed a class action to require respondent county to provide her with an emergency grant to pay her overdue electricity bill to respondent power company, to enjoin the county from its policy of failing to provide emergency assistance, and to require respondent state to advise local authorities that emergency assistance had to be provided.


OVERVIEW: The recipient was past due on her payments to the power company. The power company had turned her power off, but then turned it on again. The recipient applied for emergency assistance pursuant to N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 13-a(6), to pay the power company's bill. The county denied the application. The recipient filed a class action for injunctive relief. The county and state objected to the requested relief, and argued that the recipient had failed to exhaust her administrative remedies. The court granted the recipient's petition to the extent of requiring the county to meet the recipient's immediate emergency need to pay the power company, and otherwise denied the petition. The court held that to require the recipient to exhaust her administrative remedies would have rendered the issue moot. The court held that the state had a duty to care for the needy. N.Y. Const. art. 17, § 1. The court held that the loss of electrical power constituted an emergency pursuant to § 13-a(6). The court held that each case should be considered on its merits and that to require the county to grant each application for emergency assistance would substitute the court's judgment for that of the county.


OUTCOME: The court granted the recipient's petition to require the county to provide her with an emergency grant to pay her overdue electricity bill to the power company. The court denied the recipient's petition to enjoin the county from its policy of failing to provide emergency assistance, and to require the state to advise local authorities that emergency assistance had to be provided.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Social services -- public assistance -- payment of utility bill -- recipient of Federal supplemental security income (SSI) grant, threatened with shutoff of utilities because of nonpayment of utility bill, applied for emergency grant and, when it was denied, commenced article 78 proceeding -- her petition will not be dismissed because of her failure to exhaust her administrative remedies -- social services agency is ordered to pay so much of bill as will eliminate existing emergency situation -- in view of this, contention that emergency assistance to SSI recipients is unconstitutionally limited to "catastrophic" cases is rendered untenable -- other relief sought, to require county agency to desist from alleged policy of denying emergency grants to prevent shutoffs to SSI recipients, and to require State commissioner to advise local districts that emergency assistance must be provided to destitute SSI recipients threatened with shutoff of utilities, is denied.

1. Petitioner, the recipient of a Federal supplemental security income (SSI) grant, who was threatened with a shutoff of utilities because of nonpayment of her utility bill, made application to the county social services [***2] agency for an emergency grant to pay the overdue bill, and, when it was denied, commenced an article 78 proceeding. Under the circumstances, her petition will not be dismissed because of her failure to exhaust her administrative remedies.

2. Petitioner's inability to obtain heat and other utilities constitutes an emergency, and the social services agency must act. It is ordered to pay the utility company so much of the bill as will eliminate the existing emergency situation. In view of this conclusion, a contention by petitioner that section 303 (subd 1) of the Social Services Law and the regulations implementing that section are unconstitutional in that emergency assistance to SSI recipients is limited to "catastrophic" cases is rendered untenable.

3. Petitioner also seeks to require the county agency to desist from an alleged policy of denying emergency grants to prevent shutoffs to SSI recipients. To grant this relief would, in effect, substitute the court's judgment for that of the agency in all such cases and would constitute judicial interference with its basic operation. That relief is denied.

4. She also seeks to require the State commissioner to advise all local social [***3] services districts that emergency assistance must be provided to destitute SSI recipients threatened with shutoff of utilities. To grant this relief would constitute unwarranted judicial intervention in the operation and promulgation of rules and regulations implementing the requirements of the Social Services Law. It is denied.

 

1375 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ron--Ore Soil Systems, Ltd.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County


81 Misc. 2d 121; 364 N.Y.S.2d 310; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2344



January 21, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed motions by order directing the Attorney-General of the State of New York and the Acting Deputy Attorney-General in charge of the state-wide Organized Crime Task Force to show cause why the indictments charging defendant with conspiracy, perjury, tampering with evidence and other offenses relating to the construction of a municipal sewer project should not be dismissed.


OVERVIEW: The Organized Crime Task Force (OCTF) commenced an investigation into alleged criminal activity in connection with a municipal sewer construction project pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 70-a. Subpoenas were issued for witnesses, defendants' business and financial records and municipal records. Defendants were charged in a 57-count indictment, including charges of conspiracy, perjury and tempering with evidence. Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the indictments, which the court granted. The court held that N.Y. Exec. Law § 70-a was unconstitutional on its face and as applied. The court ruled that the Act was unconstitutionally vague because it granted almost unlimited authority to the OCTF to investigate organized crime activities in two or more counties without defining "organized crime." The court held that the Act violated defendants' Fourth Amendment rights by authorizing the OCTF to subpoena witnesses and evidence without showing that it was relevant or necessary to its investigation. The court further ruled that the Act violated defendants' due process rights because the OCTF was not required to inform them of the nature of the investigation before they were questioned.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motions to dismiss the multi-count indictments issued against them and charging them with conspiracy, perjury, tampering with evidence and other offenses.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- State-wide organized crime task force -- Executive Law ( § 70-a, subds 1, 4, 6) unconstitutional; indictments dismissed.

1. Section 70-a of the Executive Law is too vague to be constitutional, either as worded or as applied in this case. Subdivision 1 of that section establishes "a statewide organized crime task force" but does not define "organized crime"; and, though this subdivision authorizes the task force to investigate and prosecute "organized crime activities" which are "carried on" in two or more counties, in this case the basic alleged crime occurred in only one county, yet the task force issued nonjudicial subpoenas in another county which resulted in an alleged perjury in that other county and in an alleged destruction in still another county of subpoenaed materials.

2. Furthermore, the broad nonjudicial subpoena powers of the "task force" ( Executive Law, § 70-a, subds 4, 6), and its failure to comply with the code of fair procedure for investigatory agencies ( Civil Rights Law, § 73, subd 2), render both subdivision 4 and subdivision 6 of section 70-a unconstitutional.

3. Accordingly, these 7 indictments, alleging 57 counts against 6 individuals and [***2] 1 corporation, are dismissed.

 

1376 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rice


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Suffolk County


80 Misc. 2d 511; 363 N.Y.S.2d 484; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2205



January 20, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, this court having held that section 130.38, and subdivision 1 of section 130.00 and subdivision 2 of section 130.00 of the Penal Law as encompassed by section 130.38, is unconstitutional because it violates the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution and section 11 of article 1 of the New York Constitution, the defendants' motions are granted and the informations are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, charged with consensual sodomy in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 130.38, filed motions to dismiss the informations on the ground that § 130.38 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The gist of the challenged statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 130.38, was that certain conduct between two consenting but unmarried adults was a criminal offense, regardless of where such conduct took place. Married people were excluded from this proscription, as were unmarried people who engaged in certain other forms of sexual conduct. Defendants filed motions to dismiss the informations. The court held that § 130.38 and § 130.00 as it was encompassed by § 130.38 were unconstitutional. The court found that if inquiry into or regulation of a married person's sexual conduct was an invasion of the right to privacy, then inquiry into or regulation of a single person's sexual conduct was equally violative of the right to privacy. The court could not find what overriding or compelling state interest the legislature sought to protect by enacting § 130.38. Accordingly, the court held that the statute violated the Equal Protection Clause of the U.S. Const. amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motions to dismiss their informations charging them with consensual sodomy and held that the consensual sodomy statute was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- consensual sodomy -- Penal Law ( § 130.38) unconstitutional; informations dismissed.

Consensual sodomy as defined by the Penal Law ( § 130.38; § 130.00, subds. 1, 2) cannot constitutionally be made criminal (cf. U. S. Const., 14th Amdt.; N. Y. Const., art. I, § 11). The informations are dismissed.

 

1377 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Islip v. Vollbracht's Dairy, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Fifth District, Suffolk County


80 Misc. 2d 721; 363 N.Y.S.2d 307; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2245



January 17, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff town filed an action against defendant dairy for violation of Islip, N.Y., Town Code § 35-2(L), the town's anti-noise ordinance. In its motion to dismiss, the dairy argued that the ordinance was unconstitutional because it was void for vagueness.


OVERVIEW: A town filed an action against a local dairy for two violations of Islip, N.Y., Town Code § 35-2(L), the town's anti-noise ordinance. The dairy filed a motion to dismiss and argued that the ordinance was void for vagueness, unconstitutional, and unenforceable. The court explained that, like a statute, an ordinance was presumed to be valid and constitutional. The dairy had the burden to prove that the ordinance was void for vagueness. To determine that issue, the court considered whether the ordinance stated with sufficient clarity the rule to be obeyed, such that a reasonable person would be informed about the nature of the offense and about what the ordinance required. In this case, the ordinance declared that the operation of any machinery, equipment, pump, fan, exhaust fan, attic fan, air-conditioning apparatus or similar mechanical device, in such a manner as to create any unreasonable or unnecessary noise of unreasonable extent and duration, was prohibited.The court compared similar ordinances that had been upheld, found that this ordinance was constitutional, denied the dairy's motion to dismiss, and ordered that the matter proceed to trial.


OUTCOME: The court upheld the constitutionality of the town's anti-noise ordinance, denied the dairy's motion to dismiss, and ordered that the matter proceed to trial.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- anti-noise ordinance -- vagueness -- standard set up by anti-noise ordinance of Town of Islip can fairly be interpreted by "reasonable man" and is therefore not unconstitutional for vagueness.

Defendant is charged in two separate complaints with violations of the anti-noise ordinance of the Islip Town Code ( § 35-2, subd. L). Said ordinance which prohibits the operation of various mechanical devices "in such a manner as to create any unreasonable or unnecessary noise of such unreasonable extent and duration", is not unconstitutional. In dealing with noise problems at this time, a more objective standard could not be reached. The use of a decibel level standard as suggested by defendant would be a useless and inefficient standard. The standard set up by the ordinance can fairly be interpreted by a "reasonable man" and is therefore not unconstitutional for vagueness. Accordingly, the motion to dismiss the accusatory instruments is denied and the matter will proceed to trial.

 

1378 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Namath v. Sports Illustrated


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


80 Misc. 2d 531; 363 N.Y.S.2d 276; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2208



January 13, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss the complaint is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant publisher moved to dismiss plaintiff athlete's complaint which sought damages under N.Y. Civ. Rights Law §§ 50 and 51 for the alleged violation of his right of privacy and the wrongful use of his photograph without his written consent in an advertising campaign.


OVERVIEW: The court granted defendant publisher's motion to dismiss plaintiff athlete's complaint alleging violation of his right of privacy and the wrongful use of his photograph without his written consent in contravention of N.Y. Civ. Rights Law §§ 50 and 51. The gravamen of plaintiff's complaint was that defendant's magazine, in an advertising campaign, used photographs of plaintiff in 10 advertisements to promote subscriptions. Moreover, plaintiff asserted that defendant's advertisement was not an incidental use but became a collateral use with the passing of time. The court found that so long as the reproductions were used to illustrate the quality and content of the periodical in which it originally appeared, the statute was not violated, albeit the reproduction appeared in other media for purposes of advertising the periodical. The court found it commendable that under U.S. Const. amend. I freedom of speech and of the press transcended the right to privacy, particularly where a petitioner sought remuneration for what was basically a property right, not a right to privacy.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant publisher's motion to dismiss a complaint alleging violation of plaintiff athlete's right of privacy and the wrongful use of his photograph without his written consent because in connection with advertising, incidental use of plaintiff's likeness was not in contravention of a civil rights statute.


HEADNOTES

Civil rights -- unlawful use of name or portrait -- unlawful use of photograph without written consent -- plaintiff football player, whose photograph was republished and used by defendant in its sports magazine to stimulate subscriptions without his written consent, cannot recover damages against defendant for invasion of privacy (Civil Rights Law, §§ 50, 51) since such use of plaintiff's photograph is incidental advertising of news medium which is permissible under statute; freedom of speech and press transcends right of privacy.

Plaintiff is a famous football player whose photograph has appeared many times on the cover and in stories published by defendant in its sports magazine from July, 1965 through October, 1972, and who earns substantial income for commercial indorsements of many products. Defendant used a photograph of plaintiff it had published in January, 1969 to promote subscriptions during the latter half of 1972. Plaintiff's photograph was printed adjacent to a subscription application for the magazine. In an action for damages under sections 50 and 51 of the Civil Rights Law for violation of plaintiff's right [***2] to privacy and the wrongful use of his photograph without his written consent, the complaint is dismissed. The republication and use of plaintiff's photograph to stimulate subscriptions was incidental advertising of the news medium which is permissible under the statute (see Booth v. Curtis Pub. Co., 15 A D 2d 343, 349, affd. 11 N Y 2d 907). Freedom of speech and press under the First Amendment transcends the right to privacy. This is particularly so where plaintiff seeks remuneration for what is basically a property right and not a right to privacy.

 

1379 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Dunbar v. Dunbar


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


80 Misc. 2d 744; 364 N.Y.S.2d 699; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2251



January 10, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff wife filed a motion seeking a determination declaring N.Y. Ins. Law § 167(3) unconstitutional on the grounds that it violated the equal protection guarantees of both the United States and New York Constitutions. Plaintiff had brought an action for personal injuries against the estate of her deceased husband, and defendant insurer had advised that there was no coverage for inter-spousal suits under plaintiff's husband's policy.


OVERVIEW: Defendant insurer issued a policy of liability insurance in the name of plaintiff's husband. Subsequently plaintiff brought a personal injury action against her husband's estate. Defendant advised there was no coverage for inter-spousal suits under the policy, relying upon N.Y. Ins. Law. § 167(3). That statute declared that no policy was to be deemed to insure against, inter alia, liability of an insured because of death of or injuries to his or her spouse unless the policy expressly included such a provision. Plaintiff brought a motion seeking a declaration that the statute was unconstitutional on the grounds that it violated the equal protection guarantees of both the U.S. and the New York State constitutions. The court denied plaintiff's motion, as it found the statute constitutional. Plaintiff made no showing of intentional or purposeful discrimination in the application of the statute. Moreover, plaintiff failed to sustain the burden of the strong presumption of validity which attached to the statute by showing its invalidity beyond a reasonable doubt. The fact that the element of collusion was not present did not suffice to negate the plain intendment of the statute.


OUTCOME: The court denied plaintiff's motion seeking a declaration that a state statute protecting insurers from inter-spousal suits was unconstitutional as there was no showing that there was present an element of intentional or purposeful discrimination in the application of the statute. The court found the statute constitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Insurance -- automobile liability insurance -- interspousal suits -- statutory exclusion -- in plaintiff's action for personal injuries against estate of her husband, insurer properly disclaimed coverage for such interspousal suit under husband's automobile liability insurance policy; subdivison 3 of section 167 of Insurance Law is constitutional.

1. Plaintiff, while a passenger in a motor vehicle owned and operated by her husband, sustained injuries and her husband was killed. In her action against the estate of her husband, the insurer which had issued an automobile liability insurance policy to her husband properly disclaimed (Insurance Law, § 167, subd. 3). Subdivision 3 of section 167 which excludes coverage under an automobile liability insurance policy for injuries sustained by the spouse of the insured as a result of the insured's negligence "unless express provision relating specifically thereto is included in the policy" is constitutional. Plaintiff has not established that the statute results in a denial of equal protection since she has failed to sustain the burden of showing that there is present an element of intentional or purposeful discrimination in the [***2] application of the statute. Plaintiff has also failed to rebut the strong presumption of validity which attaches to a statute.

2. The fact that the element of collusion might be absent here since the alleged negligent spouse is deceased, is not sufficient to negate the plain intent of the statutory exclusion provision which was designed to prevent collusion and fraud. Coverage for interspousal suits must be declared in specific language.

 

1380 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Schenectady v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


80 Misc. 2d 223; 363 N.Y.S.2d 76; 1975 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2177



January 9, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff City sought a judgment against defendant State declaring § 131 of the Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law, 1940 N.Y. Laws ch. 254, § 131, as amended by 1974 N.Y. Laws ch. 439, § 1, to be inapplicable to the City, or, if not, unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The relief requested was based on the theory that the enactment was an unconstitutional delegation of the State's taxing power in violation of N.Y. Const. art. XVI, § 1, and permitted another city, the only city qualifying under the act, to tax beyond its territorial jurisdiction. It was further alleged that § 131 was incapable of compliance because of ambiguity and vagueness. The City impliedly, at least, urged that it was not a State statute that was being attacked but a law enacted by the other city, which had no right whatever to surcharge or tax the City disputing the legislation. The court disagreed with the City's position and ruled that the law in question was enacted by the State, not by the other city. When the non-party city passed the local law, that passage triggered the operation of § 131 state-wide. The court further held that § 131 was constitutional because the City failed to meet the heavy burden to demonstrate its unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt.


OUTCOME: The court directed judgment in favor of the State declaring the § 131 constitutional and valid and required the City to follow the statute as written.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Horse racing -- off-track Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law -- surcharge -- State statute authorizing city with over one million in population to impose surcharge on pari-mutuel betting pools distributable to persons betting at local facilities and, if so imposed, to place same tax on all other off-track betting operators in State is constitutional -- Legislature could have enacted surcharge directly, and conditional legislation is constitutional; statute was enacted by State, not locality, and plaintiff city and various State agencies have no standing to contest, since statute relates to governmental powers and duties.

1. Section 131 of the Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law (L. 1940, ch. 254, § 131, as amd. by L. 1974, ch. 439, § 1), which authorizes any city with a population of over one million to adopt a local law imposing a 5% surcharge on the portion of pari-mutuel wagering pools distributable to persons betting at off-track betting facilities within such city and, if so adopted, imposing the same tax on all other off-track betting operators in the State, is on its face valid and constitutional.

2. The Legislature could have directly enacted the surcharge but instead conditioned operation [***2] of the tax upon passage of a local law by New York City, and such conditional legislation is not unconstitutional. The statute was enacted by the State, not the City of New York, and the plaintiffs, the City of Schenectady and various State agencies and subdivisions, have no standing to contest a State statute relating to governmental powers and duties.

 

1381 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Ceracche Television Corp. v. Kelly


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


80 Misc. 2d 956; 364 N.Y.S.2d 276; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1933



December 31, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The article 78 proceeding challenging general order No. 4 is therefore dismissed and the motion for a declaratory judgment is likewise dismissed, and the cross-motion declaring the section in question constitutional is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a cable company, on its own behalf and as a representative of a class, filed a petition to initiate proceedings pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 against defendants, the New York Commission on Cable Television and others, challenging the Commission's order, which implemented N.Y. Exec. Law § 817, and filed a declaratory judgment action seeking to declare that § 817 was unconstitutional and a return of all moneys paid pursuant thereto.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 817, the Commission, which was authorized under N.Y. Exec. Law § 811 et seq., to regulate cable television companies, defrayed its expenses by allocating them among various cable television companies in proportion to their gross receipts. A cable company, individually and as representative of a class, initiated proceedings pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 against the Commission alleging that N.Y. Exec. Law § 817 imposed gross receipts tax upon proceeds from interstate commerce, violating the Commerce and the Supremacy Clause, and sought a declaration that § 817 was unconstitutional. The court held that: (1) the action was not properly maintained as a class action because the cable company was not a proper representative, as some of the services it provided were not provided by a majority of cable operators; and (2) the Commission's general order implementing N.Y. Exec. Law § 817(2) was reasonable and lawful because there was no violation of the Commerce Clause, as gross annual receipts included only income derived from operations within the State, or violation of the Supremacy Clause, as the states had power to regulate cable television companies.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the cable company's petition, which had challenged the Commission's order implementing the applicable statute, and the declaratory judgment action, which had sought to declare the statute unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- cable television company -- assessment on annual gross receipts -- section 817 of the Executive Law, which assesses every cable television company proportion of their annual gross receipts derived from operations within State to defray expenses of respondent commission, is constitutional; commerce clause and supremacy clause not violated; States have power to regulate cable television companies -- action is not properly maintained as class action ( CPLR 1005, subd. [a]).

1. Section 817 of the Executive Law which assesses every cable television company a proportion of their annual gross receipts up to a maximum of 1%, in order to defray the costs and expenses of respondent Cable Television Commission, is constitutional. Since gross annual receipts include only that income derived from operations within the State (Executive Law, § 812, subd. 5), the commerce clause (U. S. Const., art. I, § 8, cl. 3) is not violated. In addition,  [***2] the statute does not violate either the Rules of the Federal Communications Commission (47 CFR Part 76) or the supremacy clause (U. S. Const., art. VI) since the States have the power to regulate cable television companies. Congress did not intend absolute pre-emption of the field to the exclusion of all State regulations.

2. Petitioner, a cable television company, is not a proper representative of a class so as to maintain this action as a class action ( CPLR 1005, subd. [a]). Some of the services provided by petitioner are not provided by a majority of cable operators and petitioner's sources of revenue differ from the majority of cable operators.

 

1382 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Monarski v. Alexandrides


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County


80 Misc. 2d 260; 362 N.Y.S.2d 976; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1885



December 28, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, it is the decision of this court to deny plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and to grant defendants' judgment dismissing plaintiffs' complaint.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was the motion of defendant, the City of Syracuse, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6314, to vacate and set aside a prior order granting an injunction against the City's enforcement of Syracuse, N.Y., Rev. Gen. Ordinances art. 8 against plaintiff dance school, which was representing a class of similarly situated entities. The school also filed a motion for summary judgment in its action challenging art. 8 as unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Under art. 8 the dance school was required to have a license to conduct its classes in the City. The school brought an action alleging that art. 8 was unconstitutional, and an injunction was granted prohibiting the City from enforcing it. The City sought here to have the injunction vacated, and the school sought summary judgment. The court granted the City's motion to vacate the injunction and denied the school's motion for summary judgment because art. 8 was a legitimate manifestation of the municipality's police power. The school had not sustained its burden of proving that the classifications were unreasonable, without any rational basis, or an improper exercise of the municipality's police power. Further, the limited discretion given to the City's police chief to refuse or waive the requirement of a license did not usurp the legislature's authority to legislate ordinances or statutes. Rather, the chief's discretion was merely the means of implementing the general intent of art. 8. Furthermore, the police chief's discretion was not unlimited or without any guidelines because it could only be exercised for cause.


OUTCOME: The court denied the school's motion for summary judgment and granted the City's motion to dismiss the school's complaint in the school's action to prohibit the City from requiring the school to get a license.


HEADNOTES

Licenses -- dance schools -- ordinance requiring licensees to be "of good moral character" and to pay $ 150, and empowering Police Chief to waive requirements, valid.

A municipal ordinance validly and constitutionally requires all persons who conduct dance schools to be "of good moral character" and to pay $ 150 for a license and to comply with the city's health code and fire prevention code; and the ordinance validly empowers the Police Chief to make rules and regulations accordingly. The ordinance further empowers the Police Chief, "for cause", to deny an application for a license or to waive the requirement for a license. These provisions are not arbitrary, unreasonable, unfair or unequal. Action for a declaration of unconstitutionality is summarily dismissed.

 

1383 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hunt v. Marine Midland Bank--Central


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County


80 Misc. 2d 329; 363 N.Y.S.2d 222; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1890



December 26, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, it is the decision of this court that defendants' motions for summary judgment dismissing plaintiff's complaint be granted in part and denied only as to the issues of plaintiff's alleged loss of personal property contained in the automobile and the determination of Heritage's counterclaim for storage cost.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, an auto dealer and a bank, brought a motion for summary judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3212, asserting that plaintiff, the buyer of an automobile from the dealer, financed by the bank, did not create a triable issue of fact in her action for conversion following the repossession of the automobile. The dealer also sought summary judgment on a counterclaim for storage costs.


OVERVIEW: The buyer had failed to make timely payments to the bank on her auto loan. After the buyer sought to pick up the vehicle from the dealer without paying for repairs, the bank paid the dealer the amount of its mechanic's lien and repossessed the car. The buyer sought damages for conversion of the car and personal property stored in the trunk, asserting that the repossession, while in accordance with N.Y. U.C.C. Law § 9-503, violated her constitutional due process rights. The court granted the motion by the dealer and bank for summary judgment, with the exception of the buyer's personal property claim and the dealer's claim for storage. The court found no constitutional violation or unconscionability in the repossession, noting that the buyer expressly agreed to the self-help provisions in the contract with the bank, which were authorized under § 9-503. The court found that both the buyer and the bank had an interest in the car, which was subject to due process protection. The court held that the dealer had a valid lien under N.Y. Lien Law § 184, and on payment of that lien by the bank due to the buyer's default, the dealer had no choice but to transfer the car to the bank.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motions by the bank and the dealer for summary judgment dismissing the buyer's complaint in part and denied only as to the issues of the buyer's alleged loss of personal property and the determination of the dealer's counterclaim for storage cost.


HEADNOTES

Secured transactions -- repossession -- due process -- acceptance of late payment -- payment of lien by prior secured party -- plaintiff automobile buyer was not denied due process by "self-help" repossession by defendant bank of her automobile under express provisions of security agreement and section 9-503 of Uniform Commercial Code -- acceptance by defendant of certain late payments did not establish course of conduct precluding demand for timely payment -- defendant automobile dealer had valid lien on plaintiff's automobile for repairs and properly transferred possession to prior secured party upon tender of sum sufficient to satisfy lien.

1. The plaintiff was not denied due process when the defendant bank repossessed her automobile under its security agreement contract and section 9-503 of the Uniform Commercial Code for default in payments while the [***2] automobile was in the possession of an automobile dealership under a lien for repairs. There is a distinction between "self-help repossession" under a private contract and replevin prior to a taking, even though both involve a taking prior to a judicial determination of the validity thereof, and the interests of both the buyer and the seller under the contract should be protected in a resolution of the due process question. As the vendee-debtor, the plaintiff had title subject to her obligation to make timely payments. The agreement expressly authorizing the "self-help" provisions in compliance with the statute cannot be held unconscionable.

2. The acceptance by the defendant bank of certain late payments did not establish a course of conduct precluding demand for timely payments since no precedent for late payment was clearly established nor was there an intent to waive the right to repossession.

3. The defendant automobile dealer had a valid lien on the plaintiff's automobile for repairs and properly transferred possession to the prior secured party upon tender of a sum sufficient to satisfy the lien.

4. Accordingly, the motions by the defendants for summary judgment dismissing [***3] the complaint are granted in part and denied as to the issues of plaintiff's loss of personal property contained in the automobile.

 

1384 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Player


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Suffolk County


80 Misc. 2d 177; 362 N.Y.S.2d 773; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1867



December 23, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a prosecution for robbery in the first degree, defendant filed a motion for dismissal of the indictment as defective and for other alternative relief.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the indictment did not inform him of the exact place and time of the commission of the alleged criminal acts. The court held that the place of the offense was sufficiently stated if the indictment stated the county in which the offense was committed and that the exact time of the offense was inessential to the indictment's sufficiency unless time was a material ingredient of the crime. The court found that the indictment set forth the essential elements to secure a conviction for robbery in the first degree and further held that the indictment was sufficient even in the absence of a specification of details of the underlying evidentiary facts. The court also held that N.Y. Penal Law § 160.15 did not require proof that an implement brandished was capable of inflicting serious physical injury as defendant contended, although proof to the contrary adduced by defendant was an affirmative defense. The imposition upon defendant of the burden of establishing an affirmative defense by a preponderance of the evidence did not involve a violation of constitutional due process.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment, denied his motion to be tried separately from his codefendants, granted his motion to suppress his confession, denied his motion for an order directing disclosure of all exculpatory material, and granted his other requests for discovery.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- robbery -- indictment -- affirmative defenses -- joint trial -- disclosure -- indictment sufficiently states date and county of offense, although county is stated without specific designation and offense is stated to have been on or about certain date -- statement in indictment of statutory elements of robbery in first degree sets forth sufficient ultimate facts to state specific criminal acts alleged -- imposition upon defendant of burden of establishing affirmative defense that weapon used was incapable of inflicting serious physical injury involves no constitutional violation -- there has been no showing of need or intention to procure codefendants' testimony, that such testimony would be exculpatory or that defendant would be prejudiced by joint trial and application for separate trial is denied -- motion for disclosure of exculpatory material is denied, since available without order -- application for discovery of physical, mental and scientific tests is granted -- application for copies of lineup and other photographs is granted although such is evidentiary.

1. An indictment sufficiently states the date and county of the offense, although the county is stated [***2] without specific designation and although the offense is stated to have been committed on or about a certain date, without giving the exact time. There is no requirement that separate counts be stated such that it can be determined if the offenses charged were committed at the same time or place.

2. A statement in the indictment of the statutory elements of robbery in the first degree sets forth sufficient ultimate facts, as opposed to conclusions of law, even absent specification of underlying details, to state the specific criminal acts alleged.

3. The imposition upon the defendant in a prosecution for robbery in the first degree of establishing the affirmative defense by a preponderance of the evidence that the weapon used was incapable of inflicting serious physical injury involves no constitutional violation. The People are required to prove that the defendant displayed what appeared to be a firearm and allowance is made for rebuttal of the presumption that the weapon was loaded. The burden of proof of the entire case and the duty of establishing guilt beyond a reasonable doubt remain with the prosecution.

4. No adequate showing has been made of defendant's need and intention [***3] to procure the testimony of his codefendants, that said testimony would be exculpatory or that defendant would be prejudiced by a joint trial, and defendant's application for a separate trial is accordingly denied.

5. The motion by defendant for disclosure of all exculpatory material is denied, since such disclosure is mandatory, acknowledged by the People and no order is required to force compliance upon request.

6. The application by defendant for discovery of reports of physical or mental examinations and scientific tests is granted.

7. The application by defendant for copies of lineup or other photographs is granted, since CPL article 240 does not deny disclosure of evidentiary material.

 

1385 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rochester v. County of Monroe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


81 Misc. 2d 462; 364 N.Y.S.2d 678; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1949



December 19, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the reasons stated herein, the decision of the Monroe County Planning Board is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A planning director of respondent county denied petitioner city's application to construct a replacement swimming pool facility in a park. The Monroe County Planning Board (New York) affirmed the planning director's determination. The city sought review, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78.


OVERVIEW: The proposed facility was designed to replace to existing swimming pools; the new facility, which was to be operational year round, was located within one mile of a local airport and was within the approach path of incoming aircraft. On appeal from the Board's affirmance of the planning director's decision to deny the city's request to build the new pool, the city contended that the county was jurisdictionally divested of any power to deny the city's application and that Monroe County, N.Y., Charter § 703a(a) (1965), which provided the planning director with the power of review over land use within one mile of a publicly owned airport, was invalid. On appeal, the court found that sufficient standards were set forth in N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 239-1 to delineate the discretionary power of the planning director even though such standards were not specifically found in the Monroe County Charter. The Charter referred to the criteria set forth in § 239-1 as proper factors for consideration. The fact that the city's application was denied while other applications were approved did not, in and of itself, provide a basis for a claim of an arbitrary and capricious decision.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decision, which affirmed the planning director's decision to deny the city's request to build a new pool.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- Monroe County Planning Board -- land use regulation within one mile of county airport -- Monroe County Planning Board, pursuant to Monroe County Charter, properly denied application by petitioner City of Rochester to construct swimming pool in park located within one mile of county airport; there are sufficient standards and guidelines delimiting discretionary power of planning board -- petitioner was not denied due process since it was afforded appeal to full planning board -- action taken by planning director and planning board was based upon analysis of all pertinent factors and is not arbitrary and capricious -- failure on part of planning director to comment on petitioner's 1972 application does not estop county from exercising its right of review -- planning director's power of review and approval of land use within one mile of airport is not invalid zoning action against municipality.

1. The Monroe County Planning Board properly denied the application of petitioner City of Rochester to construct a replacement swimming pool in a park located within [***2] one mile of the Monroe County Airport. The Monroe County Charter gives the county planning board and the planning director the power of review over land use and land subdivision within one mile from the boundary line of any publicly owned airport within the county. There are sufficient standards and guidelines delimiting the discretionary power of the planning board since the charter provides that the land use criteria set forth in section 239-l of the General Municipal Law shall be taken into account by the planning board in reviewing municipal planning actions.

2. Petitioner was not denied due process since it was afforded an appeal to the full planning board. Petitioner made its argument, presented its witnesses and submitted evidence in refuting the decision of the planning director.

3. The action taken by the planning director and planning board is not arbitrary and capricious. Due deliberation, consideration and analysis was made of all pertinent factors relative to the land use proposed and the safety to airport operations and the safety to those on the ground affected by airport operations.

4. The county is not estopped from asserting its review powers under the county [***3] charter. Notwithstanding the fact petitioner submitted its application for review in 1972 to the regional planning board, by submitting an application to the county planning board in 1974, petitioner has subjected itself to county review procedure. Petitioner was aware of the county review powers and did not rely on the inaction of the county in 1972. The failure on the part of the planning director to comment on petitioner's 1972 application cannot deprive the county of its vested right of review.

5. The planning director's power of review and approval of land use and subdivisions within one mile of the airport is a valid police power and is not an invalid zoning action against a municipality. The sole consideration involved is safety.

 

1386 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Harrison


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Bronx County


81 Misc. 2d 807; 366 N.Y.S.2d 755; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2028



December 18, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a proceeding in New York to judicially settle the account of the ancillary executors of a decedent who died a resident of Florida, the fee of the attorney for the executor remained for decision. The decedent named her accountant, her attorney, and her husband as primary coexecutors, and most of her estate was located in New York when she died.


OVERVIEW: The decedent was a woman of mature years who had lived in New York for most of her life. Her will clearly reflected an intent to have her husband, her attorney, and her accountant all act as primary coexecutors of her estate to the maximum extent possible under the applicable laws of each state involved, and her relationships with the attorney and accountant were long standing. Florida law disqualified executors from service who were not residents of Florida or related to the decedent by blood. The court found that Florida's residency restriction was inequitable, and it held that the decedent had a fundamental property right to choose her own executors. The court noted that freedom to travel throughout the country was a basic constitutional right, and it stated its hope that legislative wisdom would correct the unfortunate restriction without the necessity for some estate to assume the burden of a search for judicial relief that might extend from the courts of Florida into the federal system.


OUTCOME: The court fixed the fee at issue and allowed it in the amount requested.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Executors and administrators -- disqualification to serve as executor under Florida statute -- residency restrictions Florida statute places upon its citizens in naming executors are inequitable and offensive to spirit and letter of United States Constitution and should be corrected; desire of decedent to circumvent statutory restrictions placed upon her in selecting her executors rendered administration of her estate unduly complex.

Although decedent had become a resident of the State of Florida, at the time of her death, the bulk of her estate was located in New York. Decedent's will reflects an intent to have her husband, her attorney, and her accountant act as primary coexecutors of her estate. However, the fact that the attorney and the accountant are nonresidents of Florida, coupled with their lack of required blood relationship to decedent, disqualified them from serving as executors under the Florida statute. The desire of decedent to circumvent the statutory restriction placed upon her in selecting her executors resulted in burdening her will with circuitous provisions otherwise unnecessary which rendered the administration of her estate unduly complex. The residency [***2] restrictions the Florida statute places upon its citizens in naming executors are not only inequitable but are offensive to the spirit and letter of the United States Constitution and should be corrected.

 

1387 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Corning v. Corning Police Dep't etc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Steuben County


81 Misc. 2d 294; 366 N.Y.S.2d 241; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1948; 88 L.R.R.M. 3220



December 17, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The petition in each of the above-entitled proceedings is dismissed without costs and the petitioners are ordered to proceed to binding arbitration pursuant to law. Submit order in keeping with this decision.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner city brought a motion before the Supreme Court of New York, Steuben County for an order staying arbitration proceedings initiated by respondents, police and firefighter organizations. The city also requested that the court declare invalid and unconstitutional statutes providing for binding arbitration of disputes involving organized policemen and firemen.


OVERVIEW: Involved in contract disputes with local police and firefighting organizations, the city was compelled by the New York Public Employment Relations Board to submit to compulsory binding arbitration. The city petitioned for a stay of the arbitration and a declaration that N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 209, was an unconstitutional usurpation of the city's legislative authority. The court held that the statutory provisions providing for arbitration were constitutional and did not impair the "home rule" powers of the city. The court reasoned that the legislature has authority to mandate the terms and conditions of employment of municipal employees directly by general law without violating "home rule." It followed, therefore, that the legislature could mandate the terms through the medium of compulsory and binding arbitration. The legislature could, in the interest of public health and welfare, require the settlement of disputes. Since, police and firefighting organizations were of great public interest, the legislature had authority to supersede "home rule" authority in such matters relating to the employment of those groups.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petitions and ordered to proceed to binding arbitration pursuant to law.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- Public Employees' Fair Employment Act -- final and binding arbitration of impasse between municipal corporation and its firemen and policemen (Civil Service Law, art. 14, § 209, subd. 4) is constitutional; court orders city to proceed to arbitration.

The Public Employees' Fair Employment Act (Civil Service Law, art 14, § 209, subd. 4, par [c], cl (vi], eff July 1, 1974) validly and constitutioally requires "final and binding" arbitration of any impasse in collective bargaining between a municipal corporation and its firemen or policemen. This applies to collective negotiations which, by July 1, 1974, were not finally decided. The court directs the city to proceed to binding arbitration pursuant to the cited statute.

 

1388 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Farr


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


80 Misc. 2d 250; 362 N.Y.S.2d 915; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1883



December 16, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendants' motion in all other respects is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for declaratory judgment asking the court to declare certain provisions of N.Y. Correct. Law § 212(8) unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant alleged that N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 212(8) violated the requirements of equal protection under both federal and New York State Constitutions. The class affected by § 212(8) was class A drug felons. The court noted that the right to have parole terminated in the discretion of the parole board was a fundamental right. Under § 212(8), the State treated class A drug felons differently from other class A felons and applied a detrimental difference to only those convicted of class A drug felonies. The court stated that to continue the drug, nondrug distinction beyond the grant of parole was irrational. The court held that it made no sense to predicate different treatment on the assumption that a defendant's decision of whether or not to engage in illegal drug activities would be affected by the eligibility for discharge from parole, especially where the discharge was entirely discretionary. The court concluded that § 212(8) was unconstitutional to the extent that it excluded class A drug felons from its operation.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion for declaratory judgment in part holding that the portion of the statute that excluded class A drug felons from its operation was unconstitutional. The court denied defendant's motion in all other respects.


HEADNOTES

Parole -- drug felons -- exclusion of class A drug felons from parole discharge provisions of Correction Law is unconstitutional, since standards for parole are same for both drug and nondrug felons and there is no rational basis for distinction between them; discharge is so tentative that it can have no impact upon purpose of drug deterrence and different treatment cannot be predicated upon assumption of such effect.

The provision of subdivision 8 of section 212 of the Correction Law which excludes class A drug felons from parole discharge is unconstitutional, since there is no rational basis for a distinction between class A drug and nondrug felonies with respect to parole. The grant of parole is a determination that the parolee has been sufficiently rehabilitated to return to society on a permanent basis, and the standards relied upon for the determination in each case are the same. In any event, discretionary discharge is so tentative that it can have no impact upon the statutory purpose of deterring the drug trade, and different treatment cannot be predicated upon the assumption of such effect.

 

1389 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bradford


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


80 Misc. 2d 24; 362 N.Y.S.2d 723; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1833



December 12, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Consequently, the defendant's motion is denied in full.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Penal Law § 60.05(3). Defendant pled guilty to the crime of robbery in the second degree and was waiting for sentencing.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that N.Y. Penal Law § 60.05(3) was unconstitutional because it contravened the Equal Protection Clause of U.S. Const. amend. XIV and U.S. Const. amend. VIII's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. The court held that the category of class C felonies was not an inherently suspect classification. The court held that defendant had failed to meet his heavy burden of demonstrating beyond a reasonable doubt that the discrimination was patently arbitrary, unreasonable, and wholly unrelated to any legitimate governmental interest. The court held that the fact that the court could not impose a sentence of probation upon a defendant convicted of certain class C felonies was not cruel and unusual punishment because there was no constitutional right to probation.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion, finding the statute constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sentence -- defendant, who has pleaded guilty to robbery in second degree, class C felony specified in subdivision 3 of section 60.05 of Penal Law, which mandates sentence of imprisonment for those convicted of class C felonies enumerated therein, and who contends that said subdivision violates his constitutional right to equal protection of law and violates constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, fails to meet his burden of establishing unconstitutionality beyond reasonable doubt.

A defendant who has pleaded guilty to robbery in the second degree, a class C felony specified in subdivision 3 of section 60.05 of the Penal Law, which mandates a sentence of imprisonment, and thus precludes a sentence of probation, for those convicted of the class C felonies enumerated therein, contends that said subdivision violates his constitutional right to equal protection of the law, because it treats him differently from those convicted of class C felonies not enumerated therein, and that it violates the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, because it singles out the [***2] offense committed by him for special punitive treatment and, despite his being a first offender, excludes him from a sentence of probation. His contentions are rejected. He has failed to meet his burden of establishing unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt.

 

1390 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Wallace v. Lhotan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


80 Misc. 2d 464; 363 N.Y.S.2d 425; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1908



December 12, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion seeking the alternative relief of an order staying this special proceeding pending the determination of Organization of Foster Families for Equality and Reform v. Dumpson, a class action currently pending before a three-Judge panel in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, is also denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff natural mother filed an application for a writ of habeas corpus seeking to obtain the return of four of her children living as foster children with respondent foster parents. The foster parents filed a motion to dismiss. Foster parents and respondent Department of Social Services of the County of Nassau, New York, filed a motion for alternative relief seeking an order to stay the action.


OVERVIEW: The natural mother voluntarily placed her children in foster care. The foster parents had two children for two years and two children for four years. The foster parents and the foster children joined in a federal class action that sought to redress the alleged denial of due process and equal protection of law under the United States Constitution to foster children and foster parents in New York State living together for more than one year. Upon review, the court determined that the provisions of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7003(a) did not require dismissal of the mother's writ of habeas corpus. The court decided that the stay issued in the federal class action restraining the social services department from removing the children from the foster parents' home did not affect returning a child from foster care to the care of a natural parent. The court found that the issue of the mother's writ was not before the federal court, the mother was not a party to the federal action, and federal courts generally leave custody decisions to state courts. The court concluded that it was not required by comity and justice to stay the custody proceeding brought by the mother.


OUTCOME: The court denied the foster parents' motion to dismiss and denied respondents' motion for alternative relief.


HEADNOTES

Parent and child -- custody of children -- proceedings to regain custody -- order of Federal court in pending class action involving due process rights of foster parents which restrained Commissioner of Department of Social Services from removing petitioner's four children from their foster home does not mandate dismissal of writ of habeas corpus ( CPLR 7003, subd. [a]) brought by petitioner natural mother to regain custody of her children since issue of custody is not before Federal court; State court is proper forum to determine custody -- hearing on writ should not be stayed since custody hearing would be in best interests of children.

1. Petitioner natural mother who voluntarily relinquished her four children in the custody of the Department of Social Services for placement in foster homes pursuant to a writ of habeas corpus, seeks [***2] to regain custody of her children who are currently living with respondent foster parents. In a class action now pending before a three-Judge Federal panel involving the constitutionality of State laws and regulations governing removal of children from the care of foster parents in New York, a temporary restraining order was issued which restrained the Commissioner of the Department of Social Services from removing the four children from their foster parents' home. However, such order does not mandate dismissal of petitioner's writ pursuant to CPLR 7003 (subd. [a]) since petitioner is not a party to the class action and the issue of custody which is the subject of the writ, is not the issue before the Federal court where the issue relates to the constitutionality of a statute. Since there are two separate and distinct issues involved, petitioner is not precluded from litigating the issue of custody in State court which is the proper forum to determine custody.

2. A hearing on the writ of habeas corpus should not be stayed as a matter of comity pending the determination of the Federal class action since a custody hearing held at this time would be in the best interests of the [***3] children. In addition, a stay would have the effect of unduly prejudicing the rights of the natural mother whose rights are paramount in such foster care cases and must be protected.

 

1391 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wegman's Food Markets, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Town Court of New York, Penfield


80 Misc. 2d 89; 362 N.Y.S.2d 902; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1845; 77 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P53,780



December 11, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a supermarket, was charged with violating N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law art. 2, the "Blue Law." It brought a motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument, arguing that the law was being enforced in a discriminatory manner.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and six other stores were charged with violating the Blue Laws, but defendant was the only supermarket charged. It presented evidence that on the three Sundays it was alleged to have violated the Blue Law, a number of other stores in the area were also selling items in violation of the law. The district attorney testified that it was his office's policy to respond to complaints about stores violating the Blue Law, but not to initiate complaints itself. In this case, competing merchants sent employees to purchase items from defendant and other stores on Sundays and then filed complaints. In addition to expressing economic concerns, the complainants said that some of their employees were worried about possibly having to work on Sundays and that they felt that all stores should be obeying the law. Stating that the motivation of the complainants appeared to be a blend of altruism, practicality, and economics and that selective enforcement alone did not violate a defendant's right to equal protection, the court held that defendant had not met its heavy burden of establishing that the People consciously and intentionally discriminated against it in enforcing the law.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Sabbath-breaking -- corporation which owns many retail supermarkets has not proved that its criminal prosecution (General Business Law, art. 2) is invidiously discriminatory; its motion for dismissal is denied.

Selective enforcement of the Sabbath laws (General Business Law, art. 2) does not amount to an unconstitutional denial of a defendant's right to the equal protection of the laws, unless the defendant establishes intentional and invidious discrimination. The defendant in this case is a large corporation which owns many retail supermarkets. It has not established such a defense. Although the Sabbath laws are confusingly and illogically worded, it is for the Legislature to amend or repeal the laws. Defendant's motion to dismiss these criminal prosecutions is denied.

 

1392 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. S.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


79 Misc. 2d 1058; 361 N.Y.S.2d 848; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1820



December 10, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People filed a memorandum contesting defendant's standing to challenge the constitutionality of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10(2)(a), which under its explicit terms made defendant not eligible for youthful offender treatment upon conviction because one of the counts of the indictment charged a class A felony.


OVERVIEW: The 18-year-old defendant had been indicted for a class A felony arising out of an alleged sale of cocaine, and other related offenses, occurring when he was age 17. Previously the court held that the § 720.10(2)(a) restriction was unconstitutional and granted youthful offender treatment to an otherwise eligible youth who had pleaded guilty to an indictment charging a class A felony. Anticipating that the court would render the same ruling for defendant, the People claimed lack of standing on the argument that only a defendant convicted of less than a class A felony had cause to complain of the alleged unconstitutionality of the statute. It was asserted that defendant must go to trial and if convicted of a less than an A felony, he may then challenge the statute. The court found that the People's interpretation of § 720.10(2)(a) was not what the Legislature intended and that in order for it to prove the lack of standing claim the statute would have to be rewritten to substitute the word "convicted" for "indicted."


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the People's memorandum.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Infants -- youthful offenders -- class A felonies -- defendant is entitled to youthful offender treatment for class A felony, since statute denying such treatment unconstitutionally bases punishment on crimes charged ( CPL 720.10, subd. 2, par. [a]), and statute has not been rewritten to make conviction basis for denial of youthful offender treatment.

The defendant, who is charged with a class A felony and related offenses, may not be denied youthful offender treatment upon a plea of guilty. CPL 720.10 (subd. 2, par. [a]), which denies such treatment where a class A felony is charged, unconstitutionally predicates punishment upon crimes charged rather than upon conviction. A defendant pleading guilty to class A felony charges has standing to challenge the constitutionality of the section under the due process clause, since the Legislature has not rewritten the statute to make conviction the basis for denial of youthful offender treatment.

 

1393 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Merante v. Burns


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Dutchess County


80 Misc. 2d 66; 361 N.Y.S.2d 989; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1842



December 9, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion to reargue is granted and upon such reargument having been had, the court adheres to its prior determination in all respects. The petitioner's cross motion is also denied. No costs on either motion.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent state employer filed a motion to reargue a decision finding petitioner employee could not be removed without a cause hearing and the employee filed a cross motion that complained of the court's failure to remove decretal language which would have vacated the notice of discipline without prejudice to refile the same.


OVERVIEW: The state brought a notice of discipline against its employee and sought to terminate his employment. The employee brought this action seeking to secure his right to continued employment. The court ruled that the employee could not be removed without a hearing to determine whether there was cause to terminate his employment. However, the court refused to vacate the notice of discipline brought by the state. The state filed an application to reargue the case and the employee brought a cross motion that asserted that the court should have vacated the disciplinary notice. On reargument, the court adhered to its former determination. The court denied the cross motion of the employee, and refused to alter its decision to require a hearing on cause before the employee's firing could be upheld. The court noted that the Lloyd-Lafollette Act relied upon by the employee was constitutional and did not create an expectation of employment on the part of the employee. The act only prescribed the due process means by which that employee could be removed for cause.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to reargue and adhered to its prior determination in all respects. The court also denied the petitioner's cross motion.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- notice of discipline -- in prior decision, court had found that notice of discipline given to correction officer offended minimal due process, and, upon reargument, adheres to this determination, discussing and distinguishing two cases cited in support of motion for reargument, and also denies cross motion to resettle order entered upon its prior decision, from which it had stricken proposed decretal paragraph, as not within purview of its opinion.

1. In a prior decision in this case (79 Misc 2d 93), the court had found that a notice of discipline sent to a correction officer offended minimal due process and contravened the terms of an applicable collective bargaining agreement, and, upon reargument, it adheres to this determination, discussing and distinguishing a recent decision of the United States Supreme Court ( Arnett v. Kennedy, 416 U.S. 134) and a subsequent decision of a Special Term in another county, both of which [***2] were cited in support of the motion for reargument.

2. It also denies a cross motion by petitioner to resettle the order entered upon its prior decision, from which it had stricken, as not within the purview of its opinion, a proposed decretal paragraph vacating the notice of discipline without prejudice to the issuance of a new notice in accordance with the collective bargaining agreement.

 

1394 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wilson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


80 Misc. 2d 353; 363 N.Y.S.2d 417; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1897



December 9, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is, therefore, denied in all respects and the court will proceed to impose sentence pursuant to the provisions of section 70.00 (subd. 2, par. [a]) of the Penal Law.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of the attempted murder of a peace officer in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 110.05(1), which at the time categorized such a crime as a class A felony. Before his sentencing, he sought an order declaring the statute invalid.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the statute violated an legislative policy of punishing inchoate crimes less severely than completed crimes and that it violated due process. He claimed that the penalty for an attempted murder of a police officer should be treated as a class B felony, as it would be if the intended victim were not a police officer. The court stated that while New York's legislature had generally preferred to provide lesser penalties for inchoate crimes, the legislature in some cases had specifically decreed that attempted crimes be punished to the same extent as completed ones. Moreover, the court stated, the legislature's enactment of a provision raising the classification of attempted murder of a policeman from a class B to a class A felony should be viewed for what it was: a clear expression of intent on the part of the legislature to increase the penalty for this inchoate crime, not to reduce it. To hold the statute invalid, the court stated, would interfere with this legislative intent. The court then held that the statute did not violate due process. It found that the statute had a rational basis in fact and was by no means arbitrary.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- attempted murder of peace officer -- for attempted murder in May, 1973, of peace officer, defendant will be validly and constitutionally sentenced to indeterminate term with maximum of life imprisonment (Penal Law, § 70.00, subd. 2 par. [a], and former § 110.05).

Defendant stands convicted of having attempted, in May, 1973, to murder a peace officer who was performing his official duties. At that time, such an attempt was a class A felony (Penal Law, § 110.05, as amd. by L. 1972, ch. 292). A class A felony is punishable by an indeterminate sentence with a maximum of life imprisonment (Penal Law, § 70.00, subd. 2, par. [a]). Even if, in this instance, the attempt is punishable as severely as the completed crime, the statute is valid and constitutional under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.

 

1395 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Pierce v. Yerkovich


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Ulster County


80 Misc. 2d 613; 363 N.Y.S.2d 403; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1917



December 4, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the acknowledged father of an illegitimate child, filed an action in which he sought to have his asserted right to visitation with his five-year-old daughter defined and enforced after respondent mother, who had physical custody of the child, adamantly refused to allow visitation.


OVERVIEW: The court was called upon to decide whether the mother, as custodial parent, had the prerogative of making the determination as to when and under what circumstances, if at all, the child could see her father, or whether the court should exercise its authority as parens patriae to temper the "best interests of the child" maxim with a recognition that the father of a child, even though illegitimate, had a right to association with his child. The court granted visitation rights to the father. The court recognized that the interest of the father of an illegitimate child in retaining custody of his child was cognizable and substantial. The court found that to deprive him of the child's custody without a hearing as to his fitness as a parent was a denial of the equal protection of the laws guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment. The court held that (1) it was not in the child's best interest to be shielded by the mother from all future contact with her father, and (2) the child's best interests required that she should have some continuing association with a father who had amply demonstrated his love and concern for his daughter.


OUTCOME: The court granted the father's petition for visitation rights.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and child -- unwed father's visitation rights -- loving, well-to-do, Florida father of out-of-wedlock daughter is awarded visitation rights on alternate weekends, away from household in New York where his child's mother lives with her present husband by whom she has recently had child.

For about 3 1/2 years, a couple lived together in Florida without marriage, and had a daughter who was about 2 3/4 years old when the woman moved out and took their daughter with her. Thereafter, the man, who dearly loves his daughter, offered to marry the woman, but she refused. From time to time the woman did permit him to visit the daughter; but recently the woman married a man in New York State and has had a child by him; and now the woman lives in New York State and she refuses to permit the father of her daughter to visit the girl, who is now 6 years old. This devoted father of this out-of-wedlock child has set up an irrevocable trust fund for his child's benefit, and he has devised his residuary estate for her benefit. Psychiatric testimony and other testimony has been presented by both sides. All the parties are emotionally normal and intelligent but the mother persists in [***2] influencing the child against its natural, loving father. In the best interests of the child, the Family Court directs the mother to allow the child's father to visit the child, away from her present household, but within New York State -- the child's father lives in Florida -- on alternate weekends from Fridays at 5:00 p.m. to Sundays at 7:00 p.m. In addition, the child' father may have temporary custody of his daughter for one month during the period from June 30 to September 1 of each year, with travel unrestricted.

 

1396 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Brown


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


81 Misc. 2d 149; 365 N.Y.S.2d 115; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1942



December 2, 1974 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to declare the statute unconstitutional is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, indicted for two counts of third degree grand larceny and fraudulent accosting, made an omnibus motion seeking the following relief: for an order declaring N.Y. Penal Law § 165.30 unconstitutional; for a bill of particulars; for discovery and inspection; and for a Wade hearing.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the statute was unconstitutional in that it violated the guarantee by the Fourteenth Amendment of due process in that it was vague and did not sufficiently define what was meant by a confidence game so as to inform a person whether his conduct and acts may or may not come within its provisions. Defendant further contended that the present statute which included the element of intent therein did not sufficiently cure its vagueness and indefiniteness. The court passed upon the challenge as to the constitutionality of § 165.30, finding that the court took cognizance of the well established principle that the statute, like all other legislative enactments, was supported by a strong presumption of validity. Further, to establish the contrary, the unconstitutionality of the statute had to be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt, which defendant had not done.
