The court concluded that § 165.30 was not vague and was a reasonable restriction upon a person's activities in the interest of the public good.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to declare the statute unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- fraudulent accosting -- section 165.30 of Penal Law is not unconstitutional for vagueness and indefiniteness; fraudulent accosting must be with intent to defraud by means of confidence game; rules of conduct must necessarily be expressed in general terms.

 Section 165.30 of the Penal Law which provides that "a person is guilty of fraudulent accosting when he accosts a person in a public place with intent to defraud him of money or other property by means of a trick, swindle, or confidence game", is not unconstitutional for vagueness or indefiniteness. The essence of the offense is the intent to swindle and defraud the victim after gaining his confidence. The statute is broad and comprehensive in its terms and is designed to cover any swindling operation. Rules of conduct must necessarily be expressed in general terms and depend for their application upon circumstances, which by the very nature of the crime, vary from case to case.

 

1397 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Amsterdam v. Helsby


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Montgomery County


79 Misc. 2d 676; 362 N.Y.S.2d 698; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1735; 88 L.R.R.M. 3208; 76 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P53,645



November 30, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city sought a preliminary injunction to enjoin defendants, individuals and others constituting the public employment relations board of New York, from enforcing 1974 N.Y. Laws chs. 724, 725. The laws required binding arbitration by the city with its police and fire department employees. The city alleged that the chapters were unconstitutional and sought to have them declared null and void.


OVERVIEW: Chapters 724 and 725 compelled the city, as a public employer, to engage in final and binding compulsory arbitration with its employees in the police and fire departments. As the laws were, they made the determination of the public arbitration panel not subject to the approval of any local legislative body or other municipal authority. As such, the political decision, namely what type and the terms of a collective bargaining agreement contract the city would make an bind itself to, was removed from the jurisdiction of elected public officials and placed within the jurisdiction of the appointive public arbitration panel. The court found that the chapters were unconstitutional because they created invidious discrimination based on wealth without reasonable classification. The principle of one-person, one-vote was applicable to local governmental units. Because the elected local legislature of the government involved and the appointed public arbitration panel were both official bodies, and because the power of the former had to terminate before the latter could exist, the court made the determination that the one-person, one-vote rule applied to the public arbitration panel.


OUTCOME: The court found that the chapters were unconstitutional. The court granted a permanent injunction against their enforcement.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Civil service -- Public Employees' Fair Employment Act -- firemen -- final and binding arbitration of impasse between municipal corporation and its firemen (Civil Service Law, art. 14, § 209, subd. 4) is unconstitutional and is enjoined.

The Public Employees' Fair Employment Act (Civil Service Law, art. 14, § 209, subd. 4, as added by L. 1974, chs. 724, 725) provides that, when a mediator and a fact finder have successively failed to resolve an impasse in collective negotiations between a municipal corporation and its firemen, the dispute shall be determined by a majority vote of three arbitrators -- one appointed by the municipal corporation, one appointed by the firemen, and one appointed by lot from a list of qualified arbitrators named by the Public Employment Relations Board -- and further, that such an arbitration award "shall be final and binding * * * for a period not to exceed two years" and "shall not be subject to the approval of any local legislative body or other municipal authority." The above-quoted provision is unconstitutional, and the court enjoins and restrains any appointment of such a board of final arbitration (U. S. Const., 14th Amdt., §§ 1, 2; N. Y.  [***2] Const., art. I, § 11; art. VIII, §§ 2, 5; art. XVI, § 1).

 

1398 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Wayburn v. Schupf


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


80 Misc. 2d 730; 365 N.Y.S.2d 110; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1925



November 27, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A habeas corpus proceeding was brought on behalf of petitioner relator, who was being detained pursuant to an order of the family court pending trial. A probable cause hearing was held at which a determination was made that there was probably cause to believe that the charged acts were committed and that the relator committed them. After the hearing the relator was ordered remanded to a juvenile center, without bail, pending his trial.


OVERVIEW: The relator challenged the validity of the remand order. A petition based upon information and belief was filed in the family court accusing the relator of acts, which if committed by an adult, would constitute murder in the second degree, manslaughter in the first degree, assault in the first degree, reckless endangerment in the first degree, criminal possession of stolen property in the third degree, and menacing in the first degree. The issue was whether preventive detention could validly be imposed in the family court for juveniles who were accused of being juvenile delinquents. On appeal, the court held that there could be no compelling state interest in prohibiting preventive detention for adults while allowing it for juveniles, and thus N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 739(b) had to be declared unconstitutional. The court held that it was irrational to conclude that persons under the age of 16, who were found to have a propensity to commit crime, needed to be kept from society while persons over 16 who were found to have an equal, or greater, propensity to commit crime could not, by virtue of that fact alone, be confined.


OUTCOME: The court ruled that the challenged legislation was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Infants -- juvenile delinquents -- despite determination that there was probable cause to believe that 15-year-old boy had commited acts which would constitute murder, manslaughter, and assault, court released him on his own recognizance, pending fact-finding hearing -- subdivision (b) of section 739 of Family Court Act unconstitutional.

Subdivision (b) of section 739 of the Family Court Act provides that, pending a fact-finding hearing, an alleged juvenile delinquent may be detained (that is, held without bail in a juvenile center or other place of detention), if a finding is made that "there is a serious risk that he may before the return date do an act which if committed by an adult would constitute a crime". This provision amounts to an unconstitutional denial of the equal protection of the laws. Accordingly, despite a finding made by the Family Court after a hearing that there was probable cause to believe that a 15-year-old boy had committed acts which, if committed by a person aged 16 or more, would constitute murder, manslaughter, assault, reckless endangerment, menacing, and criminal possession of stolen property, and despite a finding by the Family Court under said [***2] subdivision (b) of section 739, the Supreme Court in Kings County released the boy on his own recognizance.

 

1399 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Raleigh


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Saratoga County


79 Misc. 2d 846; 361 N.Y.S.2d 309; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1767



November 26, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state sought review of an order from the Saratoga County Court (New York), which affirmed the judgment of a town court dismissing a civil action brought by the state pursuant to N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 113 to recover a penalty against respondent dog owners for harboring an unlicensed dog and declaring unconstitutional N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 109-b.


OVERVIEW: The state initiated an action against the dog owners after they refused when tendering their dog license fee to pay an additional 10 cents as provided for in N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. § 109-b, subd 2. On appeal, the court reversed the lower court's judgment upon finding that the burden for the 10 cent tax being placed on dog owners as a class had a fair and substantial relationship to legislation relating to the study of dog diseases, that the classification of dog owners as the taxpayers therein was reasonable and that all dog owners were being treated alike, and that those who own dogs should rightfully help bear the financial burden of the study of dog diseases as they affect not only dogs but man and other animals as well. The court determined that the 10 cents provided for in § 109-b was a tax and not a fee and that the legislative intent was that the 10 cent tax imposed was not to be used exclusively for the study of diseases of dogs but as such diseases affect man and other animals as well.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court's affirmance of the city court's decision dismissing action of the state and declaring unconstitutional a statutory dog-licensing tax. The court resubmitted the matter for further consideration in light of its decision.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Animals -- tax on dog owners for study of dog diseases -- section 109-b of Agriculture and Markets Law which imposes 10-cent tax on dog owners to be used for study of dog diseases is constitutional; those who own dogs should rightfully help bear financial burden of study of dog diseases.

Section 109-b of the Agriculture and Markets Law which in addition to dog license fees imposes an additional 10-cent tax on dog owners exclusively for the study of diseases of dogs does not violate equal protection and is therefore constitutional. Those who own dogs should rightfully help bear the financial burden of the study of dog diseases as they affect not only dogs but man and other animals as well. Whether the studies that are being conducted are inhumane and whether the proceeds of the tax are being misapplied cannot be considered herein.

 

1400 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Security Nat'l Bank v. Village Mall at Hillcrest, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


79 Misc. 2d 1060; 361 N.Y.S.2d 977; 1974 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1821



November 22, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In plaintiff mortgagee's action to foreclose a consolidated building loan, defendant mortgagor challenged both the ex parte appointment of a receiver and the right of the mortgagee to have a receiver appointed on notice.


OVERVIEW: In an action to foreclose the mortgage that secured a construction loan for buildings containing hundreds of condominiums, the mortgagee had a receiver appointed in an ex parte proceeding pursuant to the terms of the mortgage and N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 254, which was also referred to in the mortgage. The court denied the mortgagor's motion to vacate the appointment of the receiver, because the issuance of the ex parte order was not constitutionally defective under the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment because the mortgagor had agreed to the ex parte process in arm's length negotiations at which he was represented by counsel, and because N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6405 entitled him to move immediately to vacate the receivership. The court held that even if the appointment of a receiver ex parte was constitutionally defective, that defect was cured by the subsequent motion and the opportunity to be heard fully on the issues. The court limited the powers of the receiver, however, because the mortgage lien only applied to, and did not give the receiver title to, the unsold units and the interest of those units in the common areas.


OUTCOME: The court denied mortgagor's motion to vacate the appointment of the receiver because the ex parte procedure, to which mortgagor had agreed at arm's length, did not violate his due process rights. The court granted mortgagor's motions to the extent that the receiver was not authorized to exercise the rights of the condominium management team provided for in the mortgage or to sell the remaining units, although he could lease them.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Receivers -- condominiums -- in action to foreclose mortgage on real property on which condominium units were constructed, issuance of ex parte order appointing receiver was not constitutionally defective since covenant in mortgage which provided for appointment of receiver in case of foreclosure entitled plaintiff mortgagee, pursuant to section 254 of Real Property Law, to ex parte appointment of receiver -- since defendant, as sponsor of condominium project, has no right to operate and manage project because Condominium Act (Real Property Law, art. 9-B) places such responsibility in board of managers, court-appointed receiver has no power to operate and manage said project since powers of receiver cannot exceed those of defendant -- receiver has no authority to sell any unsold condominium units.

1. Defendant corporation is the owner of a large parcel of real property which includes 458 condominium units. Of the 458 units constructed, 284 have been sold. Plaintiff is the lead-lender on a construction loan in the amount of $ 16,000,000 which is secured by a consolidated building loan mortgage. Defendant defaulted in repaying the $ 4,814,521 balance due under the mortgage [***2] whereupon plaintiff commenced an action to foreclose the mortgage. Pursuant to a covenant in the mortgage, plaintiff, by an ex parte order had a receiver appointed for the collection of rents and profits issuing from the mortgaged premises. The receiver was given the additional authority to sell the remaining condominium units and to generally manage the premises. The issuance of the ex parte order was not constitutionally defective since the covenant in the mortgage which provided for the appointment of a receiver entitled plaintiff, pursuant to section 254 of the Real Property Law, to such an ex parte appointment. Moreover, even if the appointment of a receiver ex parte was constitutionally defective that defect was cured by the opportunity afforded the parties to be heard on the issues.

2. Since the Condominium Act (Real Property Law, art. 9-B) places the authority and responsibility for the management of the condominium in the board of managers, defendant, as the sponsor of the project has no right to operate and manage the project, therefore, any court-appointed receiver has no right to collect rents from the professional or commercial space in the condominium buildings,  [***3] to undertake repairs to the common areas, pay taxes thereon or perform any of the functions a receiver normally performs, since the powers of the receiver cannot exceed those of defendant. In addition, since the board of managers has responsibility for the management of the condominium, it is doubtful that the unit owners as individuals could legally consent to giving the receiver the broad powers requested by plaintiff. There is no legal authority to grant the receiver the power to take over the management of the condominium.

3. The receiver has no authority to sell any of the unsold condominum units. However, he may apply to the court to lease such units.

4. Among the actual powers given to the receiver is the power to lease and manage those portions of the real property which are encumbered by plaintiff's mortgage but which are not part of the condominium offering.

5. It is suggested that all the parties concerned and the receiver attempt to reach some agreement as to a plan for the management of the property pending the determination of the action.
